DOC.HEAD: Portuguese Premier Shuffles Cabinet After Election Setback
DOC.TEXT: Social Democratic Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva reshuffled his government further Thursday following his party's stinging defeat in local elections last month. He said Fernando Real, rector of the northern University of Tras-as-Montes, will take over the newly created Environment and Natural Resources Ministry. Government officials said Thursday that Secretary of State for Culture Teresa Gouveia will be replaced by Pedro Santana Lopes, a leading figure in the Lisbon section of the center-right governing party. Later Thursday, three more secretaries of state _ for tourism, the budget and the treasury _ announced they would leave the government. On Tuesday, five leading ministers were replaced, including Deputy Prime Minister and Defense Minister Eurico de Melo. Opposition sources said the shake-up showed deep divisions in the Social Democrats after the Socialist Party defeated them in local elections Dec. 17. It was the first major government shuffle since the Social Democrats won general elections in 1987. A period of political stability followed, unprecedented since the 1974 revolution. The past three years also saw a consumer boom and sustained economic growth. However, the government was accused of having a high-handed style, inability to control inflation and not coping with continuing serious social problems. It also faced allegations of high-level corruption.

DOC.HEAD: Banks, Exchange Houses Reopen; Austral Stabilizes
DOC.TEXT: Argentina's national currency regained some of its lost value against the U.S. dollar Thursday when banks and exchange houses reopened for the first time since last week. The austral traded at about 1,400 per dollar, sharply higher than the 1,950-1 rate last Thursday, the final business day of the year and before the government ordered two national holidays and two bank holidays to try to stabilize the battered Argentine economy. Nevertheless, it appears premature to say whether the austral's recovery was signaling success for the fourth stabilization plan by the economic team of President Carlos Menem, who took office last July under a mandate to cut the foreign debt, lower inflation and sell of money-losing state industries. The heart of the plan, announced Monday and prompted by last week's abrupt devaluation, calls for restricting the printing of further currency so that fewer new bills would flood the market, thus bidding up the value of the austral. The effect has been immediate. Stores report fewer customers. Bus and taxi drivers have little change, and ranchers and farmers delivered only small quantities of beef and grain to distributors this week. People who bought dollars last week for 2,200 australs apiece sold them Thursday for much less, or waited in lines under a hot sun in this Southern Hemisphere summer to withdraw bank funds from savings accounts. The stabilization plan has been defended by government officials, but criticized heavily by its political opponents. Restricting the circulation of australs may bring on recession, the Social Democratic Party said in a communique, ``aggravating the suffering ... of the population.''

DOC.HEAD: Troops Home Again After Panama Fight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 9th, `The president...,' to UPDATE with reax from sister of slain soldier.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Panama, Bjt
LaserPhoto MTY1
DOC.TEXT: Combat troops flew home from battle-torn Panama on Wednesday to a welcome made more joyous by news that their mission's last objective had been accomplished with Manuel Antonio Noriega's arrest. ``I'm a young guy who's never been in anything like that,'' said Sgt. George Newsome, 27, of Jackson, Miss., who was with his wife, Sharon, and their three children. ``I was worrying and hoping I'd come back home.'' The Newsomes joined some 30 fatigue-clad soldiers who met reporters Wednesday outside the Champlain Family Life Center at Ford Ord. The soldiers were among 141 troops belonging to two artillery batteries from Fort Ord who were pulled out Monday, the first troops returning home since the Panama invasion began Dec. 20. More troops returned Wednesday evening when an airplane carrying about 75 Army Rangers landed at Hunter Army Airfield in Savannah, Ga. They were the first of about 500 Savannah-based Rangers scheduled to return Wednesday and early Thursday. One of the Rangers, Sgt. Donnie Jones, said the first night in Panama was the worst and said he would remember the experience the rest of his life. ``We were shot at the first night, '' he said, adding that the Panamanians were extremely glad to see the U.S. soldiers in the country. ``There were real nice toward us,'' he said. ``During Christmas they were very hospitable, bringing us plates of food. It was very worthwhile going down there for them.'' Later Wednesday in Washington, President Bush announced that Noriega, Panama's former dictator, had turned himself in after nine days inside the Vatican embassy in Panama City and was arrested by Drug Enforcement Administration agents. The president said Noriega's arrest on drug trafficking charges meant the United States had achieved all of its objectives in the military invasion he ordered two weeks ago. That news was greeted thankfully by families of the 23 U.S. servicemen who were killed in action in Panama. ``It doesn't lessen the pain, but at least nobody else will be killed, hopefully,'' said Sharon Roth, the 17-year-old sister of Army Pfc. Scott Lee Roth, said from her home in Milan, Ill. ``That's the most reassuring thing that can come out of all of this ... He's (Noriega's) going to pay for what he did.'' In Fort Ord, gunman specialist Mackson Hedgemond, 26, of New York City, who was stationed on the outskirts of Panama City, said the operation was warranted by Noriega's alleged involvement in drug trade. ``I think it was something that needed to be done,'' Hedgemond said. ``I'm against drugs and I think that's bigger than anything else right now.'' Sgt. Newsome said he spent most of his Panama tour in secure areas but still faced constant sniper fire. ``I've never been shot at a day in my life ... seeing dead bodies all around, I've never seen anything like that,'' he recalled. Sharon Newsome told their children that their father was at work and that he ``had a job to do.'' ``It was kind of rough but I at least knew he was down there and he was safe,'' she said. Gunnery Sgt. Scott Bell, 24, of Los Angeles spent 14 days in Panama and said he was surprised to learn he would return Tuesday night, because his unit had just been told to expect to stay in Panama another 3{ months. Bell said that when his unit _ which mostly provided fire-support for infantry troops _ arrived at Trios Airport in Panama at the beginning of the operation, they found ``the whole airport was just torn up, bullet-ridden.'' He said that after two days, his unit was flown out to the city of Rio Hodo, where he spent Christmas, which he described as ``raining, hot, miserable, rather depressing.'' Bell, who has a wife and a daughter, said most Panamanians seemed glad to see U.S. troops and waved and cheered at them. Asked if the invasion was a success, he said, ``I don't know. To be perfectly honest, I like to think of using military force as a last resort. Bullets don't discriminate. ... I've got a family like everybody else.''

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Won Three Conditions
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega won acceptance of surrender terms through Vatican officials before deciding to give himself up, administration officials said Wednesday night. These officials, who spoke on condition that their names not be used, said the United States agreed to three conditions set by Noriega, that: _He be allowed to make a few phone calls. _His decision be kept secret until the actual time of his arrest. _He be permitted to wear his uniform. The administration earlier had given assurances to Noriega that we would receive a fair trial in the United States and that he wouldn't be tried on a federal drug kingpin statute that carries the death penalty, the sources said. These assurances were relayed to Noriega through Vatican officials. The United States did not directly deal with the deposed dictator, the sources said. ``It seems that the Vatican officials basically stressed to Noriega that his only viable strategy was to give himself up,'' said one official.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Evacuated As Bush Fires Rage Across Three States
LaserPhoto SYD1
DOC.TEXT: More than 1,000 firefighters battled bush fires that raged across three states Thursday, destroying vast tracts of the Australian Outback. At least 20 towns in the states of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia were threatened by the flames that were fanned by 100-degree-plus temperatures Wednesday. There was no immediate estimate of damage. At least seven people and three firefighters were injured but there were no reports of deaths. Thousands of people were forced to flee their homes and hundreds of head of livestock perished as a state of emergency was declared across six districts of New South Wales, on Australia's eastern seaboard. Officials said thousands of miles of bushland was destroyed as fires threatened to engulf townships. Firefighters, supported by army personnel, water-bombed forests and bush to doush the fires.

DOC.HEAD: Countdown to Start for Monday Space Shuttle Launch
DOC.TEXT: The launch team prepared today to start the countdown for sending space shuttle Columbia into space Monday on a mission to release one satellite and rescue another. Shuttle managers cleared Columbia for flight Wednesday following a six-hour meeting during which they reviewed the readiness of the shuttle, the launch crew, ground support equipment and other aspects. They directed the countdown to begin at 4 p.m. today, aiming for a liftoff at 8:10 a.m. Monday. ``There are no issues, no concerns,'' NASA spokeswoman Lisa Malone reported after the meeting. During 10 days in orbit, the five-astronaut crew is to deploy a Navy communications satellite and track down and retrieve a science satellite before it falls to Earth in March. The satellite has been orbiting for nearly six years. Columbia's launch had been scheduled for December, but was delayed to allow more time to correct problems on a renovated launch pad and to let workers go home for Christmas and New Year's.

DOC.HEAD: Football Reigns In Ratings For Holiday Week
DOC.TEXT: Entertainment shows took a holiday during Christmas week as football ran up the score in the Nielsen ratings. Television's two highest-rated program's for the week ended Dec. 31 were network telecasts of National Football League games. Most of the entertainment shows, led by NBC's ``The Cosby Show'' in third place, were reruns. ABC's ``20-20'' was the only original show other than football in the Top 20. First place went to NBC's prime-time spillover of Sunday's American Football Conference wild-card playoff game between the Pittsburgh Steelers and the Houston Oilers. The NBC game ran 61 minutes into prime time after 7 p.m. Sunday. It was first on the NBC and CBS lists but not ABC's. ABC's ``Monday Night Football'' game between the Cincinnati Bengals and the Minnesota Vikings was second. ABC in its interpretation of the ratings listed its own game coverage as first. ABC excludes spillover shows in its ratings, and Nielsen's own release didn't include the game. ``My philosophy is that everything on the air after 7 p.m. Sunday and after 8 p.m. the rest of the week should be counted,'' said Arnold Becker, CBS vice president for television research. ``Once you begin to leave things out different people come up with different answers.'' NBC again topped the weekly A.C. Nielsen Co. survey with an average of 13.4. After two weeks in second place, CBS fell to third with 10.3, compared with ABC's 11.4. The ratings represent the percentage of the nation's 92.1 million households tuned to a show. It was the 11th consecutive victory for NBC, which leads for the season with 14.7, followed by ABC's 13.0 and CBS' 12.1. Here's the Top 10 according to Nielsen's release: ABC's football game between Cincinnati and Minnesota, NBC's ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC's ``The Golden Girls'' and ``Cheers'' tied, NBC's ``Unsolved Mysteries,'' ABC's ``Roseanne,'' and NBC's ``Empty Nest,'' ``A Different World,'' ``Dear John'' and ``Matlock.'' CBS did not have a show in the Top 20. Its highest show _ ``60 Minutes'' _ tied for 22nd place. ABC's ``World News Tonight'' won among the evening news shows with a rating of 11.4. NBC moved into second place with 10.3, compared with CBS' 10.2 ABC was first every week of 1989's fourth quarter, including two ties with CBS. The year's final months saw some of the biggest stories, including the end of the Berlin Wall, the invasion of Panama, the revolution in Romania, and the San Francisco Bay area earthquake. The ABC show was also the highest-rated news program for 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Risser, Rugaber Named to Pulitzer Board
DOC.TEXT: James V. Risser of Stanford University and Walter Rugaber of the Roanoke (Va.) Times & World-News have joined the Pulitzer Prize Board. They fill vacancies on the 18-member board created by the deaths of C.K. McClatchy and Howard Simons, according to an announcement Wednesday. Risser, a native of Lincoln, Neb., won Pulitzer Prizes for national reporting in 1976 and 1979 during a 20-year career with The Des Moines (Iowa) Register. He is director of the John S. Knight Fellowships for Professional Journalists at Stanford and a professor of communication there. Rugaber, born in Macon, Ga., was a reporter for the Atlanta Journal and the Detroit Free Press, then served as a reporter and deputy news editor at The New York Times. In 1978, Rugaber became executive editor of what is now known as the Greensboro (N.C.) News & Record. He has been president and publisher of the Roanoke Times & World-News since 1982.

DOC.HEAD: Police Detail Gunbattle That Led To Key Drug Trafficker's Death
DOC.TEXT: Nearly three weeks after they shot and killed a leader of the Medellin cocaine cartel, police are finally describing in detail the government's greatest triumph yet in its war with drug barons. The first report of the events Dec. 15 said simply that the trafficker, Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, his son, Fredy, and five bodyguards were shot and killed in a gunbattle with police near Covenas on Colombia's northern coast. On Wednesday, a police spokesman gave the first official detailed account. Fearing retaliation from traffickers, he spoke on condition of anonymity. Fredy Rodriguez, 17, was arrested in September on a charge of carrying an illegal weapon and imprisoned in Bogota. With all the publicity generated by the arrest, Rodriguez Gacha found that not even his power and wealth, estimated at $1 billion, could gain the boy's release. On Nov. 23, the youth was released from jail by a judge using his discretionary powers to free juvenile offenders. The spokesman at the national police headquarters in Bogota denied persistent reports that police had freed Fredy in order to follow him to his father's hideout on the Caribbean coast. He insisted police were tipped off by an informant in Rodriguez Gacha's gang. The police are not saying if the informant collected a $580,000 reward. The police spokesman gave this account of what followed: The evening of Dec. 14, Rodriguez Gacha, his son and five bodyguards boarded a speedboat in Cartagena and traveled to a ranch 75 miles south of the resort city. The next afternoon, two helicopters flew over the hideout and the police ordered Rodriguez Gacha to surrender. Rodriguez Gacha, his son and their bodyguards jumped into a pickup truck and drove toward Covenas, one of Colombia's main sea ports. Near the port, Fredy and four bodyguards jumped out of the truck and opened fire on the helicopters. Commandos who had landed from one of the helicopters fired back, killing Fredy and the bodyguards. Rodriguez Gacha and the remaining bodyguard abandoned the pickup and ran into a banana plantation. The trafficker fired at the helicopters with his R-15 rifle, and having run out of ammunition, started thowing hand grenades he had with him. The police in the helicopter opened fire, first hitting him in a foot and then in the head.

DOC.HEAD: Chico Mendes Murder Suspects Seized in Prison Break Attempt
DOC.TEXT: Three major suspects in the shooting death of Francisco ``Chico'' Mendes, the Amazon environmental activist and union leader, broke out of prison but were captured an hour later, police say. Cattle rancher Darli Alves da Silva and his sons Darcy Pereira da Silva and Oloci Alves da Silva escaped from prison in the Amazon city of Rio Branco on Saturday, officer Manuel de Brito Ramos said. News of the escape from Francisco de Oliveira Conde Penitentiary was made public only Wednesday, he said. Ramos said two guards were sent to da Silva's cell after authorities learned the three men had obtained revolvers and planned a breakout. The da Silvas overpowered the guards, dashed about 125 feet across a courtyard and scaled the 11-foot prison wall, Ramos said by telephone from Rio Branco, 2,650 miles northwest of Rio de Janeiro. With just two wall sentries on duty during the New Year's holiday weekend, the alarm was not sounded. However, Darli Alves da Silva injured himself in jumping off the wall into thick brush. The da Silvas fled into the wilderness but police quickly mounted a search and captured them about an hour later, he said. ``Darli's older and very thin and couldn't take the fall,'' said Ramos. ``Otherwise, they might have made it.'' Da Silva, indicted in August on a charge of ordering Mendes' death, and his sons have been held at the 150-inmate penetentiary for a year awaiting trial. Darcy Pereira, 21, was indicted for carrying out the shooting. Police said he confessed. Oloci Alves, 22, was arrested as an accomplice. Mendes, 44, was shot on Dec. 22, 1988, at his house in the backwoods Amazon town of Xapuri, 105 miles northwest of Rio Branco near the Bolivian border. Mendes was head of a local rubber tappers union that blocked ranchers' efforts to clear the rain forest for grazing. He had led protests in which family and community members stood in front of bulldozers. In 1987, Mendes received the United Nations Global 500 award for his work to protect the Amazon. He was an environmental watchdog for the World Bank and other international lending institutions in England and West Germany. Mendes successfully campaigned in May 1988 to stop da Silva from cutting down a stand of virgin rain forest on his property. Mendes often said the rancher threatened to kill him. Da Silva denied it. The issue of developing the Amazon jungle has often erupted into bloody clashes between large landowners on one side and ecologists and peasant farmers on the other. The government estimates that more than 800 people have died in land conflicts since 1980. Many rural leaders and the church activists who advise them were victims.

DOC.HEAD: Water Projects Have Displaced 10 Million
DOC.TEXT: Water conservation projects have displaced more than 10 million people in China over the past three decades, and up to 40 percent of those resettled are living in poverty, an official daily reported today. The uprooting of communities for the projects has caused ``unstable social problems'' the China Daily said, quoting Zhao Renxiang of the Water Resources Ministry. Zhao said 30 percent to 40 percent of displaced people lack adequate food and clothing. China has completed 86,000 dams and other waterworks since the late 1950s, but the legacy of resettlement has hurt plans for further projects, Zhao said. Last year, the government decided to delay for at least five years a decision on whether to proceed with the nation's biggest dam project, the Three Gorges Hydroelectric Project on the Yangtze River. The dam would generate 17,000 megawatts of electricity for energy-starved central China. It has long been controversial because it would cost tens of billions of dollars to build, cause serious environmental damage and require the displacement of about 1 million people. Zhao said the government plans to issue new regulations to improve resettlement programs by extending state aid for rebuilding villages and allowing farmers to find non-agricultural work.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Noriega Turns Self Over to U.S., Panama Erupts in Celebration
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 6th pvs, `If convicted' to UPDATE with conditions Noriega gave for his surrender, quote from U.S. officials, minor editing. Pick up 7th, ``We are...'
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, who defied two U.S. presidents until he was toppled by a Dec. 20 invasion, walked out of his Vatican Embassy sanctuary Wednesday night and surrendered to U.S. troops. Word of the former dictator's departure triggered spontaneous celebrations across the capital. People banged pots and pans and kissed U.S. soldiers. Fireworks lighted the sky around the Vatican mission. Groups of youngsters raced up and down the streets waving Panamanian and U.S. flags. ``It's over! It's over!'' shouted residents of the country ruled for six years by Noriega. In Washington, President Bush said Noriega, who had taken refuge in the embassy on Christmas Eve, turned himself over to American authorities voluntarily and ``with the full knowlege'' of the Panamanian government. In a nationwide address, Bush said Noriega would be flown on a C-130 transport plane from Howard Air Force Base in Panama to Homestead Air Force Base in south Florida to face arraignment at the U.S. District Court in Miami, where he is wanted on federal drug trafficking charges. If convicted, Noriega faces up to 145 years in prison and up to $1.1 million in fines. He faces similar federal charges in a Tampa court. ``It seems that the Vatican officials basically stressed to Noriega that his only viable strategy was to give himself up,'' said a U.S. official in Washington. He spoke on condition of anonymity. The United States agreed to three conditions set by Noriega: that he be allowed to make a few phone calls, that his decision be kept secret until the actual time of his arrest, and that he be permitted to wear his uniform, administration officials said. The administration earlier had given assurances to Noriega that we would receive a fair trial and that he wouldn't be tried on a federal drug kingpin statute that carries the death penalty, they said. The assurances were relayed to Noriega through Vatican officials. The United States did not directly deal with Noriega, the sources said. ``We are relieved to be rid of this criminal,'' said President Guillermo Endara in a statement broadcast on national television. ``The people feel a sense of peace knowing that the monster is leaving our land.'' ``Thank God, Panama can now feel like a free country,'' said Moises Rios, 20, who was outside the nunciature minutes after Noriega left. Hundreds of cars jammed 50th Street near the center of what was once a thriving international financial center. People stopped reporters and asked, ``Is it official? Is he really gone?'' ``I feel a very deep emotion,'' said Reyna Luz Sandoval, 21. ``The criminal is finally gone.'' Gen. Maxwell Thurman, head of U.S. Southern Command, told reporters in Panama City that ``no deals'' had been made with the Vatican. He thanked a delegation led by Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger for helping settle the 10-day impasse, but did not elaborate. Thurman said Noriega ``looked vigorous, looked confident. He looked fine.'' He said the former dictator was due to arrive in Florida at 3:46 a.m. EST Thursday after a six-hour flight. Thurman said Noriega's surrender ``completes the fourth of our four objectives'' in invading Panama. The other three, he said, were to protect American lives, safeguard the integrity of the Panama Canal treaties and restore democracy to Panama. According to authorities, about 290 Panamanian soldiers, 300 civilians, 23 U.S. troops and three American civilians died in the invasion. ``I want to express the special thanks of our nation to those servicemen who were wounded and to the families of those who gave their lives. Their sacrifice has been a noble cause that will never be forgotten. A free and prosperous Panama will be an enduring tribute,'' Bush said in conclusion. ``It doesn't lessen the pain, but at least nobody else will be killed, hopefully,'' said Sharon Roth, the 17-year-old sister of Army Pfc. Scott Lee Roth, from her home in Milan, Ill. Scott Lee Roth, 19, was killed on the first day of the invasion. He had been in Panama since August. Noriega left the compound at 8:50 p.m. accompanied by papal nuncio Monsignor Sebastian Laboa. He was wearing his general's uniform. Archbishop Marcos McGrath, asked why Noriega suddenly gave up, told ABC-TV that the former chief of the Defense Forces was ``undoubtedly a lonely man, a broken man.'' Noriega was taken to a waiting U.S. Army Blackhawk helicopter and flown to Howard, the U.S. air Base just west of the capital, Thurman said.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Case Raises Thorny Legal Questions
With AM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Ousted Panamanian strongman Manuel Antonio Noriega will finally be tried here in a drug trafficking case that has provoked thorny legal questions and could raise new precedents, experts said Wednesday. Whatever the legal headaches, the challenge was welcomed by prosecutors who helped build the complex case against Noriega and 15 others. ``Christmas came nine days late to America,'' said Robert Merkle, a former U.S. attorney who brought an indictment in Tampa against Noriega. ``I did my job. I think it's great what's happening here.'' Merkle predicted that the quick movement of Noriega to Miami would not pose legal problems. ``There is no formal extradition involved here and the case law is that the court will not look to the circumstances by which the person was brought to the United States,'' he said. Noriega was taken into custody by U.S. authorities in Panama late Wednesday and put on a plane for Homestead Air Force Base south of Miami, where he was expected to arrive at 3:46 a.m. EST, said Gen. Maxwell Thurman, head of the U.S. Southern Command in Panama. His arraignment was tentatively scheduled for Thursday afternoon in the federal courthouse in downtown Miami, about 24 miles north of the base, said Diane Cossin, a spokeswoman for U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen in Miami. ``There's going to be a plea entered tomorrow of not guilty,'' said Noriega defense attorney Steven Kollin. ``We're going to request certain pretrial discovery requests including certain sensitive documents, and these sensitive documents will get to the truth of the matter. I believe he will be found not guilty if we can find a jury of 12 people after this unparalleled pretrial publicity.'' A roadblock to prosecuting Noriega is his right to demand classified information stemming from his past cooperation with the Central Intelligence Agency, legal experts have said. Noriega stands accused of drug trafficking in indictments handed down in Miami and Tampa in February 1988. They marked the first time federal charges were filed against a foreign leader who was not in the United States. ``In my opinion, Gen. Noriega is entitled under the law to `head of state immunity,' '' said Neal Sonnett, who withdrew only last week as one of Noriega's attorneys. ``That was one of the main arguments advanced in my motion for dismissal of the indictment against him.'' The dismissal motion was denied by the trial judge in the federal case last January, but Sonnett said the legality of his extradition was sure to be a factor at Noriega's trial. ``I would think that any good lawyer representing Gen. Noriega would raise that issue again, particulary in light of the fact that Gen. Noriega was elected chief of state by the Panamian congress shortly before the invasion.'' But Ms. Cossin said a ``head of state immunity'' claim would have little effect on their case. ``We anticipate numerous allegations and claims in Gen. Noriega's defense,'' Cossin said. ``However, we have a great deal of confidence in our prosecution team and the laws of the United States.'' Noriega reportedly worked closely with the CIA and the Pentagon while he served as the head of Panama's military intelligence service and after he became commander in chief in 1983. The Justice Department acknowledged last week that it was in such a rush to indict Noriega on drug charges that it may not have followed its own rules for making sure state secrets would not be disclosed in court. But department spokesman David Runkel said, ``We believe there is a strong case against General Noriega and that case can be successfully brought to trial.'' At a press briefing last week, Runkel said the department may not have followed its usual policies of reviewing, while drawing up an indictment, any classified documents that might be used in a trial. He said the department's decision to review the national security issues was an outgrowth of a Dec. 14 meeting of prosecutors in the case with representatives of the Drug Enforcement Administration, Federal Bureau of Investigation and CIA, in which it was decided that the Miami case would have priority. In Atlanta, a former White House counsel said Wednesday night that attorneys handling Noriega's case should be able to select an unbiased jury to hear the deposed dictator's trial. ``It's more of a problem than the routine case, but it's not an insurmountable problem,'' said Robert Lipshutz, former counsel to the president during the administration of Jimmy Carter. ``There are thousands of people in every community who really don't follow these things with great attention and, therefore, would be qualified for jury duty,'' Lipshutz said ni a telephone interview.

DOC.HEAD: PANAMA CITY: Thurman said.
DOC.TEXT: At Howard, he was arrested by Drug Enforcement Administration agents and left on a flight to Florida. Thurman said the flight left at 9.31 p.m., 41 minutes after Noriega left the embassy. Thurman said U.S. officials had only a few minutes warning that Noriega would leave the embassy. He said Maj. Gen. Marc Cisneros, commander of U.S. Army South, received a telephone call at his command post in the school across the street asking him to ``report to the gate.'' Thurman declined to say who received Noriega but emphasized that he left on his own free will. He said no Panamanian officials were present but that the Panamanian government was aware of what was going on. Noriega ruled this West Virginia-sized nation of 2.2 million people since 1983. In his remarks, Bush thanked the Vatican and the papal nuncio in Panama for its help and promised Noriega would receive a fair trial. Nevertheless, he said, ``His apprehension and return to the United States will send a clear signal that the United States is serious in its determination that those charged with promoting the distribution of drugs cannot escape the scrutiny of justice.'' The trial is expected to be complicated. U.S. legal authorities have been studying secret documents this past month concerning Noriega's long tenure as a CIA and DEA informant. They expect he might try to derail his prosecution by seeking disclosure of information that would be embarrassing to Bush _ a former CIA director _ and the United States. The impasse ended hours after 20,000 people shouting ``No More!'' and ``Assassin!'' marched to the Vatican Embassy to demand Noriega's surrender. Noriega was said to be in ``strict isolation'' after Laboa told his staff not to speak to the ousted dictator. An embassy spokesman said the television set in the room was broken. Panamanian sources said the U.S. Southern Command had tried to convince Noriega's longtime mistress to try to lure Noriega out the embassy. But the sources, who asked not to be further identified, said Vicky Amado talked to Noriega for 10 minutes after her release from a U.S. military facility and told him, ``The decision is in your hands.'' There was no immediate word on the whereabouts of Ms. Amado or Noriega's wife and three children. His family had been holed up in the Cuban Embassy. Throughout the standoff at the Vatican mission, the Vatican has said it would not deliver Noriega directly to the United States and would deal with Panama. Panama's foreign minister, Julio Linares, said Panama's Constitution did not permit the general's extradition to the United States. Former President Reagan, the first of two presidents that Noriega defied during his reign in power, said he was ``pleased that Gen. Noriega will be brought to justice.'' Reagan made the comments in Los Angeles through his spokesman, Mark Weinberg. Noriega reveled in thumbing his nose at the United States, which he called ``the colossus of the north.'' Washington imposed sanctions against Panama in its effort to dislodge the general from power, but Noriega wouldn't budge. When elections apparently were going against him in May 1989, he abruptly had them annulled. For a time he had his own handpicked man as provisional president. Later his controlled legislature gave Noriega himself full civilian powers to go with the military clout he had long possessed, and which made him the most powerful man in Panama. On Dec. 20, shortly after incidents in which a U.S. Marine lieutenant was killed and in which, according to President Bush, a U.S. Navy couple was abused, U.S. troops invaded Panama and Noriega fled into hiding.

DOC.HEAD: Rare Dinosaur's Bones Found in Northern Colorado
DOC.TEXT: The fossil remains of a rare, meat-eating dinosaur that predated the more famous Tyrannosaurus Rex but rivaled it in size and ferocity have been discovered in Colorado, a scientist said Wednesday. The dinosaur, named Epanterias amplexus, weighed about four tons and measured about 50 feet long, and had a long, powerful tail that probably allowed it to bounce along like a kangaroo, said University of Colorado paleontologist Robert Bakker. The Epanterias could eat about 40 tons of meat a year and its ``claws seem to be the longest and the strongest of any meat-eating dinosaur that ever lived,'' he said. ``Because of its jaw structure, Epanterias could have swallowed a 1,400-pound Hereford cow with no trouble,'' Bakker said. The first bones of the latest Epanterias site were found west of Fort Collins in northern Colorado by a team headed by Bakker. Epanterias walked on its hind legs like Tyrannosaurus Rex, but was built lower, or ``slinkier'' to the ground, Bakker said, adding that T. Rex came along some 66 million years after Epanterias. So far the dig has recovered a jawbone, neck and tail vertebrae and chest bones, he said. ``There's more still in the ground but it's the hardest dig I've ever made, like digging porcelain imbedded in concrete,'' he said. The site is mountainous and a transitional zone between sage and pine. When Epantarias roamed the region 135 million years ago at the end of the Jurassic period, it was a vast flat floodplain stretching east and west from Nevada to South Dakota and north and south from Alberta, Candad, to New Mexico, Bakker said. The only other two known Epantarias sites were discovered in 1877 near Canon City, Colo., and in 1934 in the Oklahoma panhandle. Bakker hopes that by assembling bones from all three sites, a nearly complete composite Epanterias can be assembled. ``Since these discoveries only seem to come along about every 50 years, we still have a lot to learn about Epanterias. Even though this animal was as long as Tyrannosaurus Rex and heavier than the average circus elephant, it's rarely mentioned in standard dinosaur textbooks,'' Bakker said.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. Chairman Roger Smith doesn't see much humor in a documentary named after him _ ``Roger & Me,'' which chronicles life in Flint, Mich., where GM closed 11 plants. Smith, at a news conference Wednesday to discuss GM's new electric-powered Impact car, said he hadn't seen the movie, didn't plan to, and didn't want to talk much about it. ``I'm not muchfor sick humor and I don't like things that take advantage of poor people,'' he said when reporters brought up the film. He then changed the subject. The movie contains interviews with people who said they lost their homes. One woman said she had to kill rabbits for food after Smith shut down the GM plants. The closures eliminated 30,000 jobs in the city of 150,000. Filmmaker Michael Moore said he had made arrangements with Warner Bros. to reserve a seat for Smith at every showing of the movie across the United States.

Donna Rice, a household name after reporters found she spent a weekend with Gary Hart, has become a born-again Christian who spends much of her time doing charitable work, according to a published report. A friend of Miss Rice's, Andy Messing, told The Washington Times in a story Wednesday that she ``went back to her roots and because she did, she wound up coming out of a tailspin that would have killed other people.'' Miss Rice, 32, who declined to be interviewed for the story, became an instant celebrity in 1987 when her relationship with Hart was publicized. Hart dropped out of the race for the Democratic presidential nomination, and later made an unsuccessful re-entry into the contest. Miss Rice now lives with a female friend in northern Virginia. The newspaper said she doesn't have a full-time paying job, and quoted friends as saying she has become quietly involved in charitable work. The newspaper also said she has a boyfriend, and attends some of Washington's high-profile dinners and events. ``Donna ... has not gone through that much of a change,'' said Tricia Erickson, head of a McLean, Va., modeling agency and Miss Rice's designated crisis manager in 1987. ``I don't think that she `went to God,' so to speak. Donna's always been like that. It isn't some miraculous thing.''

World chess champion Garry Kasparov has an entire country indignant over his latest move. Kasparov, 26, proposed in an interview in Playboy magazine's November issue that the Soviet Union sell Mongolia, an independent country and loyal ally of the Soviets, to China. Soviet government spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov said Wednesday that protest letters and petitions signed by thousands of Mongolians have arrived at the Soviet Embassy in Ulan Bator, capital of Mongolia, and four Soviet consulates. He said two-hour strikes were held Dec. 30 at Mongolian plants that make goods for the Soviet market. In the interview, Kasparov said: ``I just had the thought the other day: Why don't we sell the Kuril Islands to the Japanese? Frankly speaking, I'm not sure the islands belong to us, and the Japanese, who claim them, would give us billions and billions for them! ``That would keep us going for maybe five or 10 years. Then we could sell Mongolia to China and get a few more years that way.''

CBS has denied a published report that the network will cancel the low-rated late-night ``Pat Sajak Show'' as soon as it finds a replacement. ``CBS has no response,'' said a CBS official who declined to be identified. ``This is an ongoing rumor and has no validity.'' The trade publication Daily Variety said Wednesday that CBS was delaying cancellation of the show until a replacement series was found. Rumors of the show's cancellation have been circulating for several months. Ratings for the show, introduced Jan. 9, have trailed NBC's ``The Tonight Show'' starring Johnny Carson, the syndicated ``Arsenio Hall Show'' and ABC's ``Nightline.''

Singer-songwriter Neil Diamond will be honored during the American Music Awards presentations with a special Award of Merit for his contributions to music. Stevie Wonder, the 1982 Award of Merit winner, will present the trophy to Diamond during the ABC-TV awards show Jan. 22 from the Shrine Auditorium. Past recipients include Bing Crosby, Irving Berlin and Elvis Presley. ``Beginning in the 1960s, he has written, recorded and performed his very special songs about love, loneliness, good times and patriotic feelings about America,'' reads the inscription on the trophy.

This year's Grammy Awards ceremonies will include lifetime achievement honors to Dick Clark, Paul McCartney, Miles Davis and the late Vladimir Horowitz and Nat King Cole. The five will be honored at the Feb. 21 event, said Michael Greene, president of the National Academy of Recording Artists. McCartney's impact on music as a songwriter and member of the Beatles, as well as his continuing growth as a solo performer were cited as reasons for his achievement award. Jazz legend Davis played a crucial role in the development of jazz since the 1940s, the academy said. Horowitz was included because many consider him the 20th century's greatest classical pianist, and Cole was cited as a leading singer of the 1940s and 1950s. The inclusion of Clark was a surprise because he produces the American Music Awards, which competes with the Grammys. ``We don't view these shows as competitive and when you look at the big contribution Clark has made to the recording industry, especially in exposing new talent, there is no question he is deserving,'' Greene said.

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Says He Will Model Mob Fight on Drug War
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh is remodeling the government's vaunted organized crime strike forces along the lines of its oft-criticized drug task forces. Thornburgh has expended large chunks of his political capital on a merger that has mystified Democrats and Republicans on Capitol Hill. He implemented the plan Monday during a congressional recess, spurning a last-minute appeal for delay from Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Joseph R. Biden. Since Thornburgh announced the plan last February, 33 strike force lawyers _ nearly a fourth of the government's top organized crime prosecutors _ have quit. More plan to follow. ``This is the first time I can remember where government officials seem determined to reform a program that everyone agrees has been a tremendous success,'' said Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., when the attorney general appeared before Senate committees to promote his plan. Thornburgh responded that his motive was simply to assure that ``the best management model is in place.'' The strike forces based in 25 cities followed crime families and alliances across state lines. They worked directly for the Organized Crime and Racketeering Section of the Criminal Division in Washington that formulated a national strategy. In the last decade, they have imprisoned the leadership of organized crime families in Boston, Brooklyn, Chicago, Cleveland, Denver, Kansas City, Los Angeles, New Haven, New Orleans, Philadelphia and Rochester. Thornburgh, however, has never been enamored of their independence. He is merging them this week into the existing U.S. attorneys' offices in 23 cities. Thornburgh says his new model for fighting organized crime is the ``highly productive effort'' by 13 drug task forces, each headed by a U.S. attorney who coordinates federal, state and local agencies. Not everyone, even in Thornburgh's own party or department, agrees that would be an improvement. One Senate Republican source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said flatly that ``the (drug) task forces don't work.'' Evidence of problems with the drug task forces comes from the administration itself. Charles Blau, the deputy associate attorney general who watched over them from their startup in 1983 until last year, described them as weak and decentralized. He said he spent 50 to 60 percent of his time trying to referee turf battles between U.S. attorneys. Thornburgh, however, contends that modeling organized crime efforts after the drug task forces actually will decrease turf battles. He also says the change will prod the strike forces to look more closely at newer forms of organized crime such as international drug cartels, street gangs and Asian and Jamaican criminal organizations. In a November report to Congress, drug czar William Bennett backed Thornburgh's merger plan, and he also praised the drug task forces. But he added that the drug task forces have ``two important deficiencies'' _ lack of direction from Washington to resolve disputes and to ensure that resources are not wasted on less important cases. Bennett said the government needs to take decisive action to overcome ``the `single district' focus of some U.S. attorneys.'' One source close to Bennett who spoke on condition of anonymity said the drug control director caved in on the organized crime question because he was more concerned with ``other fights we have with Thornburgh,'' like getting the U.S. attorneys to work together on major drug cases. Thornburgh has advocated making the strike forces subordinate to U.S. attorneys since 1974, when he was a U.S. attorney in Pittsburgh who clashed with the strike force chief there. Veterans of the strike forces are certain the move will ultimately allow U.S. attorneys to divert the lawyers to short-term cases that might provide quicker publicity and political gain. Jeremiah O'Sullivan, who headed the Boston strike force for 10 years until early 1989, said that prospect is driving his former colleagues out. ``They don't want to work in an office where the person they work for knows little or nothing about the subject matter, and where turnover is so rapid that there's nobody there long enough to work the long-range cases. They don't want to work bank robberies and short-range, modest drug cases,'' O'Sullivan said. Although the attorney general cannot fire U.S. attorneys _ they are presidential appointees _ Thornburgh spokesman Dave Runkel said this attorney general can prevent the U.S. attorneys from cannibalizing their new organized crime units. ``They know him and respect him and appreciate what he has done,'' Runkel said, noting that Thornburgh is one of only two attorneys general to have worked previously as U.S. attorneys. Runkel also said Thornburgh plans to pursue a unified organized crime strategy developed by a council of federal agency heads. Convinced that isn't happening with the drug task forces, Biden and other Democrats have proposed combining Justice's organized crime and narcotics operations into a separate division with its own field offices reporting to one manager in Washington. On Dec. 6, Biden wrote Thornburgh asking him to delay the strike force merger until Congress considered that proposal in February. Thornburgh's response was to implement the merger this week while Congress was away. In addition, The Associated Press has learned, he mailed Biden's letter to U.S. attorneys, telling them he ``may be calling upon you for assistance with your home state senators'' to defeat Biden's proposal. One Democratic Senate source said, ``Everyone is flabbergasted. No one can understand why he's burning up so many political bridges on this one.'' An equally surprised Republican source said Thornburgh ``put a lot of time and prestige into this.'' ``There was more vigorous lobbying on this than anything else they did this year,'' the GOP source said. ``They had squads of people going up to line up votes.''

DOC.HEAD: Banks and Thrifts Fell in Big Numbers During 1980s
DOC.TEXT: Most of the 1980s were boom years for the economy as a whole, but they were a bust for banks and savings institutions which failed in numbers not seen in half a century. Capping a decade of failure for financial institutions, savings and loans in 1989 collapsed at the highest rate ever and bank closings fell only slightly short of a post-Depression high, regulators said Wednesday. Government seizure of thrifts in Texas and New Mexico on Dec. 21 boosted the tally of failed S&Ls to 328, far above the previous high of 277 in 1938. The Resolution Trust Corp., the agency created Aug. 9 to carry out President Bush's S&L bailout, took control of 318 failed thrifts, disposing of 37 of them by year's end. The old Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp. dealt with 10 S&Ls. Meanwhile, a commercial bank failure in California and another in New York on Dec. 20 pushed the total to 207 for the year, down from a post-Depression record of 221 in 1988, according to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. The decline, although small, was the first since 1977 when six banks failed, a drop from 17 the previous year. Academic experts and analysts point to a number of factors behind the soaring failure rate in the 1980s, some of which are still present as the financial system begins a new decade. ``I don't see 1989 as being the end of this,'' said Catherine England, a scholar at the Cato Institute, a conservative research group in Washington. ``I think failures are going to continue to increase into the 1990s.'' Rapidly advancing technology is making it more difficult for financial institutions to compete. Companies that once borrowed from banks are now able to issue junk bonds or commercial paper. Consumers can bank by telephone or computer, bypassing local banks and S&Ls in favor of better deals offered by big institutions and money market mutual funds. ``That means we just don't need as many banks and S&Ls as we once did. ... And this overcapacity is one of the reasons we're seeing these failures,'' she said. Also, the expansion of federal deposit insurance in 1980 from $40,000 per account to $100,000 encouraged bank and S&L owners to take more risks, knowing the government would pick up the tab if their investments soured. A farm crisis as the decade began, followed by an oil crisis in the mid-1980s, helped guarantee that many risky investments would go bad. High interest rates used in the early 1980s by the Federal Reserve System to fight inflation depressed commodity prices and drove the value of the dollar sky high, squelching farm export sales. Farming's crisis became rural banks' crisis. Then, with the 1986 collapse of oil prices, concern shifted to Texas and other oil-producing states whose go-go economies were fueled by the expectation of endlessly increasing oil prices. The fallout of the oil bust was still being felt as late as 1989 when 134 bank failures and 90 S&L insolvencies occurred in Texas. Now, shaky real estate markets in Arizona and in some states of the Northeast are prompting concerns that as Texas recovers, institutions in other states will start to topple. Savings institutions suffered from some of the same regional problems, but added at least three other causes: weak regulation, the effect of volatile interest rates on home mortgage portfolios and the inability of the government to close bankrupt institutions because the S&L deposit insurance fund had run out of money. A few private analysts fear the true analogy for the 1980s is not the 1930s, but the 1920s, when hundreds of banks failed each year despite general prosperity. That was followed by even more collapses and general economic ruin in the 1930s. FDIC Chairman L. William Seidman agrees the historically high failure rate won't disappear overnight, but he is predicting that 1990 will bring another drop in the bank closing total. Last year's failures brought the decade total to 1,894 institutions: 1,059 banks and 835 S&Ls.

DOC.HEAD: Conservatives Rate Performance of Bush and Cabinet
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle gets the highest marks and Secretary of Transportation Samuel D. Skinner the lowest in a conservative critique of the Bush administration's first year. President Bush averages a ``C plus'' in the view of five conservative leaders asked by the magazine Policy Review to grade the performance of the president and his Cabinet. The magazine is published by the conservative Heritage Foundation. Quayle gets an average grade between ``A minus'' and ``A,'' with religious broadcaster Pat Robertson describing him as ``a superb vice president.'' Skinner averages a ``D minus.'' Edward H. Crane, president of the Cato Institute, gives him an ``F'' and says Bush's Democratic opponent, Michael Dukakis, ``would have rejected Skinner as hopelessly liberal.'' Crane gives Bush a ``D,'' saying he is ``inexcusably weak'' on domestic issues and ``avoids an `F' by his measured response to developments in Eastern Europe.'' Budget director Richard Darman rates just behind Quayle, falling between a ``B plus'' and an ``A minus.'' Burton Pines, senior vice president and director of research at the Heritage Foundation, hails him as ``a hero'' for his resistance to tax increases. Next comes White House Chief of Staff John Sununu, with a solid ``B plus.'' Paul M. Weyrich, director of the Free Congress Foundation, calls him ``the best chief of staff I have seen'' in 23 years in Washington. Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney comes out with an average of better than a ``B.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III averages a ``C minus,'' as do Secretary of the Interior Manuel Lujan, Secretary of Health and Human Services Louis Sullivan and Secretary of Energy James D. Watkins. Secretary of the Treasury Nicholas F. Brady has the second lowest average grade, a ``D.'' Amy Moritz, executive director of the National Center for Public Policy Research, says Brady's ``lackluster handling'' failed to give the needed boost to Bush's plan for a capital gains tax cut.

DOC.HEAD: Report Finds Fraud and Embezzlement in Some Foreign Aid Programs
DOC.TEXT: Theft and fraud in some foreign aid programs results in federal funds intended for food and health care being used instead to buy things like mink coats and a tennis court, a federal audit says. The report by the U.S. Agency for International Development's inspector general said that from April through September 1989, it recovered $182,946 in misused funds and saved AID $2.4 million in unnecessary expenses. The AID watchdog monitors more than 2,000 projects in 70 countries with a budget of about $7.2 billion. Most of the programs provide American money for health, education, rural development and agriculture in Third World nations. The inspector general's report said it received 133 complaints during the six-month reporting period. Of that total, 102 concerned allegations of fraud, bribery, embezzlement, false claims or conflicts of interest; 25 were linked to allegations of criminal violations and six involved administrative irregularities. According to the report, an AID bookkeeper pleaded guilty to the theft of $340,228 and ``used the stolen funds to maintain a lavish lifestyle.'' Without identifying the woman, it said she gave $111,000 to friends, purchased several mink coats, toy dolls with mink coats, eight original paintings and a sculpture. In Rwanda, investigators found that a director from a volunteer agency sold donated food to pay the labor costs for the construction of his new home and a tennis court. Several of his employees also sold food provided by AID ``and, in one instance, built a restaurant.'' In Chad, a local AID employee was found selling customs duty exemptions to local merchants. In Indonesia, an AID worker was jailed for forging stolen checks. The inspector general's office questioned the viability of a multimillion-dollar irrigation program in the Bakel region of Senegal, saying ``there was no evidence from the projects that irrigated farming was commercially viable.'' The report said the project should be terminated if an evaluation ``does not result in a positive assessment.'' The investigation also said AID continued to have problems with cash advances, with an audit showing $1.1 million in outstanding advances. ``Attempts to correct the problems had been restricted to a case-by-case basis without addressing the underlying systemic causes,'' it said. The inspector general's office found several cases of countries failing to meet established guidelines for dealing with programs. In the Food for Peace programs, for example, host nations are to use the money received from the sale of the food for approved AID projects. Problems were found in El Salvador, Uruguay and Liberia. AID's contraceptive program also ran into problems because of lack of controls. The agency provides more than 80 percent of the world's donated contraceptives, which cost about $244 million from 1982 to 1988. A lack of effective controls has ``made it more difficult for AID to efficiently deliver contraceptives,'' and some products deteriorated due to poor storage, the report said. The inspector general's report concluded, ``AID managers must deal with many countries that lack adequate systems of financial accountability and program management.'' It said investigations showed inadequate controls and accountability over local currencies, insufficient financial contributions by host governments, weak AID accounting systems, and failure to put into place systems to identify and correct problems found in projects.

DOC.HEAD: Administration S&L Plan Emphasizes Early Sales of Real Estate
LaserPhoto WX6
With PM-Decade of Failures
DOC.TEXT: A key member of Congress praises the Bush administration's emphasis on speedily selling real estate from failed savings institutions, but others worry about the effect on shaky real estate markets. The administration's strategic plan for conducting the savings and loan bailout, released Wednesday, instructs regulators to begin selling real estate and other assets from insolvent S&Ls even before the government officially closes the institutions. Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., chairman of a House task force which is monitoring the S&L bailout, praised the approach. ``Procrastinating is much more of a risk because you have to pay to manage it (the real estate). The stuff doesn't get better with age. It's not like red wine,'' Vento said. Kenneth A. Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers' Association of America, cautioned the policy ``could wind up being a major political problem on the front door of the president ... by putting downward pressure on real estate prices.'' He noted, however, the administration faces problems no matter which approach it emphasized: speed or caution. ``There's a real question of whether the market can stabilize if they don't get rid of the overhang'' of unsold properties, he said. The plan was written by an oversight board chaired by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. The board sets policy for the Resolution Trust Corp., which is run by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., an independent regulatory agency. The RTC was created Aug. 9 by S&L bailout legislation. So far, it's taken over 318 S&Ls, disposing of 37 of them. The 281 S&Ls remaining in its control have assets of $104 billion. It expects to take over an addition 200 institutions with assets of about $150 billion. Roughly half of the total assets are real estate. Oversight board President Daniel P. Kearney, in an attempt to quiet fears the real estate will be dumped, noted much of it is entangled in legal problems and said it could take several years for the RTC to get clear title required to sell. The plan released Wednesday was little changed from a draft obtained by The Associated Press three weeks ago. One difference was that the oversight board originally gave the RTC a June 30 deadline for reviewing bailout deals put together by its predecessor, the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp. The final plan extended the deadline to Aug. 31. The plan leaves an important financing issue unresolved. The bailout bill passed by Congress provides $50 billion to close insolvent S&Ls. But administration officials estimate they need to borrow another $50 billion to $100 billion in ``working capital'' to finance S&L deals, repaying it as assets from the institutions are sold. The administration emphasizes that borrowing working capital does not mean the taxpayer cost of the bailout will go up, but Vento said Congress is reluctant to permit the administration to borrow that much. Bert Ely, a thrift analyst in Alexandria, Va., said he estimates the administration needs at least $72 billion in working capital. ``That's an enormous amount of money and the question is how are they going to come up with it,'' Ely said. ``One of the things we may be seeing here is the beginning stage of a big punt that would leave hundreds of (failed) S&Ls sitting out there corrupting the marketplace.''

DOC.HEAD: Global Warming Could Alter Forests Early in Next Century
DOC.TEXT: A study showing that global warming could speed the destruction of forests by fire and windstorms suggests noticeable change could occur in the Earth's forests by early in the next century, a researcher said. ``The rate of change will be faster than we thought before,'' said Jonathan Overpeck, the study's principal author. The change will be marked by the appearance of fast-growing species of trees in areas where mature trees have been destroyed, said Overpeck, a staff scientist at the Lamont-Doherty Geological Observatory in Palisades. Previous computer projections have shown that changes in temperature and rainfall could affect the growth of forests. This is the first to show that physical destruction of trees will play a significant role in changing forests as the Earth warms, Overpeck said. George Woodwell, an ecologist and the director of the Woods Hole Research Center in Massachusetts, said Overpeck's findings agree with decades of research by ecologists showing that similar forest disturbance has occurred when climate changed in the past. Margaret Davis, an ecologist at the University of Minnesota, said: ``This is important because the effects of disturbance are much quicker than the effects of climate change. ... It gives us less time to respond to the change.'' Overpeck's collaborators were David Rind of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Goddard Institute for Space Studies and Richard Goldberg of the Institute for Global Habitability at Columbia University. Their study appears today in Nature, a British scientific journal. Global warming is occuring as so-called greenhouse effect gases build up in the atmosphere. The gases include carbon dioxide and the chlorofluorocarbons used in refrigerators and air conditioners. The Earth is expected to warm gradually during the next century as the gases enable the atmosphere to trap more and more of the sun's heat, mimicking the action of a greenhouse. Experts disagree over how much the Earth will warm and when the effects will begin to be felt. But few disagree with the premise that the Earth will warm. Overpeck cautioned that his findings should not be taken as a prediction. He cannot say precisely how soon changes in forests will begin to be noticed or how great the change will be. But the research demonstrates that computer forecasts should take into account the physical destruction of forests as well as the effects of changing temperature and rainfall, he said. Overpeck and his colleagues used a computer climate program developed by NASA to show that thunderstorms, hurricanes and tornadoes will occur more frequently as the climate warms. They then used a second computer program to assess the effect of these changes on forests. Lightning associated with the increasingly frequent thunderstorms will increase the likelihood of forest fires, they said, and the windstorms will uproot trees.

DOC.HEAD: Coin Flip Determines Winner Of Trustee Race
DOC.TEXT: For the second time in four years, a coin toss decided a deadlocked election for a trustee seat. The coin toss Tuesday at the Mahoning County Board of Elections was a repeat of the election four years ago involving the same men. The results were the same both times for Robert Spencer, who lost to Bruce Behner when he picked tails in a coin flip that came up heads. Behner will serve another four-year term as a trustee of rural Goshen Township in northeastern Ohio. ``This is unbelievable ... twice in four years,'' said Spencer, 40, a bus salesman at Myers Equipment Corp. ``Son of a gun, what can I say?'' The coin toss was needed after Behner, 53, a hog farmer, paid $50 for a recount after close balloting in November. He was a write-in candidate for one of two trustee seats open after he failed to correctly file petitions for re-election. The recount showed Behner had 261 votes to Spencer's 271. John Heffner was the top vote-getter with 307 votes. There were 10 disputed ballots where Behner's name was written in but the oval next to it was not blackened, as required by law. A ruling by Ohio Secretary of State Sherrod Brown gave the ballots to Behner, ending the election in a tie. Behner said he was glad to keep the job, which pays a maximum of $5,600 per year.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Noriega and PM-US-Panama
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of President Bush's statement announcing that deposed Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega had surrendered to U.S. authorities: On Wednesday, Dec. 20, I ordered U.S. troops to Panama with four objectives: Safeguard the lives of American citizens, help restore democracy, protect the integrity of the Panama Canal treaties and bring Gen. Manuel Noriega to justice. All of these objectives have now been achieved. At about 8:50 this evening Gen. Noriega turned himself in to U.S. authorities in Panama with the full knowledge of the Panamanian government. He was taken to Howard Air Force Base in Panama where he was arrested by DEA. A U.S. Air Force C-130 is now transporting Gen. Noriega to Homestead Air Force Base, Florida. He will be arraigned in the U.S. District Court in Miami on charges stemming from his previous indictment for drug trafficking. I want to thank the Vatican and the papal nuncio in Panama for their evenhanded statesmanlike assistance in recent days. The United States is committed to providing Gen. Noriega a fair trial. Nevertheless, his apprehension and return to the United States will send a clear signal that the United States is serious in its determination that those charged with promoting the distribution of drugs cannot escape the scrutiny of justice. The return of Gen. Noriega marks a significant milestone in Operation Just Cause. The U.S. used its resources in a manner consistent with political, diplomatic and moral principles. The first U.S. combat troops have already been withdrawn from Panama. Others will follow as quickly as the local situation will permit. We are now engaged in the final stages of a process that includes the economic and political revitalization of this important friend and neighbor, Panama. An economic team under the direction of Deputy Secretary of State Eagleburger and Deputy Secretary of Treasury Robson is just returning from Panama. A team of experts has remained on hand there to assess the full range of needs. We will continue to extend to the Panamanian people our support and assistance in the days ahead. Panamanians and Americans both have sacrificed much to restore democracy to Panama. The armed forces of the United States have performed their mission courageously and effectively. And I again want to express my gratitude and appreciation to all of them. And I want to express the special thanks of our nation to those servicemen who were wounded and to the families of those who gave their lives. Their sacrifice has been a noble cause that will never be forgotten. A free and prosperous Panama will be an enduring tribute. Thank you all very very much.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: This affluent Boston suburb is getting particular about who takes the garbage out. If the maid or butler isn't the live-in kind and turns up at the community's state-of-the-art Recycling and Disposal Facility with their employers' refuse, they will be turned away at the gate, Department of Public Works Director Pat Berdan said. ``If the maid lives in the house, she can (bring in rubbish). But if it's a hired worker that comes there, no, she can't,'' Berdan said. Though well-off, the city still counts its pennies. The Public Works Department is cracking down on commercial dumpers who try to evade the $80 per ton dumping fee. How does one determine which trash is truly Wellesleyan? ``We hold it up to the light and if it has alligators on it, we know it's from Wellesley,'' Berdan joked. In fact, he said, experienced workers will note how often someone disposes of garbage. Based on an assumption that an individual produces a daily garbage output of 3 to 5 pounds, the average family is expected to visit the dump once a week.

A Canadian steel town has linked up with its American neighbor in an advertising campaign that puts nationalism in the back seat. Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario, and Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., are advertising themselves to tourists as a single town. ``There's a saying we're using _ Sault Ste. Marie is a city so great it takes two countries to hold it,'' said Joseph Fratesi, mayor of Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario, a steel mill city of about 83,000 residents. Across the St. Marys River and the border is Sault Ste. Marie , Mich., a town of about 14,500 and home to Soo Locks, a commercial shipping passage. Lumped together, the twin cities make what locals call the Two Soos. This fall, they produced a brochure that advertises the towns as one. Tourism has new importance for the Ontario town, which is dominated by the smokestacks of Algoma Steel Corp. Employment at the mill has dropped from a peak of 12,500 to current averages of 7,500 workers, Fratesi said. ``You can't totally rely on the smoke of our steel mill to build our economy,'' he said. ``There's no question you'll see less smoke and more effort to entice people from the United States into Canada.''

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Advocated Strike Force Change Since 1974
With PM-Strike Forces, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The last time Dick Thornburgh was in the federal government he mounted an attack on the Justice Department's organized crime strike forces with mixed success. The outcome of that effort has provided ammunition for both sides of the argument over his current decision to put the strike forces under the control of local U.S. attorneys. In 1976, Thornburgh was assistant attorney general in charge of the Criminal Division and was given responsibility for reviewing the effectiveness of the strike forces on a case-by-case basis. The review was an outgrowth of Thornburgh's own 1974 recommendation, as U.S. attorney in Pittsburgh and chairman of a committee of U.S. attorneys, that the strike forces, which worked for the organized crime section in Washington, be merged into the U.S. attorneys' offices. Thornburgh closed the New Orleans and St. Louis offices and merged the strike forces in Pittsburgh and the Southern District of New York (Manhattan) with U.S. attorneys' offices there. There still is no St. Louis strike force, but a local outcry led by the New Orleans Metropolitan Crime Commission, which also opposes the current move, persuaded the Justice Department to reopen the New Orleans strike force two years later. It went on to convict New Orleans mob boss Carlos Marcello. Thornburgh himself regularly points to the successes achieved by the Southern District in New York during the 1980s as proof that his plan will provide continued strong pursuit of organized crime. Several cases culminated in the 1985 indictment under the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act of the bosses of the Genovese, Gambino, Luchese, Bonnano and Colombo families who made up the mob's governing commission. Four were convicted; one was murdered. Thornburgh told senators this fall that four separate U.S. attorneys served in Manhattan during the time that case was investigated. Thornburgh's opponents, however, said those successes were primarily the product of an unusual U.S. attorney, Rudolph Giuliani, who came to the post in 1983 from the No. 3 job at the Justice Department. ``Giuliani's predecessors also had outstanding records of achievement, but not in the area of organized crime,'' said Edward A. McDonald, who quit this summer after seven years as Brooklyn strike force chief. He told Congress that Giuliani assigned more than 20 assistants to work on organized crime. But after the mob governing commission case, McDonald said, ``Giuliani shifted his focus to public corruption'' and insider trading and reduced the office's organized crime unit ``by more than half.'' McDonald and others argued that the strike forces provided sustained, long-term enforcement but that the New York experience showed that even the best U.S. attorneys are easily distracted by the latest high-profile cases. Jeremiah O'Sullivan, who headed the Boston strike force for 10 years, also said that the RICO statute, used by the strike forces to bring down whole crime hierarchies, had never been used by a U.S. attorney in Pittsburgh against the organized crime family there. Asked about organized crime in Pittsburgh, Thornburgh's spokesman, Dave Runkel, paused, then joked, ``My first answer would be that Thornburgh wiped it out.'' Although promising to check for a further explanation of the lack of RICO prosecutions, Runkel provided none.

DOC.HEAD: CDC: AIDS Epidemic Growing More Slowly Than Expected
DOC.TEXT: The nation's AIDS epidemic may be growing more slowly than expected, according to an unofficial assessment that found an apparent drop-off in the number of cases among homosexual and bisexual men. Official estimates of the potential number of AIDS cases, ranging from 1 million to 1.5 million people, may be too high, said statisticians attending a closed meeting sponsored by the Atlanta-based federal Centers for Disease Control. Officials said the number of infected people, or eventual AIDS cases, actually ranges from 700,000 to 1.3 million _ a number that could lower direct health costs of the epidemic by as much as $12 billion, according to an article published in Thursday's editions of the Atlanta Journal-Constitution. The new estimates are the outgrowth of a November meeting of public health officials and mathematicians in Atlanta, called to find new ways of assessing the impact of the AIDS epidemic on the health care system. The meeting, summarized in the journal Science, also examined estimates of the total numbers of infections, the number of people receiving therapy at different stages of the disease and the implications for the provision of health services, the newspaper said. If the projections are correct, the United States could have between 5,000 and 12,000 fewer AIDS cases this year than predicted in 1986 by the U.S. Public Health Service. Next year's toll could be 20,000 lower. ``We're figuring out what the size of the problem is,'' said Dr. Timothy Dondero, head of the agency's AIDS surveillance program. Blood tests of military applicants, trauma patients, blood donors, childbearing women, Job Corps entrants and federal prisoners continue to suggest that between 800,000 and 1.3 million people are now infected with the virus. That estimate is very close to the new projections derived at the CDC meeting. But the unofficial projections are based on mathematical models that attempt to gauge the extent of the epidemic in the general population, rather than unrepresentative groups who have been tested for the virus. In 1988, a former CDC expert, Dr. Alex Langmuir, predicted there would be fewer than 200,000 cases of AIDS in the United States by 1991. Others suggested the number could be as high as 3 million. Researchers said the slowdown could be a result of increased caution among homosexuals, who in 1983 began using more condoms, limiting the numbers of sexual partners and avoiding high-risk sexual activity in bathhouses and group settings. Others believe that drugs such as AZT and aerosol pentamidine, available for use beginning in 1986 and 1987, may have slowed the onset of AIDS in people who began taking it before they developed symptoms of the disease.

DOC.HEAD: Northwest Plane Delayed 2 Hours by Bomb Threat
DOC.TEXT: A bomb threat Wednesday night prompted Northwest Airlines officials to delay a flight about to depart for Newark, N.J., but no bomb was found and the plane took off two hours late. Northwest Flight 1192 had been scheduled to leave Detroit Metropolitan Airport at 9:55 p.m. EST Wednesday, said Northwest spokesman Bob Gibbons in Minnesota, where the airline is based. ``Just before departure we got a threatening phone call,'' he said. ``We searched the plane. Nothing was found.'' The flight took off at 11:55 p.m. and was expected to land in Newark at 1:11 a.m. Thursday, the airline said. Gibbons said it was to carry 45 passengers and six crew members. Gibbons withheld details about Wednesday night's threat. Northwest last week revealed that it had received a bomb threat for a flight last Saturday from Paris to Detroit and offered passengers the option of changing or canceling their reservations with no penalty. Gibbons said Wednesday night's threat was the first Northwest had received since then.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Federation Wants to Visit Soviet Miners
DOC.TEXT: The AFL-CIO, which is hosting a visit by nine Soviet miners trying to form independent unions, is still pressing the Soviet government to let U.S. labor leaders visit there, the federation's president says. The Soviet government refused about a month ago to let an AFL-CIO delegation visit workers in the Soviet Union interested in setting up independent trade unions. The nine Soviet miners met Wednesday with AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland and United Mine Workers President Richard Trumka as part of their month-long study of U.S. labor unions and mining and safety practices. Kirkland, referring to the tentative settlement reached this week to end a bitter nine-month UMW strike against The Pittston Co., told the Soviet miners that workers trying to ``gain a better life for their families must face and deal with powerful and entrenched forces in every society.'' ``That is certainly true here,'' he said. Also Wednesday, the AFL-CIO called on the Soviet government to reverse last week's decision to revoke the passport and exit visa of a miner who had been scheduled to make the tour, Sergei Masalovich. The AFL-CIO says the Soviet government inaccurately claimed the strike leader was relieved of his duties by the Vorkuta Strike Committee. The miners are the guests of the AFL-CIO but the trip is being paid for through a U.S. Information Agency exchange program. The Soviets are scheduled to visit mines in Virginia or West Virginia, the Colorado School of Mines, meet labor leaders in Pittsburgh and Atlanta and attend a Texas state AFL-CIO convention on political activity. When Kirkland announced the Soviets' visit last month, he compared their struggle to that of Solidarity organizers in Poland in the early 1980s and pledged to offer the federation's support even if it meant defying the Soviet government. The AFL-CIO's support of Solidarity included the smuggling of printing and other communications equipment into Poland when Solidarity was outlawed. In all, the federation gave about $5 million worth of equipment and other assistance to Solidarity.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Ponders Fee to Promote Recycling
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is considering a proposal that would bolster environmental protection by taxing industries that don't use recycled materials. The unspecified fee on raw materials, which would be imposed on substances such as glass, paper and aluminum, is likely to be included in Bush's fiscal 1991 budget when it is submitted to Congress Jan. 29, said officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity. The proposal might appear to violate Bush's commitment against higher taxes. But administration officials suggested the levy would be classified more as a ``user fee,'' and thus escape the no-new-taxes edict.
