Meanwhile, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Wednesday that the administration has dropped a budget proposal for a new tax on recreational vehicles to pay for conservation measures. The administration ``decided there probably was a better way to do that,'' Fitzwater said. The RV ``fee'' was included in an early draft budget. Details were still sketchy because administration officials would not discuss details of the emerging 1991 budget. But the raw-materials proposal is designed to provide an economic incentive for industries to use recycled goods rather than virgin materials. The tax would not be applied to recycled substances. ``We want to encourage recycling, for obvious reasons,'' said deputy White House press secretary Stephen Hart on Wednesday. He said promotion of recycling is part of the major emphasis Bush intends to put on environmental issues this year. Bush on Wednesday signed a proclamation designating next April 22 as the 20th annual Earth Day. He said the day will be a chance ``to reflect on the progress made over the past 20 years and set the environmental agenda for the next decade.'' Earth Day ``should inspire us to save the land we love, to realize that global problems do have local solutions, and to make preservation of the planet a personal commitment.'' The president also called on Congress to work ``quickly, carefully and responsibly'' to approve strengthening amendments to the Clean Air Act. Congress recessed for the year without completing work on a legislative package to rework air quality standards. Fitzwater asserted anew that Bush's new budget, for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, will contain no new taxes. But he said it would feature ``some very interesting programs.'' Administration officials frequently seek to draw a distinction between a widely applied tax and a more narrowly targeted ``user fee,'' even though the distinction may be lost on those who pay the levy.

DOC.HEAD: First Lady Takes Radiation Treatment Swimmingly
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush will get nine more radiation treatments for a troublesome eye ailment after sailing through her first one and then jumping in the White House pool for a mile swim. Mrs. Bush, who aides said felt fine after the Wednesday treatment, is undergoing the radiation to try and cure double vision and tearing eyes that drugs have failed to correct. The eye ailment results from Graves disease, an immune system ailment that earlier attacked her thyroid. The thyroid condition has been remedied through drugs and radioactive treatment that rendered her thyroid inactive. But the eye symptoms have persisted despite treatment with prednisone, a powerful steroid. If the 10 doses of radiation don't work, she may have to consider surgery to relieve pressure in the eye socket or to reattach malfunctioning muscles, experts say. Mrs. Bush was at Walter Reed Army Medical Center for more than three hours on Wednesday for the 10-minute radiation treatment plus examinations, said her press secretary, Anna Perez. ``She said it was like a trip to the dentist, only better,'' Perez said. ``She went swimming right after she came back,'' doing her customary mile of laps in the heated outdoor pool at the White House. She later was seen walking about the White House grounds in a sweatsuit. The low-level radiation treatment is intended to halt swelling in the small muscles that control movements of the eyes. Medical experts not associated with the case said such treatment is routine for Graves' disease eye patients who have not responded to other therapy. The radiation treatment is not considered dangerous. ``The published studies report 60 to 90 percent of patients have a favorable response to this treatment,'' said Dr. Joshua Cohen, an endocrinology specialist at George Washington University Medical Center. The treatment does not cause side effects, said the experts.

DOC.HEAD: Task Force Envisions Some Drilling at Offshore Sites, Say Sources
DOC.TEXT: A federal task force is recommending a wide array of options for oil development at three controversial offshore sites near Florida and California and none of the choices would ban drilling altogether, according to administration sources. The task force report was to go to the White House today, according to Interior Department officials who said it would not be made public. Sources familiar with the recommendations said Wednesday the options for the leases off the California coast would envision oil and gas development, but in some cases include specific conditions, restrictions and various timetables. The task force adopted more restrictive options for the lease off the Florida coast, according to one source, including one that could delay development for several years because of environmental concerns. The possible damage to sensitive coral reefs was cited by the task force in the Florida lease, according to one source. The sources spoke only on the condition that they not be identified further. As only scant information about the task force findings could be obtained, several congressmen called for the report to be released by the Bush administration. ``I see no reason for keeping this report a secret,'' said Rep. Dante Fascell, D-Fla. ``Failure to release this latest study can only add to the suspicion, mistrust and confusion that has surrounded the entire (oil lease) program.'' Rep. Frank Pallone, D-N.J., said the secrecy ``creates the perception that the administration does not want to allow this report to be circulated ... that the public is being shut out of this decision-making process.'' The task force was headed by Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan and included representatives of the Energy Department, Environmental Protection Agency, Commerce Department and Office of Management and Budget. Interior spokesman Steve Goldstein said Wednesday the report outlines nine options _ three for each of the three leases _ and covers ``the gamut'' of approaches President Bush could take in deciding whether to proceed with the sale of the three leases. The recommendations ``are designed to give the president the greatest amount of latitude in decision making,'' said Goldstein. He declined to provide further details, only characterizing the options as ``not black and white, but shades of gray.'' The task force completed late editing changes in the report this week. It's not known when Bush would make a decision on whether to proceed with any of the lease sales, which he had put on hold a year ago pending the task force review. Environmentalists have strongly opposed oil and gas drilling at the three lease sites. The leases involved potential oil and gas drilling on 1.1 million acres of ocean off Southern California, 6.7 million acres off Northern California and 14 million acres off the Florida Everglades in the Gulf of Mexico. Two months ago, a panel of the National Academy of Sciences questioned whether enough information was available to make a prudent decision on drilling at the sites. That study said technical and scientific data was ``insufficient'' to warrant leases being issued at this time. At the time, Robert Kallman, task force director, said the scientific panel's findings clarified some of the issues involved and would be taken into account, but did not necessarily rule out an option that leases be issued.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantic City Mayor, Three Others Indicted in Corruption Probe
DOC.TEXT: The indictment of Atlantic City Mayor James L. Usry for influence peddling was grim but hardly unprecedented news for the seaside gaming resort, which also saw three of its previous six mayors face charges. ``I'd say that the people of Atlantic City are numb already,'' City Councilman Seth Grossman said after the indictments were announced Wednesday, five months after Usry was arrested. ``All we want is a resolution to find out what exactly happened.'' ``Atlantic City is deteriorating a little more every day and these indictments have shed some light on why this deterioration is taking place,'' said state Assemblywoman Dolores Cooper, a Republican who is the only declared candidate in the city's race for mayor this year. A state grand jury in Trenton handed up indictments of Usry and three others as part of a wide-ranging probe of influence peddling among government officials of the seaside resort. Usry, president of the National Conference of Black Mayors, was charged in two separate indictments with conspiracy, official misconduct, bribery, gifts to public servants and violating the state campaign contribution law. If convicted of all charges, he faces up to 36 years in prison and $315,000 in fines. His predecessor is serving a 15-year sentence for extortion. Also indicted were businessmen Ernest English and Clarence Gillard, and Robert Harrison, a former official with the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency. An aide said the 67-year-old Republican mayor, who has not announced whether he will seek re-election, will not resign. ``The mayor has no intention of resigning,'' said Rosalind Norrell-Nance. English said he believes the state's case is weak. Gillard and Harrison could not be reached for comment. Home listings could not be obtained. The indictment charges that Usry solicited bribes from English and businessman Ronald Bizzell in exchange for supporting their proposed motorized cart business on the boardwalk. Usry allegedly accepted $6,000 from an informant in exchange for supporting the cart business. Authorities said $6,000 in cash was found in Usry's home when he was arrested July 27, but the mayor's attorney said the money was a contribution for a children's charity from a local businessman relayed through Usry. The indictment charges English and Gillard with allegedly agreeing to pay Usry $300,000 to support the ordinance change. According to the indictment, Usry told English, a former boxer, ``You have to pay. Boxers pay to fight in other people's towns.'' English, 32, and Gillard, age unknown, both face a maximum of 35 years and $307,500 in fines if convicted on all counts of conspiracy, bribery, gifts to public servants and attempted theft. Harrison, the former human resources and minority affairs manager at the state housing agency, was charged with using his state office and directing members of his staff to plan a testimonial dinner to Usry during working hours. Harrison, 41, also is charged with tampering with evidence and refusing to cooperate with the probe. He faces up to 38 years in prison and $237,500 in fines if convicted on all charges. No arraignment date was set for the four men, said Christopher Florentz, spokesman for the state attorney general's office. On Dec. 19, the grand jury indicted four top Atlantic City officials, including the City Council president, and seven others on corruption charges. Those defendants are expected to be arraigned Monday, Florentz said. Usry was elected in 1984 after a recall election for Michael Matthews, who defeated Usry in 1982. Matthews is serving a 15-year prison sentence for extortion.

DOC.HEAD: Women Warriors Win Combat Patches; What Congressional Ban?
LaserPhoto PAN2
DOC.TEXT: The women warriors who helped invade Panama have shattered myths about gender in combat and made mincemeat of a congressional ban. ``It blew everyone's theories,'' said 2nd Lt. Kimberly Thompson, 23. ``Now they are regrouping.'' Despite the ban on women in combat, female soldiers vindicated themselves so well that the White House is leaping to their defense and a leading senator said the exclusion should be re-examined. Thompson, a platoon leader in the 988th Military Police Company from Fort Benning, Ga., knows the myths well. She is third-generation military and the wife of an airborne Ranger, a private who stayed home while she went to war. ``He's proud of me,'' she said of her husband, Steve Thompson. ``He wishes he could have been here too.'' Myth No. 1: Women can't handle combat. Capt. Linda Bray led the 988th into battle, storming the gates of a Panamanian Defense Forces kennel in an armored jeep. ``It was an important military operation. A woman led it and she did an outstanding job,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Wednesday. Bray's troops took the area after a 30-minute firefight in which three of the defenders were killed. There were no U.S. casualties. ``She knew exactly what to do and when to do it,'' said one of her platoon leaders, Sgt. Rick McGowan. ``Her voice didn't quaver when she gave an order.'' Myth No. 2: Men would spend their time protecting the women instead of fighting the enemy. ``Sex doesn't come into play. You don't really think about it,'' McGowan said. ``I wasn't going to put a female squad leader over in a corner. It wouldn't have been fair.'' When the top sergeant called for a machine gunner to advance, no one was thinking about Pvt. Christina Cabido's gender. They were thinking about firepower. ``I felt like we fought side by side. I felt equality,'' she said. ``You don't always feel that in the Army.'' Cabido, a 20-year-old from Strawberry, Ariz., recalled how she felt as her platoon went into battle. ``We were all scared. But we really pulled together as a team,'' she said. ``I thought: Congress doesn't let females in combat. But I was going. I was going.''' Sen. John Warner, R-Va., ranking minority member of Senate Armed Service Committee, said Wednesday in Panama that it is time to take another look at the ban. The women warriors in Panama ```discharged themselves in a very credible military, professional manner,'' he told a news conference. He said what happened in Panama ``will require the Congress once again to re-examine the present laws surrounding the training and the use of women in situations such as this.'' Both law and military policy bar women from being assigned to units, like the infantry, whose main job is to fight the enemy. But women, who make up 11 percent of the military, serve in the military police and in support roles ranging from intelligence to infantry. In this case, the MP unit got what turned out to be a combat assignment. Another woman, U.S. Army special agent Julie Torres, was on a three-person team assigned to Gen. Marc Cisneros, commander of U.S. Army troops in Panama. At one point, when bullets started flying, she threw herself on him and shoved his head behind an armored truck, according the St. Louis Post-Dispatch. ``That's our mission. You take the round. Not him,'' she said. The Pentagon says that 600 of the 26,000 U.S. troops who took part in the invasion were women; none were among the 23 killed. The 988th has about 120 soldiers, at least a dozen of them women. About half of them will win combat patches for the kennel attack and other firefights around town, something few soldiers in today's peacetime Army can boast. Army spokeswoman Paige Eversole said that battle lines blur in modern warfare. ``Even people in support units, where many women are, are going to be vulnerable to modern weapons where they are aimed at troops beyond the front line,'' she said in Washington. Thompson and Cabido are proud they have proved themselves under fire and think the ban on women in combat should be lifted. ``If they do it, it's going to be a long, hard battle,'' Cabido said. ``There's a lot of men in the Army who won't like it.''

DOC.HEAD: Crime Fighters Outraged by Store Selling Caps with Gang Logos
LaserPhoto BX1
DOC.TEXT: Crime fighters in this city's tougher neighborhoods, who have pledged to win their war in the 1990s, can claim a victory as the decade dawns. They beat back gang hats. When word went out Wednesday that Northside Family Sports had started selling baseball-style caps inscribed with the names of two local gangs, community activists moved in swiftly. Within hours, the shop's owner promised to stop selling them. ``If we let this store go then the one on the next block is going to start selling the same kind of stuff,'' said Georgette Watson, a recent target of gang threats. ``We've got to stop this kind of thing before it turns around everything we've been working for,'' added Watson, who has been under 24-hour police protection since a gang allegedly placed a $5,000 bounty on her last month. Watson, founder of the Drop-A-Dime anti-drug tip hot line, was among a contingent of community leaders who went to Jack Malone's sporting goods store to let him know what they thought of his new merchandise. Malone said he was unaware the hats, which were ordered at the request of customers, bore gang-related insignias and assured the activists no more special orders would be taken. The caps, selling for $12.99 each, were inscribed with the gang names, ``Castlegate'' and ``IVP Intervale.'' ``I'd rather nip this thing in the bud,'' Malone said. ``The last thing I want to see is gangs being promoted.'' His decision was probably made easier by the appearance at his doorstep of the mayor, police commissioner, district police superintendent and about a dozen community leaders from the Roxbury, Dorchester and Mattapan neighborhoods. Mayor Raymond L. Flynn, Police Commissioner Francis Roache and Police Deputy Superintendent William Celester met with Watson and other community leaders Wednesday at a doughnut shop adjacent to the sporting goods store. ``It's a free country, but that doesn't mean you have to do this kind of thing in this community,'' Celester said. ``These leaders know what to do.'' The activists stressed they didn't want to come on like vigilantes. ``We didn't come here to close anybody down,'' said Joan Almeida of the Neighborhood Justice Network. ``We came to talk.'' Still, some merchants and residents said the activists had gone too far. ``Are we going to stop selling gang members food to eat or clothes to wear?'' asked one police officer who did not want to be identified. ``It sounds like Hitler's Germany to me.'' Yvonne Waith and her daughter, who work next door at a beauty parlor, said the activists' efforts were misplaced. ``What about the guns? Never mind the hats,'' Mrs. Waith said. ``There are much more important battles than this.'' The inner-city battle against gang- and drug-related crime has been fierce. Residents say they want to reclaim the turf lost to gun-toting adolescents _ not cater to them by producing ``status'' merchandise. Grass-roots organizer Ben Haith said the community reacted to the logo-inscribed caps ``strongly and with outrage'' because they go against so much of what parents, kids and local merchants have been working for. ``There are a lot of people in the community that have businesses and who feel the pains of the violence here,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Robber Bombs Bank During Getaway
DOC.TEXT: A would-be robber dressed as a woman detonated two bombs at a bank before fleeing on foot and littering the street with money as he tried to escape, the FBI said. Police bomb experts said it was a miracle no one was injured in the Wednesday morning blast. Lloyd Walter Dickerson, 36, was arrested several blocks away by a police officer, who said the man smelled of smoke and had powder burns on his hands. He was charged with bank robbery and was being held pending a court appearance today before a federal magistrate, said Jim Dearborn, an FBI spokesman. The federal bank robbery charge carries a maximum penalty of 25 years in prison, Dearborn said. Police said Dickerson demanded money from a teller, and set off a smoke bomb after the bank employee apparently hesitated. After the smoke bomb went off, bank officials gave an undisclosed amount of money to Dickerson, who then detonated a fragmentation bomb made of match heads stuffed inside a small fire extinguisher, police said. The second bomb sent pieces of metal flying for a half-block and broke windows, damaged an automatic teller machine and a parked car at the Maryland National Bank branch. The robber was chased for several blocks by two men. Dickerson littered the street with $10 and $20 bills and dropped a bag containing four more bombs while fleeing, police said. ``I heard an explosion and a man came running down the street. Somebody said he robbed the bank so I chased him through the alleyway,'' said Jim Phillips. ``He stopped in front of a car and took off some of his clothes and a wig and sunglasses he had on.'' The two eventually lost sight of the robber. A police officer several blocks away spotted Dickerson, who matched a description of the robber.

DOC.BYLINE: Actor Fights Mother's Claim He's Incompetent ^By LINDA DEUTSCH
DOC.TEXT: A judge said she wants more information before deciding whether to hear a petition from the mother of Gary Coleman claiming that the diminutive actor is incompetent to handle his financial affairs. Edmonia Sue Coleman, of Zion, Ill., filed a conservatorship petition in Superior Court on Dec. 4 contending that her 21-year-old son's deteriorating physical and mental condition puts him at ``significant risk of financial exploitation.'' Coleman's lawyer, Charles Wake, denied the allegations Wednesday, filing papers saying that the actor is in good health and mentally competent to handle his own business affairs. He alleged that Mrs. Coleman is merely trying to wrest control of her son's fortune. Superior Court Judge Martha Goldin appointed attorney Arne Lindgren to represent Coleman temporarily and determine whether his own lawyers have a conflict of interest. She also told Lindgren to interview Coleman and his doctors and submit a report on the actor's health. Coleman was born with an atrophied right kidney and has undergone two transplants during a childhood requiring frequent dialysis treatments and use of various prescribed drugs, the court documents said. The 4-foot-5-inch actor, who gained fame in the TV series ``Diff'rent Strokes,'' appeared cheerful and alert in court and told reporters he hoped for a resolution of the case soon. Mrs. Coleman, absent from the hearing, has asked that a conservator be appointed for her son and that her bank, U.S. Trust Co. of California, be placed in control of assets that include $46 million in property and an annual income of $750,000. ``It appears that the prolonged use of (prescribed) drugs, fluid exchanges, machine dependency and failure to follow the medically recommended diet and regimen has had a cumulative, debilitating effect on Gary,'' her petition said. She claimed her son was puffy-faced and disoriented ``and unable to understand or respond to simple questions.'' In response, Wake said the actor follows a regular dialysis program and ``is in good health, is competent and is able to manage his personal, professional and business affairs.'' ``Edmonia Sue Coleman's petition is no more than an attempt by Mrs. Coleman to wrest control of Gary Coleman's personal and financial affairs away from him as a defense tactic in connection with a civil lawsuit'' by Coleman against his parents, Wake maintained. In that lawsuit, Coleman alleges that his parents and a former business adviser, Anita De Thomas, mismanaged his funds and misappropriated assets for their own benefit. The judge postponed proceedings to Jan. 31 over objections by Wake, who said Coleman's career is suffering from publicity about his mother's allegations.

DOC.HEAD: Alaska Volcano Rests After Blowup
DOC.TEXT: Redoubt Volcano slipped into slumber after gushing ash and steam eight miles high, but air traffic remained disrupted because of concerns about engine-clogging fallout. ``Seismically, the volcano is fairly quiet right now,'' geologist Robert McGimsey of the Alaska Volcano Observatory said Wednesday afternoon. ``We have no reports of eruptions.'' Scientists said it was too early to predict what the reduced seismic activity might mean. They said they would not be surprised if seismic energy rebuilds again at the mountain 115 miles southwest of Anchorage. The Alaska Volcano Observatory recorded the last explosive eruption at 2:44 a.m. Wednesday. The volcano's first violent eruption in days came at 5:48 p.m. Tuesday. It was the largest since Redoubt thundered awake in mid-December after a 25-year sleep. Pilots on Tuesday reported a plume of ash and steam to 40,000 feet and what appeared to be lava flowing down the volcano's northwest flank, observatory scientists said. The Federal Aviation Administration said there were no pilots' reports of ash on Wednesday, and the Alaska Division of Emergency Services reported no significant ash accumulations on the ground. Nevertheless, Delta and United airlines canceled flights until at least today and international airlines, some of which use Anchorage as a refueling stop, diverted planes to other airports. Alaska Airlines said it offered all but two of its scheduled flights. MarkAir, an intrastate carrier, resumed daylight flying Wednesday after a three-hour delay. The failure of all four engines on a KLM Royal Dutch Airlines passenger jet last month was blamed on ash from Redoubt. The plane made a safe emergency landing in Anchorage after the engines were restarted. Scientists tried to check on the reported lava flow Wednesday, but clouds frustrated an attempted aerial observation. ``They didn't get any kind of visual on the volcano at all,'' McGimsey said. ``It was a real disappointing flight.'' The observers found at least one large mudflow was generated by the eruption Tuesday. Mud filled the 1\-mile-wide flood plain of the Drift River and extended about 20 miles, the Volcano Observatory said in a news release. Boulders up to about 13 feet in diameter were observed. Some flooding was evident at the Drift River oil storage facility 20 miles from the volcano, the observatory said. Water flowed around a levee but did not penetrate dikes protecting individual tanks. Flood waters also crossed an airstrip. Cook Inlet Pipe Line Co., operator of the Drift River facility, on Tuesday evacuated the 11 people who were there. The company said weather and ash on Wednesday prevented it from determining when operations might resume. Power at the facility was interrupted, the company said. After a quarter century of silence, the peak erupted Dec. 13 and spewed ash 33,000 feet into the air the next day. Varying levels of seismic activity continued through the month.

DOC.HEAD: What's Next _ A Musical Assault on Congress? ^An AP News Analysis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf of b0221, which moved Jan. 3, to UPDATE with Noriega developments
DOC.TEXT: So the ordinary, everyday, ear-splitting boom box has been made into a weapon of war, and there's no knowing where that may lead. Those radio-cassette players with stereo speakers are menace enough in peacetime, clearing streets and public parks as platoons of youthful rock fanciers blare their music at migraine volume. And that was before Panama, where the United States decided to go after Manuel Antonio Noriega, no decibels barred. He could run to the Vatican embassy, but he couldn't hide; not when U.S. soldiers brought in the stereo speakers, set them up in a parking lot across the street, turned up the volume and tuned in armed forces radio rock. There went the neighborhood. Troops and everybody else in the area had to converse in shouts as numbers like ``You're No Good,'' ``Voodoo Chile,'' ``Welcome to the Jungle,'' and ``Nowhere to Run, Nowhere to Hide'' boomed day and night from olive drab, government-issue speakers. Noriega, who surrendered Wednesday night and was put on a plane to the United States, fancies opera, making a high decibel diet of rock plus country and western numbers seem a sort of musical torture. But the noise spared no one, and the Roman Catholic diplomats stationed at the embassy presumably were more comfortable with plainsong than disco music. ``Baby, You're No Good,'' the speakers blared. And ``I Fought the Law and the Law Won.'' After a day and a half, a Vatican spokesman said the musical assault was unacceptable. Another day of it and word came from the mission that the din was keeping diplomats and clerics awake while Noriega slept and the Vatican was contemplating unspecified ``further steps'' if it continued. The rock barrage was turned down last Friday. ``I think it aggravated the people inside,'' President Bush said Saturday. ``It has stopped. It would have aggravated me, I'll tell you. I'm not into rock. Country music, maybe that's different.'' Not at that volume. The military didn't explain the rock tactic; Bush's spokesman said it was a communications technique. ``There was an attempt to disrupt communications so that we could have some guarantees of the security of our conversations,'' said press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. ``Fairly standard practice.'' He said music was played to disrupt microwaves and interfere with electronic eavesdropping when White House staff members conferred at the U.S. Embassy in Moscow during President Reagan's 1988 summit meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Not around the clock, though. Who was eavesdropping in Panama City? ``I'd let your imagination deal with that one,'' Fitzwater said, sidestepping the question of whether the racket was supposed to prevent reporters with electronic gear from tuning in on military conversations and street corner talks with the papal envoy. When the Pope's man in Panama City can come under rock music assault, nobody's safe. Arms negotiations stalled? Let them hear about it. Turn up ``Big Planet, Scary Planet.'' In a while, if there's still no deal, escalate to ``Armageddon It.'' Bush has been telling people to read his lips for so long that it's become trite; next time Congress talks about raising taxes he can break out the boom box and let it shout. ``Can U Read My Lips?'' and ``I Won't Back Down.'' Vice presidential problems? Get Dan Quayle a stereo and let him advertise: ``Giving You the Best That I've Got.'' Bush has already assured his No. 2 man of renomination. Now, when necessary, he can play ``It's You Again,'' loudly enough to drown out the doubters. ``My Prerogative,'' the presidential boom box can blare.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: Health Officials Launch Program To Reduce Number Of Underweight Newborns
DOC.TEXT: Health officials hope to reduce the state's high rate of underweight newborns with a program that extends prenatal care to expectant mothers outside the health care mainstream. The program, Better Beginnings, will furnish medical care, financial assistance, nutrition counseling, follow-up counselors to encourage pregnant women to see doctors regularly, and a combination outreach-education effort to increase public awareness, officials said. It will ``give these babies ... at least a fighting chance at starting out healthy,'' John Fairman, the head of the Denver Department of Health and Hospitals, said Wednesday. A recent study showed only the District of Columbia and six southern states had higher rates of newborn babies weighing less than 5{ pounds than Colorado. The program will be coordinated through Denver General Hospital, where the rate of low birth-weight babies, 12.3 percent, is nearly twice the national average of 6.8 percent, officials said. The problem is most severe among newborn babies whose mothers either received no prenatal care, or who first saw a doctor late in their pregnancies. Denver General officials said 22 percent of the deliveries at the hospital are to women in those categories. Such babies are at much higher risk of incurring serious health problems requiring extended hospitalization at birth, have a higher chance for lifelong physical handicaps, and have a higher death rate. ``We still have many pregnant women whose first contact with a physician is on the day they show up at a delivery room,'' said Terri Bailey, director of the Perinatal Project at Denver General. ``A lack of prenatal care correlates strongly with babies who are born too early, or born weighing less than 5.5 pounds. Such babies are 40 times more likely to die during their first year, or to experience serious long-term physician and developmental problems.'' In 1988, Denver General delivered 183 babies to women who had not been seen by a doctor during their pregnancies. Better Beginnings will attempt to contact expectant mothers who normally would not seek out prenatal care and put them in touch with doctors at Denver-area clinics. Brochures printed in Spanish and English will be circulated. Counselors also will provide health advice to the mothers. Fairman said a large part of the problem is just getting the word out about routine prenatal care. ``This problem is not unlike the issue of seat belts. We know seat belts save lives,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Exile Plans Conservative Party in Czechoslovakia
DOC.TEXT: A Czech who has spent the past decade in exile is launching a conservative party to contest Czechoslovakia's first post-communist election on a platform of scrapping military ties with Moscow in favor of neutrality or alliance with the West. ``The Warsaw Pact ... has no place in our future. We feel that the question of active neutrality or adherence to Western collective security must be decided by a nationwide referendum after the free elections'' promised for June, said Dr. Jiri Kotas. The economic program of his Party of Constitutional Democracy will be all-out conservative, stressing ``gradual but vigorous'' privatization of the state-managed economy and ``the most favorable conditions for Western capital investment,'' Kotas, 37, said in remarks prepared for appearances Thursday in Washington. A critic of the communist regime who fled Czechoslovakia in 1979, Kotas has been living in Ottawa, Canada. He said he plans to return to Prague Jan. 13 to organize the new party, bringing together conservatives in the homeland with those in exile. An early move will be to propose that the Federal Assembly order redistribution among all parties of part of the money amassed by the Communist Party in ``decades of misrule,'' Kotas said. Campaign financing will be crucial to fair elections, he said, along with equal radio and television time. Election observers from ``classically democratic countries'' should be invited, Kotas said. Their presence might be a technical infringement of sovereignty but it is justified ``after 40 years of dictatorship,'' Kotas said. Czechoslovakia managed to break free of communist rule peacefully in late November because at the crucial moment the Kremlin messaged the faltering leadership that it would not help them, Kotas said, triggering resignation of the entire politburo. He termed the current coalition transition government, led by anti-communist ex-dissident President Vaclav Havel and Communist Prime Minister Marian Calfa, his homeland's best government since the 1948 communist takeover and ``the best possible at the moment.'' Kotas said he opted for all-out conservativism feeling that the best antidote to communist misrule ``was to completely embrace its absolute opposite _ to adopt the Western concept of freedom, both political and economic.'' He credited the Heritage Foundation and similar conservative groups as playing a major role ``in my intellectual and political maturing.'' Some Czechoslovak experts question how far the country will abandon socialist economics. Pre-communist Presidents Tomas G. Masaryk and Eduard Benes were Social Democrats, they recalled. Ohio State University history and journalism professor Jiri Hochman said in his opinion the Czechoslovaks ``want democracy but at the same time don't want to give up social security or job security.'' Hochman noted that Havel has upheld full employment, social security and national health service in terms similar to those used by the communist reformer, Assembly Chairman Alexander Dubcek.

DOC.HEAD: Mobile, Ala., Hires First Black Chief
DOC.TEXT: This city, where the last ship bringing slaves landed 131 years ago, will have its first black police chief. The City Council on Wednesday hired Harold L. Johnson Jr., police chief of Ecorse, Mich., and a 25-year veteran of the Detroit Police Department. Johnson, 48, will take over as chief Feb. 1. The City Council also named Charleston, S.C., Chief Reuben Greenberg, who is black, as public safety director, also starting Feb. 1. They face opposition in the department, which is 13 percent black. ``We don't know what to expect,'' said Lt. Sam Cochran, vice president of the Mobile County Law Enforcement Association. Cochran, who is white, said some officers were opposed to the high salaries for Johnson and Greenberg. He said race was not a factor in opposing the hirings. Johnson's salary is expected to be $65,000 or more. Greenberg received a six-month, $50,000 contract as public safety director and said he would return to Charleston afterward. Cochran said the opposition could be overcome with improved pay and benefits for the 357 uniformed officers. Beginning salary is about $14,000, with annual raises of 5 percent, but Cochran said some officers have been denied raises for the last few years because of budget problems. The seven-member council, which includes three blacks, unanimously approved hiring Greenberg. One councilman abstained on the Johnson vote, which was otherwise unanimously approved. Mobile's population of 200,000 is about 37 percent black. Arlene Williams, a spokeswoman for the National Organization of Black Law Enforcement Executives in Washington, D.C., said there are about 130 black chiefs in the country.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Foe Wounded By Bullets Sprayed Into Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: C.W. in 2nd graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: A community activist's house was sprayed with gunfire in the neighborhood where she has battled drug dealers for years. C.W. Roddy, 60, suffered a flesh wound in the stomach early Monday from the attack and was treated and released from the hospital. ``All of a sudden I heard the whole front open up with gunfire. It went through my walls, it went through my bedsprings, it went through my kitchen, it went through my furniture,'' said Roddy, who was watching television in her bedroom when the assault occurred. ``It makes me angry. It makes me so angry. I am so full of rage, I could kill.'' Residents of the drug-plagued neighborhood say the shooting is at least the third such attack on anti-drug neighbors. No arrests have been made and the motive for the New Year's Day shooting was unknown, East Palo Alto Police Cmdr. Frank Churchill said Wednesday. He called it ``only speculation'' that the attack was intended as a scare tactic against the anti-drug activist. But residents in the Westminster neighborhood, where the shooting occurred, believe retaliation is the motive behind the shooting. Roddy has spent years denouncing dealers who set up shop outside her home and has appeared at City Council meetings to demand action for an end to the drug traffic plaguing her neighborhood. She said she has been the target of dealers, particularly since last year, when they began to ``work in shifts, 24 hours a day, seven days a week'' along her block. Last fall, when she asked one dealer to move his truck away from her house, he punched her in the face, Roddy said. Several days before Christmas, her house was raked by gunfire, she said. In March 1988, after residents of the block next to Roddy's organized an anti-drug campaign, the window of one of their homes was hit by a single bullet during a meeting. A year later, residents said, a couple had bricks thrown through the window of their home on the next street. Churchill said police are unaware of any pattern of harassment against drug activists. ``On New Year's Eve,there were bullets sprayed into other homes and residences,'' Churchill said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished the first trading day of the year stronger against the Japanese yen, and its rise Thursday sent share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange moderately lower. After opening higher at 145.55 yen, the dollar closed the day of trading at 145.20 yen, 1.80 yen above its previous close of 143.40 yen on Friday. Financial markets were closed Monday through Wednesday for the holidays. The official Bank of Japan sold hundreds of millions of dollars in an attempt to drive down the value of the U.S. currency. Despite the initial intervention, the dollar rose to the day's high of 145.72 yen during the morning session. Repeated infusions of dollars by the central bank turned the currency around to a low of 144.90 yen shortly before the morning close. In the afternoon, the dollar recrossed the 145-yen line and then traded in a fairly narrow range. Mitsuhiko Kinugasa, a dealer at Daiwa Bank, said the central bank sold about $500 million during the morning session, and an equal amount in currency markets overseas during the previous two days. Kinugasa termed the intervention successful. ``The dollar was not as strong as it might have been.'' The central bank does not comment on its monetary policies. In a half-day session of trading on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, share prices fell on news of the dollar's strength. The leading market barometer finished the session down 202.99 points to 38,712.88, a drop of 0.52 percent on a first section volume of 400 million shares. The stock market's decline reversed four days of gains in the last few trading sessions of 1989, and stood in contrast to other major exchanges. Masahiro Umemori, of Nomura Securities' investment research division, said the market was discouraged by the dollar's rise. Umemori said, ``The Tokyo market went against the global current today, falling despite rises on the major markets overseas.'' A weak bond market also contributed to the slide, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Train Crew's Countersuit Dismissed
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has ruled an injured political protester was not legally responsible for traumatizing those who injured him. Crewmen of a Navy weapons train that ran over and maimed S. Brian Willson in 1987 cannot sue the activist and his fellow demonstrators for causing them emotional distress, U.S. District Judge Robert Peckham said in a pretrial ruling released Wednesday. ``I'm sure it's a great relief to Brian Willson and his wife to no longer be facing claims that they're required to compensate the crew for emotional distress caused by running over them,'' said their chief lawyer, Thomas Steel. Peckham also threw out Willson's suit against the commander of the Concord Naval Weapons Station, saying the commander did not cause the incident. But the judge ruled evidence that the train was intended to scare demonstrators off the tracks may be enough to show a violation of their constitutional rights. Trial is scheduled April 24 in a suit by Willson, his wife, Holley Rauen, and three others against the government, the train crewmen and two supervisors at the naval station east of San Francisco. Willson lost his legs as a result of the incident. The crewmen's lawyer, William Kolin, did not return a telephone call Wednesday. Willson and others opposing U.S. arms shipments to Central America held a demonstration Sept. 1, 1987, at the Concord Naval Weapons Station, where they said the weapons shipments were originating. A train from the station hit him as he sat on the tracks, severing both legs at the knee. Others on the tracks were able to jump away, though one man had to leap onto the locomotive. The suit contends the Navy and individual supervisors were given ample warning of the plan to stay on the tracks, and that the crew had plenty of time to stop. The three civilian crewmen _ engineer David Humiston, conductor Ralph Dawson and brakeman Robert Mayfield _ denied wrongdoing and said in their countersuit that the demonstrators had acted, deliberately or recklessly, to cause the crew emotional distress. Peckham ruled that the demonstrators did not violate the crewmen's rights _ even if, as the crew argued, Willson and his colleagues were prepared to risk being run over by the train to advance their political views. ``The munitions train could have stopped short of the protesters and the ensuing mutilation of Mr. Willson and emotional distress of the crew members (would have been) avoided,'' Peckham said. He said a reasonable jury could not conclude that the protesters' acts made it ``inevitable that the train would run them over.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Precede PANAMA CITY, Panama
Noriega Turns Self Over to U.S., Panama Erupts in Celebration
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Noriega's reported arrival in United States.
DOC.TEXT: Manuel Antonio Noriega, the former Panamanian strongman who defied two U.S. presidents until he was toppled by a Dec. 20 invasion, reportedly arrived in the United States Thursday morning to face drug charges. The ousted dictator surrendered to U.S. troops outside his Vatican Embassy sanctuary Thursday night and was flown to Homestead Air Force Base, about 25 miles south of Miami early Thursday. Sen. Connie Mack, R-Fla., told WTVJ-TV in Miami that the plane was on the ground.
DOC.HEAD: Word of, 2nd graf pvs.
Key Events During Noriega's Rule, Downfall
With PM-Noriega, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Key events related to Gen. Manuel Noriega's rule of Panama and his downfall after the U.S. invasion:
Armed forces chief Gen. Omar Torrijos, Noriega's mentor, dies in plane crash.

March _ Three of Torrijos' colonels, Manuel Antonio Noriega, Ruben Dario Paredes and Roberto Diaz Herrera, cut a deal to resolve power struggle. Paredes takes over as armed forces chief and agrees to retire in August 1983, leaving Noriega to take over, with Diaz Herrara as second-in-command. Noriega promises to deliver 1984 presidential election to Paredes.

August _ Noriega takes over as commander of the armed forces. The Panamanian legislature passes a law creating the Panamanian Defense Forces with control over National Guard, other Panamanian military and police forces, canal matters and functions such as immigration control and regulation of civilian aircraft. Noriega reneges on Paredes deal and installs his own president in 1984 election.

June _ Diaz Herrera, retiring as second-in-command, accuses Noriega of drug-related activities, rigging 1984 election and murdering Dr. Hugo Spadafora, former vice minister of health who accused Noriega of drug trafficking. June 9 _ Protest movement demands investigation into Diaz Herrera's allegations and return to democracy. Street protests are brutally crushed.

Feb. 4 _ Federal grand jury in Miami indicts Noriega on drug-running charges. Grand jury in Tampa returns similar indictments. Feb. 25 _ President Eric Delvalle, who was put in place by Noriega, announces he has fired his patron. Feb. 26 _ Noriega-dominated National Assembly ousts Delvalle, who goes into hiding. Washington continues to recognize him as head of state. Education Minister Manuel Solis Palma named minister in charge of presidency. Noriega opponents call general strike. Government closes opposition news media. March 3 _ U.S. courts block withdrawal of Panama funds from U.S. banks. March 11 _ President Reagan imposes sanctions, including eliminating trade preferences for Panama and withholding Panama Canal fees. March 14 _ Public employees riot after government is unable to pay wages. March 16 _ Coup organized by Defense Forces officers against Noriega fails. Demonstrations erupt in capital and power outage blacks out nation. March 28 _ Troops disperse thousands of anti-government marchers and storm Marriott Hotel, beating and arresting opposition activists and journalists. Several are injured and dozens arrested in one of biggest protests in months. April 9 _ United States announces economic sanctions prohibiting American companies and government from making payments to Panamanian government. Some $56 million in Panamanian funds in American banks are frozen. United States tries to negotiate Noriega's departure without success. May 9 _ Banks reopen but with severe restrictions, including a freeze on savings accounts. Aug. 21 _ U.S. accuses Panamanian authorities of 240 incidents of harassment of American military personnel in 1988.

May 7-9 _ Presidential election pits Noriega candidate against opposition candidate Guillermo Endara. Noriega's victory claim countered by rioters as well as international observers who say ballots were rigged. Former President Carter, a U.S. observer, denounces Noriega for stealing election. White House says independent exit polling showed Noriega's slate losing by a 3-1 margin. May 10 _ Government nullifies election before final results released, citing fraud and international interference. Endara and his two running mates beaten and a bodyguard killed by civilian thugs as defense forces look on. Police break up opposition demonstration with gunfire and tear gas. May 11 _ President Bush orders 2,000 more U.S. troops to Panama, joining 10,000 already there. Sept. 1 _ Provisional President Francisco Rodriguez takes office, but Noriega remains de facto leader. Oct. 3 _ Attempted U.S.-backed coup against Noriega fails. Dec. 15 _ Noriega says Panama is in a ``state of war'' with the United States and his rubber-stamp legislature appoints him chief executive officer of the government to respond. Dec. 16 _ Panamanian soldiers kill a U.S. Marine lieutenant, saying he and three others drove a car past checkpoints, then fired at Noriega's military headquarters building, wounding two civilians and a soldier. The United States says the four were unarmed, in civilian clothes, and got lost near the headquarters. Dec. 18 _ A U.S. Army officer wounds a Panamanian police corporal because he thought the man was about to draw a weapon, according to Southern Command. Dec. 19 _ Bush orders U.S. troops into combat in Panama City on a mission to seize Noriega to face federal drug charges in the United States. The White House says the mission also is intended to protect American lives, restore democracy and preserve the integrity of the Panama Canal. Dec. 20 _ Hours after American forces arrive, the United States says it has smashed Noriega's forces. Noriega broadcasts from hiding that ``We are in trench warfare now and we will maintain the resistance. ... We ask the world for help, with men, dignity and strength. ... Our slogan is to win or die _ not one step back.'' Dec. 21 _ Bush says U.S. forces would scour Panama for ``as long as it takes'' to capture Noriega. Dec. 24 _ Noriega seeks refuge at the Vatican Embassy. The Bush administration still demands he be turned over to face the drug charges and intense negotiations involving the Vatican, U.S. government and new Panamanian government ensue.
Jan. 3 _ Noriega leaves the Vatican Embassy and surrenders to U.S. authorities to face the drug-trafficking charges. Jan. 4 _ Plane carrying Noriega arrives in Florida.

DOC.HEAD: Jump in Wages Subject to Tax is Higher Than First Expected
DOC.TEXT: Some employers are confused about how much Social Security tax they are supposed to withhold this year because of a late change made by Congress. The Social Security Administration announced in October that, consistent with the law at that time, earnings up to $50,400 would be subject to the payroll tax in 1990. In November, however, Congress increased the figure to $51,300 as part of a deficit-reduction bill. Steve Pyrek, a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service, said the annual tax guide sent to employers late last year said the ``wage base'' would be $50,400. A notice that the figure has been increased to $51,300 will go out in a mailing later this month listing tax law changes, he said. Earnings above the wage base are exempt from Social Security taxes. ``There's been confusion because people are getting publications ... and various IRS documents that have what was correct information that's now incorrect,'' Pyrek said. Social Security Administration spokesman Frank Battistelli said his agency plans a special mailing this month to 400 business and trade groups publicizing the change in the 1990 figure. The wage base has gone up every year since 1971, with the latest increase affecting about 10.4 million workers and self-employed individuals who have annual earnings over last year's maximum of $48,000.
DOC.HEAD: D'Amato Senate's Top Mail Man, Posting 16.6 Million Pieces in Six
DOC.TEXT: Months

Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., sent 16.6 million pieces of mail during a six-month period last at a cost of $2.66 million, according to a recent report by the secretary of the Senate. That was more than any other senator. However, an earlier report shows D'Amato sent only 3,000 pieces in the six previous months. The flurry between April 1 and Sept. 30 came as questions were raised about D'Amato's influence at the Department of Housing and Urban Development, and as Congress was debating limits on constituent mail. The House ethics committee has announced a preliminary investigation of D'Amato's housing-related actions. Frank Coleman, a spokesman for D'Amato, said Wednesday that the senator historically has done the majority of his constituent mailing at the end of the legislative session.
DOC.HEAD: Christmas Lights Recalled
DOC.TEXT: More than a million decorative Christmas light sets that may be a shock or electrocution hazard are being recalled. The Consumer Product Safety Commission said Wednesday that the miniature ``string-to-string'' Christmas lights, manufactured by Taiwan-based Toyo Industrial, were sold nationwide in sets of 35, 50, 70 and 100 lights at several retail stores including Big Lot, Eckerd, K mart, Odd Lot, Revco and Walmart. The lights are imprinted ``TOYO'' or ``TP-6'' on the end of the female connector that has internal metal contacts that can be pushed or pulled out when plugging or unplugging the light strings, the commission said. ``Any exposed contact in the connector could present a shock or electrocution hazard to consumers,'' the agency said in a written statement. The commission warned consumers to unplug all Christmas light sets from the wall before they are removed from trees or other areas to prevent possible shock hazards. Consumers who want to return the lights should call Toyo at 800-545-8330 from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. PST.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Confronts Legal Thicket in Noriega Prosecution
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Adds editors note at bottom
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, declaring a complete victory in Panama now that Manuel Antonio Noriega has surrendered to face U.S. drug charges, now confronts a legal and political thicket. Noriega, formerly associated with the CIA, might seek to use classified government materials in his defense against drug-trafficking charges in Florida. That seemed far from the president's mind as he hastened into the White House press briefing room Wednesday night to declare victory and tell reporters that the deposed Panamanian dictator was finally in U.S. custody. Bush, admittedly frustrated over months of inability to remove Noriega from Panama, called the surrender ``a significant milestone'' showing the success of the U.S. military invasion that put Noriega on the run and forced him into the sanctuary arms of the Roman Catholic Church. Now looms Noriega's trial on drug-trafficking charges and the possibility that his defense will seek to introduce classified documents from his years of working with U.S. intelligence officials. Such material could be particularly sensitive regarding the period in 1976 when Bush was director of the CIA and Noriega was cooperating with the agency as an informant. In addition, Bush was vice president during the early 1980s while Noriega was still in the good graces of the U.S. government. A defense bid to use classified material the administration may want kept secret could mirror the strategy used by Oliver North and others in the Iran-Contra affair. Some Iran-Contra charges were dropped, but Justice Department officials have said they do not expect any secrecy problems to scuttle the charges that Noriega received $10 million for protecting drug-trafficking operations. Bush said last week he did not fear Noriega might disclose any CIA information that could embarrass him or the government. ``I think that's history, and I think that ... the main thing is that he should be tried and brought to justice. And we are pursuing that course with no fear of that,'' the president said. Prosecutors anticipate that Noriega will claim that his alleged drug activities were sanctioned by the U.S. government because he was a CIA informant. But the government is expected to argue that having been an informant does not make Noriega immune from prosecution. Bush and his aides insist Noriega will get a fair trial. In fact, one of the conditions under which Noriega agreed to surrender, White House officials said, was a fair trial that would not lead to the death penalty, which is allowed for some drug kingpins. Noriega's surrender came at the end of a day when Bush kept a low profile, making few public appearances as rumors of a possible surrender flew and tension mounted around the White House. It wasn't until he returned from playing racquetball at 6:30 p.m. EST that Bush learned his nemesis had agreed to leave the Vatican's Panama City embassy and surrender, aides said. Word came from Defense Secretary Dick Cheney at about 9 p.m. that Noriega was in U.S. military custody. Bush drafted a statement and rushed to the briefing room to deliver the news less than an hour later. It was a moment he has long wanted to savor. Bush inherited the Noriega problem from President Reagan, whose administration turned against Noriega following years of nurturing the U.S. relationship with him because of his value as an intelligence source. Bush continued Reagan's economic sanctions against Panama and urged the Panamanian people to rise up and throw him out. Yet when a group of Panamanian Defense Forces officers mounted a coup attempt against Noriega in October, the United States did not provide backup help that might have helped them succeed _ a lapse for which Bush was widely criticized. Perhaps still smarting from that missed opportunity, he sent in the military on Dec. 20, driving Noriega into hiding and eventually to the Vatican Embassy in Panama City. The Bush penchant for secrecy came into play in negotiations to get Noriega out of the Vatican sanctuary. His aides denied that a team led by Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger to Panama on Tuesday was involved in negotiations for Noriega's release. Instead, they said the group was focusing on economic relief for the invasion-ravaged nation. However, at day's end, Gen. Maxwell Thurman, commander of the U.S. Southern Command, said in Panama City that the Eagleburger team was instrumental in arranging Noriega's surrender.
EDITORS NOTE: Rita Beamish covers the White House for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Casino Backers Begin Six-City Promotional Tour
DOC.TEXT: Backers of a proposal to allow casino gambling in Ohio have begun a six-city promotional tour intended to muster public support for the creation of special gambling resort districts. The tour kicked off Wednesday in Lorain, where promoter Alan Spitzer wants to build a $400 million casino, a pilot project he says could create 3,500 to 4,000 jobs at the resort, and 5,000 to 6,000 spin-off jobs related to the complex in northeast Ohio. In Toledo Wednesday afternoon, the promoters said the proposed resort districts could create thousands of new jobs and attract tourists from all over the Midwest. ``There has been a tremendous amount of support across the state,'' Spitzer said at a news conference in Toledo. Toledo Mayor John McHugh said Wednesday that while he opposes gambling, some people have suggested that a casino complex could revitalize the city's ailing riverfront district. ``I want to look at the proposal, how it's going to be set up,'' the mayor said. ``You always hear when you have gambling or a casino that there's always crime and corruption and the Mafia. Certainly, I don't want to see that in Toledo.'' Spitzer, a prime backer of the Lorain proposal, said his group known as LUV Ohio Committee _ LUV stands for Let Us Vote _ has enough signatures on petitions to give voters the chance to vote on the issue. The tour was geared toward cities that also would be allowed to conduct local option votes on casinos if voters support the referendum, which would amend a section of the state constitution that prohibits casino gambling. Spitzer also planned stops in Cincinnati and Dayton today, and Steubenville and Youngstown on Friday. The group plans to travel to Columbus next Tuesday to submit petitions to the secretary of state, who will determine whether there are enough valid signatures to allow a referendum on the casino issue. The committee needs 306,661 signatures of registered voters; Spitzer says it has more than 500,000. The amendment would establish a pilot casino project in Lorain that would run for five years, said Anthony Giardini, a lawyer and secretary of the committee. After three years, the Legislature could review the Lorain project and authorize similar resort projects in seven areas of Ohio. In a resort district, only one hotel would be allowed, and developers would have to bid for the project, Giardini said. No state or federal money could be used to help a developer build a casino, and no tax abatments would be given. In addition, 10 percent of a casino's gross revenues would be taxed. Of that, 2 percent would help rebuild inner-city neighborhoods.

DOC.HEAD: Sixteen Stations Simulcast Anti-Drug Program
DOC.TEXT: Sixteen radio stations simultaneously broadcast an anti-drug program, but some listeners were more concerned afterward with football playoff tickets. Station officials said it's too soon to tell whether the broadcast during the morning drive time Wednesday will do any good in the city's drug war. At WERE, a news-talk show format station, dozens of callers phoned in shortly after the three-hour program Wednesday to discuss its message, said David Slutzky, executive producer at the station. ``We're not going to solve the whole (drug) problem with one radio broadcast,'' Slutzky said. ``At the same time, it instills awareness.'' But at WWWE, which also has a news-talk show format, concern focused on whether enough tickets would be sold in time to lift a local television blackout of the Cleveland Browns football playoff game against the Buffalo Bills Saturday. ``We actually got more calls about the Browns ticket sales,'' said Kevin Kenney, a reporter at the station. The Radio for a Drug Free Cleveland effort had 16 of the city's 19 major radio stations broadcasting from 6 a.m. to 9 a.m. a program produced earlier that featured interviews with law enforcement officials, medical professionals, performers and athletes on drug-related topics. Among those who taped their descriptions of their own past drug problems were singers Larry Gatlin of the Gatlin Brothers and Stevie Ray Vaughn. The show also featured an audio tape of a Cleveland drug bust, and interviews with a jailed drug dealer and a woman who worked as a prostitute to support her drug habit. The host of the show was John Walsh, who also is host of the ``America's Most Wanted'' television show. Police records for 1989 show 46 of the city's 152 homicides were drug-related.

DOC.HEAD: Panamanian Exiles in Florida Overjoyed With Noriega Surrender
With PM-Noriega, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Panamanian exiles in south Florida greeted the surrender of Manuel Antonio Noriega to U.S. authorities with jubilation. ``It's like a big relief off our shoulders to know that Noriega will come to justice,'' said Beverly Oztolaza, president of the Panamanian Club of Tampa Bay. ``I tell you, it's something that we've all been praying for.'' Panamanian natives also expressed hope late Wednesday that their country's move toward a democracy will be helped by the former dictator's decision to voluntarily leave his sanctuary at the Vatican Embassy in Panama City to face federal drug trafficking charges in Miami and Tampa. ``There's no word to say how happy I am,'' said Irma Endara, whose husband Luis is a cousin of Panama's new president, Guillermo Endara. ``It means that we're going to be free and there's going to be democracy in Panama _ and we're going to have Panama back again.'' Aurelio Barria, a leader of the opposition to Noriega who was preparing to end his exile in Miami and return home, said friends in Panama City told him of of the effect Noriega's surrender had on his country: ``My friends today told me `What a feeling!' to walk out, to feel free, to speak out. That's what it's all about. This is democracy. This is freedom. This is justice.'' Julio Dominguez, 47, left his native Panama 18 years ago after twice being arrested by agents of Noriega, who then served as head of the country's military intelligence. Dominguez echoed his compatriots' excitement. ``Everybody's happy to have the cancer removed from our country,'' said Dominguez, whose brother Roberto was recently renamed Panama's consul in Miami. There also was a note of victory in the words of Adela Giroldi, widow of the leader of a failed Panamanian coup attempt against Noriega last October. Her husband, Col. Moises Giroldi, was killed _ reportedly by Noriega _ in the attempt. ``His death was not in vain,'' Mrs. Giroldi said, ``and the effort that President Bush made with the invasion of Panama was also not in vain.''

DOC.HEAD: Cold Rain Falls Across Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Much of the Midwest, where temperatures warmed to above freezing, was drenched in a cold rain early today, while the northern Plains registered temperatures in the teens. Rain fell in Chattanooga, Cincinnati, Detroit, Chicago, Indianapolis, Kansas City and Nashville. Des Moines had snow. Western sections of the nation were seasonably cold early today. Reno, Nev., and Las Vegas had temperatures below freezing, and temperatures were in the 30s and 40s along the Pacific Coast from San Francisco to Seattle. Late Wednesday, snow fell in parts of eastern Colorado and western Kansas, and rain fell in parts of Oklahoma, Kansas and Missouri. Snowfall totals in Colorado late Wednesday included 5 inches at Rye and Beulah. Thunderstorms produced large hail in north-central Oklahoma on Wednesday night. Quarter-size hail was reported in Nash, and dime-size hail fell south of Manchester. Also Wednesday, rain extended across much of Kansas, Missouri, the lower Mississippi Valley, eastern Texas, Alabama, northwest Florida and western Washington state. Snow fell over some of the higher elevations in eastern Washington. Temperatures warmed into the 30s and lower 40s in the Great Lakes region. The afternoon high of 39 degrees at Marquette, Mich., broke their previous record high for the date of 37 degrees established in 1964 and tied in 1984. The nation's high on Wednesday was 84 degrees at Kingsville, Texas. DOC.HEAD: Computer Chip Fails on Venus-Bound Magellan Spacecraft
DOC.TEXT: The Magellan spacecraft, speeding toward cloud-shrouded Venus on a $550 million mapping expedition, will need frequent commands from Earth until NASA fixes a computer problem. Despite the failure of a computer chip on the spaceship, ``there's no threat to the mission,'' said Edwin Sherry, a technical assistant at the space agency's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. Until engineers locate the faulty chip, they must send Magellan new commands every other day to make sure it is pointing in the proper direction, Sherry said Wednesday. He said a similar computer chip failure happened before Magellan was launched and that such a failure is expected about once annually. ``You'd hope for zero faults like this,'' Sherry said. ``But they're typical of working with state-of-the-art equipment. It's remarkable we have so few.'' Magellan was launched from space shuttle Atlantis on May 4. It will go into a polar orbit around Venus on Aug. 10. About 18 days later, it will start using its radar to peer through the planet's thick clouds, spending at least 243 days making maps that will reveal the landscape of at least 70 percent of the planet. Magellan was nearly 112 million miles from Earth and 107 million miles from Venus on Wednesday. Since its launch, it has traveled a curving path of 424 million miles, and still has 369 million miles to go before reaching the second planet from the sun, Sherry said. The problem developed Sunday as the spacecraft got ready to take a fix on two distant stars to make sure it was pointing the right way. An error was detected in a tiny part of Magellan's computer memory. The error prompted Magellan to shift to a backup computer and point its solar panels toward the sun to increase the power supply. The failure was apparently the result of electrical corrosion at a junction between two types of material on a single memory chip, leaving the chip unable to remember anything, Sherry said. He said, however, engineers haven't yet ruled out the possibility that the chip was damaged by an electrically charged particle spewed out by the sun, which is near the peak of its 11-year cycle of activity. Magellan uses gyroscopes to sense when pressure from solar wind makes the spacecraft drift slightly, or point in the wrong direction. The gyroscopes normally issue automatic commands to three spinning wheels, which correct the spacecraft's alignment. Magellan's main computer is programmed to take a fix on the two stars each day to determine the spacecraft's actual alignment. If this ``star calibration'' shows the gyroscopes failed to align Magellan correctly, they again command the wheels to adjust the craft's position. Magellan continued to operate on its backup computer. Once the faulty chip is located _ scientists hope within a few days _ a new computer program will be sent to the spacecraft so the main computer can be used while the faulty chip is bypassed, Sherry said. Engineers working on the problem are at Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena and Martin Marietta in Denver. The company built Magellan and is responsible for its daily operations under National Aeronautics and Space Administration supervision.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up Sharply Against Yen
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose sharply against the yen despite central bank intervention today, the first day of 1990 trading in Tokyo, and the stock market's main index declined moderately from its latest record high. The dollar closed at 145.20 yen, up 1.80 yen from its finish of 143.40 on Friday, the last trading day before Japan's New Year holiday. The dollar had climbed 1.25 yen on Friday. It opened today at 145.55 yen and ranged between 144.90 yen and 145.72 yen. Mitsuhiko Kinugasa, a dealer at Daiwa Bank, said the central bank sold about $500 million in the morning session, after selling an equal amount in currency markets overseas on the previous two days, to check the dollar's rise. Because of the Bank of Japan intervention, ``the dollar was not as strong as it might have been,'' he said. Another dealer, speaking on condition of anonymity, estimated the central bank's total dollar sales today at $600 million to $700 million. This was ``not as much as expected,'' he said, but added that concentrated selling in the morning had the intended effect. The central bank does not comment on its money market activities. Masafumi Koyama, chief customer dealer at the Bank of Tokyo, said New York dealers sold dollars on the Tokyo market in the morning to ``square their positions,'' helping to push the dollar down from its opening level. Koyama said, however, ``It's getting harder and harder to break (below) the 145-yen line.'' In a half-day session of trading on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, share prices fell on news of the dollar's strength. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average, the market's key index, closed at 32,712.88 points, down 202.99 points, or 0.52 percent. The market had wound up 1989 trading with four consecutive days of record-high Nikkei closings. Masahiro Umemori of Nomura Securities' investment research division said the market was discouraged by the dollar's rise. ``The Tokyo market went against the global current today, falling despite rises on the major markets overseas,'' he said. A weak bond market contributed to the slide, Umemori said. Trading volume on the first section totaled 400 million shares.

DOC.HEAD: Party Atmosphere Outside Base As Scores Await Noriega's Arrival
DOC.NOTE: Eds: `Vilma' in 14th graf is cq.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Noriega, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Scores of Panamanian exiles and others converged outside this base in a spontaneous party early today with hopes of seeing fallen dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega in custody. While dozens of reporters, photographers and camera operators stood by waiting for Noriega to arrive from Panama City, the crowd banged pots and pans, waved Panamanian flags and chanted ``Down With Noriega'' and ``Pineapple Face.'' A C-130 carrying Noriega landed at the base at 2:45 a.m., and he was whisked away. None of the celebrants apparently saw him. Bernardo Matos, 27, was one of a group of people waving a Panamanian flag outside the gates of the base, about 25 miles south of Miami. He said he quickly made his way to Homestead once he heard late Wednesday that Noriega had surrendered to U.S. officials in Panama, ending a stay at the Vatican Embassy. ``I want to see Noriega in handcuffs,'' said Matos. ``That's the way he treated the people of Panama.'' U.S. Sen. Connie Mack also turned up to wait for Noriega's arrival. The Florida Republican was an observer at Panama's general elections last May 7. Those elections were later nullified by Noriega. ``My heart really goes out to the Panamanian people,'' Mack said. ``To have been there and to have seen the hope for a free and fair election stolen from them was a tragedy. The Panamanians are the real winners here.'' Anti-Castro Cuban-Americans also turned up, one holding a sign reading: ``Noriega today, Castro tomorrow?'' Damaris Dominguez, 25, left her native Panama three years ago. ``It means freedom. I just want to see,'' she said. ``I want to make sure (Noriega) gets a trial.'' She said Panamanians had expected last month's U.S. invasion to remove Noriega from power, but hadn't expected it to come so soon. ``We are celebrating,'' she said, adding the wait was no inconvenience. ``We are having kind of a party, so we don't mind.'' Vilma San Miguel, 40, who left Panama 1{ years ago to settle in Miami, was holding a spoon and pan, chanting. ``This is like a symbol of the opposition,'' she said. ``I hope (Noriega) hears me.''

DOC.HEAD: Text of Vatican Embassy Announcing Noriega Surrender
With PM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The following is the text of the Vatican Embassy's announcement that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega had surrendered to U.S. troops, as translated by The Associated Press: ``The apostolic nunciature in Panama communicates that Mr. General Manuel Antonio Noriega, ex-commander of the armed forces of Panama who on Dec. 24, 1989, sought refuge in the embassy residence after the U.S. military intervention and put an end to the confrontations between the armed forces and the U.S. troops, considered his situation serious and took the responsible decision to leave of his own will the residence of the pope's representative. ``He presented himself to the command of the North American forces that surrounded the diplomatic mission. ``Gen. Noriega therefore left the apostolic nunciature today, January 3, 1990, at around 8:50 p.m.''

DOC.HEAD: Studies Show Cancer Treatment Can Cause Leukemia
DOC.TEXT: Chemotherapy drugs that were used to treat ovarian cancer may have sharply increased the risk of leukemia, a study has found. Researchers found that among women treated between 1960 and 1985, the risk of leukemia was 12 times higher in those who received chemotherapy rather than surgery alone, according to the study published in today's New England Journal of Medicine. Although the study did not measure the benefits of treatment, chemotherapy drugs given during that time frequently failed to stop ovarian cancer. But doctors say that newer drugs now in use against this form of cancer are more effective, and their benefits probably outweigh their risks. The research, directed by Dr. John M. Kaldor of the International Agency for Research on Cancer in Lyon, France, was based on 114 women with leukemia who were among 99,113 survivors of ovarian cancer in seven European countries and Canada. Doctors have long known that the powerful medicines used to attack cancer may also cause the disease. The latest research demonstrates the magnitude of this risk. In a second study, the same researchers found that the risk of leukemia is also substantially increased in people given chemotherapy for Hodgkin's disease, another form of cancer. But since Hodgkin's disease is often curable with drugs, the benefits of treatment clearly outweigh the risks. In this work, the doctors reviewed 163 cases of leukemia among 29,552 Hodgkin's disease patients. They found that the risk of leukemia was nine times higher among those who got chemotherapy instead of radiation treatment. ``The risk in Hodgkin's disease is well worth it, because the treatment does extend life. In ovarian cancer, it's not necessarily worth it,'' commented Dr. Charles A. Coltman Jr. of the University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio. Several of the cancer drugs taken by the European women for ovarian cancer are no longer used. ``Management of ovarian cancer is moving ahead very rapidly,'' said Coltman. ``Some of the more recent studies suggest an impact on survival'' that outweighs the increased risk of leukemia.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Bars Punitive Damages in Flight 103 Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf to CORRECT that plane was en route from London to New York.
DOC.TEXT: Families of the victims of Pan Am Flight 103, which was blown up over Scotland a year ago, have no right to sue for millions of dollars in punitive damages, a judge has ruled. U.S. District Thomas C. Platt ruled Wednesday that the Warsaw Convention governing international flights bars such claims ``whether or not willful misconduct exists.'' More than 150 lawsuits, each seeking $5 million to $25 million in compensatory damages and $5 million to $25 million in punitive damages, have been filed in the crash. ``We're disappointed with the result, but this is not going to be the last word on the matter,'' said Steven Pounian, a lawyer for the victims. He said he would likely file an immediate appeal of the ruling by Platt. Under the terms of the Warsaw Convention, compensatory damages due survivors is generally limited to $75,000. In his ruling, Platt criticized the treaty's monetary limits, saying the limit ``adds insult to injury.'' James M. Shaughnessy, a lawyer for Pan American World Airways, said Platt was ``eminently correct with his ruling and we are very pleased with it.'' Lawyers for the victims' families had argued that even if punitive claims are generally barred, a provision of the treaty, Article 24, provides that when ``willful misconduct exists, the liability limits of the Warsaw Convention are inapplicable and thus ... punitive damage claims should be determined by referring to local law,'' according to court papers. In his 16-page ruling, Platt agreed with Pan Am lawyers' interpretation that ``Article 24 actually seems to be persuasive evidence that the Warsaw Convention intended to bar punitive damage claims.'' The Pan Am flight originated in Frankfurt, West Germany, and changed in London to a larger Boeing 747. The jetliner was en route from London to New York when it exploded over Lockerbie, Scotland, on Dec. 21, 1988, killing 259 passengers and crew members and 11 people on the ground.
