The lawsuits allege that Pan Am and its security service, Alert Management Systems Inc., did not adequately protect Flight 103 and its passengers from a terrorist bomb attack and were negligent in not alerting passengers to telephone threats against the airline. Investigators in Europe have found evidence linking a radical Palestinian faction to the bombing, government officials have said. According to news reports, investigators believe a bomb was hidden in a bag checked on a flight that originated in Malta and connected with the Pan Am jetliner in Frankfurt. The luggage was reportedly allowed on the plane even though it was apparently not checked in by any passenger aboard the plane.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against major foreign currencies in moderate European trading today, pushed lower by central bank intervention to stem the dollar's rise. Gold prices were slightly lower. The West German central bank, the Bundesbank, and the Swiss National Bank confirmed that they had sold dollars, buying up their own currencies. London dealers said the Bank of England was selling dollars for Japanese yen on behalf of the Bank of Japan. The Bank of England refused to comment. The dollar soared in trading earlier in Asia and dealers said the currency would have gone higher if the Japanese central bank had not intervened. Despite the rally, European traders said the dollar's downward trend would continue. ``There could be a slightly upward trend because U.S. interest rates aren't falling any further, but there is certainly no trend reversal,'' said a dealer at a major West German bank in Frankfurt. ``I would be surprised if the dollar had another upward push,'' said John Chapman, chief dealer at Standard Chartered Bank PLC in London. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 1.80 yen to a closing 145.20 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 144.65 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Wednesday: _1.7165 West German marks, down from 1.7203 _1.5660 Swiss francs, down from 1.5722 _5.8605 French francs, down from 5.8745 _1.9532 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9370 _1,285.50 Italian lire, down from 1,286.00 _1.1627 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1602 In London, the dollar fell against the British pound. It cost $1.6170 to buy one pound, compared with $1.6080 late Wednesday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $395.60 a troy ounce, unchanged from late Wednesday. At midmorning, the city's five major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $394.95. In Zurich, the bid price was $394.80, down from $395.25 bid late Wednesday. Gold in Hong Kong fell $1.40 to close at a bid $394.89. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $5.19 a troy ounce, up from Wednesday's $5.16.

DOC.HEAD: Experimental Electric Car Goes 120 Miles on Charge, GM Says
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. unveiled a prototype electric car it says outpaces some gas-burning sports cars and runs twice as far between charges than previous electric models. The two-seater Impact, which tapers at the rear like a Citroen, can travel 120 miles at 55 mph before recharging and zooms from 0 to 60 mph in eight seconds, GM Chairman Roger Smith said at a news conference Wednesday. ``The public perceives electric vehicles as golf carts,'' Smith said. ``The Impact absolutely shatters that perception.'' GM showed a film in which the Impact outpaced a Mazda Miata and a Nissan 300 ZX on a level-ground acceleration test. John Zwerner, GM's executive director of advanced product engineering, said the prototype has never been crash-tested or passed other government tests and would go into production only if extensive tests find a market for it. Boasting a top speed of 75 mph, the Impact can be charged halfway in as little as half an hour and almost fully recharged in six hours, GM said. Most electric vehicles need up to 12 hours for a full recharging. Electric cars are virtually non-polluting and are under close scrutiny in Los Angeles by environmental officials who are enacting stringent air quality rules. He declined to reveal how much GM had spent developing the vehicle or to estimate a price, although he said it would have to be competitive in price with existing, internal combustion-powered cars. A person driving a gas-powered car in Los Angeles 10,000 miles a year might now spend about $30 a month on fuel and another $10 on maintenance, Smith said. The Impact would use a maximum of $12 per month in electricity under the same conditions, but would still cost about twice as much to operate because the batteries must be replaced every 20,000 miles, adding another $70 a month to operating costs, Smith said. Zwerner said that within three years, improvements in batteries may make it possible for the Impact to double its battery life to 40,000 miles, which would make operating costs nearly equal to those of gas-powered cars. The 120-mile range is not expected to be improved much, officials said. ``You've got to keep in mind that this is not a car for driving to New York,'' he said. ``But as a second car, running around L.A., I think it's great.'' Smith said GM might need to produce as many as 100,000 of the vehicles a year for them to compete with cars powered by internal-combustion engines. Each of the Big Three automakers has aggressive programs to research cars powered by fuels other than gasoline, but Smith said the Impact was far more advanced than any other electric car.

DOC.HEAD: 12-Year-Old Raped, Tortured By Teens
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents in grafs 5-6
DOC.TEXT: A 12-year-old girl was raped and tortured by three teen-age boys who dangled her from the roof of a building during the four-hour assault, police said. The girl told detectives she went to visit a girlfriend in her class Tuesday evening when her friend's brother and two other boys dragged her into the apartment. Police arrested the brother, 16-year-old Masa McGrier, and were seeking two other teen-agers. McGrier was charged with rape, sodomy, assault, criminal possession of a weapon and menacing, police said. ``They tied my arms, my legs, too,'' the girl told New York Newsday. ``They got me down in the kitchen and started beating me. ``I told them to stop. ... One guy put a gun to my head. They burnt a knife on the stove and started to cut my breasts. ``They took an ice pick and did like this,'' she said, stabbing angrily at the bandage on her thigh. ``They raped me.'' Then they dangled her from the roof of the five-story Manhattan building, and demanded money, she said in today's editions of Newsday. One of the teens accused the girl of having stolen $45 in cash from the apartment during a prior visit, Manhattan Chief of Detectives Ronald Fenrich said. The teen-agers took their victim to her grandmother's house and the grandmother called police, Vreeland said. The girl was taken to St. Luke's Hospital, where she was treated and released.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty Means Huge Personnel Losses for Industries
DOC.TEXT: Production is threatened in some key industries because they are losing thousands of prisoner-workers to President Vaclav Havel's broad amnesty, officials say. State television said 35 enterprises have petitioned the Labor and Social Affairs Ministry for help in filling about 5,000 vacancies caused by the amnesty. Thousands of inmates had been working in industries as part of or in lieu of prison terms. Under the amnesty, announced Monday, about two-thirds of the country's 31,000 prisoners will go free before Jan. 21. The Skoda auto factory in Mlada Boleslav, 50 miles northeast of Prague, is down more than 1,500 workers _ or 15 percent of its workforce _ because of the decree, the state news agency CTK reported Wednesday. Frantisek Brodsky, spokesman for Skoda, said he expected production to drop by about a third at the factory, one of Czechoslovakia's main exporters. Brodsky said the jobs could be filled by bringing in foreign workers from Poland, Vietnam or elsewhere, CTK reported. Havel, Czechoslovakia's first non-Communist President in 41 years, declared the amnesty and sentence reductions three days after he was sworn in. The decree applies to all prisoners except those charged with abuse of power, murder, terrorism and sex crimes.

DOC.HEAD: Unprecedented Strike Shuts Down Major Port Complex in Mozambique
DOC.TEXT: The government today rejected what it called immoral demands by more than 4,000 railworkers who have shut down the nation's largest port in the first major strike during 15 years of independence. The strike at the main railway and port complex in Maputo, the capital, began Tuesday, when employees of Mozambique Railways stopped work to demand a year-end bonus and payment of wage arrears dating back to 1987. The national news agency, AIM, said 4,000 of the 6,500 railway employees at the complex joined the strike Tuesday, and the entire workforce there _ including dockworkers _ stopped work Wednesday amid reports of coercion. AIM said some dockworkers began returning to their jobs today, but the railway workers remained on strike. The Transport Ministry announced today that wage arrears would be paid to three of seven categories of workers and promised full implementation of wages scales approved in 1987. But the ministry rejected demands for a bonus, saying a money-losing company like the railroad could not afford such a step. ``In the extremely serious economic situation facing Mozambique Railways, the demand for an end-of-year bonus has no rationale and is immoral,'' a ministry statement said. The ministry noted that Mozambique's railways have been a prime target of anti-government rebels during a 13-year-old insurgency. Major rail lines linking Maputo to Zimbabwe and South Africa have been shut down frequently by sabotage during the war, causing hundreds of millions of dollars in losses for the railway. The minium wage for industrial workers in Mozambique is 22,500 meticais a month, equivalent to only $27 because of recent devaluations. No information was available as to the average wage of the railway workers. AIM said the strike was the first of major significance since Mozambique became independent of Portugal in 1975. The leftist government, which last year dropped Marxism as its official ideology, has allowed trade union activities but up until now has not faced serious confrontations. The Transport Ministry accused strikers of trying to coerce other workers at the port complex into joining the strike, saying such actions were ``extremely incorrect and dangerous.'' It said the strikers ``resorted to physical threats against their colleagues and blocked the entrance to their workplace.'' The ministry urged the railway management to take immediate disciplinary steps against ``elements who contine to seriously disturb the normal activity of the company.''

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Joins Five Other Defendants Awaiting Drug Trial in Miami
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 10-11, `A federal...' with two grafs to UPDATE with details of Pardo's arrest. Picks up 12th graf pvs, `Pardo allegedly....'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Noriega, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Deposed Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega is the sixth of 16 defendants charged with drug trafficking in a February 1988 federal indictment here to be brought to Florida to face trial. Hours before Noriega was handed over to U.S. drug agents in Panama Wednesday night, two of his fellow defendants had hearings in Miami and a federal official said a third was being flown to Homestead Air Force Base, where Noriega arrived early today. Noriega was scheduled to appear this afternoon at U.S. District Court in Miami. Despite extraordinary security precautions planned by U.S. Marshals, U.S. District Judge William M. Hoeveler said Noriega would be treated like any other defendant. ``If General Noriega is apprehended and brought here for trial, he would be given the same treatment as any other person accused of a crime _ no more, no less. All his rights will be protected,'' Hoeveler said. Noriega is accused of accepting millions of dollars in bribes from Colombia's Medellin cartel in exchange for allowing Panama to be used as a conduit for cocaine shipments into the United States. If convicted on all charges, Noriega faces up to 145 years in prison and $1.1 million in fines. Five people accused of aiding Noriega in his alleged drug-trafficking schemes have been arrested and brought to Florida to face trial. Lt. Col. Luis del Cid, 46, accused of acting as a liaison and money courier between drug traffickers and Noriega, pleaded innocent, and is being held pending a Jan. 16 hearing. Del Cid, who was arrested in Panama on Christmas Day, faces 70 years in prison and $550,000 in fines if convicted on all counts. Daniel Miranda, 36, accused of flying $800,000 in drug profits from Fort Lauderdale to Panama in 1983, was arrested Sunday in Panama and was scheduled for a court hearing Friday. Miranda on Tuesday challenged the legitimacy of his extradition by refusing to answer charges against him. An innocent plea was entered for Miranda by U.S. Magistrate Peter Palermo. Federal court officials in Miami who spoke on condition of anonymity said this morning that another co-defendant, pilot Eduardo Pardo, had been arrested in Panama City by U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agents. He was flown to South Florida immediately afterward, separately from Noriega, and was being held at an undisclosed location. He was to be arraigned this afternoon at the same time as Noriega. Pardo allegedly flew the plane with Miranda, according to the indictment. He faces five years in prison and $10,000 in fines if convicted. Earlier Wednesday, two other co-defendants, William Saldarriaga, 45, and Brian Davidow, 28, asked for separate trials. Hoeveler said he would rule on their requests later this month. Saldarriaga, a reputed Colombian drug trafficker, is being held without bond. He faces 40 years in prison and $500,000 in fines if convicted. Davidow, an alleged cocaine dealer in Miami, remains free on bond. Both men have pleaded innocent, and neither attended Wednesday's court session. Noriega's ten other co-defendants include five alleged members of the Medellin cartel, two Panamanian pilots who allegedly flew cocaine shipments, two Panamanian businessmen accused of arranging flights of cocaine into the United States, and another Panamanian who allegedly arranged for the protection of cocaine shipments through Panama. All are still at large.

DOC.HEAD: Revolutionary Government Names 11-Member Executive Committee
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 graf to UPDATE with homeless being put in Securitate housing, Shevardnadze to visit Romania on Saturday. Pickup 11th pvs, `Rompress said...; Delete last 2 grafs to trim.
DOC.TEXT: The government today officially legalized public rallies following the creation of an executive committee that will have final say on how the country is run until free elections promised for April. Rompres, the official news agency, reported that interim President Ion Iliescu had signed a decree that says ``public gatherings ... are means of exercising freedom of opinion and speech, of organizing the citizens' participation in the country's public life.'' Organizers of rallies and demonstrations will ``be obliged to take all the necessary measures so that they should proceed peacefully and they also must notify police 48 hours in advance,'' Rompres said. Under ousted dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, demonstrations were banned unless they were staged in support of his leadership. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, the country's second-in-command, were toppled in a popular revolution and tried and executed Christmas Day on charges of genocide and other grave crimes during 24 years of despotic rule. Families whose homes were destroyed in fierce fighting in Bucharest during the revolution will move into spacious apartments Ceausescu built for his security forces in the city, media said today. The 110 apartments were intended for security police who were to work in the Palace of the Republic, one of Ceausescu's pet projects that was not completed, and have been vacant for four years. Thousands of old homes and landmarks were razed to make way for the palace. On Wednesday, the military chief of staff denied foreign news reports that the revolution was planned several months in advance, but he acknowledged that tensions had been rising. ``The revolution was spontaneous, but the discontent had been piling up for years,'' Col. Gen. Vasile Ionel told reporters. ``Civilians and the military alike had felt the hardships. The army was dissatisfied by the way it was treated as a labor force on huge projects without any use for Romania,'' he said. He said at least 196 officers and non-commissioned officers were killed during the uprising in fierce street fighting with Ceausescu loyalists. He did not give a figure for enlisted men or civilians who also took up arms. Army troops joined pro-democracy demonstrators in ousting Ceausescu on Dec. 22, battling the despot's dreaded Securitate security police in the capital and other cities. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze will visit Bucharest on Saturday, Soviet Embassy sources said. It will be the first visit by a top Kremlin official to the new leadership. Rompres said Wednesday the National Salvation Front, which has been running the country since Ceausescu's ouster and promises to usher in democracy, had created an 11-member executive committee that has ultimate governing authority. It said President Iliescu would serve as chairman and that Dumitru Mazilu, a leading critic of Ceausescu, was named first deputy. Mazilu blasted the old regime in a report smuggled out of Romania this fall and delivered to the United Nations' Human Rights Commission in Geneva, where he had worked until being placed under house arrest by Ceausescu in 1987. Romania also has a Cabinet, led by Premier Petre Roman. But the Salvation Front has legislative powers and chose the premier. Roman was excluded from the executive committee, as announced by Rompres. Rompres said a new justice minister, Teofil Pop, and supreme court president, Teodor Vasiliu, were named on Wednesday. It did not provide any details of their backgrounds. The news agency said initial estimates of those killed in the first days of the revolution were exaggerated. It said ``rigorous inquiries are being made to establish the exact number of the dead and wounded.'' Initial reports put the death toll as high as 70,000, but later reports have varied widely and Western diplomats say the actual figure could be about 10,000. Ionel, the army chief of staff, said ``there is a high number of dead all over the country ... Just how many died in the revolution will be found out later on.'' He said: ``Many who belonged to the security units have been arrested. They are all being interrogated and will be punished according to their deeds.'' He reiterated that the army had refused orders to fire on protesters in the western city of Timisoara, where the revolution began when security forces massacred anti-government protesters on Dec. 17. ``But some elements of the security troops had infiltrated into the army and fired upon the people. The dead there are not victims of bullets fired by soldiers of the Romanian army,'' Ionel said. At least six political parties have been formed to compete in the April elections. A spokesman for one of them, Nicolae Costel of the Romanian Democratic Party, said Wednesday that he believed the elections should be delayed. The Christian Democratic National Peasants' Party also has urged postponement, contending that early elections will give candidates of the interim government an unfair advantage.

DOC.HEAD: Blood Shortages Reported in Some Parts of Nation
DOC.TEXT: The American Red Cross has issued emergency appeals for blood donations in several parts of the nation, but other regions have enough to ensure an adequate supply in case of disaster. Critical shortages were reported in parts of Arizona, Florida, Georgia, Michigan, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Virginia, while most of the nation was simply experiencing a normal post-holiday tightening of supplies. But the blood supply was at its strongest level in 11 years in Los Angeles and Orange counties in California, Red Cross spokeswoman Cheryle Babbit said. The Penn-Jersey Region of American Red Cross Blood Services said its shortage was threatening patient care at hospitals in southeastern Pennsylvania and southern New Jersey. The region, which provides 94 percent of the blood used in 93 hospitals, needs about 1,750 donors a day and was down to about 1,000 donors daily. ``Supplies are so low that over New Year's weekend we curtailed distribution of red cells and platelets sharply and worked with physicians and hospitals on a case-by-case basis,'' regional director Dr. William C. Sherwood said. A heart bypass operation was postponed for two hours Tuesday at Albert Einstein Medical Center in Philadelphia because of the shortage, said Dr. Ierachmiel Daskal, chairman of the hospital's Department of Pathology. ``If you have a limited amount of product, you must use it the best way you can,'' Daskal said. ``We have not had to cancel surgery yet, but we have had to postpone and reshuffle the schedule.'' The Red Cross collects about 6.2 million units of blood per year, or more than half the nation's blood supply. A unit is 450 milliliters, or slightly less than a pint. Blood and blood products are used to replace blood lost by patients, to stop bleeding by forming blood clots, to fight severe infection and to increase the oxygen-carrying ability of the blood during surgery. Severe cold weather and flu outbreaks combined with the usual drop in donations at holiday time to create the scattered shortages, Red Cross officials said. ``I'm not having any indication that we're having a general shortage across the country,'' said Pat Davis, a national Red Cross spokeswoman in Washington. If a major emergency occurred, blood supplies from around the country could be released to areas in need, she said. In Atlanta, daily donations had dropped to half the 900 units collected normally and an emergency appeal was issued for type O blood. ``We need 800 donors over the next few days to get supplies back to a safe level,'' said Ann Wilcox, spokeswoman for the Red Cross blood bank serving more than 100 hospitals in 82 Georgia counties. Similar emergency appeals were under way in the south Florida, Great Lakes, southern Arizona and Tidewater, Va., blood regions, Ms. Davis said. Blood supplies generally tighten every year during the holiday season and during the summer because donors are busy with other activities. In Arizona, a flu outbreak contributed to the drop in donations, while two severe ice storms kept donors home in Virginia, Red Cross officials said. ``Our shelves are bare,'' said Red Cross spokeswoman Chris Chidley in Miami, where the organization usually has at least a three-day supply of blood, about 1,500 pints. Tuesday's inventory was down to 300 pints for 66 hospitals from Key West to Palm Beach. Janet Connor, administrator for the Central Illinois Community Blood Bank in Springfield, Ill., said the seasonal shortage there was being met by aggressive phone calls to potential donors. ``We don't end our day unless we get enough,'' she said. Mary Joe Smith, manager of the Parkland Blood Donor Center in Dallas, said an increased number of accidents over the holiday season helped create a shortage there. It wasn't critical enough to curtail elective surgery, but a liver transplant was delayed by a short supply of one blood type.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Turns Self Over to US and Panama Erupts in Celebration
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 20 grafs to add Panamanian archbishop's comments on Noriega's mood; moves up death count. Pickup 17th pvs, `Gen. Maxwell...; Delete last 5 grafs to conform.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos PAN1,2,3,10,11
DOC.TEXT: Exultant Panamanians danced in the streets and embraced American soldiers when they heard that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, who intimidated them for years, had left the Vatican Embassy and surrendered to U.S. troops. ``The people feel a sense of peace knowing that the monster is leaving our land,'' said President Guillermo Endara, who was a frequent target of Noriega's thugs. The ousted strongman decided to give up Wednesday night after realizing that he was cornered _ that even his long-time supporters had turned against him, the archbishop of Panama, Marcos McGrath, said today. ``Once the Vatican had made it quite clear that he was not a diplomatic nor political refugee _ but rather a refugee with criminal charges against him _ it was quite clear he could not go to a third country. Therefore, his choice was simply Panama or the States,'' McGrath told ABC's ``Good Morning America.'' After hundreds of angry Panamanians staged an anti-Noriega protest outside the Vatican Embassy on Wednesday afternoon, Noriega ``began to realize how much feeling there is against him in Panama _ that it's much safer going to the States,'' McGrath said. Jubilation gripped the capital of 1 million residents seconds after radio and television announced that Noriega, who ruled Panama six years with no popular mandate, had given up after evading American troops sent in to capture him Dec. 20. ``It's over! It's over!'' people shouted as, leaning out of their cars and blaring their horns. Some people screamed themselves hoarse. People ran up to the U.S. military roadblocks and hugged and kissed U.S. soldiers. They banged pots and pans, and fireworks exploded in the sky around the Vatican mission. Youngsters raced around waving Panamanian and U.S. flags. ``Thank God, Panama can now feel like a free country,'' said Moises Rios, 20, one of hundreds outside the Vatican Embassy minutes after Noriega left. A Vatican Embassy spokesman said Noriega left ``of his own will'' in his general's uniform shortly before 9 p.m. Wednesday. As soon as he walked out, he was arrested by U.S. soldiers who had surrounded the building since he sought refuge there Christmas Eve. Noriega was whisked by helicopter to Howard Air Base west of the capital and flown by military transport to Florida, where he faces drug trafficking charges. The surrender took place just hours after about 20,000 people shouting ``No More!'' and ``Assassin!'' marched to the Vatican Embassy to demand Noriega's surrender. Noriega was said to have been under ``strict isolation'' at the mission on orders of the papal nuncio, or ambassador. McGrath said he saw little of Noriega in the embassy, but ``from what I hear while he was there, he kept pretty much to himself and was downcast and a bit moody.'' The television in the room Noriega used was broken, but Noriega must have heard the protesters and knew from radio reports broadcast by U.S. loudspeakers that his supporters had abandoned him. Less than an hour after Noriega surrendered, President Bush announced victory in Washington: ``His apprehension and return to the United States should send a clear signal that the United States is serious in its determination that those charged with promoting the distribution of drugs cannot escape the scrutiny of justice.'' Bush also paid tribute to servicemen who were killed and wounded in the invasion, saying ``Their sacrifice has been a noble cause.'' By official count, 23 American soldiers and three American civilians were killed in the fighting. More than 300 American troops were wounded. At least 290 Panamanian soldiers and about 300 civilians were killed. Gen. Maxwell Thurman of the U.S. Southern Command said American forces had only a few minutes' notice before Noriega surrendered. Noriega's surrender ended days of bargaining. In the end he got three concessions: to be allowed to make a few phone calls and wear his uniform, and that his decision to give himself up be kept secret until his arrest. Sources in Washington also said Vatican officials relayed to Noriega assurances he wouldn't be tried on a federal drug kingpin statute that carries the death penalty. The surrender came after a visit by Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger and Vatican diplomat Monsignor Giacinto Berloco, and Thurman thanked Eagleburger for his efforts. Administration sources said the United States did not deal directly with Noriega at any time and that all negotiations were through church officials. The Vatican Embassy said in a statement after Noriega's departure that he ``considered the situation serious and took the responsible decision to leave of his own will the residence of the pope's representative.'' Noriega made no public statements during his stay in the Vatican compound. Thurman said Noriega didn't say anything when he was spirited out but added that the former strongman ``looked vigorous, looked confident. He looked fine.'' Vice President Guillermo Ford, familiar to U.S. television viewers as the bloody-shirted victim of a beating by Noriega loyalists in May, said Noriega would be returned to Panama for trial on a long list of charges after his trial in the United States. ``No revenge. Due process,'' he said on ABC's ``Nightline.'' Officials of Panama's new government have said they plan to charge Noriega with murder in the deaths of officers who led a failed Oct. 3 coup and were allegedly slain after their capture.

DOC.HEAD: Vatican Stresses Decision to Surrender Was Noriega's
With PM-Panama, Bjt, PM-Noriega, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Vatican declared today that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega voluntarily left its embassy in Panama and was given no special guarantees before turning himself over to U.S. authorities. In giving the Vatican's first official comment on Noriega's leaving the embassy, spokesman Joaquin Navarro insisted that the Holy See did not give in to U.S. demands that church officials hand over the deposed dictator. ``It did not consist of a handover but a free decision'' by Noriega to leave the embassy, where he sought refuge on Dec. 24, four days after U.S. troops invaded Panama, Navarro told reporters at an early-afternoon briefing. Navarro said he did not know what prompted Noriega's decision to surrender Wednesday night to U.S. forces who had been surrounding the Vatican mission. Noriega was flown to Florida, where he faces federal drug-trafficking charges. Noriega gave the papal nuncio, or representative, a letter for Pope John Paul II, Navarro said, adding he did not know its contents. He said the nuncio, Monsignor Jose Sebastian Laboa, accompanied Noriega out of the embassy into a Catholic school across the street where the general was seized by U.S. troops. In Panama City, Marcos McGrath, the archbishop of Panama, said today that Noriega gave up after realizing that he was cornered _ that even his long-time supporters had turned against him. ``Once the Vatican had made it quite clear that he was not a diplomatic nor political refugee _ but rather a refugee with criminal charges against him _ it was quite clear he could not go to a third country. Therefore, his choice was simply Panama or the States,'' McGrath told ABC's ``Good Morning America.'' Navarro said of Noriega's surrender: ``International law has been respected. This is a solution that was taken voluntarily by Noriega himself.'' Throughout the negotiations between U.S. and Vatican officials to try to end the stalemate, the Holy See had stressed that its nunciature, like any other accredited embassy, was empowered to deal directly only with the host country and thus it would have been impossible, under international law, to hand over Noriega directly to U.S. authorities. Navarro said that while Noriega's surrender to U.S. authorities might appear as if the Vatican had given in to U.S. demands, from the ``point of view of international law'' the situation was ``completely different.'' He said the Vatican had provided Noriega with no guarantees but that the nuncio had explained how the U.S. justice system works, with its provisions for fair trials. Asked if the United States got want it wanted, Navarro replied: ``If this is all viewed like a game of soccer, it's ridiculous. I said from the beginning of the negotiations that this is not a matter of who wins, who loses.'' Navarro said he did not know exactly what element prompted Noriega to leave his refuge at the nunciature but that the general probably had ``reflected'' on such issues as the future of Panama and his responsibilities to the nation. While officials of the Roman Catholic Church and the U.S. administration debated Noriega's fate, he was described as being kept isolated in a small room with a broken television, unable to receive visitors or phone calls. Navarro, the pope's chief spokesman, said he had not spoken to the pontiff about the resolution of the case but added, ``I suspose the Holy Father has been pleased'' with the outcome. He said that before leaving the nunciature, Noriega asked for a memento of his stay but didn't know what the souvenir was. Four colleagues of Noriega remained in the Vatican embassy, Navarro said: a captain, a colonel, the former Panamanian director of immigration and the wife of one of them. Navarro said he did not immediately have their identification. Negotiations were expected to continue over their fate. Throughout the negotiations, the Vatican stressed that Noriega was being sheltered but that no granting of political asylum had been made. It also stressed that the papal nuncio agreed to let Noreiga into the mission only after he pledged to use his influence to get his supporters to quit resisting the United States forces, and the Vatican portrayed the whole affair as a means to stop bloodshed. Before Noriega showed up at the embassy, the pope had decried the loss of life caused by the U.S. invasion of the strategic Central American nation.

DOC.HEAD: Tough-Talking Noriega Spent Last Days in Isolation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 17 grafs to ADD quotes from McGrath, detail of room where Noriega stayed. Pickup 16th pvs, ``I have...' Delete last graf to trim.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Tough-talking and heavy-handed while in power, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega spent his last days in Panama as a refugee in the Vatican Embassy, mostly keeping to himself in a state of nervous isolation. While little information has been released on his 10-day stay, details gleaned through telephone calls to the papal mission indicate the toppled ruler found himself with little to do. In the end, Vatican Embassy workers shunned Noriega, who was confined largely to a simple room with a crucifix and a broken television set. Outside, people howled for his expulsion from the Vatican mission and trial in Panama or in the United States. The Defense Forces that had kept him in power for six years were crushed quickly by invading U.S. troops on Dec. 20 and reduced to a handful of holdouts who surrendered or were captured. Noriega sought refuge at the Vatican Embassy on Christmas Eve. Officials there urged him to leave and although it was said they would not throw him out, it was no secret he was hardly welcome. Panama's top churchman, Archbishop Marcos McGrath, said publicly that Noriega would stand a better chance of a fair trial and decent treatment in the United States than in Panama. Panama said it had no jail to hold him and third countries that might have been acceptable destinations to people calling the shots weren't interested in granting the ousted strongman asylum. The man who was cheered by thousands weeks earlier was wanted only by the United States, and there only for his hide. ``He saw himself as something of an emperor in this part of the world, and I think that dream has been shattered,'' McGrath said on ABC's ``Nightline'' Wednesday night. His detractors, who called him ``pineapple face'' because of his acne-scarred countenance, hung pineapples over the streets and used sticks to smash them to yellow sticky pulp. Thousands of people wore ``Noriega-buster'' T-shirts depicting pineapples with a red circle and slash. How much of this Noriega knew is uncertain, but radio reports of his bank accounts being frozen, his military support wilting and his cronies being captured were blared over loudspeakers by American troops around the Vatican Embassy. Hours before he gave up, tens of thousands of Panamanians gathered near the compound demanding he leave. No doubt much of this came as a shock to the stocky, up-from-the-slums city kid whose early military career, by most accounts, was brilliant and promising. ``He was cornered,'' McGrath said today of Noriega's decision to give up. ``He had come to the Vatican Embassy ... looking for refuge because he was cornered physically, militarily ... and as the days went by it became more obvious he would not be able to get to a third country,'' the archbishop told NBC's ``Today'' show. The protest outside the embassy Wednesday night further convinced Noriega there was no way out, McGrath said. ``I have often wondered if he really knew what people thought about him,'' Luis Martinz, an aide to President Guillermo Endara, said earlier this week. ``I have known him for a long time and I have to admit that at one time I liked him. He was sort of shy and self-effacing. He knew I was in the opposition but he never tried to change my mind. ``But he wasn't like that at all in the more recent years.'' Martinz was jailed by Noriega for two months earlier this year for his activities with the opposition. As the heir to Omar Torrijos, the strongman who signed the 1977 treaties by which the United States cedes control of the Panama Canal, Noriega did have support among the poor and the black and Chinese minorities. Even when the United States attacked in overwhelming force, there were Panamanians willing to die for Noriega. But in the end there was no massive pool of support or faith of the kind that allowed Hungarian Cardinal Josef Mindszenty to survive 15 years in the U.S. Embassy in Budapest. The only time Noriega is known to have socialized at the Vatican Embassy was on New Year's Eve, when the papal envoy, Sebastian Laboa, served a pasta dinner for all those at the mission. Noriega reportedly spoke little except to recall that his cook also made excellent pasta.

DOC.HEAD: List of Recent Train Wrecks
With Pakistan-Train Wreck
DOC.TEXT: Here are some of the worst train wrecks within the last 10 years, with estimates of the number dead and injured:

Jan. 4, 1990 _ Passenger train crashes into standing freight train in southern Pakistan killing about 200 people and injuring an estimated 400. Nov. 1, 1989 _ Express train traveling from New Delhi to Calcutta derails, killing at least 52 and injuring 64. Aug. 9, 1989 _ Bridge weakened by floods and torrential rain collapses, pitching train into river in northern Mexico; 112 killed, 205 injured. June 4, 1989 _ Gas explosion in Ural mountains of Soviet Union engulfs two passing trains, killing 645. April 18, 1989 _ New Delhi-bound passenger train derails and tumbles down rocky ravine in central India; 67 dead, 137 injured. Jan. 15, 1989 _ Express passenger train carrying worshippers to religious festival and mail train collide head-on in central Bangladesh; 114 dead, 1,000 injured. July 8, 1988 _ Train derails into a lake in India; 103 dead, 500 injured. June 27, 1988 _ Train hits another in a Paris station; 59 dead. Jan. 24, 1988 _ Train derails in China; 90 dead, 66 injured. July 3, 1987 _ Truck and train collide in Zaire; 128 dead. Aug. 6, 1986 _ Passenger train and a freight train collide in India; 52 dead, 100 injured. Feb. 17, 1986 _ Two passenger trains collide in Chile; 58 dead, 510 injured. Sept. 13, 1985 _ Two passenger trains collide in Portugal; 52 dead. Jan. 14, 1985 _ Train derails into a ravine in Ethiopia; 428 dead. Aug. 16, 1984 _ Railroad bridge collapses in India; 61 dead, 41 missing. June 20, 1984 _ Train wreck in Angola kills 50. April 1983 _ Two passenger trains collide in China; 600 dead, more than 2,000 injured. Feb. 20, 1983 _ Train wreck in Mexico kills 56.
June 19, 1982 _ Train wreck in Uganda; 200 feared dead. March 20, 1982 _ Train hits a tourist bus in India; 59 dead. Jan. 27, 1982 _ Train derails in Algeria; 100 dead, 150 injured.
Jan. 27, 1982 _ Two trains collide near Agra, India; 63 dead. June 7, 1981 _ Train plunges into a river in India; more than 215 dead. Aug. 19, 1980 _ Freight train and passenger train collide in Poland; 67 dead.

DOC.HEAD: East German Opposition Groups Form Coalition for May Elections
DOC.TEXT: Six pro-democracy groups banded together today to challenge the Communist Party in national elections set for May, creating a force likely to pose a serious threat to the once omnipotent Communists. Steffen Reiche, a leader of the Social Democratic Party of East Germany, announced that his group was entering a coalition with New Forum, the largest of the pro-democracy forces with 200,000 members nationwide, as well as with Democracy Now, Democratic Awakening, the Initiative for Peace and Human Rights, and the United Left. The coalition is calling itself Election Alliance 90, Reiche said. He accused the Communists of trying to stir up public fears of a resurgence of ultra-rightist activity and use it against opposition groups. Communist Party leaders marched Wednesday night in the southeastern neighborhood of Treptow to protest vandalism committed by neo-Nazis over the past two weeks. The official ADN news agency said the march drew 250,000 people, but witnesses said that figure was inflated. ``This country was born from anti-fascists,'' Communist Party leader Gregor Gysi told the gathering at the site where rightist vandals last week defaced a Soviet war memorial. ``Don't let it become the homeland for neo-fascists.'' Gysi said the rightists cannot be allowed to ``ruin the chances for a democratic socialism in East Germany.'' Leaders of the opposition groups fear the Communists are using the neo-Nazi issue as a springboard to gain support for the May elections, while at the same time discouraging calls in East Germany for reunification of the two German states. Despite losing their constitutional mandate to rule during the fall pro-democracy movement, the Communists remain the strongest single political force in the country, according to recent public opinion surveys. But the new coalition pools the resources and voter support of the largest reform groups into a force likely to pose a serious challenge to the Communists. The May 6 elections will be the first free, secret and competitive balloting in East Germany's 40-year history. They will choose a new 500-member Parliament, which will then select a new Cabinet. Communist Premier Hans Modrow is viewed as an interim government leader by the opposition forces, who have pressed him to take the views of the rival political factions into consideration during weekly talks. Opposition leaders contend Modrow's Cabinet has limited powers to govern because it was named by a Parliament under the control of unelected Communist Party figures. Modrow enjoys relatively broad support as a transitional figure, but there have been increasing opposition complaints that control of the government apparatus gives the Communists an unfair advantage in elections.

DOC.HEAD: Three Reported Killed in Fighting Between Shiite Militias
DOC.TEXT: Rival Shiite Moslem militias armed with artillery and machine guns clashed in south Lebanon today despite the intervention of a Palestinian guerrilla peacekeeping force. Three people were reported killed. In Beirut, Gen. Michel Aoun, the Christian leader, was entangled in a growing financial scandal caused by foreign news reports that he had $15 million stashed away in French banks. The Iranian-backed fundamentalist Hezbollah, of Party of God, and the secular, Syrian-backed Amal militia have been battling for 13 days in the latest campaign of their 2-year-old war for control of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's largest sect. Including today's toll of three killed and 11 wounded, police say 73 people have been killed and 263 wounded since fighting broke out Dec. 23. Police said 300 guerrillas from the Fatah movement headed by Palestine Liberation Organization Chairman Yasser Arafat deployed Wednesday across the strategic Hamade hill that Hezbollah captured Tuesday after a fierce battle. Hezbollah needs to hold the hill to protect the supply lines to its southern bases from the Bekaa Valley in east Lebanon, a Shiite stronghold where an estimated 2,000 Iranian Revolutionary Guards are based. Zeid Wehbi, Fatah's political chief in the southern port city of Sidon, said the Palestinian deployment was aimed at ending the fighting. He said the guerrillas also sought to keep the fighting away from the Palestinian refugee camps of Ein el-Hilweh and Mieh Mmieh, a few miles to the north. Palestinian sources said Arafat fears that Hezbollah, which has gained the upper hand and captured five villages, would provide support for dissident PLO factions in the camps. Amal chief Nabih Berri appealed again today to Iran to stop sending military supplies to Hezbollah, saying Syria had discontinued the supply of arms and ammunititons to Amal after fighting erupted in the southern province. In Moslem west Beirut, newspapers gave prominent coverage to reports that Aoun has bank accounts in Paris. On Wednesday, the satirical Paris weekly Le Canard Enchaine published a bank statement showing two accounts in Aoun's name at the Banque Nationale de Paris, one with a balance of $500,00, the other with $14.7 million. Moslem-controlled radio stations said the reports have created a corruption scandal that could seriously damage Aoun's standing in the Christian community. The reports came amid efforts by the Syrian-backed government to force Aoun to end his defiance of President Elias Hrawi, who dismissed Aoun as army commander and interim prime minister in November. Aoun refuses to stand down, or accept a peace treaty approved by the Lebanese parliament. Aoun acknowledged having millions of dollars in foreign bank accounts. ``It's not a secret for anyone. It's an open secret,'' Aoun said in an interview Wednesady on France's state-run radio station France-Inter. He said he had accounts in other French banks, as well as in the United States and Lebanon. The general said the funds in the accounts came from donations and were not for his private use. ``If necessary, I can withdraw the money needed to resolve financial crises,'' he said. ``For the last year and three months, I have received no money from the central bank as concerns the army.''

DOC.HEAD: Policy Chief Sees Progress in Drug War
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's drug policy coordinator, William Bennett, said today that the surrender of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to U.S. authorities in Panama proves that the war against drugs is ``moving toward dawn.'' However, he said, ``We still have a long way to go,'' in fighting the scourge. ``The message is getting through,'' Bennett told The Associated Press in a telephone interview. ``The message is that the price of doing drug business is going up. The night of the drug lord is past midnight. We're starting to move toward dawn.'' Drug dealers should learn that, ``If you want to share in his trade, you may share his fate,'' Bennett said of Noriega, who was to Florida overnight to face federal drug-trafficking charges. Bennett expresed optimism that the charges can be prosecuted successfully. ``The largest part of justice has been done,'' he said. ``A tyrant has lost power. A tyrant has lost lucre. He's a man without a country. Now he goes to trial.'' Bennett also took a poke at critics of Bush's decision to send in a military invasion force of more than 11,000 to drive Noriega from power. The people of Panama, he said, ``understand, unlike some critics here in the United States ... that the United States was a liberating force.''

DOC.HEAD: Search Continues for 14 Missing in New Year's Day Yacht Sinking
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with home states of missing Americans, CORRECT that Watson is 62, sted 53, and that two people, sted two Americans, among survivors. Pickup 7th, ``Watson said...''
DOC.TEXT: Rescue teams resumed their search today for 11 Americans and three Mexicans missing since their yacht sank, but officials held out little hope of finding them in the cold Gulf of California waters. ``Unfortunately, we are not expecting very much,'' said Port Capt. Joaquin Dorantes. ``A lot of time has gone by and the water is cold.'' The chartered yacht sank New Year's Day, and the captain said few people could survive for more than 40 hours in water as cold as 61 degrees. The boat was carrying 16 people, 12 American scuba divers and four Mexican crew members. Two people were rescued. The U.S. Coast Guard said a 17th person, an American crew man, also may have been aboard, but it provided no details. No bodies from the Santa Barbara, a 68-foot refitted shrimp boat, had been found by nightfall Wednesday. Eight of the missing Americans were from Arizona and three from California, according to a spokesman for Silent Experience Scubacenter, a Tucson, Ariz. company that helped arrange the charter. The two survivors _ Opha Watson, 62, of Tucson, and Mexican crewman Vicente Gonzalez Mancilla, were picked up separately Tuesday afternoon and brought to San Carlos, the Mexican Navy and the U.S. Coast Guard said. Watson said that shortly after the yacht sank, probably after being struck by a large wave, four people clung to a door of the boat, then disappeared. He told The Arizona Daily Star that two of those four people wore flotation devices and that rescue workers may find them. ``They should be in the same drift pattern that I was in,'' which would carry them toward Guaymas, he said. All four disappeared in the night, apparently losing their grip on the door, before Watson was rescued around 5 p.m. Tuesday, 38 hours after boat sank. Watson identified them only as Nora, Jenny, Joe, and Jerry. Guaymas is 270 miles south of Tucson and 875 miles northwest of Mexico City. The boat sank about 40 miles west of Guaymas. ``Judging from what the captain said, we hit heavy seas,'' Watson said. ``Then, she keeled over,'' Watson said. He managed to put on a wet suit after he found his dive bag floating. He told Coast Guard officials he thought about seven people went down with the boat. He said he saw small groups of people clinging to debris. The Santa Barbara was being sold by Guaymas businessman Amado Navarro to Lane and Wanda Larson of Silent Experience Scubacenter, The Arizona Daily Star said. A woman who identified herself as Wanda Larson's mother said the yacht had been ``fully inspected less than a month ago.'' Dorantes said eight Mexican navy boats and two private planes searched a 40-mile strip between San Carlos, on the coast northwest of Guaymas, and Isla Tortugas, where the group had been diving on Sunday. They had sailed from the island about two hours before the boat sank. The Coast Guard sent two planes from California to help with the search.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega's Surrender Generally Welcomed, But Soviets Question Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Soviet reax. Pickup 3rd, `News that..'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Panama, Bjt, Noriega, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The international community today generally welcomed the decision by Gen. Manuel Noriega to accept U.S. justice and expressed hope that it would lead to peace in Panama. In scattered initial reaction, countries across the globe also expressed relief that the standoff over Noriega had ended. That was not the case in the Soviet Union, however. Gennady I. Gerasimov, spokesman for the Soviet Foreign Ministry, questioned whether the United States has the right to put Noriega on trial and said that even a conviction on drug trafficking charges would not justify the U.S. invasion of Panama. ``No state has the right to take the law into its own hands,'' he told reporters in Moscow. ``That's basically lynch law.'' News that Noriega had left his sanctuary in the Vatican embassy in Panama City and surrendered to U.S. troops led radio and television news bulletins and captured headlines of late newspaper editions in Europe. He was flown to Miami to face federal drug charges. Bahrain's Information Minister Tariq al-Moayyed said ``that is the best possible end'' to the situation in Panama. The British Foreign Office said: ``We are glad that this problem between the U.S. and the Vatican has been resolved,'' Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was one of the only world leaders to give full backing to President Bush when the United States invaded Panama on Dec. 20. ``Noriega faces criminal charges and we are naturally pleased that he should be brought to justice,'' said a Foreign Office spokesman, who spoke anonymously in accordance with British practice. Foreign Minister Francisco Fernandez Ordonez of Spain told Spanish National Radio: ``Noriega accepted the only option he had left since his remaining in the Vatican mission was not in the least easy while surrounded by U.S. military troops and under growing pressure by demonstrators outside. ``This appears to be a voluntary decision by Noriega and that's how I suppose the Vatican will underscore it,'' he said. Spain was the sole member of the 12-nation European Economic Community to vote along with Latin American nations to condemn the U.S. invasion in the U.N. General Assembly. ``We want Panama to recover its moral conscience, which has been left enormously perturbed as a result of all these events,'' Ordonez said. ``We also want it to recover its hope for the future, rebuild its economy, and that the government can advance in the paths of peace, freedom and prosperity. That's what's most important,'' he said. Thailand's government spokesman Suvit Yodmani said: ``We think it is important that a person who has been accused and indicted for a crime _ especially a crime such as narcotics, which is damaging internationally _ will be brought to fair trial. ``It is none of our business. However, as drug trafficking affects countries internationally, we are happy that the accused will be tried fairly in U.S. court. ``I think this will lead to more permanent peace in Panama,'' Yodmani said. The Japanese Foreign Ministry said it had no comment because the matter is strictly among the three nations, the United States, Panama and the Vatican. Japan has not yet officially recognized Panama's new government, ``although Japan has an impression that the new government has made a remarkable improvement,'' in the country, said a Foreign Ministry official, speaking on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Mass for Slain Nun, Body to Be Flown to Wisconsin
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 2 grafs with body leaving Nicaragua. Pickup 3rd graf pvs, ``She and...''
DOC.TEXT: Government, opposition and church representatives attended a Mass for an American nun slain in an attack the government blamed on U.S.-backed Contra rebels. A Contra leader denied responsibility. Following the Mass on Wednesday, the body of Sister Maureen Courtney, 45, left Nicargua today on a Honduran SAHSA flight to Miami, where it will be transferred to a plane bound for her hometown of Milwaukee. She and Sister Teresa Rosales, 24, a Nicaraguan, were killed and two other church workers were wounded Monday while riding in a pickup truck in Ojo de Agua, between the mining towns of Siuna and Rosita in northeastern Nicaragua. ``We do not have words to express our deep sorrow over such an act of violence,'' said a communique read Wednesday at the Mass by Bishop Salvador Schlaefer of Bluefields, in the Atlantic coast region where Sister Courtney worked with Miskito Indians. Commander Jose Gonzalez, the Interior Ministry's delegate in the Atlantic coast town of Puerto Cabezas, represented the government at the Mass. Sandinista President Daniel Ortega and Interior Minister Tomas Borge sent flowers. Attending for opposition presidential candidate Violeta Barrios de Chamorro was her mother-in-law, Margarita Cardenal de Chamorro. The candidate, who is in Houston for knee surgery, published a newspaper advertisement Wednesday condemning the killings and demanding an investigation. Aristides Sanchez, a spokesman for the Nicaraguan Resistance _ an umbrella group for the Contras _ said on Costa Rican radio the Sandinista government blamed the rebels for the attack to rob them of U.S. congressional support. U.S. non-lethal aid for the Contras runs out after Nicaraguan presidential elections are held Feb. 25. ``We protect the civilian population, we are Catholic and we support the episcopal work of the Catholic Church,'' Sanchez said on Radio Impacto. He said the Resistance regretted the deaths but that the rebels ``are incapable of taking such an action.'' Barricada, the newspaper of the ruling Sandinistas, said the attack was ``a premeditated ambush'' by the Contras, who have a strong presence in the remote region of Zelaya province where the attack occurred. The region is 250 miles northeast of Managua. Sister Francisca Colomer, 24, suffered face and body wounds and Auxiliary Bishop Pablo Schmitz, 48, a Capuchin priest from Fond du Lac, Wis., was wounded in the left arm in the attack. All three nuns belonged to the Order of St. Agnes. Sister Colomer and Schmitz were being treated in a Managua military hospital and were expected to recover. In Fond du Lac, Sister Jean Steffes, mother superior for the Sisters of St. Agnes, said: ``Both sisters were killed instantly as result of gunfire. The white pickup truck in which the group was traveling was clearly marked with yellow crosses. When those still alive in the truck shouted they were religious, the firing ceased, but by then two were dead.'' Sister Colette Hartman of Fond du Lac, who knew Courtney about 18 years and spent 27 years in Nicaragua, said nuns in Nicaragua told her by telephone that a group of about 60 Contras known as the Jorge Salazar group were involved. She said she was told the rebels used a rocket and a hand grenade in the ambush. Schmitz told reporters in Puerto Cabezas that the attack came after dark and he could not identify the assailants. ``I only know that a mine went off or a grenade and there was heavy shooting afterward,'' Schmitz said. ``We identified ourselves, but nobody came to the pickup.'' Jaime Arauz, one of two peasants detained by the army in the area of the attack, said they were kidnapped by a Contra group and were told the rebels were waiting to ambush an army convoy. Arauz spoke to The Associated Press and other news media in Puerto Cabezas on Tuesday. Sister Courtney, a Nicaraguan missionary for 15 years, is believed to be the first American killed in the 9-year-old Nicaraguan civil war since Contras killed Benjamin Linder in April 1987. Linder was a 27-year-old engineer from Portland, Ore.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Struggles Against Separatism in Two Republics
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met today with Lithuanian Communists in hopes of persuading them to reverse a decision to break with the federal Communist Party, but the talks reportedly ended in a deadlock. Meanwhile, party leaders in Estonia were meeting to consider a draft policy statement that favors independence for the republic and its Communist Party. A local journalist, Tarmu Tammerk, said the statement was expected to win approval during the Central Committee meeting today in Estonia's capital, Tallinn. The Lithuanian party voted 855-160 two weeks ago to split from the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, leading Gorbachev to summon party leaders for a meeting in Moscow. Lithuanian journalist Eduardas Potashinskas said a party member who was at the meeting described the mood as respectful but said the talks broke up after 5{ hours without a compromise. Gorbachev strongly opposes the Lithuanian decision to split from the national party, but he also has ruled out the use of force against the Baltic republic. In a speech on Christmas Day, Gorbachev noted that extraordinary measures, such as deployment of troops and tanks, have been used against ``hooligans'' in rioting in the republic of Uzbekistan and the disputed region of Nagorno-Karabakh. ``But in these conditions, when we have the participation of wide strata of the population, we have tried and are trying to use political means,'' he said, referring to the wide public support for Lithuania's independence movement. After that speech, the national party's Central Committee directed Gorbachev to visit Lithuania to try to heal the break. He is expected to go next week. Vida Laumenskaite, a secretary of Lithuania's pro-independent Sajudis group, said there were rumors Gorbachev would ask Lithuanians to suspend their action until a national Communist Party congress can be held in October. The congress is expected to redefine the party's role in Soviet society, to fall in line with Gorbachev's calls for the party to get out of day-to-day affairs and play more of an ideological role. Faced with the Lithuanian break, some dissenting Communists in the republic formed an alternate Central Committee that proclaims loyalty to Moscow and the Soviet Communist Party that Gorbachev heads.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Chief Reportedly Kidnaps Son of Presidential Adviser
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper said today that Pablo Escobar, a reputed leader of the Medellin cocaine cartel, has kidnapped the son of President Virgilio Barco's closest adviser. El Tiempo said it was the latest in a series of abductions aimed at pressuring the government to ends its crackdown on drug lords and raising money from ransom payments to make up for losses caused by the crackdown. A group of men contracted by Escobar abducted Alvaro Diego Montoya, the president of a financial services firm, as he left his office in Bogota on Dec. 20, El Tiempo reported. El Tiempo, Colombia's largest newspaper, said it obtained the information from sources at the presidential palace and at Montoya's company, Probolsa. A presidential press spokesman, reached by telephone today, said he had no information about the report. Montoya is the son of German Montoya, Barco's secretary general and considered the president's right-hand man. Last year, Montoya carried several messages to Barco from a lawyer representing the drug chiefs. In the messages, Escobar and other cartel leaders promised to abandon their multibillion-dollar business in exchange for a government amnesty, Montoya has said. The Barco administration said the offers were rejected. Montoya's son is one of 18 people, many of them belonging to Colombia's richest families, abducted by the cartel in the past three weeks, according to El Tiempo. A source quoted by the paper said the government had information tying the cartel to the kidnappings. The source said the abductions were in retaliation for Barco's war against drug traffickers. As part of the anti-drug campaign, police shot and killed Escobar's close associate, Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, in a Dec. 15 gunfight on Colombia's northern coast. A special police force is said to be hounding Escobar and has come close to catching him at least once. Authorities occupy several of the drug suspect's properties, which were raided shortly after the government began its crackdown Aug. 18. The crackdown began after traffickers assassinated a leading presidential candidate. Traffickers have responded to the government offensive with a terror campaign that has killed scores of people. The source quoted by El Tiempo said the Medellin cartel is using the kidnappings not only to pressure the government to call off its campaign but also to earn money. The newspaper did not say how much money the cartel had demanded in exchange for release of kidnap victims. The source reportedly said the cartel needs ransom money to solve a cash-flow problem caused by police raids on its facilities. ``Although it may seem hard to believe, the cartel is confronting a liquidity problem,'' the source was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEAD: 210 Killed in Pakistan's Worst Train Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE casualty figures. Pickup 4th graf pvs, `Pakistan radio...'
DOC.TEXT: A packed passenger train was switched onto the wrong track and plowed into a standing freight train early today, killing 210 people in the worst rail disaster in Pakistan's history, officials said. Many of the estimated 700 injured were trapped in mangled and derailed coaches of the 16-car passenger train. Army troops rushed to the scene in southern Pakistan and helped extricate victims from the wreckage. Railway officials said rescuers recovered 188 dead by this afternoon, but officials at the scene said there were 210 known dead. The death toll was likely to rise as troops with metal torches searched through the wreckage. Pakistan radio broadcast appeals for blood donations. The passenger train was packed beyond its 1,408-seat capacity when, traveling at more than 35 mph, it hit the empty freight train, said Muktar Ahmad Abassi, the regional traffic officer for Pakistan Railways. He said the engineer had no chance to brake. ``It was apparently a lineman's (switchman's) fault, who put the passenger train on the same track,'' said Abassi. The accident occurred 225 miles north of the port city of Karachi at Sukkur. The city's deputy administrative commissioner, Hazul Baksh, said its seven hospitals were overflowing with injured an that some of the injured were being moved to other cities. Sukkur's hospitals have about 300 beds in all. Baksh said hundreds of people had responded to the appeal for blood. Abassi said three cars of the passenger train, each seating 88 people, were destroyed and two were badly damaged. The passenger train was traveling south on a 500-mile trip from Multan to Karachi and approaching the village of Sangi shortly after midnight when an improperly set switch shunted it off onto a siding and into the parked 67-car freight train, he said. ``It's a disaster, and the worst rail accident in Pakistan's history,'' said Abassi. The country won independence from India in 1947. Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto ``expressed her deep sense of shock and grief over the tragic railway accident,'' according to the official news agency, Associated Press of Pakistan. It said she told her railway minister and other authorities to expedite rescue and medical aid, and start an immediate investigation. Ms. Bhutto had been scheduled to fly to Karachi today and was expected to add a stop at Sukkur. Pakistan's previous worst rail disaster was in 1958 when at least 150 people were killed as two trains collided near Gamber, in Punjab province. In April 1983, two passenger trains collided in China, killing 600 people and injuring more than 2,000. On Jan. 14, 1985, 428 people were killed in Ethiopia when a train derailed into a ravine.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Gather in Mail Bomb Case
DOC.TEXT: Authorities from three states investigating a series of mail bombs have been shown the high-tech tools the federal government is using in the case. A special computer network reserved for major cases and sophisticated laboratory tests, including procedures for DNA identification, were demonstrated Wednesday during a meeting of authorities from Atlanta, Savannah, Birmingham, Ala. and Jacksonville, Fla., said FBI spokesman Diader Rosario. It was the first meeting involving federal, state and local law enforcement representatives from all four cities in which mail bombs were received during a series of attacks in December that killed a federal judge and a civil rights lawyer. Those attending the meeting also were briefed on evidence gained from a public hotline set up to receive tips in the case, Rosario said. Rosario said today there will be further such meetings, but no date has been set for the next one. He said the FBI, which is coordinating the investigation, does not want to have the meetings too often. ``Every time you meet you pull people out of the field, where they can do more good,'' he said. Rosario said the investigation has not narrowed to any particular area, and still is in full swing in Georgia, Alabama and Florida. Robert Vance, a judge on the Atlanta-based 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, was killed Dec. 16 when a mail bomb exploded at his home near Birmingham, Ala. Two days later, Savannah Alderman Robert Robinson, an attorney who did work with the NAACP, was killed by a similar bomb. Authorities intercepted bombs sent to the 11th Circuit courthouse in Atlanta and an NAACP office in Jacksonville before they could explode. A letter to Atlanta television station WAGA-TV last week claimed a group calling itself Americans for a Competent Federal Judicial System was responsible for the bombs and threatened more violence. The letter writer expressed anger over crimes committed by blacks against whites and also made an apparent reference to a school desegregation case in DeKalb County. FBI agents searched DeKalb County schools during the Christmas holidays, looking for clues to the bomber and for bombs, according to news reports. The FBI and the school system have refused to comment on the reports. Georgia Gov. Joe Frank Harris said at a news conference Wednesday that he would be willing to post a reward for information in the case, if police ask him to do so. He said he has received no such requests.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Husband's Desperate Call to Police
With Double Shooting-Death
DOC.TEXT: Here is an edited transcript of the 10-minute conversation the night of Oct. 23 between state police dispatcher Gary McLaughlin and Charles Stuart, who allegedly had been abducted and shot along with his wife after leaving a birthing class at Brigham and Women's Hospital. Stuart was communicating on his automobile telephone as he and his wife lay wounded in the front seat of their car. Stuart's wife Carol and baby son Christopher, delivered by Caesarean section, both died.

``My wife's been shot, I've been shot. ...'' ``Where is this, sir?'' ``I have no idea, I'm off, I was just coming from Tremont ... Brigham and Women's Hospital.'' ``Try to give me an indication of where you might be, a cross street or anything else.'' ``Hello?'' ``Yes, go ahead.'' ``Hello. I got into the car at Huntington Avenue ... drove straight through Huntington Avenue.'' ``Where are you right now, sir, can you indicate to me?'' ``No, I don't know, I don't know, he drove us, he made us go to an abandoned area.'' ``OK, sir, can you see out the windows, can you tell me where you are, please?'' ``No. I don't know, I don't see any signs. Oh, God.'' ... ``What kind of car do you have, sir? What kind of vehicle do you have?'' ``Toyota Cressida.'' ``Toyota Cressida?'' ``Cressida. It's, it's a ...'' ``You're in the city of Boston, though?'' ``Yes.'' ``Can you give me any indication where you might be, any buildings?'' (Groans) ``No.'' ``Okay, has your wife been shot as well?'' ``Yes, in the head.'' ``In the head?'' ``Yes, I ducked down.'' ``How far, how long ago did you leave Brigham and Women's, sir, and what direction did you go?'' (Groans) ``Two minutes, three minutes ...'' ``OK, sir, bear with me now, stand by, stay on the phone with me.'' ``Should I try to drive or should I stay where I am?'' ``No. ... The people that shot you, are they in the area right there?'' ``No, they, they took off, they left.'' ``OK, can you look out, can you get out of the vehicle and look around to see where you are, sir? I'm trying to get some assistance to you.'' ``Should I drive up to the corner of the street?'' ``If you can drive, sir, without hurting yourself, yes, if you could. Just try to give me a cross street. If you can drive give me any street indication and stay there, I'll get someone right to you.'' ``I'll start the car. He took the keys but I have a spare set. Oh, man. I'm starting the car.'' ``OK, sir. What's your name, sir?'' ``Stuart, Chuck Stuart. Ahh, man.'' ``Bear with me, Chuck, I'm going to get someone to you, hang in with me, now.'' ``All right. ... I'm at a place, but I can't read it.'' ``Just try to read it, Chuck. Just calm down, just stay with me, I'm gonna get help to you, help is gonna be on the way.'' ``I'm coming up to a, an intersection, but there's no...'' ``What color is your car, buddy?'' ``Blue.'' ``Blue Toyota Cressida?'' ``Yeah, ahh!'' ``OK, Chuck, try to give me a street.'' ``I'm coming to an intersection.'' ``OK, Chuck, help's gonna be on the way, bear with me. Is your wife breathing?'' ``She's still gurgling. There's a busy street up ahead. Ahh, man. I can't see where I am.'' ``Bear, hang in with me, Chuck. Just try to give me any indication of where you might be, hospitals, if you see a building.'' ``I'm turning onto a busy street ... my lights are out.'' ``Chuck, just pull over, pull over, Chuck.'' ``Are you there?'' ``I'm here, Chuck.'' ``Oh. I'm driving with my lights off, I can't reach forward, it's too painful.'' ``Is it Francis Street, Chuck, are you near Francis Street?'' (unintelligible) ``OK, why don't you pull over. Is there someone there you can ask where you are?'' ``Ahh, I'm coming up a busy street. Oh, man, ahh!'' ``Hang in there with me, Chuck.'' ``I'm turning onto a busy street. I recognize where I am now, should I drive to the hospital?'' ``Just tell me what the, what the street is, Chuck.'' ``Ahh, man! I'm pulling over. Tremont Street.'' ``You're at Tremont?'' ``Oh, man, I'm gonna pass out.'' ``Hang in with me, Chuck. Tremont street where? Help's gonna be on the way. ``Chuck, Chuck ... Chuck?'' ``Yeah.'' ... ``Tremont Street where?'' ``I don't know. I'm in front of (unitelligible). Oh, man.'' ... ``I'm blanking out.'' ``You can't blank out on me, I need you, man. Chuck? Chuck?'' ... ``Oh, man, it hurts and my wife has stopped gurgling, she's stopped breathing.'' ``Chuck, I'm gonna get assistance to you, buddy. Open the door, talk to someone on the street.'' ``I'm gonna try to drive straight to the hospital.'' ``Can you drive?'' ``Ah! I'm trying.'' ... ``Are you driving now?'' ``Yeah, I'm driving.'' ``Can you indicate to me exactly where you might be? I got Tremont Street, we got assistance on the way to you.'' ``I gotta pull over.'' ``Is there anyone on the street, Chuck? Stop a passerby in the street so they can tell me where you are.'' ``Ahh!'' ``Chuck, pull over on the side of the street and talk to any passerby so I have an indication of where you are.'' ``I can't move. Oh, God.'' ``Chuck, can you see anyone on the street?'' ``My car died. Oh, man!'' ``Chuck, pull anyone over on the street, anyone you see on the street, pull over.'' ``I'm looking, I'm looking, there aren't that many people.'' ``OK, calm down, just hang in with me, I'm gonna have assistance right there to you.'' ... ``Chuck. Chuck? Can you give me anything. Just look out the window. Can you see anything?'' ``Ohh!'' (long pause) ``Chuck, can you hear me, Chuck? Chuck? ... Do you hear a siren? I can hear a siren. Chuck. Chuck, pick up the phone, Chuck. Chuck?'' (long pause) ``Chuck, can you hear me? Chuck ... Chuck, pick up the phone, I can hear you breathing there, Chuck, come on, buddy.'' (long pause) ``Chuck? I don't know on a definite location, we heard the siren, though. Chuck? ... Chuck Stuart, come on, Chuck, I can hear you breathing. Can you hear me, Chuck? Pick up the phone. ``Chuck, can you hear me, buddy? ... I need a little better location to find you right away. Come on, Chuck. Damn! Chuck? Hello Chuck, can you hear me?'' (long pause) (In the background other police officers can be heard discussing whether sirens can be heard. After more pleas for Chuck to respond the officers can be heard in the background ordering patrol cars to individually flick on their sirens so it can be determined which car is nearest the open phone line.) ``Chuck Stuart, stay with me buddy, I can still hear you moving. Can you pick up the phone, Chuck? Chuck Stuart, come on Chuck, can you pick up the phone? Chuck Stuart, are you there? Chuck? Hello, Chuck.'' (Long pause. Stuart is implored again to pick up the phone. Finally, he does.) ``I hear the police.'' ``Chuck!'' ``I hear the police.'' ``Chuck! Where are you, Chuck?'' ``Help, help. Get in touch with the state police, my wife and I've been shot.'' ``Chuck!'' ``Right here there's Boston police.'' ``Put the Boston police officer on the phone, Chuck.'' ``Boston, hello Boston. Hello?'' (Background voice calls ''We've located him!'') ``I don't want to terminate until someone can hear me. Want me to terminate, Sarge?'' (The tape becomes a jumble of voices and activity. Then Stuart can be heard.) ``Get my wife out.''

DOC.HEAD: Peace Corps Recruiting English teachers for Poland
DOC.TEXT: The Peace Corps announced today it is recruiting 60 teachers of English to train other teachers in Poland beginning in June and that 90 more instructors will be needed next year. ``We need very quickly to train 10,000 English teachers,'' said Paul Coverdell, director of the Peace Corps. He said the request for trained teachers of English as a foreign language originated with Poland's new regime and that a formal agreement is expected to be signed in February. The Peace Corps recently began recruiting English teachers to serve in Hungary, training other teachers. The job requirements are a degree in teaching English as a foreign language, a year's experience, U.S. citizenship and a willingness to serve abroad for two years.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Retreat From Soviet-Iran Border
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 16 grafs to UPDATE with protesters reported retreating. Pickup 20th pvs, `The unrest...
DOC.TEXT: Protesters in the republic of Azerbaijan began retreating from the Soviet-Iran border today after four days of violent attempts to reunite with with their Iranian brethren, a protest organizer said. ``The situation is stabilizing. People are gradually going home,'' said Yusif Samedoglu, a writer and leader of the Azerbaijani People's Front, which organized the protest. He spoke by telephone from Baku, the capital of Azerbaijan. The Azerbaijanis, who are largely Shiite Moslems, began demonstrating Sunday for unification with a region peopled by their ethnic kin in Iran. The protesters demanded an open border and the freedom to trade and cross the frontier, practices that were suspended by dictator Josef Stalin. Savili A. Perets, deputy director of the official news agency Azerinform, said in a telephone interview from Baku that the border area was calming down. He said Azerbaijan party chief Abdul-Rakhman Vezirov and other officials traveled to the protest area today to investigate. The KGB rushed border troop reinforcements to the area Wednesday to stop protesters from demolishing guard towers and security alarms. The disturbances along Azerbaijan's nearly 500-mile-long border with Iran were the latest flare-up in two years of ethnic unrest among Azerbaijanis, Armenians, Georgians, Abkhazians and other ethnic groups in the Soviet Caucasus region. More than 300 people have died nationwide in ethnic unrest in the past two years. Lt. Gen. Nikolai Britvin, head of the political department of the KGB's special border guard units, told the official Tass news agency Wednesday that one person was killed in a clash on the Soviet-Iran frontier, but he did not say when. He also did not say whether others were injured. Britvin said one Soviet citizen crossed the border into Iran and ``there were probably other crossings,'' but that there was no large-scale flight. The government daily Izvestia said some protesters were armed with pistols and hunting rifles, and it estimated damage from the rioting at more than $8.2 million. Tass said about 7,500 protesters destroyed guard observation towers, electronic alarm equipment and communications lines along the border when rioting broke out on Sunday.
