Izvestia said the turmoil stretched from the Azerbaijani enclave of Nakhichevan, sandwiched between Armenia and Iran, to the regions of Zangelansk and Pushkinsk and the Caspian Sea port of Lenkoran in Azerbaijan itself. It said unrest continued through Wednesday. Britvin told Tass, however, that the incidents lasted only through Tuesday and that the situation was ``gradually returning to normal.'' Nonetheless, he said border guard reinforcements were sent in with armored personnel carriers. Neither he nor Izvestia said how many guards were normally stationed along the frontier or how many reinforcements were dispatched. A KGB spokesman refused to comment today on the latest developments. The border disturbances threatened to complicate Soviet-Iranian relations, the Workers' Tribune newspaper said, noting the Iranians had lodged a protest of the unrest. But Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov said today, ``It's not a big international issue.'' The unrest began Dec. 4 when a crowd of Soviet Azerbaijanis gathered at the border with loudspeakers and called on their Iranian neighbors, both members of the same ethnic group and predominantly Shiite Moslems, to unify their regions, Izvestia reported. About 4 million ethnic Azerbaijanis live in the adjoining Iranian province of Azerbaijan, where Stalin briefly set up a puppet state during World War II before being forced by Western powers to withdraw in 1946. The Azerbaijanis are the only Soviet ethnic group who, like Iranians, are largely Shiite Moslems. Since the 1979 Islamic revolution in Iran, Soviet officials have expressed concern about Islamic fundamentalism creeping across the border.

DOC.HEAD: Pollution Expert Says Oil Danger Passed in Moroccan Spill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with pollution expert saying coastline out of danger, Iranian comment. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Morocco's coastline is no longer in danger of being spoiled by a huge oil spill, and nearly all the 19 million gallons of oil that gushed into the sea have dissolved, pollution experts said today. The Iranian tanker Khark 5, which began leaking oil after an explosion Dec. 19, had been towed 300 miles off the Moroccan coast by Wednesday night, said the Dutch salvage firm Smit Tak. The edge of the slick held its position today 20 miles off the oyster-farming community of Oualidyia, the official Maghreb Arab Presse agency said. Sailors laid floating barriers Wednesday, while helicopters sprayed chemicals on the greenish, 100-square-mile oil slick. ``The real danger to the Moroccan coast is over,'' Jean-Claude Sainnos, director of Mediterranean Marine Anti-Pollution Center in Valletta, Malta, said today. ``If the vessel had come ashore, that would have been a major catastrophe.'' Sainnos said more than 90 percent of the spill had dissolved in the relatively warm 60 degree water, had been broken up by waves, or dissolved by chemicals. Darko Domovic, a technical expert at the Anti-Pollution Center, said there was practically no danger of massive spoiling of Morocco's coast, although bits of oil could wash ashore over the next couple of months. ``There is very, very little oil left on the sea surface,'' said Domovic. ``What's left is an extremely thin sheen with patches of emulsified oil.'' Morocco threatened to sue Iran's national oil company and accused Smit Tak of reacting too slowly to the explosion that tore through the Khark 5's hull. Smit Tak, however, said its salvage operation was hampered because Morocco and Spain refused to let the tanker be towed near their coasts for emergency repairs. Instead, three tugboats were towing the 283,632-ton ship toward calmer waters near the Cape Verde islands, a 1,100-mile journey expected to take eight days. Iranian Oil Minister Gholamreza Aqazadeh said today that reports of environmental damage caused by the spill were exaggerated, and he said the ship met all safety specifications. The vessel, built in 1975, was damaged at least three times in Iraqi air strikes in the Persian Gulf during the Iran-Iraq war. The normal lifepsan of a supertanker is 15-20 years. Speaking on Tehran radio, Aqazadeh said a storm ripped a hole in one of the tanker's storage tanks, causing the explosion that started the leak. He said some oil from the damaged storage tank burned in the fire, while a ``limited amount'' leaked out. The Khark 5 was loaded with 72 million gallons of light Iranian crude when the explosion occurred 400 miles north of Las Palmas in the Canary Islands. As the oil crept toward the coast, the Moroccan government said it endangered fisheries, tourist beaches, a migratory bird reserve and in important breeding ground of pink flamingoes. Coast Guard Lt. Cmdr. Glenn Wiltshire, head of an oil spill strike force in Mobile, Ala., left Wednesday for Rabat to see what the United States could do to help, said Cmdr. John McElwain, a Coast Guard spokesman. Wiltshire will look into equipment needs, response tactics and possible cleanup operations, McElwain said in Washington. He said strike force teams in Alabama and San Francisco could be used in helping to deal with the spill. Dutch Television said authorities in the Netherlands had seized five Iranian-owned tankers over the past 14 months and prevented them from leaving Rotterdam until they underwent repairs. They included three sister ships of the Khark 5, according to the report, but none of the vessels was identified. The report said the vessels failed to meet international safety and environmental standards; it did not elaborate.

DOC.HEAD: Congressmen Happy Noriega Will Face U.S. Justice
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 3 grafs of Dodd reax after 5th graf, `Noriega will'
DOC.TEXT: Members of Congress hailed the surrender of Manuel Antonio Noriega as a major victory in the fight against drug traffickers, but one senator said today it ``could wind up being mere fluff'' unless U.S. demand for drugs is reduced. Noriega's peaceful surrender is ``a triumph for diplomacy and a triumph for justice,'' said Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass. THU. DOC.HEAD: Consolidated Sales *# *# *# *# *#
Goetz Wants To Interview Shooting Victim
DOC.TEXT: Subway shooter Bernhard Goetz says he'll agree to give a deposition in a $50 million lawsuit against him only if he can interview the plaintiff, one of the four young men he shot in 1984. The suit was filed on behalf of Darrell Cabey, who was paralyzed from the waist down by the shooting in a subway car. Cabey's lawyers say he also suffered brain damage and is mentally incompetent. ``I think all this mental vegetable business is to prevent Darrell Cabey from having any legal exposure,'' Goetz said. ``I'll be deposed after Cabey meets his legal obligations.'' One of Cabey's lawyers, William Kunstler, said Goetz is obligated under state law to give his deposition first since he is the defendant. In a legal notice filed Wednesday, Goetz said he wanted to interview Cabey Jan. 18. Kunstler said a hearing is scheduled Jan. 12 to determine if Goetz should be declared the loser in the lawsuit for failing to show up for his own deposition last month. Goetz has said in court papers that he has been unable to appear in court because he had major cancer surgery last month and was undergoing radiation treatments. He would not specify what type of cancer he has. Cabey and three companions, all teen-agers at the time, were shot by Goetz when they approached him in a subway car on Dec. 22, 1984. Goetz said they intended to rob him; they said they were panhandling. Goetz, 42, was acquitted of attempted murder but convicted of violating weapons laws, for which he served eight months in prison. Goetz told The Associated Press he will not be deposed until he is allowed to interview Cabey. ``I'm taking the position that I have some rights under this legal system,'' Goetz said. Kunstler dismissed Goetz' action as ``a last-ditch attempt at avoiding coming to the Bronx to be interrogated by hostile lawyers.'' Goetz is aware that Cabey is mentally incompetent, Kunstler said. ``He should know. He paralyzed him,'' Kunstler said. ``He brain damaged him.''

DOC.HEAD: Washington County Passes Unusual Health Law To Fight Crack Houses
DOC.TEXT: Operators of crack houses in King County must run their businesses in accordance with public health rules or face huge fines, in an unusual legal move that officials hope will close down the drug dens. The ruling, approved Wednesday by the King County Board of Health, requires crack house operators ``to submit a plan of operation for reducing health and safety hazards'' or face a $10,000-a-day fine. The hazards listed in the ruling include drug use and associated health effects, exposure to toxic chemical fumes, the spread of sexually transmitted diseases through prostitution, violence and neighborhood blight. ``It is just another tool we can use to get at crack houses,'' said Ron Sims, King County councilman and a Board of Health member. Under the ruling, police would identify a crack house and inform the Seattle-King County Health Department. The department would then notify the owner or operator by registered mail that a plan to reduce health risks must be submitted within 10 days and be accompanied by a $100 fee. The board must approve of the plan or the penalty applies. King County police and the county prosecutor's office supported the ruling, although they had urged delaying passage so it could be studied for flaws. Robert Stier, senior deputy King County prosecutor in the civil division, said he had never seen similar legislation. Although King County encompasses Seattle, the regulation does not apply in Seattle city limits because the city council, not the county council, acts as the governing body for the Seattle portion of the health department.

DOC.HEAD: Overcrowding Forces New York City Hospitals To Cancel Elective Admissions
DOC.TEXT: City hospitals have become so crowded that they have suspended elective admissions and the state has provided them with lists of where the few available beds are. ``This is the first time we've used the system to effect a transfer of patients from an overcrowded hospital to one with open beds,'' Frances Tarlton, a Health Department spokeswoman, said Wednesday. The state acted after a computer analysis showed that more than 900 patients could not be placed in city hospitals Wednesday because of lack of beds, she said. ``We have identified 230 open beds and sent that information to hospitals,'' Tarlton said. The city's Health and Hospitals Corp. reacted to the influx by canceling elective admissions, said HHC spokeswoman Suzanne Halpin. Early January is traditionally a crowded time in hospitals because it is flu season and because many people put off elective surgery until after the holidays, Tarlton said. The problem is particularly acute in the boroughs of Queens and the Bronx, she said. Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx, for example, had 50 people waiting for admission. Tarlton emphasized that the state has not ordered the transfer of any patients. Monitoring of available hospital beds and patients waiting in the emergency room began last year. Wednesday ``was the first time since the system was put into effect it became actually necessary to identify hospitals able to accept transfers,'' she said today. ``We're going to continue to monitor the system and continue to try to help the hospitals redistribute the patient load as long as its necessary,'' Tarlton said. Dr. Donald C. Meyer, executive director of the Doctors Council, praised the action by state Health Commissioner Dr. David Axelrod but called it long overdue. ``We've had a crisis for quite some time. But like anything else in New York, we have a crisis for a while and we get used to it,'' Meyer said. On any given day, there are about 600 people awaiting admission to New York City hospitals. But on Wednesday, the number was closer to 900, said Tarlton. Meyer said private hospitals are being asked to take some of the patients, but he acknowledged that some of those hospitals are also overcrowded. Many of the patients being transferred are poor or have no health insurance, making it less likely that a private hospital would accept the patients, Meyer said. Transferring patients is only a short-term solution, Meyer said. ``One of our major problems is that we have the beds available but we can't get enough nurses,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Hastened Delivery of Decade's First Baby For TV Show Prompts Probe
DOC.TEXT: State regulators are said to be investigating a doctor who speeded up delivery of a baby, plopped the infant into a Christmas stocking and dashed to a TV studio next door to display her as the county's first newborn of the '90s. The Board of Medical Quality Assurance opened a formal investigation Wednesday, the Los Angeles Times reported Thursday, citing unidentified sources. Myra Kristine Palmer was officially delivered 15 seconds after midnight by Dr. Charles Wesley Turner Jr. and presented a short time later on a nationally televised religious service led by the Rev. Ralph Wilkerson. Turner, 64, insisted neither the mother, Brigitte Palmer, nor her 6-pound, 12-ounce baby girl was harmed by his hastening of the delivery at Turner's Covenant Birthing Center in Orange County. The doctor said the mother went into labor naturally. Turner said Wilkerson, pastor of the next-door Melodyland Christian Center, had asked months ago if he could provide a newborn for the New Year's Eve service. ``We had the mother push at 11:59,'' Turner said. ``I put the forceps on and pulled the infant out. We had her at 15 seconds after midnight. ... I used the forceps because I wanted to have the first baby in the New Year. ``I was highly jubilant,'' he said. ``The congregation yelled and screamed and applauded. And everybody wanted to see the baby.'' Mrs. Palmer, 25, said she ``felt felt a little funny because he took her and ran off with her. But he wanted to have her on TV. It was a special feeling for everyone to see the baby.'' Dr. Roger Schlesinger, president of the Orange County Obstetrics and Gynecological Society, said he believes Turner took a risk in taking the newborn outside. ``I don't think I'd take my newborn out of a hospital,'' Schlesinger said. ``Any newborn baby requires some degree of observation. Some have low blood sugars. Some convulse.'' ``Babies are pretty hardy,'' he said. ``Most do well. But some don't. So I guess he was playing the odds a bit.'' Turner, who said he has delivered more than 18,000 babies in his 40-year career, said: ``I don't think there's anything wrong with having the first baby of the New Year. And the baby was delivered safely. And I see nothing wrong with taking the baby and showing it to the 4,000'' people at Melodyland. In 1984, the state medical board accused Turner of illegally prescribing dangerous drugs and placed his license on five years' probation. Turner pleaded no contest to a related misdemeanor and was placed on three years' criminal probation and fined $15,000. In 1988, he was named in a 1988 wrongful death lawsuit after a child he delivered at Santa Ana Hospital Medical Center died immediately after birth, the Times reported. The suit alleges Turner caused the death by failing to perform a timely Caesarean section. Turner denied any wrongdoing in the case Wednesday. He remains on the staff at Santa Ana but lost the privilege to practice obstetrics there, the Times said.

DOC.HEAD: Political Parties Plead for Postponement of Elections
With AM-Romania, Bjt
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The emerging political parties may be split on platforms and ideologies, but they are united on one point: the proposed April 17 election date is too soon for a nation awakening from decades of despotic Communist rule. The task of reviving democratic traditions stifled since 1947 is complicated by the fact that none of the half-dozen parties planning to contest the elections has the basic tools for a successful campaign. Until three weeks ago, typewriters had to be registered so that any dissenting texts could be traced back to their authors, who in turn could be punished by dictator Nicolae Ceausescu's feared security police. The machines are a rarity. The few telephones available are always busy. Westerners asking about the availability of photocopiers, computers and teletypes draw laughter. The Christian Peasants' Party, one of Romania's most dominant political forces before being forced to disband after the 1947 Communist takeover, is typical of how the emerging democratic parties stand a little more than three months before the planned polls. ``We're lucky, we have four typewriters,'' said Anca Dobrota, a volunteer secretary at the party's headquarters. ``Unfortunately, only three are working.'' Ms. Dobrota said that her party, which set up operations Wednesday at what was a district Communist Party building, had two telephones, ``and they are busy all the time.'' She had to shout to make herself heard above the voices emanating from hundreds of people crowding rooms, halls and stairways of the three-story building and discussing politics with the explosive vehemence born of 41 years of repression. ``The Social Democrats are as bad as the Communists!'' shouted one octogenarian. His aged friend nodded. ``There's no point in all of this!'' he shouted back. ``The National Salvation Front is going to win anyway.'' Others agreed that the Front _ the interim body running the country since Ceausescu's overthrow Dec. 22 and his execution three days later _ likely would win early elections because of its high profile and control of the mass media. ``We don't have access to television or to the newspapers, and so, we do not have contact with the people,'' said Niculaie Costel, a spokesman for the Democratic Party of Romania. ``In this way, the front can control the opposition, and a large part of the communist hierarchy will be re-elected, and that will be a catastrophe.'' Others disagree that the Front poses a Communist threat, pointing to the de facto dissolution of the Communist Party in the wake of Ceausescu's downfall. But members and officials of several different parties all agreed the Front has unfair advantage and that its high profile, coupled with the lack of resources available to other parties, threatens the concept of free and fair elections. ``If the Front truly wants to promote democracy, they have to understand that April is too soon,'' for elections, said Ion Puiu, the 72-year-old vice president of the Peasants' Party. Some of his aged counselors nodded in agreement. Party official Vicente Zagun shared that view outside Puiu's office, referring to the poor communications in a country where road and rail travel are near impossible in winter. ``It is very difficult to organize by April,'' Zagun said. ``We have no way of communicating with our sister organizations across the country, and have little access to newspapers, radio and television.'' ``As a matter of fact, the Front's National Council is sure to win, unless the elections are postponed, at least until August,'' said Zagun, 73, seated near a table crowded with people _ nearly all of them in their 70s or 80s _ filling out membership forms. Zagun acknowledged concerns that many supporters of his party are elderly people who were members before 1947, and he suggested that also could hurt its chances at the polls. ``We want to be a party for the young, but the young people don't know what democracy means because they grew up in a dictatorship,'' he said, alluding to the 24-year Ceausescu era, and the 17 years under his Communist predecessor, Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej. Youths disagree that they know little of democracy, noting that university students were a main force behind the December revolution that toppled Ceausescu. But political movements representing almost exclusively young people also appear ill-prepared for April elections. At a Bucharest night school Thursday, several dozen people were crammed into a room that is the temporary headquarters of the Romanian Ecological Movement, discussing whether or not to field candidates. Outside, workers replaced glass doors shattered by fighting just 12 days ago. ``It is so stupid to be wasting time on this debate!'' shouted organizer Dorina Enescu. ``We don't even have time to organize, we have no funds, we have no telephone. `We have nothing.''

DOC.HEAD: People In The News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: A new traffic headache is in store for Southern Californians _ a Giblock. That's what happens when state transportation officials close a freeway so a film crew can shoot a Mel Gibson movie. This weekend, four miles of the Terminal Island Freeway will be closed for filming of ``Air America,'' an action movie in which Gibson and Robert Downey Jr. play pilots for the CIA's secret airline. Motorists won't get a glimpse of the star of the ``Mad Max'' and ``Lethal Weapon'' films in exchange for the inconvenience. ``He's not even going to be there,'' said California Department of Transportation spokeswoman Margie Tiritilli. ``It's just extraneous shots they're going to shoot, so we don't want gawkers and that type of thing.''

Work has begun on a new house for Mickey Spillane to replace the one destroyed by Hurricane Hugo. The mystery writer has joked that his former home ``looked like Godzilla took a walk all through that place.'' Spillane and his wife, Jane, watched the start of work Wednesday while stakes were planted and the areas of the rooms were roped off. ``We're going way up on stilts. It's going to be a bigger house but with more of a country flavor and facing the water,'' Mrs. Spillane said. The author has said he waited 19 years to write his latest book, ``The Killing Man,'' because ``I was doing OK and didn't really need the money.'' ``After (Hurricane Hugo), I needed the money very badly,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: Michael J. Fox says his infant son will have a regular, conventional upbringing _ like his own. ``He'll have a fairly stable future,'' the 28-year-old actor says in this Sunday's Parade magazine. ``Not one where the schoolyard talk is whose father grossed $8 million on his last picture. I hope he'll grow up in New England somewhere. I want a more accessible lifestyle _ for him and for us.'' Fox said that when he became a star with television's ``Family Ties'' and the movie ``Back to the Future,'' people he knew casually felt free to ask him if he would lend them $50,000. ``But my mother stuttered and stammered over whether I'd autograph a `Family Ties' mug for the Ladies Auxiliary tea. I've always been really impressed by that. They taught me to have respect for people,'' he said.

A producer is suing Ron Kovic, the Vietnam veteran whose autobiography was made into the film ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' contending the author sold him the movie rights and then failed to help make the film. Mel Goldberg, in a lawsuit filed Wednesday in Superior Court, alleges Kovic sold him the film rights to the book in 1985 and agreed to put Goldberg in touch with Hollywood figures such as actors and potential financiers. Goldberg contends Kovic breached the contract by never setting up meetings and failing to allow renewal of the movie option. He is seeking $1 million in general damages and unspecified punitive damages. Telephone calls to Kovic were not immediately returned. ``Born of the Fourth of July,'' starring Tom Cruise as the young soldier who returns from Vietnam as a paraplegic, was released last month by Universal Pictures.

Manfred Rommel, mayor of Stuttgart, West Germany, and son of World War II Gen. Erwin Rommel, the ``Desert Fox,'' will be made an honorary Commander of the Order of the British Empire. Rommel's award is ``in recognition of his long and valuable services to Anglo-German relations,'' the Foreign Office said Thursday. The 60-year-old mayor has promoted reconciliation since World War II and encouraged a sister-city relationship between Stuttgart and Cardiff, Wales. He also assisted British architecture by encouraging James Stirling, Stuttgart's art gallery designer.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A longer version moved on the sports wire.
DOC.TEXT: Chucky Mullins, a University of Mississippi football player paralyzed by a broken neck suffered in a game this past season, has undergone surgery to remove pressure from a nerve that controls breathing. Doctors as Baptist Memorial Hospital in Memphis said the surgery, performed Tuesday, could help Mullins' breathing but is unlikely to help him regain any movement. Mullins, who has been paralyzed from the shoulders down since the Oct. 28 game, was reported doing well after the surgery. ``I'm not real optimistic that it's going to change a whole lot, but if we didn't do it then we'd never know,'' said Dr. Clarence Watridge. Watridge said the surgery removed pieces of two vertebrae and some bone fragments from his spinal cord. Doctors said the surgery could help Mullins get off the ventilator that has helped him breathe.

DOC.HEAD: Former West German Foreign Minister Dies at Age 79
DOC.TEXT: Gerhard Schroeder, former foreign minister and a co-founder of the country's conservative Christian Democratic Union, has died at the age of 79. Schroeder died of heart and kidney complications Jan. 1 at his home in the town of Kampen on the island of Sylt off the northern coast of West Germany, said his wife, Brigitte. Born Sept. 11, 1910 in the southwestern German city of Saarbruecken, Schroeder studied law, philosophy and history in Berlin and Bonn before receiving his law degree in 1932. In 1939, he began practice as an attorney before being drafted into the German army, where he reached the rank of sergeant. Schroeder was captured by the British during World War II, and was freed after the war in 1945. He was among the founders of the conservative Christian Democratic Union party in Hamburg and a leading member of the party council. In 1949, Schroeder was voted into the first West German parliament as a deputy from the Duesseldorf district of Mettmann. He remained a member of parliament until he retired from politics in 1980. From 1953 to 1961, Schroeder served as interior minister under West Germany's first chancellor, Konrad Adenauer. Schroeder, a strong supporter of close ties with the United States, was awarded an honorary doctorate by the University of Maryland in 1959. In 1961, he became foreign minister under Adenauer, a post he kept when Ludwig Erhard took over as chancellor in 1963. When the ``great coalition'' of Christian Democrats and the leftist Social Democratic Party formed a new government in 1966, Schroeder was appointed defense minister. Three years later, when a coalition of the Social Democrats and the business-minded Free Democrats under then Chancellor Willy Brandt took over the government, Schroeder's career as a cabinet minister ended. However, he remained a member of parliament until his retirement in 1980. An active member of the Luthern Church, Schroeder served as president of its working council. He also was president of the West German Society of Photography from 1954 to 1978. Besides his wife, Schroeder is survived by two daughters and a son.

CHICAGO _ Secretary of State Jim Edgar announces that Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. has agreed to pay Illinois a record $1.3 million in administrative fines for securities violations. ``Any company that violates the integrity of the marketplace must compensate Illinois residents for its wrongdoing,'' Edgar said in a statement announcing the largest penalty for such a violation in state history. Slug AM-Drexel-Illinois. By Business Writer David Dishneau. New material, should stand.

DOC.HEAD: Female Alderman Loses Fight For Gender-Neutral Title
DOC.TEXT: An alderman's one-woman campaign for a gender-neutral political label has been defeated for the third time, forcing her to rethink her title fight. ``It didn't have a chance,'' said Evelyn G. Chesky. ``I think the board (name) has to be labeled sexist even though that's strong. It's a definite gender.'' Chesky's measure to change the name of government to City Council instead of the Board of Aldermen was defeated 9-6 Tuesday. Two years ago the proposal lost 12-3, and a year ago it failed 9-5. After four years on the 15-member board, Chesky said her cause has drawn ``mostly ridicule in a nice way. It's like they get a kick out of putting me on for something like this.'' Alderman Francis E. Rogers said he doesn't see any reason to switch names. ``There's no gender gap per se in the fact that it's by charter `aldermen' and so be it,'' he said. He said female members can be called ``alderwoman'' if they want, but the board should keep the name it has had since 1873. Three women serve on the board. One voted against the name change, which needed 10 votes to pass, saying she wanted to keep the traditional name. But Chesky said the old name hampers the image of the board, which saw its first female member in 1926. Chesky said she had hoped the issue would pass this time. ``I even went for the symbolism of the last decade and going in the next century and all that,'' she said. On Thursday, Chesky said she does not know whether she'll pursue her title fight for a fourth time.

DOC.HEAD: Independent Medical Team to Decide If Honecker Can be Jailed
With AM-East Germany
DOC.TEXT: An independent medical team has been asked to determine if ousted Communist leader Erich Honecker is fit to be jailed while he awaits possible charges of corruption in office, it was reported Thursday. Honecker, 77, underwent gall bladder surgery in August, and he has been described as incapacitated by the illness. A decision is expected soon as to whether he could sustain imprisonment, the official ADN news agency said. It also disclosed that the security cordon imposed around the opulent Wandlitz residential compound where Honecker lives was removed several weeks ago because ``no legal grounds were established'' on which to detain him. An earlier and very brief report from ADN had said simply that the house arrest of Honecker had been lifted but did not specify when. The Wandlitz complex is being converted to a care center for handicapped adults, and Honecker will have to be moved to some other location before the facility opens in February, government spokesman Wolfgang Meyer has said. A parliamentary commission overseeing the corruption investigation of Honecker and other top officials of his disgraced regime named a group of independent doctors to determine his physical condition, ADN said. He has been living in seclusion since being forced to step down from the Communist Party leadership Oct. 18 under pressure from massive pro-democracy demonstrations and an exodus of skilled young workers to the West. East German officials announced in December that because of his illness, Honecker had been placed under house arrest amid allegations of massive corruption in the former government. The house arrest came at the same time seven former Communist Party Politburo members were jailed pending corruption investigations against them. The investigations are continuing. Opposition groups have accused the former leaders of extravagance while the economy declined and East Germans were forced to make do with bare essentials. On Wednesday, a West German newspaper reported that Lutheran and Catholic church leaders had offered to house Honecker in church facilities for the elderly or at a monastery to protect him from enraged citizens.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Dispatches Powell to Panama, Thanks Pope for Help
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new 8th graf, However, Pentagon, with Williams saying size of force little changed
DOC.TEXT: President Bush dispatched the nation's top military officer to Panama today to plan further U.S. troop withdrawals and called Pope John Paul II to thank the Vatican for its help in persuading Manuel Antonio Noriega to surrender to American authorities. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush was ``gratified this operation was completed in such a successful fashion.'' Fitzwater said Bush had called the pope ``to thank him for the distinguished efforts of the Vatican and the papal nuncio in Panama.'' ``The pope expressed his humanitarian concerns for the people of Panama. Bush assured the pope that General Noriega will be treated to all the protections of U.S. law and would receive a fair trial,'' the spokesman said. Noriega turned himself in to U.S. authorities Wednesday night after leaving the protection of the Vatican embassy, where he had holed up for 10 days. He was flown to Homestead Air Force Base near Miami and held for arraignment late today on drug-trafficking charges. Fitzwater said Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, was heading for Panama to work with Gen. Maxwell Thurman, commander of U.S. troops in Panama, to help speed up further withdrawal of forces. The spokesman said that some 2,000 troops have now been brought home of the 26,000 that were in Panama on Dec. 20, the day of the invasion that toppled Noriega's government. About half already were stationed there. However, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said the total number of troops in Panama was little changed because military police and civil affairs specialists have replaced some combat units. Fitzwater said Noriega was handcuffed briefly after he was taken into custody, read his constitutional rights in Spanish and examined by two U.S. military doctors on the C-130 cargo plane that took him to Florida. The doctors found ``no discernible abnormalities'' and reported that Noriega appeared to be in good health, Fitzwater said. The spokesman said that four Panamanians remain sheltered in the Vatican embassy in Panama City. He said U.S. troops will continue to maintain a vigil outside the building while they remain inside. ``We would expect to question them and ascertain their situation just as we have others who have left the nunciatura (embassy) in the past,'' Fitzwater said. He said Bush's discussion with the pope was brief. The president also called Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney to discuss the Noreiga apprehension and to thank Canada for supporting the United States at the United Nations, which voted 75-20 last week to condemn the U.S. invasion. Fitzwater said Bush, who announced Noriega's arrest on nationwide television Wednesday night, ``feels very pleased ... he's fairly upbeat about the entire situation.'' But the president was staying out of the public eye today, and Fitzwater said Bush and other White House officials would be careful about what they say lest they prejudice Noriega's trial. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, appearing earlier on CBS, said the United States did not strike a deal with Noriega. He explained Noriega's surrender this way: ``I think he saw the handwriting on the wall.'' He said Noriega's decision to leave the Vatican embassy clears up a host of legal questions that could have complicated his prosecution. ``We have a good case,'' Thornburgh said on NBC. ``If we can make it better, we won't hesitate to do so.'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, also appearing on CBS, said Gens. Powell and Thurman would work to ``develop a plan for withdrawing those troops (sent to Panama) over the next several weeks.'' Cheney called Noriega's surrender ``the icing on the cake'' for Operation Just Cause, the military invasion the United States mountedon Dec. 20 to drive Noriega from power. Bush said Wednesday night that all his objectives in ordering the troops to Panama ``have now been acheived.'' Bush said the remaining U.S. troops in Panama will be withdrawn ``as quickly as the local situation will permit.'' Although Thurman stressed Wednesday night that no deals had been made, administration officials said the United States promised Noriega that he would receive a fair trial and would not be prosecuted under a new federal law allowing the death penalty for ``drug kingpins.'' The United States also agreed to meet three last-minute conditions by Noriega, the officials said: that he be allowed to make a few phone calls; that his decision be held secret until his arrest; and that he be allowed to wear his uniform. Bush said in a nationally televised announcement that the United States ``is committed'' to provide Noriega a fair trial. ``Nevertheless,'' Bush added, ``his apprehension and return to the United States should send a clear signal that the United States is serious in its determination that those charged with promoting the distribution of drugs cannot escape the scrutiny of justice.'' Bush said he had four objectives in ordering the invasion: safeguarding the lives of Americans, helping to restore democracy, protecting the integrity of the Panama Canal and bringing Noriega to justice. ``All of these objectives have now been achieved,'' He declared. He left the briefing room without answering questions. Noriega's return to the United States ended a two-year effort by the United States to bring him to justice and eliminated the source of what Bush called the major frustration of his first 11 months in office. But it opened the book on a whole new set of legal problems. U.S. legal authorities have been studying secret documents this past month on Noriega's long tenure as a CIA and Drug Enforcement Administration informant. They expect he might try to derail his prosecution by seeking disclosure of information that would be embarrassing to Bush _ a former CIA director _ and the United States. Bush several days ago said he was concerned that Noriega might try to ``blindside'' the legal process with such demands; but he said he wanted him brought to justice in a U.S. court anyway. If convicted on all charges, Noriega could face up to 145 years in prison and more than $1.1 million in fines. Bush praised Vatican officials for ``their evenhanded, statesmanlike assistance in recent days.'' Administration sources said the United States did not deal directly with Noriega at any time, and that all negotiations were conducted between the former military leader and church officials. Presidential spokesman Fitzwater said Bush was notified at about 6 p.m. EST by national security adviser Brent Scowcroft that Noriega was ``willing to give himself up.'' Even then, Fitzwater said, ``we could not be sure it would actually occur.'' He said Bush was notified by Defense Secretary Cheney at about 9 p.m. that Noriega had strolled out of the Vatican embassy and was in custody. At 9:30 p.m., the plane carrying Noriega back to the United States took off. Bush paid a special tribute to ``those servicemen who were wounded and to the families of those who gave their lives. Their sacrifice has been a noble cause and will never be forgotten.'' Twenty-three U.S. servicemen were killed and more than 300 injured in the invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Musical `Barnum' Folds its Tent in London
DOC.TEXT: ``Barnum,'' the musical about the life of P.T. Barnum, has closed after 11 performances and losses of $2.4 million, the producers said Thursday. The show, a revival of the original 1981, suffered scathing reviews, dwindling audiences and technical difficulties. The production, staged under a big top tent in west London with a 25-member cast and 22-piece orchestra, was due to tour 20 British towns in the summer after its London run. ``Barnum'' starred Peter Duncan, who trained for months to perform tightrope walking, stilt dancing and juggling. ``It is very sad but the ax dropped,'' Duncan said. ``The receivers were there, these men in suits came in saying `You can't take anything away.' It was the final insult.'' Michael Fontaine of LMC Entertainments, the show's producers, confirmed the company had been placed in receivership.

DOC.HEAD: Rights Group Says Administration Disregards Human Rights
DOC.TEXT: A human rights group Thursday accused the Bush administration of ``widespread disregard for human rights,'' saying it was soft in its response to the crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in China and an apologist for military abuses in El Salvador, Guatemala and the Philippines. The two-volume report by Human Rights Watch did say there were ``bright spots'' in President Bush's rights policies toward Eastern Europe, South Africa and Burma, but criticizied the administration's dealings in most of the 50 nations covered. ``Unfortunately, our review of the public positions taken by the Bush administration during its first year reveals a widespread disregard for human rights,'' the report said. ``Its insistance on seeing the world in geopolitical terms, and other priorties, gave rise to a striking silence on abuses in many countries, and a frequent refusal to adjust U.S. policy in light of those abuses.'' However, the report said it would be premature to make a final judgment on the administration's policy because it's so early in the president's term. The State Department said it had no immediate comment. The administration ``imposed the minimum sanctions'' on China after hundreds of people were killed to crush a pro-democracy movement, the report said. It criticized a secret meeting between Chinese officials and National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft and Lawrence Eagleburger, deputy secretary of state. ``The administration thus made clear that the killing and imprisonment of pro-democracy demonstrators would have no material impact on its dealings with the Chinese leadership,'' the report said. Human Rights Watch said the U.S. policy toward El Salvador also showed a disregard for human rights. ``Despite reduced fears that leftist advances in Central America would provide a beachhead for Soviet expansionism, the administration persisted in acting as apologist for abuses committed by the Salvadoran military in its war with leftist rebels,'' the report said. U.S. officials, the report said, badgered a witness who implicated the Salvadoran military in the November killing of six Jesuit priests and two of their employees. The administration earlier denied similar allegations. The United States provides El Salvador with millions of dollars in economic and military aid in its 10-year-old war with leftist rebels. Human Rights Watch said the administration strengthened ties to the Guatemalan military ``although political killings increased dramatically'' and ``refrained from criticizing widespread killings'' in the Philippines. In addition, the group said, the administration has ``all but stopped public comment'' on human rights issues in the Soviet Union. The ``silence seems to be based in large part on new political considerations _ the fear that pressing for human rights might weaken (Mikhail) Gorbachev,'' it said. In what the group called ``bright spots,'' it said the Bush administration ``has begun a welcome break from the policies of its predecessor'' regarding South Africa by calling for an end to the state of emergency, the freeing of political prisoners and the abolition of ``various legislative pillars of apartheid.'' In Burma, the administration was credited with playing a constructive role after the 1988 crackdown on a pro-democracy movement. The rights group said it was a ``positive development'' that the administration did not seek to renew military aid for the Contra rebels fighting the leftist Nicaragua government. However, it said, ``the administration continued past policy of refusing to condemn Contra abuses.'' The administration also was criticized for ``largely ignoring abuses'' in areas that don't attract much U.S. public attention such as executions by government forces in Sudan, mass expulsions in Mauritania and the purge of government opponents in Malawi. Human Rights Watch is a New York-based group that monitors and promotes human rights world-wide.

DOC.HEAD: Bright and Brief
DOC.TEXT: An 18-foot statue of Paul Bunyan, that giant lumberjack of lore, and his blue ox, Babe, has become the center of a controversy of an appropriately grand scale. The 8-ton concrete-and-steel work, which has graced the Lake Bemidji waterfront for more than a half-century, was called ``tacky'' by an art critic in a Dec. 13 column in The Daily Pioneer. Since then the paper has been deluged with letters for and against the figures. Paul and Babe were built in 1937 by the local Rotary Club with $200 worth of materials. The labor, at 60 cents an hour, cost $442.20. In the newspaper column, sculptor Kent Nerburn, who holds a doctorate in theology and art, called the artwork ``the well-meaning gropings of a group of fine civic-minded men with plaster, chicken wire and trowels, creating objects for a simpler time with a simpler vision.'' ``By featuring the happy trowelings of bygone Rotarians as the centerpiece of our community, we are building a monument to ourselves as naive rustics,'' Nerburn wrote. ``There's probably been a letter a day ... ever since he wrote the thing. Some of them are indignant, some are humorous, some are off-the-wall,'' said Pioneer Managing Editor John Ainley, who joined the fray by writing a column he described as ``pro-Paul, pro-Babe.'' One Nerburn dissenter, Cliff Miller of Lake George, is a logger who came down the Schoolcraft River with the last log drive into Bemidji. He said he likes having the statue of Paul and Babe looking over the lands they might have logged. Stuart Desjarlait of Red Lake wrote that Paul and Babe have overstayed their welcome and called them ``a symbol of destruction of our forest and wildlife.'' Nerburn, who directs an oral history project at Red Lake, said he is surprised by the outpouring of opinion. ``I'm hard-pressed to take Paul and Babe seriously as symbols,'' he said. ``I can take them seriously as sculptures because they are so unbelievably abominable.''

At last, newspaper consumers who won't complain about the ink rubbing off on them. Officials demonstrated a new use for old newspaper Wednesday by showing it off as barnyard bedding for animals in the state's prison agriculture program. Cheaper than straw and hay, shredded newsprint is less dusty and far more absorbent than traditional barnyard materials, Department of Corrections officials said during a demonstration at Jones Farm. When mixed with manure, newspapers decompose quickly. Surplus newspaper is available at little or no cost and eliminates the need for the state prison farm system to grow its own straw and hay, the land for other crops, the officials said. The officials also plan to use newspaper shredders at Skillman Fram and Bayside farm. In all, the state farms about 10,000 acres through its prison agriculture program. The change will mean the three farms can reduce their waste by about 1.5 tons a day.

DOC.HEAD: Northwest Airlines Plane Lands Safely After Dropping Engine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-7, bgng `Flight 5....' with 3 grafs to DELETE erroneous FAA information and show flight was nonstop and UPDATE with NTSB talking to crew. INSERTS two grafs after 17th graf, `Gibbons said...' with NTSB quote about search for the missing engine.
DOC.TEXT: A Northwest Airlines jetliner dropped one of its three engines while in flight over northern Florida before landing safely today, officials said. There were no injuries reported aboard the Boeing 727, said Northwest spokesman Bob Gibbons at the airline's headquarters in Eagan, Minn. ``The plane turned around, landed at Tampa without any problem at all, 139 customers, and we're working now to book them on other airlines to move them along,'' Gibbons said. Flight 5 took off from Miami shortly after 8 a.m. EST bound nonstop for Minneapolis-St. Paul, Gibbons said. The plane lost its No. 3 engine at about 9:35 a.m., said Arlene Salac of the Federal Aviation Administration's regional office in Atlanta. Gibbons said the engine on the right side of the fuselage dropped off over the Cross City, Fla., area, a sparsely populated section that includes forests and marshlands west of Gainesville and southeast of Tallahassee. National Transportation Safety Board officials said they asked the crew for information that could help pinpoint where the engine landed. Boeing officials in Seattle said they would send someone from their Miami office to assist with the investigation if Northwest asks for help. Tom Cole, spokesman for Boeing Commercial Airplanes, said 727s are designed so an engine will break away if necessary. ``They are designed to fall off in cases of extreme vibration in order to protect the airplane, so the plane won't be damaged if the engine breaks apart or so engine won't shake the airplane so hard it causes a loss of control.'' All three engines are mounted in the rear of the plane, one in the tail section and the other two on either side of the fuselage, Gibbons said. The engine separation caused no other structural damage to the plane, Gibbons said. ``There were no problems with control, pressurization or anything,'' he said. ``It was a routine, two-engine landing, the kind of thing pilots are trained for all the time.'' The plane landed at the nearest airport, in Tampa, at 9:58 a.m. EST, officials said. Passengers said they felt something, but didn't know an engine was missing until after they got on the ground. ``There was a little rock and roll but not that much,'' said Alfred Cortina of Miami, as he awaited another flight at Tampa. ``It was extremely smooth. I was surprised when I got off the plane and saw that we didn't have a engine.'' ``I felt a lurch and then a big bump,'' added Sandy Altner of Winnipeg, Canada. ``It was almost like we ran into something in a car. The pilot came on about 10 minutes later and said we had lost the right engine _ he didn't say it fell off.'' Gibbons said the plane is 14 years old. He said he did not know when it had last been inspected, but said he was not aware of any problems with it. NTSB investigator Jorge Prellezo said in Miami that the agency has not yet considered offering a reward for the return of engine parts, as it did after last year's crash of a jetliner in Sioux City, Iowa. ``We hope we can find it for free right now,'' he said. ``We have to look at what happened and the value of the engine to our investigation. It doesn't appear this was due to any catastrophic engine failure,'' he said. Boeing delivered the plane to Northwest in December 1975. The 727 model, designed as a short-run carrier but which airlines have used more for medium-range flights, was put into service in 1964 and discontinued in 1984 after 1,831 had been delivered, Cole said. In April 1985 an American Airlines flight from Dallas to San Diego lost its right-side engine but landed normally and without any injuries in San Diego. A Boeing 737 flown by Piedmont lost an engine on takeoff from Chicago in January 1989 but turned around and made an uneventful landing, Cole said.

DOC.HEAD: Some Airlines Adding Fuel Surcharges While Discounting Fares
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to UPDATE with American and Pan Am matching fare cuts. A longer version moved on financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: The good news for travelers is that airlines are cutting fares to lure passengers. But there's bad news: For the first time since the 1970s oil crisis, some are imposing a surcharge to cover a jump in fuel prices. Trans World Airlines said Wednesday it is adding a surcharge ranging from $5 to $20 per ticket. TWA spokesman Don Morrison in St. Louis said the charge represents about 4 percent of an average ticket price. Meanwhile, TWA, Pan Am, American Airlines, United Airlines, Midway Airlines and USAir said they were matching steep fare cuts announced Tuesday by Eastern Airlines, but were keeping the usual cancellation penalties that Eastern eliminated. The prospect of weak passenger traffic this year and a slowing economy may mean more fare discounting. But in many cases, the savings are reduced by fuel surcharges, which also were announced by Northwest Airlines. For flights of at least 500 miles, the new TWA fuel surcharge will cost $10 on a one-way ticket and $20 round trip. For less than 500 miles, passengers will pay an extra $5 one way and $10 round trip. Pan Am said it is raising most domestic fares 4 percent to cover fuel costs. Its Northeast shuttle service, which hiked fares last week, is excluded. United, the nation's second-largest airline, also said it is boosting domestic fares 4 percent because of the fuel price rise. Other big carriers, including Eastern, said they were considering fuel-related increases. On Tuesday, Eastern's sister carrier, Continental Airlines, led the move by raising fares 4 percent to cover fuel costs; Northwest quickly followed with a one-way surcharge of $6. The changes are effective Jan. 10. Some industry analysts suggested the highly visible fuel surcharges could be a way of bringing public pressure on the oil industry to lower prices. ``It may be a way of putting some of the heat on (oil) refiners,'' said Louis Marckesano, an airline analyst at the Philadelphia brokerage Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. Oil prices have surged in recent weeks amid the cold wave and refinery problems in Texas and Louisiana. Jet fuel, which represents around 35 percent of an airline's operating budget, has jumped to nearly $1 a gallon from 64 cents at the end of October. The fuel surcharges do not require government approval for domestic flights, and most of the airlines imposing them said they have sought permission from foreign governments to apply them to international flights. ``What's happened here, it's a matter of supply and demand,'' said Earl Ross, a spokesman for the American Petroleum Institute, an industry association in Washington. He would not comment on the recent demand by several Northeast governors and members of Congress that federal authorities investigate the possibility of price fixing. Eastern spokesman Robin Matell, in a statement Friday on the possibility of a fuel surcharge, cited a ``precipitous and unprecedented increase in fuel prices _ considering there hasn't been a disruption in supplies.'' Eastern's fare cuts are designed to lure passengers as the airline attempts to rebuild after a hobbling strike and bankruptcy proceeding. But they also show concern shared by all the airlines about the economy this year, said Raymond Neidl, an analyst at Dillon, Read & Co. Inc. ``Bookings are soft; that's why you're seeing discounts,'' he said. Neidl and other analysts estimate that the airline industry's total seat capacity will increase 6 percent this year as new jets are put into service, while passenger traffic will rise only 2 percent to 3 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Publisher Enrico Vallecchi Dies at 87
DOC.TEXT: Book and magazine publisher Enrico Vallecchi died Thursday in his castle on the outskirts of Florence at age 87. Vallecchi took charge of the family publishing company after World War II from his father, Attilio, who had founded it. The firm published some of the most prominent Italian writers of the 1930s and 1940s, such as Curzio Malaparte, Aldo Palazzeschi and Vasco Pratolini. In the postwar years, however, it faced increased economic difficulties due to growing competition and the lack of a sales network. Vallecchi was forced to sell the company in the early 1960s, and went on to found a new one and successfully publish magazines on hunting, fishing, horseback riding and other outdoor activities, which he loved. He never lost interest in his father's venture, and in 1983, bought back a controlling interest in Vallecchi, becoming chairman of its board of directors. The company has made a slow but steady recovery and still prints novels and non-fiction. Vallecchi is survived by his wife and three children.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Suspects Sleeping on Floor While Officials Search For More Space
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with marshals meeting, quote. Picks up 3rd graf pvs.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. marshals are throwing mattresses on the floor for federal prisoners and driving hundreds of miles a day in a hunt for empty jail beds as authorities grapple with the Northeast's inmate glut. The overcrowding problems were being discussed today at a ``Northeast jail crisis meeting'' that was to continue Friday at the U.S. Marshals Service headquarters in Alexandria, Va., said Fran Wermuth, a marshal's service spokeswoman. ``This problem is not just in the Northeast area. This group is meeting, but this problem with jail crowding is fairly typical across the nation,'' she said. The federal prison population has ``not just expanded, it has exploded,'' said U.S. Marshal Pasquale A. Mangini of Connecticut. The Bureau of Prisons said Wednesday a projected doubling of population in federal prisons during the next five years won't provide relief. Flip Lorenzoni, chief deputy marshal of New York's southern district, said the two pretrial detention centers near New York City are full. Women prisoners sometimes have to be driven 500 miles to Alderson, W.Va. ``We make that trip about weekly,'' he said. Greg Bogdan of the Bureau of Prisons in Washington estimated the federal prison population nationwide at 54,000 _ a 66 percent overcrowding rate _ and said that figure was expected to grow to about 90,000 by 1995. He said the problem is especially acute in the East, but a growing concern elsewhere. ``The East and West Coasts, and the Southeast portion of the country are the areas where we anticipate the biggest growth,'' Bogdan said. Chronic overcrowding in Rhode Island's only prison forced the state Department of Corrections to cancel a contract with federal officials to keep suspects there. Rhode Island and Massachusetts have no federal detention center. U.S. Marshal Donald Wyatt said Rhode Island marshals at minimum take a two-hour trip to the federal detention center in Hartford, Conn. The nearest federal prison is a 3{-hour drive to Danbury, Conn., a prison with a 514-inmate capacity that has 868 prisoners, he said. Sometimes, deputies are driving to Otisville, N.Y., from Philadelphia, Rhode Island, Vermont, Maine and Massachusetts. ``The ultimate solution is to build federal detention centers close to courthouses,'' said Wyatt, adding that his office has spent about $175,000 in overtime and hiring new guards. The Defense Department, meanwhile, is reviewing a list of 18 military bases in the Northeast proposed for housing temporary cells. The pretrial population has ballooned because new laws lock up more prisoners until trial, and other laws eliminate parole and lengthen sentences for chronic, armed and drug offenders. Providence attorney John F. Cicilline, who represents many federal defendants, said the distances that defense lawyers must drive to see their clients creates ``a serious constitutional violation.'' Rhode Island U.S. Attorney Lincoln C. Almond said the problem of where to put the prisoners is so acute that occasionally arrests and indictments have been delayed. In Boston last month, six or seven prisoners, including three reputed Mafia capos, had to sleep on the floor in a holding cell, which usually houses prisoners only during the day. ``If you have a multiple defendant arrest, it's a mind-boggling experience to find a place to put them,'' Mangini said. Bogdan said 10 prison construction projects are in various stages across the country, and plans to build four more detention centers and expand some existing facilities were on the drawing board. Nixon said there were a ``multitude of solutions'' to the overcrowding problem, including building more local jails, building a federal facility in Massachusetts, or erecting metropolitan correctional centers, he said. Such jailhouses, already in use in New York and Florida, are easy-to-build temporary housing for prisoners, located close to the courts.

DOC.HEAD: Husband, Suddenly a Suspect in Shooting of Wife, Commits Suicide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with body found, confirmed to be Stuart; wife's father stricken with undisclosed ailment; CLARIFIES that officials say Stuart apparently knew he was suspect, sted learned he was suspect; add detail. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BX6, BX10, BX13
DOC.TEXT: A man who told police his pregnant wife was fatally wounded by a robber as they left a hospital childbirth class killed himself this morning hours after becoming a suspect in the slaying, police said. The body of Charles Stuart of suburban Reading was pulled from the harbor shortly before 1 p.m. and positively identified, said Trooper Barbara Bennett, a State Police spokeswoman. Stuart's wife, Carol, was fatally wounded Oct. 23 and their son, Christopher, delivered prematurely by Caesarean section as his mother lay dying, survived just 17 days after the widely publicized shootings. ``Basically, it's fair to say, he could not handle the allegations or statements made about him,'' Suffolk County Prosecutor Newman Flanagan said, describing a handwritten suicide note found in Stuart's car. Stuart, who spent more than a month in the hospital after being wounded in the shootings, died after he jumped off Tobin Bridge into Boston Harbor. It took police divers several hours to find the body after it was originally spotted in the water by a police officer and a worker. Flanagan said Stuart became a suspect Wednesday after Boston police and investigators from his office interrogated several people late into the night. The prosecutor said the dramatic story Stuart initially told about being attacked by an unknown robber while leaving the hospital ``is not true.'' He would not elaborate, or say whether Stuart was one of those who was interrogated. Stuart, the 29-year-old manager of a fur store, had told police that he and his wife, 30, a laywer, were leaving Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston after attending a birthing class when an assailant commandeered their car and forced them to drive into an adjacent neighborhood, where he robbed and shot them. Mrs. Stuart, seven months pregnant, was shot in the head, Stuart in the abdomen. Though critically wounded, Stuart summoned help on the car telephone. His frantic 10-minute call to police and the dispatcher's efforts to determine where the car was were broadcast nationally and prompted an outpouring of sympathy for Stuart. No arrest warrant had been issued prior to Stuart's disappearance, but Flanagan said, ``I would assume he could very well have been aware of'' having become a suspect. Flanagan would not comment on a report by WNEV-TV that Stuart became the prime suspect after his brother Matthew went to police and offered information. A man who answered the telephone at Matthew Stuart's suburban home this morning said the brother was not there and no one in the family would comment. After the news of Stuart's death came out, Mrs. Stuart's father, Giusto DiMaiti, was rushed to Massachusetts General Hospital with an undisclosed ailment. The hospital would not discuss his condition. Edward Marchand, chief of police in Charles Stuart's hometown of Reading, said Stuart's house had been watched by police overnight after Boston police informed the suburban police that Stuart was a suspect. But Stuart never returned home. Marchand said he believed Stuart was aware his house was being watched. The shootings shocked the city and caused some racial tension; Stuart had described the attacker as a black man. In a note read at Mrs. Stuart's funeral that Stuart had written in his hospital bed, he said: ``My life will be empty without you. Now you're taken away from me. I will never know the feeling of your hand in mine.'' Among the mourners were Gov. Michael Dukakis and Mayor Raymond Flynn. Marchand would not say why Stuart had become a suspect, but he said ``there's a lot more to the story.'' Steve Aitkins of the Coast Guard said a wallet and a note were found in Stuart's car, which was discovered parked on a lower level of the 300-foot-high, double-decked bridge over Boston Harbor. Shortly before Christmas, Stuart viewed a lineup containing an alleged suspect, but officials and lawyers refused to say whether an identification was made. Asked if a man named in news reports as the alleged suspect, William Bennett, could still be suspected of being involved in the shootings, Flanagan said he was no longer a suspect.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyers Argue Over the Fine Line Between Illinois and Kentucky
DOC.TEXT: Life on the river and the law of the land were at odds Thursday as lawyers for Illinois and Kentucky argued about the border between their two states and control of the Ohio River. Illinois' lawyer told retired New York Court of Appeals Judge Matthew J. Jasen, appointed a special maser in the case, that an unbroken line of U.S. Supreme Court precedents supports his state's claim to a strip of the Ohio River about 100 feet wide. But a Kentucky assistant attorney general said Illinois, by refusing to police the river or exercise any control over it, has tacitly acknowledged for years that Kentucky owns the entire river, up to the Illinois shore. Illinois fishermen complain that Kentucky authorities have demanded they buy Kentucky licenses to fish from the Illinois shore. After attempts to resolve the fishermen's complaints failed, Illinois Attorney General Neil Hartigan took the case to the U.S. Supreme Court in 1986. The high court appointed Jasen, who retired that year after 18 years on New York State's highest court, to hear evidence and make a recommendation. When Kentucky was admitted to the Union in 1792, its border was declared to be the low-water mark on the northern shore of the Ohio River. That was fine until 1909, when dams raised the water level. Kentucky claimed it should control the river up to the new low-water mark, while Illinois, Indiana and Ohio said the 1792 boundary should still hold even though the shoreline had moved beyond it John J. Brunsman, an Illinois assistant attorney general, said the U.S. Supreme Court had settled that argument in favor of Ohio and Indiana and should do the same for Illinois. Rickie L. Pearson, Brunsman's counterpart from Kentucky, conceded that the precedents were against him but said the high court, in the Ohio and Indiana cases, had not considered the facts of life on the river. ``Kentucky has patrolled the river. ... There have been no law enforcement officers from Illinois on the river to do anything,'' Pearson said. He cited three incidents that he said bolster his case: _Illinois State Police once said they doubted they had crowd-control jurisdiction over a strike at a waterfront business in Joppa, Ill., because its pier extended into the river. _Firefighters in Golconda, Ill., refused to put out a fire on a boat grounded 5 to 10 feet from shore because ``the boat was in Kentucky and it was their problem.'' _Illinois State Police told a man whose boat had been moored on the Illinois side of the river to call Kentucky to report it stolen. Brunsman responded with examples of his own, including 73 building permits issued by the Illinois Department of Transportation for structures extending into the river. Pearson said the fact that Illinois coroners call their Kentucky counterparts before issuing death certificates for drowning victims showed the Illinois coroners knew the river was in Kentucky. Brunsman said the Kentucky coroners acknowledged Illinois' jurisdiction by releasing the bodies to that state. Jasen asked both lawyers for more detail, ordered a status report by March 1. He said the high court wants a report in time for its October session.

DOC.HEAD: Angola Says Pope to Visit In 1991
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II will visit the African nation of Angola next year, the Angolan state news agency reported Thursday. The report, monitored in Lisbon from the Angolan capital of Luanda, cited a statement from the Roman Catholic Auxiliary Bishop of Luanda Pedro Luis saying the Pope had accepted an invitation from President Jose Eduardo dos Santos. There was no immediate confirmation of the visit from the Vatican. Dates for the papal visit have yet to be fixed. Relations between the Roman Catholic Church and dos Santos' Marxist regime had been improving recently, but a statement issued by the country's Catholic bishops in November angered the government by calling for negotiations with rebels on free elections. The National Union for the Total Independence of Angola _ the rebel group _ has been fighting a civil war to share power with the Luanda government since the country gained independence from Portugal in 1975. An estimated 40 percent of Angola's 9.1 million population are Roman Catholics.

DOC.HEAD: River Navigation Back to Normal After Gas Spill
DOC.TEXT: Navigation resumed along the entire Monongahela River on Thursday, three days after at least 61 barges broke free and crashed downstream, one of them spilling 10,000 gallons of gasoline. The Coast Guard reopened the river near the Maxwell Locks and Dam after searching 11 hours with sonar equipment for sunken barges. The 20-mile section south of Pittsburgh had been closed to traffic since the New Year's Day accident, and all but five miles was reopened Wednesday. Six vessels were waiting to clear the Maxwell locks near Brownsville, 61 miles upstream from Pittsburgh, when clearance came before dawn. The Coast Guard gave the OK after the sonar failed to turn up any barges it didn't know about. ``We're about normal,'' lockmaster Todd Rankin said at midday. ``There was a little bit of a mad dash when we first opened. Some boats had been waiting in the landing for us to open up. As soon as we opened up, they cleared out pretty quickly.'' The Coast Guard warned operators Dec. 26 that a thaw was expected by weekend and advised them to make certain their barges were tied strongly to shore so rushing chunks of ice and high water would not knock the vessels free. Offenders could be fined up to $1,000 for each runaway craft. The barge that spilled 10,000 gallons of gasoline had been moored at at Speers, 44 miles upstream from Pittsburgh. The vessel went over the locks and dam at Charleroi, then hit the Monongahela Bridge. State officials said environmental damage was slight. One of the sunken barges remained jammed Thursday beneath one of the gates at the Maxwell Dam. The vessel was among 37 that were ripped from their moorings there. Thirty of them sank and piled up against the dam. The Army Corps of Engineers said it would try removing the barge from the gate this weekend, then try to salvage the other vessels.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Guard Overheard U.S. Troops Discussing Invasion
With AM-US-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: One of Manuel Antonio Noriega's bodyguards overheard U.S. servicemen discussing the invasion of Panama hours before it occurred, a Pentagon spokesman said Thursday, but it was unclear whether the incident enabled the ousted Panamanian leader to evade the Americans. ``There is some evidence that some officials may have had some advance thought that this operation was about to happen. But there isn't a lot of evidence that actions were taken as a result of that,'' Defense Department spokesman Pete Williams told reporters. ``A bodyguard, during a debriefing interview, said that two U.S. soldiers had been overheard discussing their positions for H-hour. And that supposedly happened at 10 p.m., three hours before the attack was to begin,'' said Williams. ``I have no other details.'' Noriega is believed to have escaped from one of his residences minutes before a U.S. commando unit arrived just after midnight Dec. 20, and fled from house to house in Panama City in the days thereafter, according to military officals. Noriega found refuge in the Vatican Embassy on Dec. 24, and turned himself over to U.S. officials Wednesday. Fighting has all but ceased in Panama, said Williams, and Pentagon officials were withdrawing some troops and sending new ones in their place. The number of U.S. servicemen in Panama stood at about 25,000, the same as it was shortly after the invasion, as combat troops were withdrawn and replaced by military police and civil affairs specialists, said Williams. The spokesman was unable to give a breakdown of the remaining troops by unit and function, or to say whether or when the number of troops in Panama would be reduced to the pre-invasion level of about 12,000. The troops are stationed there to guard the Panama Canal under the terms of bilateral treaty under which the United States is to turn the waterway over to Panama in the year 2000. Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, flew to Panama today to assess the withdrawal schedule. Williams said that four Noriega associates remain inside the Vatican embassy despite Noriega's decision to surrender. He identified the four as: Lt. Col. Nivaldo Madrinan, director of the Panamanian equivalent of the FBI and CIA; Capt. Asuncion Gaitan, an escort to Noriega; Carlos Castillo, leader of a pro-Noreiga political party, and Castillo's wife, Belgica Castillo, director of immigration. In other developments, two U.S. servicemen had been killed and three others injured in non-combat incidents, said Williams, but he did not have details. The number of American troops killed in action stood at 23, and the nunmber wounded at 323. All of the combat casualties were men, he said. Three U.S. civilians were killed and one was injured. Among Noreiga's Panama Defense Forces, said Williams, 314 were killed and 124 were wounded in the fighting. Williams also said that U.S. forces had collected 76,553 weapons in Panama, including 7,743 under a cash-for-guns program that has cost the U.S. government $691,000. Additionally, said Williams, U.S. forces had captured 39 armored vehicles, 36 aircraft and seven vessels. He was unable to specify what would become of the armaments.

DOC.HEAD: Keating Relative Says Lawyers Advised Appraisals Not Needed
DOC.TEXT: A son-in-law in charge of buying and selling land in Phoenix millionaire Charles H. Keating's now-collapsed real estate and savings and loan empire said Thursday he was advised by attorneys he did not need appraisals on the deals. Testifying in Keating's suit to overturn a federal takeover last April of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, Robert M. Wurzelbacher Jr. also said he did not investigate the ability of some buyers of the land to repay loans from the thrift financing the deals. But, he added, ``as far as I know'' the thrift complied with all state and federal regulations in using Lincoln and its federally insured deposits to carry out an estimated $1 billion in land, stock and other transactions between 1984 and 1988. Keating and his son, Charles H. Keating III, were scheduled to testify later Thursday in U.S. District Court here as subpoenaed government witnesses. Citing Fifth Amendment protections against self-incrimination, the elder Keating refused to answer questions the last time he was subpoenaed _ a November appearance before the House Banking Committee. As a large political benefactor, Keating is now the centerpiece of a congressional ethics scandal involving $1.3 million he gave to five senators who interceded with the regulators on Lincoln's behalf in 1987. In seizing the Irvine, Calif., based Lincoln S&L, federal regulators have contended that Keating was operating it in an ``unsafe and unsound manner,'' citing as examples the lack of appraisals and inadequate reviews of borrowers' financial status. The regulators now claim that Lincoln's losses of depositors' federally insured savings in what they call ``sham'' land deals eventually could cost taxpayers up to $2 billion, making it the most expensive of nearly 600 S&L failures in the past two years. Wurzelbacher, the chief executive officer of Lincoln's real estate subsidiary and a vice president of its holding company, American Continental Corp., is married to one of Keating's daughters. He acknowledged in testimony that Keating purchased Lincoln in 1984 to provide a source of cash for large, planned residential developments that he wanted to build in the Phoenix area. ``The bank provided a source of funds to acquire and develop the properties,'' he said. ``We were able to capitalize subsidiaries with funds from Lincoln.'' Wurzelbacher said Lincoln did not review the ability of borrowers to repay the loans because the thrift would get the land back through foreclosures if the payments were not made. He said he was told in 1985 or 1986 by the thrift's 15-lawyer legal department that the appraisals were not needed. ``We were delighted,'' Wurzelbacher said. ``I knew that it would elimninate a usually lengthy and cumbersome step in selling real estate.'' Government attorneys on Wednesday revealed documents showing that a real estate attorney hired by Lincoln to review its loan portfolio in 1987 labeled as ``ridiculous'' a $50 million loan to a business associate's partnership that listed only $110 in assets, documents show. The attorney, Lois Gordon, called the loan to Phoenix developer Ernest C. Garcia a ``suspicious transaction'' and warned Lincoln's executives in a letter in early 1988 that its linkage to other deals with Garcia ``may cause investigators to seek to uncover other linked transactions.'' Miss Gordon testified Wednesday that she was hired by Lincoln and its owners to review its loan portfolio for weaknesses that might be objectionable to state and federal regulators. She said she found fault with several Lincoln loans she reviewed, including the absence of property appraisals, financial statements from borrowers and other normal underwriting requirements. ``A more important concern,'' she said in a Feb. 4, 1988, confidential letter to American Continental's chief counsel, ``is the number of loans that may, if reviewed, be found to be unsafe and unsound and-or inappropriate for a savings and loan institution.''

DOC.HEAD: Shoppers Empty Stores Ahead of Next Round of Price Increases
DOC.TEXT: Shoppers have virtually emptied State Store 122 of its goods because the switch to a market economy is driving prices up and Poles figure everything will cost more next week. ``I had heaps of sugar and flour, enough to last three months, but when the year came to an end people bought everything out within a week,'' said Teresa Sasin, who manages the food store. ``The day after New Year's I had a delivery of 500 kilos (1,100 pounds) of sugar and it was sold out within an hour,'' she said, gesturing toward the empty shelves. ``Same with eggs. Ten crates were sold out in an hour.'' Similar scenes have been reported in state-run grocery and meat stores around the nation Thursday as customers stock up before prices are raised again. Some stores closed because they had nothing more to sell. Prices have been freed as part of a radical economic plan designed by the Solidarity-led government to end central economic control and subsidies and, after an initial spurt in prices, halt the inflation that has plagued the moribund economy. Electricity went up 600 percent and the price of gasoline doubled this week alone. Food prices are supposed to rise more gradually _ from 25 to 50 percent a month _ to cushion the shock. Prices increased this week in stores that received deliveries based on new prices for January, but others still were selling goods at last year's prices. Private and cooperative groceries, which charge higher prices than state stores, also were crowded. ``We're still operating on old prices so people are buying everything they can get their hands on,'' said Jadwiga Dzierecka, director of Agricoop No. 1 in Warsaw. The Agricoop chain is a cooperative soon to be become a stock company under economic legislation passed by Parliament last week. Its stores sell an array of cheeses, fresh produce and imported foods, including canned shrimp and Italian pasta and olive oil. ``Our products are so attractive that people still buy,'' Ms. Dzierzecka told a reporter between telephone conversations with suppliers.
