Halina Samsel, co-owner of a vegetable stand in Warsaw's busy Hala Mirowska market, said she had raised prices but was confident people would continue to buy. She was charging $1.90 a kilo (2.2 pounds) for tomatoes, 17 cents a head for lettuce and 84 cents a kilo for fresh mushrooms. Average monthly pay in Poland is about $37, or 350,000 zlotys. Ms. Samsel said with a smile: ``The prices are shocking. Customers get upset. They are not used to them, but they buy. There is no other way out.'' Jan Kubajek, sales director of a wholesale supply house run by the state, said Thursday: ``This unrestrained way of introducing new prices is unacceptable. Retail firms don't have enough money, so they are delaying payment and we'll have to limit deliveries.'' Kubajek said his warehouse supplies sugar and flour to more than half the city. He said enough stocks are on hand for current needs, but he expects problems later. ``Prices for many social groups will be unacceptable,'' he said, which means sales will decline and many stores may have to close. Agriculture Minister Czeslaw Janicki told the newspaper Zycie Warszawy in an interview published Thursday there would be no interruption of food supplies. ``There are no rational reasons to fear this,'' he said. ``There are no disturbances in food production.'' Janicki acknowledged, however, that Poland had to import 300,000 tons of grain in January and that meat reserves had fallen to 65,000 tons, half the nation's monthly consumption. Farmers have complained about the rising costs of fuel and electricity. ``The avalanche of price hikes has already started and this is only the beginning,'' Tadeusz Zablocki, a farmer from the Baltic coast, told the newspaper Dziennik Ludowy. ``Production costs in agriculture will increase enormously.'' Butcher shops often are empty by early afternoon. ``There is a real problem with meat,'' Ms. Sasin said. ``It was the worst holiday season I can remember in years as far as meat and sausage go.'' Janicki said he hoped farmers would begin selling their reserves soon. Many farmers have held products off the market, waiting for price increases.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Extends Sanctions Against Libya
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday extended sanctions against Libya under national emergency procedures, saying the North African nation ``continues to use and support international terrorism.'' Bush, in a letter to House Speaker Thomas S. Foley and Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, said he was continuing the economic sanctions imposed Jan. 7, 1986, by President Reagan. The sanctions would have expired Jan. 7 without the executive order to extend them. Bush said the government was utilizing the National Emergencies Act ``to deal with the unusual and extraordinary threat to the national security and foreign policy of the United States ... by the actions and policies of the government of Libya.'' The sanctions include freezing of Libyan assets in U.S. banks; a ban on sales of weapons to Libya; a ban on trade; curtailment of travel by Americans there; a ban on credits or loans to the Libyan government by U.S. interests; and suspension of contracts relating to activities in Libya. ``The government of Libya continues to use and support international terrorism, in violation of international law and minimum standards of human behavior,'' Bush said in his letter to Foley and Mitchell. ``I have determined that it is necessary to maintain in force the broad authorities necessary to apply economic pressure to the government of Libya to reduce its ability to support international terrorism.'' Relations between the United States and Libya have deteriorated, especially since December 1985 attacks at the Rome and Vienna airports that killed 19 people. U.S. officials accused Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi of aiding the terrorists who carried out those attacks.

DOC.HEAD: President Will Make Disability Council Appointments
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Thursday that he will appoint Mary Matthews Raether of McLean, Va., to the National Council on Disability. He also announced two reappointments to the council: Chairwoman Sandra Swift Parrino of Briarcliff, N.Y., and Alvis Kent Waldrep Jr. of Dallas, president of the Kent Waldrep National Paralysis Foundation.

DOC.HEAD: Finance Minister Says Comecon `Has No Reason to Exist'
DOC.TEXT: The new finance minister said Thursday there is no reason for the continued existence of Comecon, the East bloc economic alliance, and he said Czechoslovakia would quit the organization unless it is overhauled. Finance Minister Vaclav Klaus, an outspoken advocate of free-market reforms, also announced the devaluation of the Czechoslovak crown by 18.6 percent against Western currencies. A Polish newspaper quoted Klaus as saying Czechoslovakia would propose the dissolution of Comecon when the alliance meets in Sofia on Tuesday. Asked at a news conference whether Czechoslovakia would propose the alliance be disbanded, Klaus replied: ``Comecon cannot function, the way it is now and there is no reason for its existence anymore.'' ``I don't have to call it dissolution, but if all our proposals are accepted, it will not be the same organization,'' he said. Klaus, 49, who was appointed Finance Minister in Czechoslovakia's reformist government last month, is a non-party economist who was forced to serve as a lowly bank clerk for his beliefs through the 1970s. Czechoslovakia will propose the abolition of a whole range of agreements concluded earlier between Comecon members, Klaus said. Those agreements ``are so far binding our hands,'' he said, adding that if the Czechoslovak proposals are not accepted, ``we are ready to get out of such commitments unilaterally.'' Andrej Barcak, the foreign trade minister, said Czechosolvakia was not able to function within the organization ``on the economic rules which exist.'' ``It is quite obvious that from a multilateral point of view we are not able to form any, kind of fundamentally deep integration and not many countries are going to even attempt that,'' Klaus said. He said most of the bloc's activities would be transformed into bilateral relations between countries. Comecon, which stands for the Council of Mutual Economic Assistance, was formed under the guidance of the Soviet Union in 1949 and has since controlled trade among Soviet-allied countries. The member nations are the Soviet Union, Bulgaria, Cuba, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Hungary, Mongolia, Poland, Romania, and Vietnam. Dramatic political changes recently in Eastern Europe have radically decreased the power of Communist rulers and many Comecon members have begun moving away from centrally planned economies. East bloc countries say Comecon's payments framework doesn't work because it is based on barter, fixed prices and a non-convertible currency, the Soviet ruble. More reform-oriented countries like Czechoslovakia say they need hard currency to breathe new life into stagnating economies. The devaluation of the crown against major currencies means that, as of Jan. 8, one dollar will buy 17 Czechoslovak crowns, compared to the current rate of just over 14. A new tourist rate will be introduced on Jan. 8 giving the tourist 38 crowns, up from 9 crowns, for one U.S. dollar, in a bid to match the current black market rate in hard currencies. At the same time, Klaus said the crown would be revalued by 10 percent against the transfer ruble, to encourage exports to Western countries. Referring to the new crown rate for tourists, Klaus said: ``We know this is not going to destroy the black market completely, but it should be a serious obstacle.'' Klaus also said that a currency and rate committee of the Comecon is to meet in Prague on Jan 16.-18. ``All the things we cannot settle in Sofia we can take care of then,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Marks Law Enforcement Training Week
DOC.TEXT: President Bush issued a proclamation Thursday marking Jan. 7-13 as National Law Enforcement Training Week. Congress earlier passed legislation designating the week. ``By equipping our officers with the knowledge and skills they need, law enforcement training helps them to protect our homes, businesses and communities,'' the president said. ``This week we recognize the dedicated men and women who provide this training, as well as the hard-working individuals who participate in it.''

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Groups Unite Against Communists in Election Drive
DOC.BYLINE: With AM-Romania, Bjt ^By CAROL J. WILLIAMS
DOC.TEXT: Associated Press Writer= EAST BERLIN (AP) _ Six fledgling opposition groups put aside their political differences Thursday and joined forces to compete in national elections against the dominant Communist Party. ``It's certainly clear that if we don't work together we will fail together,'' said Detlef Poge of New Forum, the largest of the opposition groups. New Forum has about 200,000 members. The coalition, to be called Election Alliance 90, joins New Forum with the Social Democratic Party, Democratic Awakening, Democracy Now, the Initiative for Peace and Human Rights, and the United Left. The groups have espoused varying policies since they were formed after the fall pro-democracy movement, which ended the Communist Party's monopoly on power and led to the scheduling of elections May 6. The Communist Party has been portraying itself as the defender of democracy against greedy capitalists and a resurgence of neo-fascism. Polls show it would attract more voter support than any single party if elections were held today. An anti-fascist rally sponsored by the Communists on Wednesday drew up to 250,000 people, according to some estimates. Steffen Reiche of the Social Democrats said leaflets distributed at the rally seemed to suggest his party sympathized with the aims of right-wing radicals. Reiche rejected any association of his party with the right and said the opposition groups have grown to realize their only chance of overcoming the Communists is as a bloc. ``In order to ensure a democratic restructuring of East Germany, we need an alliance of the opposition,'' he said on West Berlin television. Reunification of East and West Germany is one area where the opposition parties have differed. Leaders of Democracy Now have advocated a gradual reunification with West Germany, while New Forum and the Social Democrats contend East German sovereignty must be protected. The degree that Western investment should be encouraged to ease East Germany's economic crisis has also been a matter of dispute among the opposition forces, as have environmental policies such as whether nuclear energy should replace brown coal, a heavy pollutant that fires much of the nation's industry. In a late December survey of 800 East German voters conducted by the Academy of Social Sciences and confirmed by West German researchers, 34 percent said they would vote for the Communists if elections were held now. The newly independent Christian Democratic Union drew the second-strongest support with a distant 7.9 percent. The Christian Democrats had for decades been aligned with and dominated by the Communists, but they broke away and reorganized last month. Five of the six groups in Election Alliance 90 polled support in the latest survey, but together they got only 14.3 percent support. Reformist Premier Hans Modrow is a Communist Party member and enjoys more public trust than any other figure on the national scene. The opposition forces contend his government is transitional and has limited authority to decide how the nation should proceed with reforms. Lech Walesa, leader of Poland's Solidarity movement, met with some East German opposition leaders Thursday and told them they need to use more common sense to achieve their goals. ``I don't have to remind you that we are taking part in a great game that only just started. I would not like you to be too euphoric. ... This is a serious game,'' Walesa said during the meeting in Gdansk. The East Germans at the meeting included Barbel Bohley and Jens Reich of New Forum, Michael Bartoszek of Dmocracy Now and Wolfgang Templin of Peace and Human Rights. Meanwhile, East Germany said the compulsory term for military service has been cut from 18 months to 12 months. About 25,000 of the army's 170,000 soldiers who have already served a year or more will be released, National People's Army spokesman Uwe Hempel told reporters. The age range for compulsory service has also been shortened, from 18 to 23 instead of 18 to 26.

DOC.HEAD: Black Group Cancels Meeting
DOC.TEXT: An organization of black journalists canceled its national board meeting here because of the suspension of a state holiday in memory of the late Martin Luther King. Directors of the National Association of Black Journalists had scheduled their quarterly meeting for Jan. 12-14 in Phoenix. The King holiday was to have been celebrated Jan. 15. ``At a considerable cost to NABJ, we have canceled ... because we cannot in good conscience spend our money and do business in a state which ... will not commemorate the values of truth, freedom and justice that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. so courageously embodied,'' NABJ President Thomas Morgan said in a statement. Carl Morris, executive director of the organization, said about 40 people had been expected at the meeting. The organization of print and broadcast journalists has about 1,800 members. David Radcliffe, executive director of the Phoenix and Valley of the Sun Convention and Visitors Bureau, said he had not heard of other groups canceling visits to Phoenix. The holiday, approved by the 1989 Legislature, was suspended because opponents filed nearly 80,000 signatures calling for a referendum on repeal. Secretary of State Jim Shumway put the observance on hold until it is determined there are insufficient signatures or until the election. To force the election in November, 43,350 signatures are needed. The meeting has been rescheduled for Jan. 26-28 at an undetermined site.

DOC.HEAD: Marshals Guard Courthouse, Survey Neighborhood
With AM-Noriega, Bjt
LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Federal marshals guarding the biggest catch of their careers, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, secured a courthouse Thursday with two-way radios, metal detectors, binoculars and weapons. Officers were stationed throughout the 10-story federal courthouse, at all doors and in the streets outside while the ousted Panamanian leader occupied a basement cell before his arraignment in a 1988 drug indictment. ``Obviously they've increased security,'' said a receptionist who worked for Daniel Horgan, chief U.S. marshal in Miami. ``But he won't make any comment.'' The receptionist would not give her name. Jose Cepero, a Cuban-American who was picketing outside court with a sign saying ``U.S. Hands Off Panama,'' was attacked by a member of a Panamanian exile group. His sign was torn to pieces, and he was hit on the head and shoulders before police and marshals moved in. Cepero, who was led away for his own protection, was shaken up but had no visible injuries. About 20 marshals, about double the usual number, guarded barricades at the prisoner entrance to the courthouse, and pedestrians were forced to walk on the other side of the street. Plainclothes marshals equipped with binoculars scanned the surrounding neighborhood from the roof throughout the day, instead of the normal twice-daily practice when prisoners are being moved in and out of the building. Hours before Noriega was to reach a ninth-floor courtroom, two airplanes flew overhead with banners saying ``Bye Bye, Tony'' and ``Rent This Ad When Fidel Falls,'' showing Cuban-American solidarity with Panamanians. Private security officers supplemented the radio-equipped marshals in the courthouse, and a half-dozen Miami police officers kept an eye on a growing array of news crews with satellite dishes and towers sprouting from their vans. Two Miami officers patrolled the front courthouse plaza where a few Panamanian exiles expressed support for the prosecution of Noriega. One woman wore a T-shirt with the words ``Noriega Enemy No. 1 of Panama,'' and a man's shirt read ``Democracy for Panama'' in Spanish. The U.S. Marshals Service has a self-contained system for moving defendants in the courthouse outside the public eye. Holding cells in the basement lead to a private elevator that connects by rear hallways to courtrooms. Each courtroom has an adjoining holding cell so prisoners can make a court appearance without having any contact with the public. The courtroom reserved for the hearing before U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler has 40 seats, and 30 were reserved for news media. Visitors must pass through a metal detector to enter the courthouse and submit to a search of bags. No cameras or tape recorders are allowed in the building _ routine in federal courts. Marshals routinely carry sidearms outside the courthouse but store them before coming in contact with prisoners. Court security officers carry handguns in courtrooms. The Marshals Service has a small arsenal of automatic weapons, rifles and shotguns in the courthouse in case of emergency. There was no indication from federal officials where Noriega would be placed after his court appearance. Federal prisoners awaiting trial in Miami are routinely held at the federal Metropolitan Correctional Center south of Miami, but some high-profile drug defendants facing trial in Florida, notably Colombian cocaine kingpin Carlos Lehder Rivas, were transported out of state for detention. Lehder's attorneys became frustrated with federal marshals for moving their client at irregular intervals without notice from one maximum-security prison to another, but federal judges did not restrain the transfers until shortly before trial.

DOC.HEAD: Army Announces Six-Month Reduction in Length of Service
DOC.TEXT: Defense Minister Florian Siwicki, attempting to reform the armed services and cut costs, announced Thursday that the length of compulsory military service will be reduced beginning next fall from 24 to 18 months. Siwicki, one of four communists serving in the new Solidarity-led government, said in a television interview that the armed forces had been reduced by 33,000 soldiers in 1989. According to the latest figures from the London-based Institute for Strategic Studies, the size of the Polish army last year was 394,000. Military officials say cost-cutting is one of the reasons for reducing the armed forces. Siwicki, who said the cost of maintaining the army last year was 16 percent lower than in 1988, told viewers Poland was seeking a smaller, more efficient armed forces and that 50 more army units would be dissolved shortly. The defense ministry said the length of service reductions will begin with the autumn 1990 class of new conscripts.

DOC.HEAD: Dinosaur Discovery Strengthens Theory Of Rapid Evolution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for item slugged AM-Epanterias on news advisory.
DOC.TEXT: The discovery of the fossilized bones of a giant meat-eating dinosaur predating the fearsome tyrannosaurus rex strengthens the theory that dinosaurs evolved rapidly before becoming extinct, a scientist said Thursday. The bones of an Epanterias were found at the top of the Morrison Formation deposit, an ancient saline lakebed near Fort Collins, by a paleontology team from the University of Colorado Museum in Boulder. The discovery a year and a half ago was only the third of an Epanterias, according to Robert Bakker, a research associate at the museum, who announced the find Wednesday. Bakker identified the giant member of the allosaur family from a jawbone and parts of the neck and tail vertebrate. Bakker said the discover strengthens the theory that dinosaurs entombed in the Morrison Formation, which dates to 130 million years ago, and elsewhere in North America evolved rapidly. ``On average, the rule is that big animals tend to get bigger until they go extinct. The incredible size of Epanterias indicates there was some sort of an evolutionary arms race going on,'' Bakker said in a telephone interview from Boulder. The Epanterias, which weighed about four tons and was 50 feet long, could have eaten about 40 tons of meat annually, and its ability to expand its enormous jaws _ much like modern-day snakes _ would have allowed Epanterias to gulp huge bites of prey easily. The Morrison Formation, about 50 miles north of Denver, contains up to six distinct dinosaur fauna from successive time periods, Bakker said. The formation is only about 300 feet deep, he said, ``but every 50 feet or so you have a different species. This one was only in the last 20 feet and the earlier ones also were short-lived. Things were really moving at that time.'' The other two discoveries of Epanterias fossils were in 1877 near Canon City, 80 miles south of Denver, and in 1934 in the Oklahoma panhandle. Epanterias apparently was the last and largest species in the evolutionary line of allosaurs, carnivorous dinosaurs that walked on their hind legs, Bakker said. Epanterias' great size confused early paleontologists, he said. The bones of the Canon City specimen were so large they were initially misidentified as brontosaur bones. Bakker speculated the size increase of many dinosaur species over time may have been due to sexual selection, predation success or disease resistance. He subscribes to the theory that dinosaurs were warm-blooded like modern birds and that dinosaur mass extinctions about 66 million years ago may have been brought on by extensive migrations and outbreaks of disease. Bakker said he and other researchers will study all three Epanterias specimens and they hope to assemble a complete model pieced together from portions of each dinosaur.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Gets Report on Volunteerism Project
DOC.TEXT: President Bush was presented Thursday with recommendations for establishing a privately financed national volunteerism program. ``We're recommending setting up a private-public foundation,'' said New Jersey Gov. Thomas H. Kean, the chairman of the five-member President's Advisory Committee on The Points of Light Initiative. Although Bush has discussed a $50 million annual budget to get the initiative moving _ $25 million from the private sector and another $25 million in public money _ Kean said the foundation should begin immediately without tax dollars. ``Let's get it up first as a private foundation so we can get it going right away,'' he said. The Points of Light Initiative Foundation, which would be composed of 19 to 25 board members, would seek to instill a desire for community service in the 50 percent of all Americans who never have volunteered, Kean said. ``I don't think there's a problem out there that can't be helped by volunteers,'' Kean said. ``That's not to replace what government should be doing. No matter what government does, it can never be enough.'' The program takes its name from the president's inaugural speech in January 1989, in which he referred to a national volunteer spirit shining like a thousand points of light.

DOC.HEAD: Selma, Ala., School Boycott Suspended as Protester Arrested
DOC.TEXT: Civil rights activists suspended a classroom boycott by black students Thursday and announced plans to sue the majority white board that ousted the city's first black school superintendent. One picket was arrested Thursday, the second day of the boycott, and the number of students taking part in the protest dropped. The 6,000-student system's absentee rate dropped to 15 percent from 25 percent Wednesday, but protest leader Hank Sanders called the demonstration ``very successful.'' District enrollment is about 70 percent black. Sanders, a state senator, said the boycott was being suspended until Jan. 16, because final exams begin Monday. He dismissed critics' charges that keeping students out of school was only hurting them, saying, ``The boycott is for the future. We sometimes have to make a sacrifice in the present for gains in the future.'' Sanders said he would file suit challenging the 1977 act creating Selma's majority-white school board, contending it did not meet the requirements of federal voting rights law. Last month, the board refused to renew Superintendent Norward Roussell's contract, which expires June 30. The vote followed an evaluation by board members that accused the superintendent, who has held the post since 1987, of being dictatorial and intimidating teachers. Roussell has described the evaluation as unfair but opposes the boycott, saying it had less to do with him or the schools than with Selma's history of racial unrest, including the violence used on civil rights marchers in 1965. A protester was arrested Thursday after Roussell signed a warrant for his arrest. Ernest J. Swift was arrested while picketing outside an elementary school attended by his two children. He was charged with disorderly conduct and harassment and released on $1,000 bail.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Reportedly Accepts Lithuanian Party's Decision to Split
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian Communist leaders met Thursday with Mikhail S. Gorbachev and said the Kremlin leader failed to sway them from their decision to split from the Soviet Communist Party and pursue local independence. The No. 2 party official in the Baltic republic reported that Gorbachev vowed not to interfere. ``We determined our positions, from which we will not be moved,'' Romualdas Ozolas, a member of the Lithuanian party's 19-member ruling bureau, told state-run TV in Vilnius, Lithuania's capital, after he and the rest of the delegation flew home from Moscow. There was no immediate report from the Tass news agency or other Moscow-based official media on the closed-door talks, which the Lithuanians said lasted more than five hours. Gorbachev has vigorously opposed the Lithuanians' decision two weeks ago to create an independent party, and the national party's policy-making Central Committee has directed him to travel to the republic soon to try to mend the schism. The Dec. 21 vote by a congress of Lithuanian Communists to break with Moscow ran counter to more than seven decades of recognized local party subservience to the Kremlin. In an atmosphere of growing restiveness among the Soviet Union's patchwork of ethnic groups, it could trigger a stampede from central party control elsewhere in the country. After the talks with Gorbachev, party Second Secretary Vladimir Beriozov told radio and TV in his republic that ``no attempt will be made to try to stop the process (in Lithuania). Communists want independence. I think we were understood.'' Beriozov's comments, like those of Ozolas, were reported to The Associated Press by TV journalist Eduardas Potashinskas in Vilnius. However, Beriozov also noted that the opinion of Gorbachev ``is not the opinion of the Central Committee.'' The Soviet party's 250-member Central Committee, which sets policy and can change the party's leader, reportedly includes members who advocated taking strong measures against the separatists. The Central Committee held a two-day emergency meeting on the split. On Dec. 26, it instructed Gorbachev to go to Lithuania to try to heal the break. Beriozov said Gorbachev will meet with a variety of people during the visit, which he said was scheduled Jan. 10-12. As Gorbachev and the Lithuanian leaders conferred, the Estonian party's Central Committee convened to consider following the example set by their Baltic neighbors by adopting a draft policy statement favoring independence for Estonia and its Communist Party, said local journalist Tarmu Tammerk. The draft, reportedly opposed by ethnic Russians, is somewhat vague on whether the party would separate or try to be ``independent'' within the Soviet party, Tammerk said. He said Estonian media announced a statement had been adopted Thursday night but gave no details, so it was not clear whether the draft had been approved as written. In remarks reported by Tass, however, Estonian party leader Vaino Vyalyas pointedly told his Central Committee that the ``Lithuanian Communist Party's path to autonomy cannot serve as a direct example for reforming the Estonian Communist Party.'' The Estonians scheduled a special party conference Feb. 9 and a more formal congress March 23, where a vote could be taken on creating a separate party, said Tammerk, speaking from Tallinn, Estonia's capital. Gorbachev had summoned the entire bureau of the Lithuanian party to a meeting in Moscow apparently in hopes of winning a reversal of the decision to break away. Potashinskas said they were received by three of the 12 members of the ruling Soviet Politburo: Gorbachev, party ideology secretary Vadim A. Medvedev and international affairs specialist Alexander N. Yakovlev. Medvedev and Yakovlev are regarded as key Gorbachev advisers. The Politburo's strongest conservatives, such as Yegor K. Ligachev, were absent, Potashinskas said. Previously, Gorbachev opposed the Lithuanian decision to split from the national party. But he and other officials have also indicated the Kremlin would not use force to keep the secessionist Baltic republics in line. ``We are not talking about using force, but we are talking about clearing the matter up,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov said Sunday. On Tuesday, he told the BBC the Kremlin has ``only one tool'' for preventing a breakup of the union: ``It is dialogue, dialogue and dialogue. The only way is political means. We have no other choice.'' In a speech to the party's Central Committee on Dec. 25, Gorbachev noted that extraordinary measures, such as troops and tanks, have been used against ``hooligans'' in rioting in Uzbekistan and the disputed region of Nagorno-Karabakh in Azerbaijan. ``But in these conditions, when we have the participation of wide strata of the population, we have tried and are trying to use political means,'' he said. The movement in Lithuania for the independence of both the local party and the republic is supported by hundreds of thousands of people. Gorbachev went on to denounce party members calling for traditional ``strong-arm'' methods. Terror, he said, ``is an ineffective and hopeless means of regulating social life, and in the final account, a measure of weakness.'' Some dissenting Communists in Lithuania have formed an alternate Central Committee that proclaims continuing fealty to Moscow and the Soviet Communist Party that Gorbachev heads.

DOC.HEAD: Members of Congress Say Focus Should be on Troop Withdrawal, Aid
With AM-US-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Members of Congress, hailing the surrender of Manuel Antonio Noriega, said Thursday that the United States must quickly reduce its military presence in Panama and provide large-scale economic aid. ``The U.S. should now devote its energies to assisting President Endara and the Panamanian people in establishing an effective, new democratic government,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. Mitchell also said American troops should ``return home as soon as possible.'' Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Forces Committee who spent 36 hours in Panama on an inspection tour, agreed. ``We need the U.S. military presence not only to become less visible but less present,'' Nunn said Thursday on his return to Washington, adding that ``hundreds of millions of dollars'' in international aid will be needed to speed Panama's economic recovery. Early Thursday, a 32-member congressional delegation led by House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., left on a previously planned two-day trip to Panama. Gephardt said issues to be addressed include how long the military occupation will last, how much public and private aid is needed to rebuild the economy, how democratic and social institutions can be strengthened, and the status of the Panama Canal. Noriega, who surrendered to U.S. officials in Panama City on Wednesday night after taking refuge in the Vatican Embassy, faces drug trafficking charges in the United States. If convicted of charges cited in the major of two federal indictments, Noriega could be sentenced to 145 years in prison and fined more than $1.1 million. ``I predict Noriega is going to spend the rest of his life behind bars,'' said Sen. Alphonse D'Amato, R-N.Y. ``Noriega will receive justice in this country, which is more than he gave the Panamanian people,'' said Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. Noriega, said Rep. Ike Skelton, D-Mo., is an ``international snake (that) has finally been put in his cage.'' Several House and Senate members said the Panamanian army, used by Noriega as an instrument of dictatorial control, should either be eliminated or sharply scaled back. Nunn said he was told by Panama Canal Co. officials that Noriega's forces had increased harassment of Panamanaian workers, causing key employees to leave. He said he was told that the continued operation of the canal would have been jeopardized had the harassment continued. Nunn said that while a new Panamanian army will be needed to help defend the canal, it should not be allowed to become an all-pervasive instrument of control as it was under Noriega. Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on Latin America, said the Panamanian Defense Force should be abolished and that elections be called as soon as possible to legitimize the Endara government. The Foreign Relations Committee will begin extensive hearings soon on a substantial aid authorization for Panama to repair war damage, rejuvenate the economy and build democratic institutions, he said. Many members of Congress said Noriega's arrest represented a major victory in the war on drugs and the elimination of Panama as a money-laundering center. ``All Americans rejoice that the United States armed forces have brought this indicted drug-running thug to justice,'' said Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich. Sen. John F. Kerry, D-Mass., who has conducted a series of hearings on international drug traffic, said the action against Noriega ``has very significant impact,'' but warned that Noriega's arrest ``could wind up being mere fluff in the drug war'' unless there is emphasis on reducing U.S. demand for drugs. A spokesman for former President Reagan said Reagan believes that the arrest of the former U.S. ally ``will send a clear message to drug dealers around the world that their behavior will not be tolerated.''

DOC.HEAD: Space Shuttle Countdown Begins
DOC.TEXT: NASA began the countdown Thursday for Monday's launch of space shuttle Columbia on a 10-day satellite rescue mission. The clock began ticking at 4 p.m. when NASA test director Jim McKnight issued the traditional call to stations at the launch pad and in the control center. Liftoff is scheduled at 8:10 a.m. Monday for the first of a record 10 shuttle flights planned in 1990. During 10 days in space, the crew of five is to deploy a Navy communications satellite and track down and retrieve a 21,400-pound science laboratory the size of a small bus before it falls back to Earth on Feb. 28. The laboratory, which has been orbiting for nearly six years, will be returned to Earth for a study of its 57 experiments and to determine what has happened to it during long exposure to space. Liftoff had been scheduled to take place before Christmas, but problems with the launch pad, which recently underwent a $50 million overhaul, forced a postponment. Fourteen hours of ``hold time'' were added to the countdown to allow NASA to stop and deal with any problems with launch pad 39A, which has not been used in four years. The astronauts will fly to Cape Canaveral on Friday from their training base in Houston to prepare for the flight. The commander is astronaut Dan Brandenstein. The other crew members are pilot Jim Wetherbee and mission specialists Bonnie Dunbar, Marsha Ivins and David Low. Brandenstein and Dunbar have made shuttle flights, while the others will be on their first trip.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Snow Hits Nebraska, Iowa And Wisconsin
DOC.TEXT: Heavy snow fell around the Great Lakes on Thursday from a storm that blew out of the Southwest and across the Plains, and heavy rain fell across the South. The storm carried snow to the central Plains and the upper Mississippi Valley late Wednesday and early Thursday, with heavy snow in Nebraska and Iowa. A narrow band of heavy snow, with amounts of 5 to 9 inches, fell across southern Iowa, and southeastern Nebraska got 3 to 8 inches of snow. Extreme northwestern Missouri got up to 5 inches late Wednesday in Atchison County. The snow then spread across southwestern and east-central Wisconsin during the morning Thursday, with up to 6 inches in Grant County. By early afternoon Thursday, snow fell across northern Lower Michigan. Rain and snow developed elsewhere over the Great Lakes. Showers and thunderstorms developing ahead of a cold front produced heavy rain in the lower Mississippi Valley late Wednesday and during the night. Heavier rainfall totals for the 24-hour period up to 7 a.m. EST included 1.76 inches at Port Arthur, Texas; 1.71 inches at Jackson, Miss.; 1.52 inches at Fort Polk, La., and 1.46 inches at El Dorado, Ark. During the morning Thursday, showers and thunderstorms produced heavy rain in the central Gulf Coast region. Heavier totals for the six hours up to 1 p.m. EST included 1.90 inches at Baton Rouge, La., and 1.03 inches at McComb, Miss. Showers extended northeastward from the central Gulf Coast region to the middle Atlantic Coast. Another cold front produced wet weather in the Pacific Northwest with heavy rain along the coast of Washington. Quillayute, Wash., got 1.93 inches of rain during the 24-hour period up to 7 a.m. EST. Showers were scattered from the northern Pacific Coast to the northern Rockies on Thursday, with snow at some higher elevations. Elsewhere, light showers were scattered over the Northeast. A new cold front ushered cold air into the north-central part of the nation and afternoon temperatures were only in the single digits across northern North Dakota and northwestern Minnesota. Overnight temperatures dipped into the 30s in Southern California and southern Arizona, with freezing temperatures reported in some agricultural areas of Southern California. Thursday's low for the Lower 48 states was 12 degrees below zero at Craig, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Former Colombian President Dead at 83
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf with 2 grafs with burial, national mourning.
DOC.TEXT: Former President Alberto Lleras Camargo, whose career as a political leader, journalist and diplomat spanned 50 years, died Thursday of lung cancer. He was 83. Lleras Camargo, a member of the ruling Liberal Party, began his career in the 1930s as a reporter for Bogota's El Liberal and as a correspondent for the Buenos Aires daily La Prensa. He gained influence with Liberal Party leaders, was named interior minister by President Alfonso Lopez Pumarejo, then succeeded Lopez when he resigned in a political crisis in 1945. Lleras Camargo served one year as president before new elections brought the opposition Conservative Party to power in 1946. In 1947, he was chosen as director of the Panamerican Union, which became the Organization of American States one year later. Lleras Camargo became the first secretary-general of the OAS. In 1958, he was elected to Colombia's presidency in a landslide victory and served until 1962. Afterward, he returned to writing and editing but continued to wield power in the Liberal Party. He also founded the Colombian weekly magazine Semana. Lleras Camargo is survived by his wife, Berta Puga de Lleras, and four children. He was buried at a Bogota cemetary Thursday in an austere, private ceremony, attended by his family and President Virgilio Barco. The government declared three days of national mourning.

DOC.HEAD: Schoolgirl Roots for Noriega
With AM-Noriega Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The 12-year-old who picked Gen. Manuel Noriega to be her pen pal says she stands by the fallen dictator no matter what. ``I don't think he will get a fair trial,'' Sarah York said Thursday. ``In the first place, everyone believes everything that was said against him, and then on the news today I heard that they weren't even going to listen to what he had to say about secrets, about George Bush and the CIA.'' Noriega surrendered to U.S. authorities and was brought Thursday to Miami to face drug trafficking charges. Sarah, daughter of a prison guard, began writing to Noriega following his 1988 indictment in the United States. She visited him twice _ as his guest in October 1988 and on her own with her father a year later. On the last trip, Noriega lauded her as a ``meritorious daughter'' of Panama. She said she sent Noriega an embroidered bookmark for Christmas. Her parents, Pauline and Mitchell York, have been criticized for encouraging their daughter's friendship with a man the United States was trying so hard to oust. Sarah has steadfastly described Noriega as nice and trustworthy. York is writing a book about her friendship with Noriega, with a title President Bush might recognize. ``It's about me and General Noriega,'' York said. ``It's going to be called, `The General I Know: A Kinder, Gentler Noriega.'''

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Government to Open New Holding House for Boat People
DOC.TEXT: A new holding center for Vietnamese boat people is being built in a restricted area, newspapers reported Thursday, and they suggested the new site was selected in part to prevent eyewitness accounts of further forced repatriations. The newspapers identified the new holding center as San Uk Ling, which is in an area of the rural New Territories that requires special permission to enter. On Dec. 12, 51 Vietnamese were forcibly repatriated from the British colony by security forces who entered the Phoenix House detention center before dawn. Reporters outside Phoenix House could hear Vietnamese scream for help and could see a handwritten sign that read: ``Where is your humanity?'' Photographs of the Vietnamese pleading for help through the barred windows of the detention center were printed in newspapers around the world, embarrassing the Hong Kong government. A government spokesman refused to comment directly on the news reports about the new holding center, which appeared in The Hong Kong Standard and the South China Morning Post, but referred reporters to an official statement Wednesday that said: ``The government continues to look for additional sites which could be used for Vietnamese boat people. San Uk Ling is being considered for this purpose and minor works are being carried out there.'' About 44,000 Vietnamese who sailed into this British colony after mid-June 1988 are in squalid detention centers and face repatriation unless they can prove they face persecution in their Communist homeland. The government considers the vast majority of the boat people to be illegal immigrants who fled to Hong Kong to seek a better economic life. Hong Kong media have speculated that the next forced repatriation will take place later this month.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Politburo Member Found Beside Burning Barn with Gunshot Wound
DOC.TEXT: A former Politburo member and Prague Communist Party chief was hospitalized in a psychiatric clinic Thursday after being found shot in the head beside a burning barn, the state news agency CTK reported. Antonin Kapek, who supported the Soviet intervention in Czechoslovakia during the 1968 Prague Spring movement, was found outside a country house at Hlohovice, a Bohemian town west of Prague, CTK said. The agency said investigators recovered a 9mm pistol and one spent cartridge near Kapek. CTK said there was no indication anyone else had been involved in the shooting. Kapek, dismissed from the Politburo and as Prague party boss in 1988, was reported out of danger but was expected to remain in the Plzen psychiatric clinic for several days' evaluation, the agency reported. Several former Communist leaders who opposed the reforms of Alexander Dubcek in the 1968 reform movement, including former President Gustav Husak, have been publicly disgraced since pro-democracy demonstrators this fall forced the Communists to give up their monopoly on power and form a coalition government. Dubcek now heads the new Parliament. Kapek's successor as Prague party chief, Miroslav Stepan, is under arrest and faces charges of abusing power in police crackdowns on demonstrators in Prague during 1988 and 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Coyote Attacks Skier in Yellowstone Park
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT to Oak Lawn sted Oaklawn.
DOC.TEXT: Park rangers Thursday searched for a coyote that mauled a cross-country skier in the worst such attack in at least a decade. Brian Dean, 27, of Oak Lawn, Ill., was listed in good condition at Bozeman Deaconess Hospital in Montana, where he treated for cuts and puncture wounds to his head, neck and arms. Doctors were deciding whether to treat him for rabies. The attack was the boldest in a series of aggressive acts by coyotes in recent weeks, said Yellowstone spokeswoman Joan Anzelmo. ``We have not had anything this severe in a very long time. ... There have been no severe attacks during the 1980s,'' Anzelmo said. ``Each year we have `beggar coyotes' that have been fed and approach people occasionally, and attack them, to a lesser degree than this attack.'' Dean, who works for a park concessionaire, was skiing Wednesday when he saw the coyote lying on the trail in front of him, the spokeswoman said. Anzelmo said the animal attacked Dean before he had a chance to stop or go around it. Dean beat the animal with a ski and was able to ski to a nearby road, where a snowmobiler gave him a ride to the Old Faithful geyser complex. ``If it is found it will be destroyed and taken to the Fish and Wildlife lab in Bozeman for analysis and tests,'' said Anzelmo. Late Wednesday night rangers came across two coyotes near Old Faithful that had been seen repeatedly approaching people for food. Because the animals had lost their fear of man, the rangers shot and killed them, said Anzelmo.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Noriega Appears in Court to Face Drug Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with court appearance. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `Noriega's attorney...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos PAN1,2,3,10,11
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge entered an innocent plea for Manuel Noriega after the fallen dictator refused at his arraignment on drug trafficking charges to acknowledge the United States has a right to try him. ``General Noriega refuses to submit to the jurisdiction of this court ... because he is a political prisoner brought to this country illegally,'' Noriega attorney Frank Rubino told U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler. The judge then entered the plea. Noriega, who defied two U.S. presidents until he was toppled by the Dec. 20 American invasion, was flown to Homestead Air Force Base, 25 miles south of Miami, after surrendering to U.S. troops outside his Vatican Embassy refuge in Panama City. Rubino had indicated the defense might begin with the theory argued earlier that Noriega is immune from prosecution in the United States as a former head of state. Noriega's attorney Steven Kollin earlier had discussed plans for an innocent plea and the initial stages of a defense. ``We're going to request certain pretrial discovery requests including certain sensitive documents, and these sensitive documents will get to the truth of the matter,'' Kollin said. ``I believe he will be found not guilty if we can find a jury of 12 people after this unparalleled pretrial publicity.'' The archbishop of Panama, Marcos McGrath, said today that Noriega decided to give up after realizing that even his long-time supporters had turned against him and he was cornered. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, in television interviews from Washington, explained the surrender by saying on CBS: ``I think he saw the handwriting on the wall.'' He said prosecutors have a strong case against Noriega, adding on NBC, ``If we can make it better, we won't hesitate to do so.'' Security officials speaking on condition of anonymity told The Associated Press that Noriega had been detained at the courthouse. Noriega, who left Panama in his general's uniform, was wearing a khaki open-neck shirt and dark trousers as he awaited the proceedings, a federal worker said. The U.S. Marshals Service has holding cells in the courthouse basement and a private elevator. Each courtroom in the 10-story building has an adjoining holding cell so prisoners can make a court appearance without being seen or having any contact with the public en route. Noriega was greeted at the Florida base by Panamanian exiles, Cuban-Americans and others cheering his downfall. Some of the celebrants moved their party before dawn to the courthouse where authorities briefly sealed off adjacent streets. Streets were reopened as the demonstration broke up, but about 150 to 200 people, many from the news media, remained outside this morning. Panamanians celebrated in the streets as he left the country he has dominated since 1983 as military leader, and Panamanian exiles cheered in the cool night air outside the air base where a C-130 carrying him landed at 2:45 a.m. ``I wanted my children to see the reason people in Panama have been suffering,'' said 33-year-old Manuel Arana, who brought his two young daughters to Homestead. ``To me, this is as important as the Berlin Wall coming down.'' Maj. Bob Barca of the Air Force said Noriega departed the base at 2:51 a.m., but he would not disclose where Noriega was taken. Word of Noriega's departure from Panama late Wednesday triggered celebrations across Panama City. People banged pots and pans and kissed U.S. soldiers. Fireworks lighted the sky around the Vatican mission. Youngsters raced up and down streets waving Panamanian and U.S. flags. ``We are relieved to be rid of this criminal,'' Panamanian President Guillermo Endara said in a statement broadcast on national television. ``The people feel a sense of peace knowing that the monster is leaving our land.'' In Washington, President Bush said Noriega, who had taken refuge in the embassy on Christmas Eve, turned himself over to U.S. authorities voluntarily and ``with the full knowledge'' of the Panamanian government. ``It seems that the Vatican officials basically stressed to Noriega that his only viable strategy was to give himself up,'' said a U.S. official in Washington, speaking on condition of anonymity. Bush said in his nationwide address that he is committed to giving Noriega a fair trial. The United States agreed to three conditions set by Noriega: that he be allowed to make some phone calls, that his decision be kept secret until the actual time of his arrest, and that he be permitted to wear his uniform, administration officials said. Although Gen. Maxwell Thurman, the commanding general of U.S. forces in Panama, said there were ``no deals here,'' administration officials said the United States had also promised Noriega he would not be prosecuted under a new federal law allowing the death penalty for ``drug kingpins.'' The assurances were relayed to Noriega through Vatican officials. The United States did not directly deal with Noriega, the sources said. Thurman said Noriega ``looked vigorous, looked confident'' as he walked out of the compound with the papal nuncio, Monsignor Sebastian Laboa. Thurman said Noriega's surrender ``completes the fourth of our four objectives'' in invading Panama. The others, he said, were to protect American lives, safeguard the integrity of the Panama Canal treaties and restore democracy to Panama. According to authorities, about 290 Panamanian soldiers, 300 civilians, 23 U.S. troops and three American civilians died in the invasion. If convicted, Noriega faces up to 145 years in prison and fined $1.1 million. He faces similar federal charges in Tampa. A roadblock to prosecuting Noriega is his right to demand classified information stemming from his past cooperation with the Central Intelligence Agency, legal experts have said. Noriega reportedly worked closely with the CIA and the Pentagon while he served as the head of Panama's military intelligence service and after he became commander in chief. But the fact he was on U.S. soil brought hope to Panamanians who had lived under Noriega's regime. Among those waiting outside Homestead's main gates early today was Adela Giroldi, whose husband, Moises, was executed after leading a failed coup against Noriega last October. ``This is a great day,'' said Mrs. Giroldi. ``I never thought I'd see Noriega being brought to justice in this way. ... This is a day all Panamanians celebrate.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Promise Extensive Aid to Romania
LaserPhotos BUC3,5
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has promised Romania extensive aid, a senior leader said Thursday, including fuel to provide the winter warmth Nicolae Ceausescu allowed only himself and his acolytes. Foreign policy official Silviu Brucan said Romania expects much from talks with Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the Soviet foreign minister, who arrives Saturday on the first visit by a ranking Kremlin official since Ceausescu was overthrown Dec. 22 and executed three days later. Eastern Europe's democratic tide has pulled other former satellites away from the Soviet Union, but the Romanian revolt appears to have improved relations with Moscow. Ceausescu often went his own way on trade and foreign policy, and had resisted the reform promoted by Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Brucan told a news conference the Communist Party had collapsed and that the National Salvation Front now running the country hopes to publish a new law in late January providing for free elections. He denied reports of an advance plan to oust Ceausescu and said the front's current leaders ``first met'' on Dec. 22 after an uprising of students and workers, supported by the army, had forced Ceausescu out. The Front will enter candidates in the elections, expected in April, and ``take part with all its might,'' said Brucan, a 73-year-old former diplomat dismissed by Ceausescu in 1966. A half-dozen independent parties formed since the downfall of Ceausescu, who ruled Romania for 24 years, argue for a delay in elections. They say holding them so soon will give candidates of the Front an unfair advantage. Brucan said the Front originally wanted elections in July or August, but chose April at the request of students who led the uprising against Ceausescu. ``From the Soviet Union, we expect massive assistance,'' said Brucan, who told British television Wednesday he had received reluctant backing for a revolt against Ceausescu when he discussed the possibility with Soviet policymakers on a visit to Moscow in late 1988. ``We have been promised from the top in Moscow that we will receive aid in oil and natural gas to help us overcome this difficult winter,'' he said. The Soviet Union traditionally been a major energy supplier to Romania. In recent years, Ceausescu paid for the fuel with food and used it for industrial projects while ordering severe energy rationing in frigid, dark homes and offices. His restrictions on heat and light have been lifted, enabling Romanians to enjoy those basic comforts for the first time in eight winters. The new leaders also have said all Romanians will be able to travel freely. Brucan said the Communist Party, which had nearly 4 million members in a nation of 23 million, would not be a contender in the elections. ``The Communist Party is finished, terminated, because it never dissocated itself from Ceausescu,'' said the former ambassador to the United States and United Nations. He had spoken out against Ceausescu the past two years and now oversees foreign policy for the National Salvation Front. ``Moscow is interested in knowing what is going on in Romania because the revolution here was unique and because the Communist Party vanished from the scene,'' Brucan said. He did not say whether Shevardnadze's visit would include discussion of Soviet Moldavia, which consists largely of territory annexed by the Soviets from Romania in 1940 under a secret protocol to the Hitler-Stalin Pact. Soviet Embassy sources said the issue probably would be raised. Moldavians speak the same language as Romanians and want more independence from the Kremlin, which has caused speculation they may seek eventual reunification with Romania. Gorbachev telephoned Romania's interim president, Ion Iliesci, an acquaintance of many years, to express good wishes. The call was prominently reported in Romania's new ``free'' press, which is controlled by the National Salvation Front. Public rallies were legalized Thursday and the leadership said the schools would drop compulsory social and political sciences intended to inculcate admiration of Ceausescu, replacing them with lessons in democracy. Only rallies in support of Ceausescu were allowed while he ran the country. The new decree, signed by Iliescu, requires 48 hours notice of a demonstration.

DOC.HEAD: Medellin Cartel Kidnaps Son of President's Closest Adviser
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Two grafs SUB for grafs 5-6, Two Bogota ... CORRECTING attribution to one paper, not two. Picks up 7th, `Neither the..., SUBBING 10th graf, La Prensa ... to conform
DOC.TEXT: The Medellin cocaine cartel kidnapped the son of President Virgilio Barco's closest adviser in retaliation for the government crackdown on drug lords, a police spokeswoman said Thursday. An official of the secret police, Maj. Alberto Gomez, said a group of men abducted Alvaro Diego Montoya as he was leaving the northern Bogota offices of his financial company on Dec. 20. Montoya is the son of German Montoya, Barco's secretary-general and his closest adviser. ``Evidence indicates the Medellin cartel is behind the kidnapping,'' Gomez said in an interview. He refused to give details of the case. The Bogota newspaper El Tiempo, citing sources at the presidential palace, said Medellin cartel leader Pablo Escobar ordered the abduction in retaliation for the government's antidrug offensive, which began after traffickers assassinated a leading presidential candidate on Aug. 18. A spokeswoman for the investigative unit of the national police said by telephone that Escobar ordered the kidnapping. She gave no details and spoke on condition she not be identified. Neither the woman nor Gomez could confirm a report in El Tiempo that the Medellin group has kidnapped 18 people the last three weeks, many of them members of Colombia's richest families. El Tiempo did not say how authorities established that traffickers, instead of leftist guerrillas, were responsible for the kidnappings. Leftist rebels have abducted scores of political leaders, wealthy farmers and other Colombians in recent years. The guerrillas often either exchange the victims for hefty ransoms or use the victims to carry messages to the government. Another Bogota paper, La Prensa, also citing presidential palace versions, said as Montoya was leaving the offices of his financial services company, Probolsa, an undetermined number of men forced him into a car and drove away. Montoya's family kept the kidnapping secret in an effort to gain his release, La Prensa said. The newspaper said traffickers were apparently holding Montoya in an effort to force the government to negotiate with them. The Extraditables, a shadowy terrorist group linked to the Medellin cartel, has repeatedly demanded negotiations. The group has said traffickers are willing to lay down their arms and abandon the cocaine business in exchange for a government amnesty for past crimes. Barco has rejected such proposals. Since August, the government has seized millions of dollars in property allegedly belonging to Escobar and other drug chiefs, and it has extradited 11 drug suspects to the United States to face charges. Authorities blame the drug barons for 261 terrorist attacks that have killed 209 people since the crackdown began. El Tiempo said Escobar may have ordered Montoya's kidnapping with the intention of demanding a huge ransom. It quoted a presidential source as saying the crackdown has disrupted Escobar's cocaine business and hurt his cash flow. ``Although it is hard to believe, the cartel is confronting a liquidity problem,'' El Tiempo quoted the unidentified source as saying. Police have concentrated on finding Escobar since his close associate, Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, was slain in a gunbattle with police on Dec. 15.

DOC.HEAD: CNN Will Provide Satellite News to Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: Turner Broadcasting System said Thursday it had won its battle with the Bush administration over providing Cable News Network and a satellite receiving station to Vietnam. The Atlanta-based Turner said the Commerce and Treasury departments, which had refused Turner's request on grounds the deal would violate a strict U.S. trade embargo against Vietnam, finally agreed Thursday to allow the company to deliver its 24-hour cable TV news channel to Vietnamese Television. In return, Turner will drop a lawsuit it filed last week in U.S. District Court against the Treasury, Commerce and State departments seeking an injunction to overturn the government's refusal, said Bert Carp, Turner's vice president for government relations. Turner had said it would provide the earth receiving station at no charge and the CNN signal for the price of 50 Vietnamese dong a year, which is less than one U.S. penny. But the administration, in agreeing to the deal, said Turner will not be allowed to collect any payment, according to an administration official who spoke only on the condition of anonymity. The administration official said that in making its decision, the government considered ``the importance of having U.S. news programs in Vietnam.'' At the same time, the administration stuck to its guns over ``strictly prohibiting'' any money changing hands, the official said. Treasury Department spokesman Larry Batdorf said he would have no immediate comment. Congress had amended the trade embargo in 1988 to exempt information materials from trade sanctions. The administration had interpreted that to mean physical materials such as books and videocassettes could be exchanged with Vietnam, but not ``immaterial'' commodities, including TV signals. Vietnam already provides videocassettes to Turner for ``CNN World Report,'' Carp said. Carp, in a prepared statement, said the company was ``pleased the departments of Treasury and Commerce today approved our requests for licenses to provide CNN, along with a satellite dish, to Vietnamese Television.'' He said Vietnam will become the 86th country to receive CNN International.

DOC.HEAD: East German Officials Seek Interim Intelligence Force
AM-With East Germany
DOC.TEXT: The government of Communist Premier Hans Modrow said Thursday it wants to reconstitute an intelligence service to combat a reported rise in ultrarightist activity. The pro-reform movement has insisted that no state security force be authorized until a new government is seated after May 6 elections. Government spokesman Wolfgang Meyer told a news conference the Cabinet reviewed recent incidents of vandalism and violence and determined that a dangerous situation was taking shape. Meyer said failure to move swiftly ``to investigate the rightist tendencies would cause an irrecoverable delay.'' He said Modrow plans to provide ``a very important clarification'' to Parliament next week on the need for a state security service. On Wednesday, a mass march was held in East Berlin's Treptow district to protest recent vandalism by neo-Nazis, including desecration of a Treptow monument to Soviet soldiers. The official ADN news agency said the march drew 250,000 people. Witnesses called that figure inflated. ADN reported numerous instances in the past two weeks of vandalism and confrontations involving right-wing extremists. Opposition groups say the Communists are playing up the neo-Nazi issue to gain support for the party prior to elections. The gravoid charges from congressional Democrats that President Bush was violating his no-new-taxes pledge, the official said. The proposal would have imposed new taxes on paper, glass, plastic and metals that were not recycled. The Environmental Protection Agency, which favored the tax concept as a way of encouraging greater use of recycled materials by U.S. industry, wants to reduce the nation's output of waste by 25 percent by 1992. Bush, as part of his 1988 presidential campaign, promised to ``make a national commitment to reduce waste by recycling and developing technology that produces less waste.'' By making products made from virgin materials more expensive, supporters of the tax had argued it would encourage businesses to use more recycled materials. Another revenue raiser rejected by the administration in recent days would have imposed a sales tax on off-road vehicles, camping equipment, motor homes and pleasure boats. Supporters of that rejected proposal wanted to have the new revenue earmarked for specific recreation and conservation programs on federal lands, but it, too, fell victim to Darman's concern that critics would charge the president with violating his pledge against new taxes. The various decisions on spending and taxes are being made as the administration puts the finishing touches on a proposed $1.23 trillion budget for the fiscal year beginning next October. The budget will be sent to Congress on Jan. 29.

DOC.HEAD: Panamanian Leader is Latest in Extradited Kingpins
DOC.TEXT: The arrival of U.S.-ousted Panamanian leader Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to face federal drug charges was the crowning achievement of stepped-up U.S. efforts to bring key Latin drug figures to this country. Removing drug suspects from their homelands by force has drawn criticism in the foreign countries, threats of retribution by traffickers, and concern from some American defense attorneys. However, prosecutors and President Bush have hailed the cooperation of other nations. Noriega's apprehension ``should send a clear signal that the United States is serious in its determination that those charged with promoting the distribution of drugs cannot escape the scrutiny of justice,'' Bush told the nation Wednesday night. The arrests of leading figures have had little effect on the flow of drugs, said Broward County Sheriff Nick Navarro, but they make life more difficult for traffickers and hearten U.S. drug fighters. ``I think it is important for all of us engaged in this effort to see that some of the people who have been getting away with so much for so long are being neutralized,'' said Navarro, leader of a statewide anti-drug task force and of a department known for cocaine sting operations. Since the Colombian government began a new crackdown on drug dealers last August, 11 fugitives have been brought to the United States to face charges. They include Eduardo Martinez Romero, reputed financial wizard for the Medellin cocaine cartel, being held at the federal penitentiary in Atlanta. No trial date has been set. Last month, the Bolivian government arrested former Interior Minister Luis Arce Gomez, dubbed the ``minister of cocaine,'' and turned him over to U.S. authorities on 1983 drug-trafficking indictments. Arce Gomez is being held without bond south of here. Some Bolivian opposition politicians criticized the extradition of Arce Gomez from the country. Colombian traffickers, blamed for some 200 deaths and hundreds of woundings in the past year in Colombia, have vowed revenge for extraditions and security has been increased for U.S. officials from President Bush to Miami Mayor Xavier Suarez because of alleged assassination plots. A Miami attorney who's a veteran of drug cases said Thursday that Noriega's overthrow highlights a trend toward questionable actions abroad in the war on drugs. ``I am troubled as a criminal defense lawyer about sending troops in a high-fashioned posse to secure someone who's alleged to be a fugitive,'' said Joel Hirschhorn. ``It's scary. It's as if the rule of law has been abandoned in quest of solving a major problem. Even though it's our government that's doing it and it's for a very lofty reason, that doesn't make it right,'' he said. ``When we look back in the year 2000, I'm afraid we're going to have a wasteland of constitutional rights,'' Hirschhorn said. However, he and other attorneys said that while Noriega's attorneys may challenge the way he got here, similar cases have stood up in the courts before. ``There is no formal extradition involved here and the case law is that the court will not look to the circumstances by which the person was brought to the United States, unless those circumstances shock the conscience,'' said Robert W. Merkle, who was U.S. Attorney in Tampa when Noriega was indicted there in 1988. Merkle, who is in a private law practice, successfully prosecuted Colombian cocaine kingpin Carlos Lehder Rivas, taken to the United States on Feb. 4, 1987, after a shootout at a jungle hideout near Medellin, Colombia. Lehder, 40, was convicted of conspiracy, cocaine importation, operating a continuing criminal enterprise and eight counts of possession of cocaine with intent to distribute. He was sentenced in July 1988 to life in prison without the possibility of parole, plus 135 years, and is being held in federal prison in Marion, Ill. Lehder Rivas was considered a leader of the Medellin Cartel, as was Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, killed last month by Colombian police in a shootout at a ranch owned by Pablo Escobar, a reputed kingpin still being pursued by Colombian authorities.

DOC.HEAD: Developer of Strobe Photography Dies
LaserPhoto BX16
DOC.TEXT: Harold ``Doc'' Edgerton, a pioneer in strobe and underwater photography and a professor emeritus at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died of a heart attack Thursday. He was 86. Edgerton died at Massachusetts General Hospital after suffering a heart attack at the MIT faculty club, where he was having lunch, MIT said. The achievements of Edgerton, a much loved professor, spanned history. Edgerton's revolutionary work in the use of strobe lights captured images long hidden to the naked eye. His famous photographs of a drop of milk splashing on a tabletop and of a bullet shooting through an apple showed the world what time looks like when it stands still. Edgerton's strobe lamps enabled the Allies to track enemy movements at night during World War II. His strobes were used to photograph the first atomic tests. His work in sonar helped locate underwater wrecks and was used by undersea explorer Jacques Cousteau. ``If it comes, it comes,'' Edgerton once said of his ideas and inventions. ``It'll come by inspiration and God almighty and hit you right in the middle of the night.'' Edgerton, a native of Nebraska, had been at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology since 1926, when he started as a student in electrical engineering. Officially retired from MIT in 1968, he lived in an apartment next to the campus and still came into his office five days a week. ``I got stuck,'' he said. ``But it's given me a very nice place to work.'' Most weekdays, Edgerton could be found in his laboratory at MIT, just off MIT's ``Strobe Alley,'' where his work is displayed. In addition to his inventions, Edgerton and two former students started a company called EG&G in 1947 specializing in electronic technology. Now a multi-million dollar engineering concern, the company was under contract to the military and designed and operated systems that timed and fired U.S. nuclear bomb tests. At a recent meeting of the Archaeological Society of America, Edgerton offered words of advice to a group gathered to honor his life's achievements. ``Work like hell, tell everyone everything you know, close a deal with a handshake, and have fun,'' Edgerton told the society's members. He was awarded a national medal of technology by President Reagan in 1988. Undersea explorer Jacques Cousteau, who used some of Edgerton's sonar equipment and the two collaborated in locating the British Army ship, the HMS Britannia which was sunk by a mine off the Greek coast during World War I. Cousteau nicknamed Edgerton ``Papa Flash.'' Edgerton's influence even penetrated to the depths of the Titanic. His Edgerton-Benthos underwater camera was used to photograph the shipwreck when it was discovered in 1986. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Esther, a daughter and a son.

DOC.HEAD: William F. Share Named President of Journal
DOC.TEXT: William F. Share, senior vice president-marketing for Journal-Sentinel Inc., was on Thursday named president of the company, which publishes The Milwaukee Journal and Milwaukee Sentinel. Share replaces Robert A. Kahlor, who was named vice chairman of the board of Journal-Sentinel Inc. He remains executive vice president of Journal Communications, the parent company of Journal-Sentinel Inc. Beverly Klein was named senior vice president-marketing; Jack Koller was named vice president-advertising, replacing Klein; and Barry Slavsky was named to a new position of senior vice president-publishing operations. Koller had been advertising sales manager, and Slavsky had been marketing manager. Robert M. Dye, who had been communications manager for the newspapers, was named director of corporate communication for Journal Communications. He replaces Jack E. Knake, who is retiring. The appointments were announced in a news release.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Son-In-Law Found Guilty Of Drunk Driving
DOC.TEXT: The estranged husband of President Bush's daughter was found guilty Thursday of drunken driving, fined $1,285, and prohibited from driving in Massachusetts for one year, a court clerk said. At a pre-trial conference in Framingham District Court, William H. LeBlond changed his plea from innocent to guilty to a charge of operating under the influence of alcohol, said court clerk Anthony Colonna. A charge of possession of marijuana was continued without a finding until July 3, 1990, Colonna said. LeBlond, 32, of Cape Elizabeth, Maine, was stopped by police Nov. 10, 1989, when a pick-up he was driving in Maynard was reported weaving, court records showed. LeBlond, a contractor, is separated from his wife, Dorothy Bush LeBlond. They have two children.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Search for Bodies in Train Wreckage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead graf; SUBS 8th graf, The first ... DELETING eight as number of remaining cars
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers with acetylene torches cut into crushed railroad cars searching for victims of Pakistan's worst train wreck, which officials said killed at least 210 people Thursday and injured 700. Television showed rows of bodies wrapped in blankets near the wreckage of an overcrowded 16-car passenger train that was switched onto the wrong track early Thursday and struck a freight standing in a village station. The locomotive was overturned and several cars were crushed or ripped open. Bodies, baggage and debris were strewn near the wreckage. Officials at the scene said 210 people were known dead and Pakistan Railways said rescuers had recovered 165 bodies. The engineer of the passenger train survived. The passenger train Zakaria Bahauddin, named for a Moslem saint, was on a 500-mile overnight run south from Multan to Karachi with many more passengers than its 1,408-seat capacity, said Muktar Ahmad Abassi, regional traffic officer for Pakistan Railways at Sukkur, 225 miles north of Karachi. When it approached Sangi village in Sindh province, which it was supposed to bypass, an improperly set switch threw it onto a siding where an empty 67-car freight train was standing, he said. Abassi said the passenger train was traveling at least 35 mph when it hit the freight, and the result was ``the worst rail accident in Pakistan's history.'' The first three cars, built to hold 88 passengers each, were devastated and the next two were badly damaged, Abassi said. The remaining cars stayed on the track and later were hauled to Karachi. Most of the dead were in the first three cars and many passengers in the next two were seriously injured, officials said. Medical workers said hundreds of people went to Sangi and Sukkur to donate blood in response to an appeal on Pakistan radio. Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto expressed ``her deep sense of shock and grief,'' said a statement reported by the official Associated Press of Pakistan. ``The prime minister offered her heartfelt sympathies to the bereaved families,'' it said. ``She prayed to almighty Allah to grant eternal peace to the departed souls.'' Ms. Bhutto dispatched her railway minister and other authorities to the scene to start an investigation, the agency reported. Hazul Baksh, a municipal official in Sukkur, said some of the injured were taken by helicopter to Karachi and other cities because of overcrowding in the city's seven hospitals, which have a total of 300 beds. Pakistan's worst previous railway accident occurred in 1958 and took 150-200 lives. Far fewer people were injured than in the crash at Sangi.

DOC.HEAD: Fellow Nuns Have `No Doubt' Contras Ambushed Religous Workers
DOC.TEXT: Other Roman Catholic nuns said Thursday they believed Contra rebels were responsible for an ambush in which two nuns were killed and two other members of the clergy were wounded. ``We know the area is full of Contras,'' said Mother Superior Paquita Alcacer, head of the Immaculate Conception School in Managua. ``By logic, if they (Contras) are capable of killing peasants, defenseless women and children, then there is no doubt'' they attacked the pickup truck on New Year's Day. She said that ``is what I think, which doesn't necessarily mean it's the truth, but I think so.'' Mother Superior Raymond Grieble of the Order of St. Agnes, the Fond du Lac, Wis., order to which the nuns belonged, said her religious workers always travel in clearly marked vehicles. Mother Raymond, regional head of the order in Managua, said she did not know whether the pickup carried the customary white-and-yellow Roman Catholic flag, but added: ``We did have red crosses on the front window and the back window.'' Such identification may have been meaningless because the attack occurred after nightfall, when only headlights would be visible. The leftist Sandinista government and U.S.-backed Contras have accused each other of ambushing the vehicle in a remote part of northeastern Nicaragua. Sister Francisca Colomer, a Nicaraguan Miskito Indian wounded by grenade shrapnel was flown Milwaukee Thursday morning on a plane that carried the body of Sister Maureen Courtney home for burial. The other dead nun, Sister Teresa Rosales, a Miskito Indian, was buried Wednesday in Puerto Cabezas, about an hour's drive from her hometown of Santa Teresa in northeastern Nicaragua. Auxiliary Bishop Pablo Schmitz of the Capuchin order was wounded in the left arm. Sister Mirna Alvarado of the Order of St. Agnes said he underwent surgery Wednesday and was in good condition at a military hospital in Managua. Barricada, the Sandinista party newspaper, said in an editorial Thursday the attack proved the need for disarming the Contras. While the rebels are armed, it said, ``each day that passes there will be a greater number of defenseless citizens assassinated.'' Contra leaders have denied responsibility for the attack and accused the Sandinistas of carrying it out n an attempt to discredit the rebels with the U.S. Congress. Current U.S. aid to the Contras runs out at the end of February and Congress is expected to discuss continued non-lethal assistance. The Bush administration has indicated it wants the Contras to remain in existence until after Nicaragua's general elections Feb. 25.

DOC.HEAD: Official Says China Indicating It Will Change Human Rights Record
