DOC.TEXT: A senior administration official said Thursday that China has given indications it will improve its grim human rights record in the wake of talks with two high-ranking Bush administration officials. The official, speaking to White House reporters on condition of anonymity, would not disclose those indications but answered affirmatively when asked if there were any signs Beijing would conduct itself differently on human rights. President Bush was widely criticized for sending National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft and Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger to Beijing in the months after the president barred high-level exchanges to protest China's violent crackdown on pro-democracy protesters in Tiananmen Square in June. The second trip, a clandestine mission announced only after the two arrived in Beijing last month, was billed as an opportunity for the officials to brief the Chinese on Bush's recent summit meeting with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, as well as open the door to possibly normalizing U.S.-China relations. ``We were given some indications of the Chinese attitude which, in addition to the president's interest in a strategic sense in informing the Chinese of the discussions at Malta, seemed to make it important'' that the two make that trip, the official said. Vice President Dan Quayle has predicted that China will take actions within six months that will make it clear that Bush made the right decision in resuming contact with Beijing. While dropping such hints, officials have refused to say what China is expected to do. Bush said he was cutting off high level contacts and imposing economic sanctions after Beijing sent tanks to mow down the demonstrators, leaving a massacre of hundreds. It was only after the December trip was announced that it was revealed Scowcroft and Eagleburger had also visited China in July, the month after the bloody repression at Tiananmen Square. ``I don't think simply sitting on the sideline and condemning is really the way to deal with the situation that prevailed in China,'' the official told reporters. Scowcroft and Eagleburger ``forcefully represented'' what the United States expects of China, the official said. Meanwhile, Bush notified Congress that the International Development Association, a World Bank subsidiary that makes low-cost loans to poor nations, had not made any new loans to China since June's crackdown. Bush filed the report to comply with legislation enacted in November that puts restrictions on U.S. payments to the fund.

DOC.HEAD: Legislator Accuses Shamir of Inciting Extremists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to include Shamir on Baker meeting to revive peace efforts; picks up 6th, `There is...'
DOC.TEXT: A legislator of the center-left Labor Party accused Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir on Thursday of helping incite death threats against liberal legislators who supported a peace demonstration in Jerusalem. Police Commissioner David Krauss ordered an investigation of police behavior during the demonstration, which took place Saturday in Arab east Jerusalem. Police fired rubber bullets, tear gas and water cannons, and beat demonstrators with clubs when about 15,000 peace activists tried to form a human chain around the walled Old City. Shamir said Parliament members who supported the demonstration were ``traitors.'' Labor Party legislator Avraham Burg said Thursday Shamir's comments were partly to blame for death threats Burg and other liberal legislators received. In another development Thursday, Shamir said Secretary of State James A. Baker III and the foreign ministers of Israel and Egypt would meet next month in an attempt to revive Middle East peace efforts. The meeting had been expected in January, but never was scheduled. ``As a result of the events in the world and the crisis that we had in the government and the fact that the Egyptians are not prepared, it seems as though the meeting will be in February,'' Shamir's office said in a statement. Baker proposed the meeting as a way of breaking a deadlock caused by Israel's refusal of any contacts with the Palestine Liberation Organization. The death threats against liberal legislators came from the Sicarites, a shadowy group that has claimed responsibility for several attacks on Arabs and liberal Israelis. ``There is an exact, direct and full connection between verbal violence and physical violence,'' Burg said on army radio. ``When the prime minister is the prosecutor, the Sicarites are his henchmen.'' Peace activists demanded an independent inquiry to examine what they called ``excessive use of force'' by police during the demonstration. Officials said police charged after demonstrators hurled stones and raised outlawed Palestinian flags, but most reporters said they saw no flags or stone-throwing before the police charged. Krauss asked for film and tapes from television crews to be examined by a special police unit that will investigate the incident. The unit includes a state attorney. About 1,000 Israelis plan to make another appeal for peace by holding what would be an unprecedented meeting with PLO chief Yasser Arafat, organizers said. Adopting the theme ``Reach Out for Peace,'' the activists hope to urge Palestinian-Israel negotiations and dramatize opposition to a law that bans contacts with the Palestine Liberation Organization. The daily Hadashot newspaper said the planned meeting in Egypt may be attended by European Parliament members and several dovish Israeli legislators. Sarah Osashki of the collective farm of Kibbutz Ramot Menashe said the meeting was expected in late January or early February. Neva Garbars, another activist involved in the organizing, said Egypt had not formally consented to act as host. In the occupied territories, the army said Muhammad Shehta Abu Shaar, 20, died Thursday of a rubber bullet wound to the head suffered during a clash with soldiers last week in Gaza. Shaar is the 642nd Palestinian to be killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the 2-year-old uprising against Israeli occupation. Forty-three Israelis have been killed in the violence, and 166 Palestinians have been slain by fellow Arabs who accused them of collaborating with Israeli officials.

DOC.HEAD: Families to be Housed in Apartments for Ceausescu Associates
With AM-Romania
DOC.TEXT: Families whose homes were destroyed in fierce fighting in Bucharest after Nicolae Ceausescu was overthrown will move into spacious apartments built for the late dictator's associates, media said Thursday. The daily Adevarul (Truth), which replaced the Communist Party daily after the Dec. 22 revolution that ousted Ceausescu, said 110 of the apartments built along the Boulevard of the Victory of Socialism, the dictator's pet project, would be turned over to homeless families. The homes were destroyed in fierce fighting last month around the state-run television, one of the centers of the revolution, and other points in Bucharest, Adevarul said. It said the 110 apartments concerned had been vacant for four years, pending completion of the Palace of the Republic that tops what Adevarul referred to as ``the Pharaonic artery'' of the ``former Boulevard of the Victory of Socialism.'' Families are being allotted some of the new apartments. But officials at the site said actual turnover might be delayed because only the facades of many apartment buildings are complete. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, poured money and labor into their pet project to put their stamp on central Bucharest, and workers hurriedly put up the elegant facades. But the interiors are still largely incomplete, apart from a few apartments clsoe to the vast Palace itself, officials told The Associated Press. The 10-story, elegantly designed apartment blocks were originally built for members of the Securitate, the Communist Party and government elite who were to work in the Palace, Adevarul said. Six years ago, Ceausescu ordered thousands of old homes and dozens of churches and other historic landmarks destroyed in the center of Bucharest to make way for the 500-foot wide, three-mile-long boulevard and the gigantic, still unfinished Palace at its head. Ceausescu and his wife were tried by a military tribunal and executed on Christmas Day.

DOC.HEAD: With Noriega in Custody, Pressure Is on the Prosecutors
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 4 grafs for grafs 5-7 pvs, It would, to raise reference to possibility of superseding indictment, inserts graf after 25th pvs, Runkel said, with additional comment on superseding charges
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors facing a minefield of legal challenges to their drug cases against Manuel Antonio Noriega combed CIA files Thursday for secrets that defense lawyers might be able to expose at his trial. What's more, there is the potential problem of finding a jury for a man publicly branded as a thug by President Bush. Earlier this week, Dexter W. Lehtinen, the U.S. attorney in Miami and the prosecutor overseeing the case against Noriega, came to Washington to join in the review of CIA documents that might pertain to the case, said Justice Department spokesman David Runkel. ``It would be our intention to review material which may be relevant,'' Runkel said of the review, which began this week. In the meantime, Runkel suggested that financial documents and other material seized from Noriega's headquarters in Panama might be used to bring a superseding indictment against the fallen dictator. Those documents have already helped investigators trace drug-trafficking profits Noriega allegedly stashed in European banks, Runkel said. The review of files at CIA headquarters was being conducted by Justice Department lawyers and prosecutors from Miami and Tampa, where Noriega faces a second set of drug charges, Runkel said. The review, which would normally occur before an indictment is returned, is being conducted to determine if there are intelligence documents that Noriega could obtain for his defense because of the extensive dealings he once had with the CIA as an informant. The deposed Panamanian ruler is expected to try to force the dismissal of the drug-trafficking charges against him by threatening to disclose sensitive information about his longstanding relationship with the CIA. But Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, in an appearance on ABC-TV's ``Good Morning America'' Thursday, indicated the review had not turned up anything so far that would hobble the case. ``Obviously, we can't anticipate what General Noriega may raise by way of defense at trial, but suffice it to say at the moment that there's nothing that's come to our attention that would indicate that this trial can't go forward,'' the attorney general said. Runkel stressed that Noriega would have to show that any secrets he thinks are in the CIA's possession are relevant to the charges that he provided a haven for Colombian drug lords and shared in their profits. ``This is a drug case and I would assume that any documents which anyone would seek to introduce have to meet the test of relevancy,'' Runkel said. To show relevancy, Noriega would have to demonstrate that the CIA was a partner in drug operations and such evidence ``is just not there,'' said one Justice Department official, speaking on the condition of anonymity. Besides CIA secrets, prosecutors face a number of potentially serious legal issues that are expected to be raised by Noriega's defense lawyers. One is the issue of pre-trial publicity that will most certainly be raised in light of statements since the U.S. invasion of Panama made by Bush and others in the administration. Before Noriega gave himself up, Bush said that the general should be ``brought to justice for poisoning the children of America'' with illegal drugs and that the Vatican, in whose embassy Noriega took refuge, had a history ``of giving asylum to people who are fleeing _ even thugs like Noriega.'' After Noriega's arrest, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater told reporters, ``You can expect the president and all of us to be very careful in the days ahead not to offer any comments on the case that might prejudice it in any way.'' The Justice Department's Runkel, who himself once called the ex-ruler an ``international thug,'' has now taken to describing him as ``a defendant of allegations of criminal conduct.'' Thornburgh, noting that pre-trial publicity did not prevent trials of Watergate defendants, expressed confidence that statements about Noriega wouldn't jeopardize the courts' ability to pick impartial juries. ``We've had numerous cases within the past decade or so of persons who have recived a great deal of public attention who have, in fact, been the subject of extended congressional hearings that set forth all kinds of charges against them,'' Thornburgh said, recalling trials arising from the Watergate and Iran-Contra affairs. Louis Michael Seidman, a criminal law professor at the Georgetown University Law Center, noted that then-President Nixon's comments labeling Charles Manson as a criminal didn't derail the cult killer's murder trial in Los Angeles. ``The Supreme Court has never said that adverse pre-trial publicity is such that it would make a trial impossible in a notorious case,'' Seidman said. The justices ``have always said it is the obligation of the judge to do the things necessary to minimize the effect of the publicity.'' Careful questioning of prospective jurors would accomplish that goal, Seidman said. If the Justice Deparment tries to use as evidence material seized during the U.S. invasion, defense lawyers are expected to claim that the warrantless search violated Noriega's Fourth Amendment rights. The Justice Department says that items found include cocaine and financial documents that have allowed investigators to trace as much as $10 million Noriega allegedly kept in foreign banks. The assets are being frozen in five European countries. Runkel said prosecutors may use evidence seized in Panama to bolster the existing case and he wouldn't rule out the option of using it to seek a superseding indictment against Noriega. Later in the day, Runkel said: ``We're on the early end of reviewing documents and no decisions have been made in this area. It's premature to talk about what action might or might not be taken in the future.'' Seidman said he doubted a Fourth Amendment challenge to the use of the evidence would result in the evidence being excluded from the case. ``In an emergency situation, in a fast-moving situation or in situations where the primary aim is not law enforcement, you don't need a warrant and you don't need probable cause'' to search a location, Seidman said. ``I would not be surprised if a court would hold that the exclusionary rule does not apply to the armed forces when conducting military operations,'' Seidman said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Vatican Planned to Lift Immunity to Allow Noriega's Arrest
With AM-Panama
DOC.TEXT: The Vatican Embassy told Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega it would lift its diplomatic immunity and invite Panamanian security forces inside to arrest him if he didn't voluntarily leave, a spokesman said Thursday. Rev. Javier Villanueva, assistant to the papal nuncio, Monsignor Sebastian Laboa, said Noriega was not given a specific deadline. ``But if he would not have given himself up, the Panamanian government, not the U.S. government, would have been invited to send in forces to take him out. We would have lifted the diplomatic immunity,'' Villanueva said in a telephone interview. He said that position was made explicitly clear to Noriega, who surrendered Wednesday night to U.S. troops after a 10-day stay at the embassy that began Christmas Eve. Meanwhile, Maj. Gen. Marc Cisneros, the commander of U.S. Army South, confirmed that Noriega kept a submachine gun under his bed during his entire stay at the nunciature. That would have made it difficult for unarmed embassy staffers to remove him against his will. Vatican and U.S. officials have insisted Noriega walked out of the embassy Wednesday night because he came to the conclusion that ``he had no other option'' or that it was in his own best interests. ``This (lifting diplomatic immunity) would never be done with anyone taking sanctuary for political reasons. But this man is a highly dangerous criminal,'' said Villanueva. Capturing Noriega might have been a mixed blessing for the Panamanians. President Guillermo Endara said that the new government had no facilities or judicial system adequate to the task of prosecuting and imprisoning the fallen dictator and that Noriega should go to the United States, where he has been charged with drug trafficking. But several top Panamanian officials said there was no provision in Panamanian law for Noriega to be extradited, so if he had come into Panamanian hands they might have been legally stuck with him. Vice President Ricardo Arias Calderon had suggested early this week that if Noriega did not voluntarily give himself up, the Vatican could move its embassy, leaving Noriega behind. According to that scenario, the Vatican would have taken down its flag from the pole in front of its compound, removed its personnel and established a temporary or permanent mission in another building. But Villanueva, a parish priest at one of Panama's most important churches who was helping Laboa, said that course was not seriously considered. He said the lifting of immunity so Noriega could be removed was ``a hypothesis that became logical.''

DOC.HEAD: Baby Drowns in Toilet While Mom Washes Dishes
DOC.TEXT: A 10-month-old girl accidentally fell into a toilet an drowned while her mother washed dishes in the kitchen of their home, state police said Thursday. The mother thought the baby, Stephanie Ann Lewis, was playing with her 3-year-old brother, according to state police at Westport. Authorities said the baby was left alone for a matter of minutes. The woman noticed the baby was missing and found the toddler face-down in the toilet, police said. The mother tried to revive the baby, who was rushed by ambulance to an area hospital and pronounced dead at 2:30 a.m. Wednesday. Police declined to identify the mother because she was not charged.

DOC.HEAD: Ortega Urges U.S. Troops to Leave Panama
With AM-Panama
DOC.TEXT: President Daniel Ortega said Thusday the United States should withdraw its troops from Panama at once because they had achieved their goal of capturing Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. ``Noriega is already in the power of the Yankees ... so there isn't a single reason for the Yankees to remain in Panama, not one more moment,'' Ortega said. U.S. withdrawal, he added, would provide ``some tranquility to the Central Americans and the Latin Americans.'' Noriega turned himself in to U.S. authorities Wednesday night in Panama City after spending 10 days in the Vatican Embassy. He was flown to Miami and arraigned Thursday on drug trafficking charges. ``The people and government of Nicaragua, as well as the peoples and governments of Latin America ... demand that the North American government withdraw immediately from Panama,'' Ortega said in La Libertad, his hometown in central Chontales province, 110 miles east of Managua. His remarks were broadcast on the official government radio station La Voz de Nicaragua. The president is campaigning for the Feb. 25 general elections. Ortega put the armed forces on maximum alert when U.S. troops invaded Panama on Dec. 20. The leftist Sandinista government often has predicted a U.S. invasion of Nicaragua.

DOC.HEAD: General Mills to Drop Benefit Breakfast Cereal
DOC.TEXT: General Mills Inc. says it will drop its Benefit breakfast cereal because of poor sales in the wake of a federal inquiry provoked by the company's claim that the cereal could help lower cholesterol. ``We envisioned that, with all the interest in cholesterol, a product like Benefit would appeal to a broad range of consumers,'' company spokesman R. Craig Shulstad said Wednesday. ``What we found was that it appealed to a much narrower range than we had expected.'' The cereal contains about 8 percent by weight of psyllium, a soluble fiber that General Mills said had been scientifically shown to reduce cholesterol. The company said it was removing Benefit from grocery store shelves after eight months of disappointing sales in test markets. ``It was strictly a business decision based on disappointing product performance,'' Shulstad said. General Mills' marketing strategy and psyllium, which separated Benefit from other cereals promoted for their health benefits, led to a controversy in the food industry over whether the cereal was a drug or a food. The Food and Drug Administration expressed concern about the amount of psyllium people should consume and called for supporting scientific data. ``General Mills brought the downfall of this product on themselves by trying to market t with Noriega associates:

DEC. 19 _ President Bush orders U.S. troops into combat in Panama City on a mission to seize Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega to face federal drug charges in United States. Noriega, aware of increased U.S. military activity, goes to Colon, 50 miles north of Panama City, to inspect a new military facility. Seven hours before the invasion he visits a Panamanian Defense Forces officers' club on the military side of the international airport. DEC. 20 _ American forces attack and announce within hours they have smashed Noriega's forces. Noriega flees the club when the airport is attacked and eludes American troops by driving around Panama City in circles. He avoids contact with PDF forces, fearing a trap, and does not take charge of his troops in the fighting. In a radio broadcast recorded in advance, he tells Panamanians: ``We are in trench warfare now and we will maintain the resistance. ... Our slogan is to win or die _ not one step back.'' DEC. 21 _ Bush says U.S. forces will scour Panama for ``as long as it takes'' to capture Noriega. An ``agitated'' Noriega spends several days at different locations but most of the time is at the home of a relative of Marcella Tason, his personal secretary. While in hiding he considers but rules out fleeing to the mountains. He also was believed to have contemplated going to Cuba's embassy, but backed off because that compound was surrounded by U.S. troops. DEC. 24 _ Noriega ends up in the house of the mother of his mistress, Vicky Amado. Reports say her teen-age daughter called the information number set up to take tips on finding Noriega and that the 82nd Airborne Delta Force sent a five-man team to seize him but missed him by 30 minutes. Noriega contacts the Vatican Embassy and within a few hours a rendezvous is arranged and a representative of the Embassy picks Noriega up at a Panama City Dairy Queen and drives him to the nunciature. Other reports said Noriega drove to the Vatican after learning of the surrender of one of his closest commanders, Luis del Cid. The Bush administration demands he be turned over to face drug charges and intense negotiations involving the Vatican, U.S. government and new Panamanian government ensue. DEC. 25-JAN. 2 _ Noriega stays in Vatican Embassy with minimal hospitality, living in a small room on the second floor with no telephone, a broken TV set and a Bible. JAN. 3 _ After being assured he would not face the death penalty in the United States, Noriega decides to surrender. He asks only that he be permitted a few phone calls, including one to his wife in the Cuban Embassy, that he be permitted to wear his uniform, and that his surrender be kept secret until it was done. He leaves the Vatican Embassy and surrenders to U.S. authorities. JAN. 4 _ Plane carrying Noriega arrives at Homestead Air Force Base in Florida. Noriega is arraigned on drug-trafficking charges and remanded to the custody of the U.S. marshals.

DOC.HEAD: Administration: Vatican Had Been Ready to Kick Noriega Out
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 6th graf: ``In Panama,'' with similar account from nuncio's assistant; drops last graf and minor editing to trim
DOC.TEXT: Manuel Antonio Noriega surrendered to U.S. authorities only after the Vatican Embassy in Panama City told him his safe haven there ``would expire'' as of noon Thursday, a senior Bush administration official said Thursday. The official, briefing reporters at the White House on the condition of anonymity, said the ultimatum may well have prompted Noriega to turn himself over to U.S. troops rather than be left to deal with a hostile crowd surrounding the embassy. ``The papal nuncio had said that his asylum or what have you would expire by noon today, meaning he (Noriega) would no longer be a welcome guest,'' the official said. He speculated that Noriega might have noted the crowd and wondered what would have happened to him ``if the troops stepped aside.'' ``As far as I know, we had absolutely no role to play in organizing that demonstration,'' the official said. In Panama, Rev. Javier Villanueva, assistant to the papal nuncio, said it was made clear to Noriega that if he had not given himself up, ``the Panamanian government, not the U.S. government, would have been invited to send in forces to take him out.'' In Miami, at Noriega's arraignment on drug charges, attorney Frank Rubino said that the general had been told Wednesday protection would be withdrawn from the embassy and that he surrendered to avoid further bloodshed. Rubin told the judge at the arraignment that Noriega is a political prisoner, and he refused to enter a plea to the charges. The judge then entered an innocent plea. Meanwhile, Noriega's removal from Panama was hailed by U.S. officials, who said it would hasten withdrawal of U.S. troops. The officials vowed to avoid harsh comments that might sabotage his trial on drug charges. But there was no doubt the administration was enjoying Noriega's surrender and subsequent trip in custody to Florida to stand trial. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney called it the ``icing on the cake'' for the U.S. military action that began Dec. 20. The senior administration official, asked about reports that Vatican staff members were considering evacuating the mission and leaving Noriega alone at noon, said: ``I have no further understanding of what would happen at noon today if Noriega didn't leave.'' The official said that members of Noriega's family now sheltered in the Cuban Embassy in Panama City are expected to be given safe passage to the Dominican Republic. With Noriega facing arraignment in Miami and his countrymen rejoicing at his departure back in Panama City, Bush dispatched Colin Powell, the nation's top general, to Panama to work on troop withdrawals. Cheney said on CBS-TV that Powell, who is chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, would work with the head of the Southern Command to ``develop a plan for withdrawing those troops over the next several weeks.'' Several Democratic members of Congress also called for quick withdrawal of the forces that ousted Noriega from power. ``We need the U.S. military presence not only to become less visible but less present,'' said one of them, Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee. At the White House, Bush's spokesman was choosing his words carefully in speaking of the deposed ruler previously dismissed as a ``thug'' in comments by the president as recently as last weekend. ``You can expect the president and all of us to be very careful in the days ahead not to offer any comments on the case that might prejudice it in any way,'' said press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. Some 2,000 of the 14,000 extra troops sent in for the invasion have come home. However, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said the total number of troops in Panama _ about 26,000 _ has changed little because military police and civil affairs specialists have replaced some combat units A day after he triumphantly announced Noriega's surrender on nationwide television, the president kept out of the public eye. He was said to have telephoned Pope John Paul II to thank him for any efforts in persuading Noriega to leave the Vatican Embassy in Panama City and surrender. ``The pope expressed his humanitarian concerns for the people of Panama. President Bush assured the pope that Gen. Noriega will be treated to all the protections of U.S. law and would receive a fair trial,'' Fitzwater said. In other developments: _A U.S. drug enforcement official said Noriega might eventually be returned to Panama for trial on other charges, including murder. ``Returning him to Panama remains a possibility for the future'' after his U.S. trial, said David Westrate, assistant administrator of the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration. _Pentagon spokesman Williams said a Noriega bodyguard overheard two U.S. servicemen discussing the invasion of Panama hours before it occurred. It was unclear, however, whether the guard relayed that information to Noriega, Williams said. U.S. prosecutors combed CIA files for sensitive materials in advance of an expected request by Noriega _ in connection with his trial _ for classified documents dealing with his long relationship with the agency. In recounting Noriega's surrender and arrest, U.S. officials said the ousted military leader was handcuffed, read his constitutional rights in Spanish and examined by U.S. military doctors aboard the C-130 military transport plane that flew him to Homestead Air Force Base, near Miami. The doctors found Noriega in good health, Fitzwater said. He faces trial on two-year-old drug-trafficking charges that accuse him of accepting a $4.6 billion bribe from Colombian drug lords, among other offenses. Noriega could face up to 145 years in prison and $1.1 million in fines if convicted on all counts. Administration officials said that Noriega's surrender left four Panamanians still sheltered in the Vatican Embassy in Panama City, all Noriega loyalists. Fitzwater said that U.S. troops will stay outside the building while the four remain. Bush also called Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney in Canada Thursday to discuss the Noriega surrender and to thank Canada for supporting the United States at the United Nations, which voted 75-20 last week to condemn the U.S. invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Toyota Exec: Won't Be Able to Tell Import From Domestic
DOC.TEXT: Distinctions between domestic and imported cars will disappear in this decade, a Toyota Motor Corp. executive said Thursday, and Ford Motor Co. introduced what it said ushered in the age of the ``world car.'' During the 1990s, engineering, design and manufacturing centers will move freely around the world, focusing in Europe, Asia and North America, said Robert McCurry, executive vice president of Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. Inc., the American marketing arm for Japan's largest automaker. ``Protectionist sentiments will be out of step as trade deficits begin to balance out,'' McCurry said during the second day of a three-day media preview of the North American International Auto Show in Detroit. A few hours before he spoke, Ford officials described their ``centers of excellence'' approach that led to the development of the 1991 Ford Escort. The car was developed in association with Mazda Motor Corp. of Japan, which provides some of the drivetrain and other components for the successor to one of the best-selling cars in the 1980s. ``It's a new way of doing business at Ford,'' said company executive vice president Alex Trotman. The ``world car,'' along with its sister vehicle Mercury Tracer, will be built in Wayne, Mich., and Hermosillo, Mexico, and Ford expects to sell about 500,000 of them in North America and 950,000 worldwide annually. Sales of Escorts have been slipping lately. In 1987 and 1988, it was the best-selling car in the United States. In 1989, it slipped to third place, behind the Honda Accord and the Ford Taurus. But Escort assembly plants were down for part of the year to change over for new models. One of the reasons Ford executives hope the car will catch on is the impact that it will have on the company's corporate average fuel economy ratings, or CAFE. The federal government mandates that automakers must maintain a fleet fuel economy average of 27.5 miles per gallon during the 1990 model year or face fines. There has been speculation the minimum will rise in coming years. That gives automakers an impetus to sell small, more fuel-efficient cars. But there's a gamble involved since small cars don't provide automakers with as much profit on a per-car basis as larger cars. And incentives, which have become a part of buying cars these days, can cut further into the profit margin for each car sold. ``These products don't provide the normal level of profit because of the volumes we have to maintain for CAFE,'' said Kenneth Dabrowski, program manager for international and small car programs. Ford Chairman Donald Petersen said the new Escort ``couldn't be more crucial'' to Ford's CAFE rating. ``It's the foundation upon which the whole Ford Motor Company CAFE is built,'' said Ford Division General Manager Tom Wagner. In addition to helping the company with its average fuel economy ratings, auto analysts said Thursday it keeps Ford in the lower-priced, entry-level market, a market segment that Chrysler Corp. largely is leaving when it stops production of its Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizon cars next month. General Motors Corp. is in the segment with its Geo line of small cars. The Escort-Tracer program involves a $2-billion Ford investment. The level of Mazda's isn't known, but analysts speculated that it must be in the neighborhood of $1 billion. Mazda builds its 323 Hatchback off the platform used in the Ford and Mercury vehicles.

DOC.HEAD: Harvard Team Details, Denounces Activists' Torture in Haiti
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ A team of health and human rights experts from Harvard University on Thursday denounced what they called the torture of four jailed activists charged with plotting to assassinate Haiti's military ruler. ``The inability of the prisoners to get adequate and independent medical treatment amounts to a continuation of the original torture,'' said Matthew Dumont of Harvard's International Health And Human Rights Group. Dumont, a physician at Massachusetts General Hospital, said the nine-member delegation on Tuesday visited Jean-Auguste Mesyeux, Evans Paul, Marino Etienne and Frantz Patrick Beauchard in the national penitentiary. Delegation co-leader Kari Nadeau, a Harvard medical student, said that following a medical examination of the prisoners delegates found Paul had a crushed hip, extremely high blood pressure and his chest ``had been beaten in.'' Ms. Nadeau said Mesyeux had kidney damage and hearing problems as a result of beating. Beauchard's right eardrum was scarred, and his hearing and vision were impaired. Etienne, who cannot stand up alone, had kidney problems, anemia and a broken finger as a result of mistreatment, she said. Ms. Nadeau said the men were receiving no medical treatment, and ``all are still in pain.'' She said the penitentiary was disease-ridden and guards carried whips and beat inmates. Mesyeux, Paul, and Etienne were arrested Nov. 1 and accused of plotting to assassinate military leader Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril. Beauchard was arrested Dec. 13. The first three, who along with Beauchard have denied the charges, were arrested the day after signing a communique calling for demonstrations to denounce the government's human rights abuses. The sight of their battered faces on state television Nov. 2 triggered general strikes that paralyzed Haiti for three days. The Roman Catholic Church denounced what it called the torture of the four at police hands. Avril repeatedly has promised to respect human rights, but rights and civic groups have often denounced his government for such violations.

DOC.HEAD: Summary of Developments
With AM-Noriega Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief summary of developments Thursday concerning Panamanian Gen. Manuel Noriega: _ Noriega refused to enter a plea to drug-trafficking charges in Miami, saying he was a political prisoner. The judge entered an innocent plea for him. He was held without bond. If convicted, he faces 145 years in prison and $1.1 million in fines. _ Noriega's lawyer said Noriega decided to surrender to avoid further bloodshed after being told protection would be withdrawn as crowds surrounded the Vatican Embassy. _ A senior Bush administration official said the Vatican Embassy had been planning to order Noriega to leave at noon on Thursday had he not surrendered. _ The Vatican had said Noriega freely decided to leave the embassy. But a Vatican Embassy spokesman later said the embassy had told Noriega it would lift its diplomatic immunity and invite Panamanian security forces inside to arrest him if he didn't leave. The spokesman said no specific deadline was set. _ Lt. Col. Nivaldo Madrinan, a top Noriega adviser and head of his secret police, walked out of the Vatican Embassy and surrendered to U.S. troops. _ A Drug Enforcement Administration official said Noriega could be returned to Panama for trial on a long list of charges after his U.S. trial. _ President Bush sent Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, to Panama plan the withdrawal of U.S. combat troops. Some 25,000 remain in Panama. _ Members of Congress said the United States must quickly reduce its military presence in Panama and provide large-scale economic aid.

DOC.HEAD: Network Cameras Turned Special Night Lenses on Noriega
With AM-Noriega Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The videotape pictures, taken at night, were grainy. But you could make out the beetle shape of a U.S. Army Blackhawk helicopter. You also could vaguely see human forms. Special night lenses on network cameras helped record Panamanian Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's surrender Wednesday night to U.S. officials who took him aboard the helicopter and eventually to the United States to face drug trafficking charges. It was not-so-new technology, though. The lenses, which NBC News executive David Miller says cost about $30,000 each, amplify existing light and are similar in principle to night-vision devices used in Vietnam. They have been routinely used for years, network executives say. ``We have several of them. Most of the bureaus have them. ... It's a standard piece of equipment,'' said Robert Murphy, ABC News vice president for news coverage. The lenses were used last year in Eastern Europe to cover demonstrations, he said. After it was learned that Noriega fled to the Vatican Embassy in Panama City on Christmas Eve, all the networks set up observation posts at a Holiday Inn overlooking the embassy, and began a day-and-night stakeout. All but CNN had a camera with a night lens. When Noriega began to leave the embassy at 8:50 p.m. EDT Wednesday, CBS, first to report he would surrender, and NBC had crews up and ready at the Holiday Inn. They got their night-lens shots. So did ABC's crew, but from an office building, ``from a perpendicular angle. I think we had the better shot,'' Murphy said. ABC, whose taped pictures were broadcast first, at 9:31 p.m. EDT, showed a figure wearing white _ ABC's corrrespondent John Martin said the man was believed to be Noriega _ walking from the gate of the Vatican Embassy. ``That was our shot _ stolen by several other organizations,'' said Murphy, who declined to identify the offenders.

DOC.HEAD: Pan Am Resumes Panama Service
With AM-Noriega Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Pan American World Airways resumed daily round-trip flights from Miami to Panama on Thursday following a two-week suspension, the New York-based carrier announced. Pan Am resumed service after military officials in Panama lifted restrictions on commercial flights to Omar Torrijos International Airport in Panama City. On Wednesday, deposed Panamanian leader Manuel Noriega surrendered to U.S. officials and was flown to Miami to stand trial on drug charges. Eastern Airlines resumed special flights to Panama on Dec. 31, and plans to resume its scheduled two daily round-trips from Miami on Tuesday, said Robin Matell, spokesman for the Miami-based carrier.

DOC.HEAD: Suit Challeges Name, Mission of Mississippi University for Women
DOC.TEXT: A lawsuit has been filed in federal court asking that the name, mission and recruiting practices of Mississippi University for Women be changed so more men will enroll. The lawsuit filed by attorney Wil Colom on behalf of himself, Keith Washington and Edward Pleasant follows their previous lawsuit which was thrown out by a federal judge in November. The lawsuit claims Washington did not apply to MUW in 1985 because of its single-sex mission, name and recruiting practices and is now at Alcorn State University. Pleasant is a senior at the state's School for Math and Science, a high school on the MUW campus in Columbus. His mother, Phyllis, said in the court papers filed Tuesday that her son is attracted to MUW for economic reasons, because he would be able to live at home, but will not apply for admission because of the school's name and mission. Following a U.S. Supreme Court decision, MUW first admitted men in 1982, when 131 enrolled. Male enrollment then rose for five years, to 460 in 1987. It fell to 417 in 1988 and to 390 in the fall of 1989. The school's total enrollment this year is 2,109. The latest lawsuit names MUW President Clyda Rent, the State College Board and Gov. Ray Mabus. There was no comment from them Thursday: the school is on holiday break and Rent's home phone was answered by an answering machine; the board's director was in a meeting; the governor's office referred questions to the attorney general's office, where Assistant Attorney General Gail Lowery said there was no comment because they had not seen the lawsuit. Colom said he believes the federal court can order the Legislature to create a gender-neutral name and mission for the Columbus school, now in its 105th year. ``That change would be required if the court finds the present mission and name to be unconstitutional. That's what we seek in this suit,'' he said. The lawsuit was filed as a class action on behalf of all males who failed to apply to or attend the school because of its philosophy and admissions requirements. The lawsuit asks the court to stop the defendants from carrying out the single-sex mission, to order them to adopt a gender-neutral name for the school, and to order MUW to recruit male students on the same basis it uses in recruiting females.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Demonstrate Against Liberal Ethnic Policies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with demonstration, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people marched past Parliament on Thursday to protest liberal new ethnic policies, while the ruling Communist Party and democratic opposition met inside to plan Bulgaria's future. BTA, the official news agency, said detailed ``round-table'' talks between the party and opposition would be held Jan. 16-24. The protesters, most from the southern cities of Kardalji and Haskovo, threatened strikes in several cities for Friday unless the government reversed its decision to restore minority rights to ethnic Turks. They waved banners reading ``Bulgaria for Bulgarians,'' and chanted slogans against a decision announced Dec. 29 that ended such discriminatory practices as requiring ethnic Turks to take Bulgarian names. Leaders of the protest delivered a petition to Parliament demanding a referendum on ethnic questions. BTA quoted spokesmen for both the Communists and opposition as rejecting the demand on grounds that ``the validity of human rights in Bulgaria cannot be submitted to any referendum.'' In Ankara, Foreign Ministry spokesman Murat Sungar said the demonstrations were intended to damage Turkish-Bulgarian relations. Ivan Angelov, a prominent economist speaking for the Communists, said high-ranking officials he did not identify met Thursday to discuss ethnic issues, the agency reported. It gave no details. Angelov and opposition spokesman Georgi Spassov spoke after the Communists, the opposition and other groups reached agreement on future negotiations after two days of negotiations. The discussions later this month will cover ``problems of national agreement and reconciliation,'' restructuring of the political, economic and legal systems and drafting a new law for free elections, according to the report. An umbrella organization of opposition groups, the Union of Democratic Forces, demanded the right to publish its own daily newspaper, time on state television and radio and the use of a building as headquarters, the agency said. It said a decision would be made before the talks began. Parliament is expected to pave the way for a pluralistic political system Jan. 15 when it votes on removing Communist Party's guarantee of a power monopoly from the constitution. The Dec. 29 decision on ethnic rights also gave Turkish Bulgarians the right to choose their own religion and schools. About 300 ethnic Turks fled to Turkey last year after the restrictions were imposed by Todor Zhivkov, the Communist Party chief whose Stalinist regime was deposed in November after 35 years in power.

DOC.HEAD: DEA Official Says Noriega Eventually Could Be Returned to Panama
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf pvs: ``Panamanian Vice,'' with with 3 new grafs bgng: ``He left, Calderon comments, and one graf edited for transition; picks up 4th graf pvs: ``No revenge,''
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A top Drug Enforcement Administration official indicated Thursday that ousted Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega, now in Miami to face drug-trafficking charges, may be returned to Panama for trial afterward. ``We feel it's important to bring people to trial wherever the best case exists,'' David Westrate, assistant DEA administrator for operations, said in an interview. ``Returning him to Panama remains a possibility for the future.'' Richard Arias Calderon, a vice president of Panama, said it would be imposible for Panamanian officials to provide Noriega with either security or a fair trial now. ``He left us without a judicial system,'' Calderon said. ``We couldn't have guaranteed, under the circumstances, due process,'' he said on the ``MacNeil-Lehrer Newshour'' program on public television. But Calderon said Panamanian officials would definitely seek to prosecute Noriega in Panama if ``by some impossible occurrance, he were to go scot free'' in the United States. Earlier, Guillermo Ford, another vice president installed in office following the Dec. 20 invasion of Panama by U.S. troops, said Noriega would be returned to Panama for trial on a long list of charges after his U.S. trial ends. ``No revenge. Due process,'' he said on ABC's ``Nightline,'' Wednesday night several hours after Noriega emerged from the Vatican Embassy in Panama City _ where he had been holed up since Christmas Eve _ and gave himself up to U.S. forces. Officials of Panama's new government have said they plan to charge Noriega with murder in the deaths of officers who led a failed Oct. 3 coup and were allegedly slain after their capture. DEA officials formally arrested Noriega at Howard Air Base west of Panama City and accompanied him to Miami along with U.S. marshals and U.S. military. In his interview, Westrate discussed the impact Noriega's incarceration on the drug trade. ``The functioning of Panama as a safe haven and a point of facilitation to the (drug) trafficking organizations has been important and is now eliminated,'' Westrate said. ``In fact, I think Panama will emerge as a strong ally in the anti-drug fight in the weeks ahead.'' ``You have to take this in context with a lot of other things going on right now,'' he said. Other recent events include the Dec. 15 shoot-out in Colombia in which alleged Medellin cocaine cartel kingpin Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha was killed by security forces, the Dec. 10 extradition from Bolivia of Luis Arce Gomez, dubbed Bolivia's ``Minister of Cocaine,'' to the United States for trial in Florida on charges of conspiracy to import and distribute cocaine, and Colombia's extradition to the United States of 11 people wanted on drug charges here. The capture of Noriega has had a major impact on those fighting the drug war, he said. ``This is an important confidence builder, the type of thing that renews everybody's commitment _ agents, prosecutors, people working in the prevention areas. We know we can get this job done.'' He acknowledged that U.S. law enforcement officials, including DEA Administrator John C. Lawn, had praised Noriega as recently as a few years ago for his help in anti-drug efforts. ``We've done a lot of positive business there with the Panamanian Defense Forces over the years in individual cases,'' Westrate said. ``But in recent years, it's quite clear that Panama has been utilized by these trafficking organizations to their benefit. ``Now, in addition to good work in the past, we will be able to do even more with the officials in that country,'' specifically in curtailing money-laundering and eliminating Panama as a stopping off point for traffickers, he said. The DEA, which closed its Panama office when the U.S. Embassy was shut down last May, expects to re-establish a presence there soon with a few agents, he said.

DOC.HEAD: 22 People Rescued from Ship Fire at Mouth of English Channel
DOC.TEXT: All 22 people aboard a Panamanian-registered ship were rescued Thursday night after the 7,402-ton bulk carrier caught fire in the mouth of the English Channel, the British defense ministry reported. The ministry said in a statement that the ship, the Pioneer Sea, sent out a distress call when its engine room caught fire 25 miles west of the island of Ouessant, or Ushant as it is also known in Britain, off northwestern France. Two British Royal Navy helicopters, a British reconnaissance Nimrod plane, a French helicopter and an East German cargo ship, the 2,543-ton Themar, took part in the rescue operation. The ministry statement said 20 of the 22 people aboard the Pioneer Sea were taken aboard a lifeboat launched by the Themar. It said the two others were rescued from the blazing Pioneer Sea by one of the British helicopters. The second British helicopter later flew the captain of the Pioneer Sea, who was suffering from smoke inhalation, from the Themar to a hospital at the nearby French military air base at Lanveoc. The French radio station at Le Conquet broadcast a navigation warning to shipping to steer clear of the Pioneer Sea as it drifted out of control.

DOC.HEAD: Row Flares in Czechoslovakia Over German Issue
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party chairman assailed on Thursday remarks by new President Vaclav Havel that indicated Czechoslovakia might apologize for expelling its 3 million German minority after World War II. ``I declare with the utmost resolution that the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia and I personally do not agree with apologies to Sudeten Germans for their resettlement from Czechoslovakia,'' chairman Ladislav Adamec said in a front-page article in his party's Rude Pravo daily. It marked the first public rift between Havel and Adamec since a peaceful revolution in November stripped the Communists of their monopoly on power and forced creation of a coalition with former dissidents until free elections this year. Sources in the Civic Forum, the opposition group that backed Havel for president, acknowledged that popular reaction to Havel's suggestion was ``unequivocally negative.'' Czechoslovaks traditionally have been wary of German expansionism, and retain strong memories of Nazi atrocities and occupation during World War II. Havel himself underlined the importance of the German question here by making East and West Germany his first state visit. That visit was meant to stress the need for a new era in relations with both Germanys. But when Civic Forum spokesman Martin Palous was asked Thursday about the prospect of an apology to the Germans he replied: ``As far as we are informed, the Czechoslovak government is not contemplating anything of the sort.'' Rude Pravo quoted Havel as saying on television before Christmas and his Dec. 29 election that ``it is our duty to apologize to Germans who were resettled after World War II.'' It further quoted from what it said was a letter Havel wrote to President Richard von Weizsaecker of West Germany that referred to the expulsion as ``an immoral act of the utmost depth,'' damaging both Germans and Czechs. Lubos Dobrovsky, another Civic Forum spokesman, commented, ``It is not in agreement with the spirit of European politics to resettle an entire minority. The way the Third Reich acted against Czechoslovakia and other nations is even less in agreement with such policy. ``The point is to realize our duty, to make sure that such evil is not repeated.''

DOC.HEAD: Delta Says Trans-Atlantic Flights Threatened
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to CLARIFY that flights do not leave only from Atlanta, UPDATE with only 20 to 30 passengers switching airlines, quotes. SUBS last graf to CORRECT number of passengers to 22, sted 28.
DOC.TEXT: Delta Air Lines said Thursday it is stepping up security and giving passengers the option of canceling their reservations after receiving a ``general threat'' against its trans-Atlantic flights. Delta spokesman Jim Lundy said the threat did not name a particular flight, city or day. He would not say when the threat was received or give other details. Lundy said passengers were being notified of the threat upon check-in and were given the option of canceling or delaying their trips. Delta's trans-Atlantic operations include flights to and from Germany, Ireland, England and France. ``At this point, we have no information that it is anything but a hoax,'' Lundy said. ``We've got to take it seriously. We do take it seriously.'' Lundy said federal authorities had been notified, but a spokeswoman for the Federal Aviation Administration, Arlene Salac, said the agency was not involved. The intensified security will remain in effect until officials are sure the threat has ended or have confirmed it as a hoax, Lundy said. Delta officials said early Thursday evening that only 20 to 30 of about 700 ticket holders on its four international flights scheduled out of Atlanta during the night had switched airlines. Patrick Walsh and his wife of Belfast, Northern Ireland, said they switched from Delta to Swissair after hearing about the threat. The switch means they will arrive in Dublin six hours later than planned. ``You have two options about it, so you take the one you're more comfortable with,'' Mrs. Walsh said. ``If we'd known about it sooner, we'd have stayed in Miami a little longer.'' Birgit Sekulin of Munich, West Germany, said her family of four switched to Lufthansa German Airlines, but the move made her feel only slightly better. ``First of all, we are a family. We don't like to fly all four of us on the same plane if there are things like this,'' she said. Roger White of Chicago, however, said he was not changing his flight plans. The bomb threat ``didn't mean a thing about choosing an airline,'' he said. Last week, a Northwest Airlines flight from Paris to Detroit received a bomb threat. After passengers were told they could cancel, the DC-10, which holds 284 passengers, made a safe flight Saturday carrying 22 passengers and 14 crew members.

DOC.HEAD: Driver Gets Three Months in Accident That Killed Former Kidnap Victim
DOC.TEXT: A man was sentenced to three months in jail Thursday in connection with the hit-and-run accident that killed childhood kidnap victim Steven Stayner last September. Antonio Loera, 28, had pleaded no contest to a charge of felony hit-and-run driving for leaving the scene of the accident. He was also placed on probation for a year by Merced County Superior Court Judge George C. Barrett. A vehicular manslaughter charge against Loera was dropped after an investigation showed a defective carburetor and loose throttle caused his car to stall when he pulled out of a driveway. Stayner, 24, was killed when he hit the car with his motorcycle. Loera, a packing house worker, told reporters through a Spanish-speaking interpreter that he regrets fleeing after the accident and hoped others would learn from his experience. He voluntarily returned to Merced and surrendered. Stayner's widow, Jody, was in the courtroom during sentencing but declined to comment to reporters. Stayner returned to his family at age 14, seven years after he was kidnapped by a drifter as he walked home from school in Merced. He eventually married and had two children, now 3 and 2.

DOC.HEAD: Cuban Diplomat Arrested Outside Residence
DOC.TEXT: U.S. troops arrested a Cuban diplomat and held him for two hours Thursday after he was apprehended while walking out of the ambassador's residence, another diplomat's wife said. ``He was forced out of the car, separated from the others and taken,'' said Sandra Faxas, wife of Luis Delfin Peres, the second-ranking diplomat in the Cuban Embassy. She said Victor Fernandez Gonzalez was walking out of the embassy with six other diplomats who were to drive to the airport to board the first commercial flight to Cuba since the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion toppled Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. ``The Americans arrested Fernandez because his name is the same'' as that of a member of Noriega's disbanded Defense Forces, she said. U.S. Embassy spokeswoman Jan Edmonson said she did not know anything about the incident. U.S. troops have surrounded the Cuban, Nicaraguan and Libyan embassies since the invasion to prevent Noriega's henchmen from coming or going. The plane had been scheduled to carry more than 60 Cubans, among them the 10-year-old son of ambassador Lazaro Mora, said Mrs. Faxas. She said Fernandez was released after two hours but the troops remained outside the embassy ``in a really provoking way.''

DOC.HEAD: Salmonella Killed 13 People Last Year, CDC Reports
DOC.TEXT: Salmonella poisoning, on the rise in the late 1980s, struck more than 1,600 people and killed 13 last year, federal health officials reported Thursday. A total of 1,628 cases of salmonella enteritidis _ including 13 fatalities _ were reported through October, in 49 separate outbreaks, the national Centers for Disease Control said. That's up significantly from 19 outbreaks, 608 cases and one death reported in 1985, the CDC said. Contaminated food was implicated in 64 percent of the 1989 outbreaks, and 73 percent of those involved eggs. The CDC noted that salmonella reporting has increased dramatically in New England and the mid-Atlantic states since 1979. ``In regions where egg-associated salmonellosis has been identified, the public should be advised not to eat raw or undercooked eggs,'' the Atlanta-based CDC said in its weekly report. The agency said a single contaminated egg can cause outbreaks of severe illness, with symptoms including fever, cramps and diarrhea. Thorough cooking kills salmonella bacteria.

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys Say Noriega Refuses to Recognize U.S. Justice
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with detail from courtroom, security, possible whereabouts; SUBS 11th graf pvs, `He is not .. ., to CLARIFY that death penalty statute does not apply to Noriega; Picks up 12th graf pvs: `Noriega surrendered ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: Fallen Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega told a federal judge Thursday that he is a political prisoner and refused to enter a plea to charges he took $4.6 million to turn his nation into a way station for the cocaine trade. ``General Noriega refuses to submit to the jurisdiction of this court ... because he is a political prisoner brought to this country illegally,'' Noriega attorney Frank Rubino told U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler. The judge then entered an innocent plea for Noriega. Rubino said during the half-hour hearing that the general had been told Wednesday that protection would be withdrawn as crowds surrounded the Vatican Embassy in Panama City. He said Noriega surrendered to avoid further bloodshed. However, the archbishop of Panama said the surrender followed Noriega's realization he had lost all support. In Washington, a senior Bush administration official said the Vatican Embassy had been planning to order Noriega to leave at noon on Thursday had he not surrendered to U.S. authorities. That previously undisclosed ultimatum may have been the final straw that prompted the surrender, the official said. Noriega was dressed in olive-green trousers and a khaki uniform shirt with a general's four stars on the epaulets. He walked into the courtroom without handcuffs or shackles. When questioned by the judge, he stood with a military bearing, hands clasped tightly behind him. He answered softly in Spanish and stared at the judge, showing no emotion. Noriega listened to a translation of the judge's questions through head phones, which he removed when he answered. U.S. marshals stood against the doors of the courtroom, which was filled with reporters. The defense said the case could take nine months to prepare and six months to try. U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen said he thought the trial would take only two months. Noriega is accused of accepting $4.6 million in bribes from Colombian drug cartels to aid and protect their smuggling and processing _ charges that carry 145 years in prison and $1.1 million in fines. A bond hearing was waived until it is requested by the defense. Noriega, who gave his age as 51 although some records indicate he may be older, will be held without bond. He also faces drug charges in Tampa. Rubino said U.S. marshals have assured that Noreiga can be made available to defense counsel within a half-hour to an hour. Noriega will first held at an undisclosed location in the Miami area, said Rubino. Administration sources said Noriega was assured he would not be tried under a statute that carries the death penalty for drug-related killings. The law was passed in 1988, after his indictment, and he has not been charged under it. Noriega surrendered Wednesday night to U.S. troops outside Panama City's Vatican Embassy 10 days after he took refuge there, and was flown into Homestead Air Force Base south of Miami under cover of night Thursday. U.S. marshals with binoculars scanned the downtown area continuously from atop the federal courthouse and patrolled halls in plain clothes, but otherwise were inconspicuous in what Hoeveler said was an effort to treat Noriega like any other defendant. Exactly a year ago, Hoeveler ruled the United States has jurisdiction, rejecting defense claims of immunity for a head of state. The judge said the State Department never recognized Noriega's political legitimacy. Several experts in international law said Noriega has little basis for the claims. It is not clear if such immunity exists, they said, but if it did, Noriega probably wouldn't qualify because the crimes he allegedly committed were not part of his official duties. ``As far as I know, the things Noriega is accused of doing have nothing to do with his being a head of state,'' said Alfred Rubin, a professor of international law at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University. Noriega co-counsel Steven Kollin has noted other potential legal pitfalls in the case, including extreme pretrial publicity and Noriega's links with U.S. intelligence agencies, but U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said he was confident the case was solid. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said President Bush and other White House officials would be careful about what they say lest they prejudice the trial. Justice Department spokesman David Runkel said that Noriega was not formally placed under arrest until the C-130 he was aboard was taking off from Panama. Runkel said U.S. officials decided to make the arrest in American territory. Noriega's surrender was met with joyous celebrations in the streets of Panama City and Miami that continued Thursday. The general _ who had ruled for six years, thumbed his nose at two U.S. presidents and annulled an election he apparently was losing _ gave up, still wearing his military uniform, after realizing even his supporters had turned against him, the archbishop of Panama, Marcos McGrath, said Thursday. ``The people feel a sense of peace knowing that the monster is leaving our land,'' said Panamanian President Guillermo Endara, frequently a target of Noriega's thugs. The indictment against Noriega names 15 other people, including the reputed head of the Medellin cocaine cartel, Pablo Escobar Gaviria, who is being hunted by Colombian authorities. One of Noriega's right-hand men, Lt. Col. Luis del Cid, surrendered to U.S. troops after the Dec. 20 invasion of Panama and has pleaded innocent. Prosecutors have refused to say if he will testify against his former boss. U.S. troops who seized Noriega's military headquarters in Panama City reportedly found documents and files supporting the prosecution case. That, along with the arrests of del Cid and others, has made the case stronger, said Richard Gregorie, who headed the investigation until he left the U.S. attorney's office a year ago. President Bush on Thursday sent Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, to plan the withdrawal of U.S. combat troops. Some 25,000 remain in Panama. Panamanian exiles here celebrated Noriega's fall, illustrated by a plane flying above the courthouse towing a banner that said ``Bye Bye, Tony.'' ``For all Panamanians, this is one of the final chapters,'' said Aurelio Barria, head of the Noriega opposition until he was forced into exile in 1988. ``But he still has to answer for what he did in Panama.'' Gen. Maxwell Thurman, commanding general of U.S. forces in Panama, said Noriega's surrender ``completes the fourth of our four objectives'' in invading Panama in Operation Just Cause. The others, he said, were to protect American lives, safeguard the Panama Canal treaties and restore democracy to Panama. According to authorities, about 290 Panamanian soldiers, 300 civilians, 23 U.S. troops and three American civilians died in the invasion. Fitzwater said Bush was ``gratified this operation was completed in such a successful fashion.'' Bush had called Pope John Paul II ``to thank him for the distinguished efforts of the Vatican and the papal nuncio in Panama'' in getting Noriega to surrender.

DOC.HEAD: Electronic Music Composer Ussachevsky Dead at 78
DOC.TEXT: Vladimir Ussachevsky, a composer and teacher who collaborated in the first electronic musical works performed in the United States, died Thursday of a brain tumor. Ussachevsky, who was 78, died in Calvary Hospital in the Bronx, according to a statement from Columbia University. Ussachevsky, who taught at Columbia from 1947 until his retirement in 1980, started experimenting with electronic, or synthesized, music in 1951. On May 9, 1954, a work he composed for tape recorder was performed in the first demonstration of electronic music in the country. His work and that of Columbia professor Otto Luening attracted attention on Oct. 28 of that year when introduced by conductor Leopold Stokowski in a concert of music for tape recorder at the Museum of Modern Art. In 1959, Ussachevsky helped establish the Columbia University Electronic Music Center, the first music organization devoted entirely to composition and research of electronic music. Ussachevsky was born Nov. 3, 1911, to Russian parents in Manchuria. He came to the United States in 1930 and earned an undergraduate degree at Pomona College in California in 1935. He earned his Masters degree and Ph.D. at the Eastman School of Music. Ussachevsky was married to Elizabeth Denison Kray, who died in 1987. He is survived by a niece, Alla Stewart Du Vall of Chico, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: PANAMA CITY: devoutly wished.
DOC.TEXT: That, and the constant calls he made for the lower class to rally against the U.S.-oriented oligarchy, were enough to create stiff resistance that flashed into the fear, if for a few days, that the United States had stepped into a guerrilla war. But in the end he was alone, separated from his lover and from his wife and three of his daughters, who sought refuge inside the Cuban Embassy. Many of his cronies and friends were scattered in embassies throughout the capital. There was no reservoir of faith or affection, the kind that allowed Cardinal Josef Mindszenty of Hungary to resist Communist rule and stomach 15 years in a U.S. Embassy. He could feel none of the loyalty that Chinese dissident Fang Lizhi commands in the U.S. Embassy in Beijing, an exile that has lasted seven months so far. The last day of Noriega's stay inside the mission was perhaps the loneliest, as 20,000 people filled the streets and shouted ``Assassin!'' ``No more!'' and ``Out of the nunciature!'' They hanged his effigy. Clad in military garb, Noriega's face was made out of a pineapple, a reminder of the acne scars that gave him the nickname ``pineapple face.'' Often during his 10 days in the embassy, angry Panamanians smashed pineapples to yellow pulp in the street. If he had any supporters, they were silent. ``He saw himself as something of an emperor in this part of the world, and I think that dream has been shattered,'' said Archbishop Marcos McGrath on ABC's ``Nightline.'' Shrouded by palm trees, the gates of the Vatican embassy opened and closed Wednesday. The papal nuncio, in his long white robe, a crucifix dangling from his neck, came in and out, talking to U.S. Army officials. Panamanian sources said one of Noriega's last conversations was with his longtime mistress Vickie Amado. The U.S. Southern Command had tried to convince her to lure Noriega out. But she didn't. The sources said that during a 10-minute conversation, she told him, ``The decision is in your hands.'' Gen. Maxwell Thurman, head of the Southern Command, agreed: ``People have to make up their own minds.'' The man who survived two coup attempts and humiliated the United States eventually made his decision, under pressure. Villanueva said the Vatican told Noriega it was preparing to lift its own diplomatic immunity to allow Panamanian security forces to enter the embassy and capture ``a highly dangerous criminal.'' Despite the submachine gun he had brought into the embassy, and despite his image as a man who would rather die than surrender, Noriega decided not to go down shooting. He made few demands: phone calls, that his surrender be kept secret until it was time, to wear his uniform one last time. Thurman said Noriega's coffee-colored uniform was brought to him because he didn't have it with him. He reportedly talked to his wife, Felicidad, who was in the Cuban Embassy. Sources in the Dominican Republic said she and the couple's three daughters would join a fourth daughter married to a military officer in Santo Domingo. In Washington, officials said Noriega was assured he would not face the death penalty. Just before he left, he got a hug from Lt. Col. Nivaldo Madrinan, who was himself to surrender Thursday. Noriega bid farewell to the former head of his secret police just inside the mission's big wooden door. ``Madrinan came to attention and saluted militarily,'' said Villanueva. ``Then they embraced.''

DOC.HEAD: Joy Over Noriega's Departure Blurs Tough Battle Ahead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to RECAST. INSERTS one graf after 14th, `The walls ... on how demonstration began. Picks up 15th, `He was ... with minor editing to trim; INSERT one graf after 24th, `Also Thursday ... UPDATING with Ortega wants U.S. troops out. Picks up 25th, `In the ...
DOC.TEXT: With the dictator gone and the wild celebrations over, Panamanians on Thursday tried to start rebuilding their country, battered by more than $2 billion in damage from the U.S. invasion and burdened by six years of despotic rule. Still, the joy here seemed boundless. ``We are too happy,'' said Reynaldo de Gracia, a night watchman who witnessed the revelry in the capital Wednesday night after word spread that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega had surrendered to U.S. troops. Noriega's transfer to Florida to face federal drug trafficking charges ended a brutal reign that had intimidated this nation of 2.2. million people since 1983. ``Down to the small kids, everybody knew he is a criminal,'' said truck driver Crispiniano Avila. ``We don't want to see him ever again. Not even in a painting.'' Avila was part of the wild singing, drinking, chanting, kissing, horn-blowing and pot-banging that took over the streets until the wee hours Thursday. The scene recalled nothing so much as the Munchkins' ecstasy at the death of the wicked witch in ``The Wizard of Oz.'' ``The guy was a danger and a burden to the country. He had the whole nation knotted up, wasting away,'' said de Gracia. Panamanians are still trying to figure out just how much harm Noriega caused. The economy, hobbled by American sanctions designed to get rid of Noriega, suffered another blow from the widespread looting and vandalism during the American Dec. 20 invasion. Economiss are trying to total the damage, but estimates run to more than $2 billion in an economy that shrank by 18 percent last year. In recent years, millions of dollars were sent out of the country for safe-keeping as Panama's banking system began to crack. Panamanian funds were frozen in the United States and government income such as Panama Canal fees have been held in escrow. Guillermo Ford, who is planning minister as well as second vice president, said his agency hopes to quantify damage to the economy in the next few days. If Noriega was unaware of his unpopularity, the misconception could not have survived Wednesday afternoon. The deposed leader sat isolated in a small room at the Vatican mission where he was holed up for 10 days, fleeing thousands of U.S. troops who invaded the country Dec. 20. The walls of his room could muffle but not block out the thunderous chant of 20,000 people outside clamoring for his head. Cruzada Civilista, the coalition that ran opposition candidates during Noriega's time _ including Guillermo Endara, Panama's new president _ called the demonstration and then tried to cancel it because of ``security concerns.'' But the people showed up anyway, to let Noriega know how their felt about him. ``He was cornered,'' said Roman Catholic Archbishop Marcos McGrath. He also was unwelcome. The Vatican Embassy had told Noriega it would lift its diplomatic immunity and ask Panamanian security forces to come into the mission to arrest him if he did not leave voluntarily, a spokesman said Thursday. Rev. Javier Villanueva, assistant to Papal Nuncio Monsignor Sebastian Laboa, said Noriega was not given a deadline, but the position was made clear to him. He said the Vatican would not have lifted diplomatic immunity on anyone taking sanctuary for political resasons. ``But this man is a highly dangerous criminal,'' he said. Maj. Gen. Marc Cisneros, commander of the U.S. Army South, confirmed that Noriega kept a submachine gun under his bed during his stay at the nunciature, which would have made it difficult for the unarmed staff at the Vatican mission to evict him. Gen. Maxwell Thurman, head of the U.S. Southern Command, said Thursday that the demonstration was a key factor in Noriega's decision to turn himself in. Also Thursday, Lt. Col. Nivaldo Madrinan, a top Noriega adviser and head of his secret police, walked out of the embassy and surrendered to U.S. troops. In Managua, Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega said Thusday the U.S. troops should leave Panama at once because they achieved their goal of capturing Noriega _ ``so there isn't a single reason for the Yankees to remain in Panama, not one more moment.'' In the meantime, the cleanup continues. U.S. Army engineers are bulldozing blocks of the the poor El Chorrillo district, which was heavily damaged and in some cases leveled. Thousands of people displaced by the fighting went to a camp in a baseball stadium, but most have relocated with relatives. Many of the slums destroyed were barracks built to house Panama Canal laborers at the turn of the century, and were never meant to last more than a dozen years. American delegations are arriving here to examine, among other things, what the United States can or should do to help but nobody is discussing specific numbers yet. Money is dribbling back in. About $70 million in frozen funds has been thawed, but about $300 million more remains blocked in accounts frozen by economic sanctions imposed nearly two years ago. Millions of dollars of Noriega's money also has been taken over and given to the government. But insurance companies said they will not honor claims for losses because of a war clause in the policies. Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger said in Panama Wednesday the United States feels no responsibility to businesses that were looted, and therefore is not obligated to make good on the losses.

DOC.HEAD: Wiesel Addresses Sakharov Memorial
DOC.TEXT: Elie Wiesel remembered fellow Nobel Peace laureate Andrei Sakharov on Thursday as the ``godfather'' of perestroika and glasnost at a memorial service for the Soviet dissident. ``It is possible for one person to say no to evil, and in doing so, render it vulnerable,'' said Wiesel. ``He taught his contemporaries that every human being is unique.'' Wiesel, the American writer and death camp survivor who won the 1986 Nobel for his human rights campaign emphasizing the Nazi Holocaust, was among the speakers Thursday at the New York Public Library service. Sakharov, a human rights activist and a physicist who created the Soviet hydrogen bomb, died Dec. 14 at age 68. He won the Nobel in 1975, but the Soviet leadership at the time refused to let him go to Norway to accept it. He was banished in 1980 to what Wiesel termed ``prolonged, horrifying, ugly'' internal exile after calling for the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev allowed him freedom of movement in December 1986. Robert L. Bernstein, chairman of the U.S. Helsinki Watch who published much of Sakharov's writings, said he was sad that Sakharov did not live to see the publication of his latest book, which is scheduled for next spring. ``His was the strongest voice in the world for individual rights,'' said Bernstein. ``In a short time, he was really able to change things around,'' said Alexey Semyonov, son of Elena Bonner, the dissident's wife. In 1981, Bonner and Sakharov's wife went on a hunger strike to convince Soviet authorities to allow Semyonov's wife to emigrate to the United States. ``He has changed, it seems, the way people in the Soviet Union look at things ... what is important and how it can be achieved,'' Semyonov said. The service was organized by the International League for Human Rights, a private group that works to end torture, disappearances, religious intolerance, censorship and other human rights abuses. Sakharov became honorary president of the group's Moscow affiliate in 1970.

DOC.HEAD: General: USSR's Military Doctrine Has Changed to Defensive Posture
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has shifted its military doctrine from an offensive posture to a strictly defensive one, a high-ranking Soviet military planner said Thursday. The definition of Soviet military doctrine now includes prevention of war and civil defense, Lt. Gen. Herman Starodubov said Thursday at the opening session of a two-day arms control symposium sponsored by Texas A&M University's Mosher Institute for Defense Studies.
