The conference, ``Arms Control Problems and Prospects 1990,'' has brought together negotiators and policy-makers involved in top arms control negotiations. ``We are consciously putting ourselves at a disadvantage by being defensive and turning over the military initiative to any adversary,'' said Starodubov, deputy operations director for the Soviet general staff. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has previously heralded a shift to a defensive posture by proposing deep cuts in conventional and nuclear arms. In May 1987, the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact announced a new military doctrine of ``reasonable sufficiency,'' which stipulates that a country needs only enough military might to repel an assailant. American and Western European officials, however, questioned whether any army could be used strictly as a defensive tool. Nuclear weapons in Europe may be needed to ensure coexistence, they said. Gen. Edward Meyer, former U.S. Army Chief of Staff and moderator of the conference, said the challenge before the military on both sides is to define doctrines and strategy. ``The opportunity is now on the military's side to make a difference. There will be great political and economic pressure to make those changes,'' he said. While Starodubov called for a ``nuclear-free, democratic'' world, Jean Felix-Paganon, the diplomatic adviser to the French minister of defense, stressed French security would continue to depend on nuclear weapons. ``Nuclear weapons are not weapons of war,'' Felix-Paganon said.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing Will Deliver Air Force One in September, 2 Years Late
DOC.TEXT: A new Air Force One jet will be delivered to President Bush Sept. 30, almost two years late largely because of efforts to make it resistant to a nuclear explosion, Boeing said Thursday. Boeing, which has been building two modified 747 jumbo jets for the president's use, originally promised a new Air Force One would be ready in November 1988, or in time to take former President Reagan home to California when his term ended. Boeing Military Airplanes spokeswoman Carolyn Russell in Wichita, Kan., said the original delivery was revised to November 1989 as design modifications slowed the production schedule. A second, backup Air Force One plane is expected to be delivered from the Wichita plant by early 1991, Boeing said. Progress on the planes was burdened by Boeing efforts to equip the plane with wiring that could withstand a nuclear blast, the company said. When about 70 percent of the planes' wiring was complete, Boeing engineers foresaw that the rest of the wiring wouldn't fit and about 20 percent had to be removed and replaced, Russell said. The Air Force told Congress in 1988 that the planes' cost had soared to $385 million over budget. Russell would not confirm that estimate or comment on the planes' final cost. Boeing signed a fixed-cost contract with the U.S. Air Force to deliver both planes for $250 million. That price was later revised to about $266 million, the News Tribune of Tacoma, Wash., reported.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Bush Gets Second Dose of Radiation
DOC.TEXT: First lady Barbara Bush on Thursday underwent the second of 10 radiation treatments for eye irritation caused by her immune system disease. The 64-year-old first lady received the 10-minute radiation dose early in the morning at Walter Reed Army Medical Center. She suffered no after-effects and returned to the White House for her normal daily activities, said her press secretary, Anna Perez. That included an afternoon tea for people involved with a Washington home for the infirm with which Mrs. Bush has long been associated. She is undergoing 10 consecutive days of radiation treatments in hopes of eliminating swelling behind her eyes that has caused her double vision and tearing for months. The eye problem results from Graves disease, a condition in which the thyroid gland becomes overactive. An earlier radioactive treatment and drugs rendered the thyroid inactive. Treatment with a powerful steroid, prednisone, has failed to correct the eye disorder, however, so doctors are using low-intensity radiation, aimed at swelling in the small muscles that control the eyes, as the next therapy. Aides say the first lady is otherwise perky and has not had to curtail her activities because of the disease, which was initially diagnosed last winter.

DOC.HEAD: Zurich Attorney's Office Agrees in Principle to Unfreeze Funds
DOC.TEXT: The Zurich district attorney's office has agreed to transfer to the Philippines about $260 million reportedly stashed in banks here by Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos, an official said Thursday. But district attorney Peter Cosandey said the funds would remain frozen in Zurich pending Manila's completion of criminal procedings against the Marcos clan, and so are unlikely to be returned to the Philippines in the ``foreseeable future.'' Cosandey said the district attorney's office in three recent rulings had agreed to an April 1986 request from Manila to hand over documents relating to the Marcos funds. The documents are held by Lichtenstein-based foundations administered by the late dictator or his wife, he said. Marcos lawyers already have lodged an appeal against a December ruling and are expected to appeal two more recent ones, Cosandey said. In an interview on the German-language news program, Tageschau, Cosandey said the appeal procedure in Swiss courts was likely to last at least a year. He said release of the funds depends on judicial procedings in the Philippines. So far, Manila has not filed criminal charges against the Marcos clan. President Corazon Aquino's government has claimed that Marcos plundered up to $10 billion in government funds during his 20-year reign. Manila authorities allege hundreds of millions of dollars in ill-gotten wealth are stashed in Swiss banks. The Swiss government froze assets held by Marcos and his associates in March 1986, shortly after he was ousted, pending complex procedings in Zurich and two other cantons, Geneva and Fribourg. About $45 million of alleged Marcos funds are frozen in Fribourg banks and a further $6 million in Geneva. Authorities slapped a similar ``precautionary'' freeze Dec. 24 on any Swiss assets of the deposed Romanian leader Nicolae Ceausescu, who was executed Christmas Day.

DOC.HEAD: Victim in Sensational Shooting, Suddenly a Suspect, Kills Himself
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 13th, `Asked if ..., to UPDATE with further quote from lawyer saying it seems `inevitable' that Stuart already was shot at the time of exchange with brother.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BX6, BX10, BX13, BX18
DOC.TEXT: A man whose cries for help over his car phone led police to where he and his pregnant wife had been shot threw himself to his death off a Boston Harbor bridge Thursday after he became a suspect in her slaying. ``Basically, it's fair to say, he could not handle the allegations or statements made about him,'' Suffolk County Prosecutor Newman Flanagan said, describing a suicide note found in Charles Stuart's car at the bridge. Stuart was implicated by his brother, who went to police Wednesday because Stuart apparently was identifying an innocent man as his assailant, the brother's attorney said Thursday. Flanagan said he ordered police to arrest Stuart in his wife's killing. But police could not find him and no arrest warrant had been issued. Stuart, 29, had told police that he and his wife, Carol, who was seven months pregnant, were shot by a robber who commandeered their car after they left a childbirth class at a hospital Oct. 23. Their son was delivered by Caesarean section but died 17 days later. Flanagan said Stuart's account ``is not true.'' He said the case was still active and other people were being questioned, but he gave no details. Officials said Stuart apparently knew he was a suspect. Police in his hometown of Reading, a Boston suburb, had watched his home overnight, but he did not go there, and police didn't find him before he jumped off the 300-foot Tobin Bridge over the Boston Harbor. His death was ruled a drowning. At a news conference Thursday, Flanagan confirmed that his office was contacted Wednesday by a lawyer for one of Stuart's two brothers. Police spoke with the brother and then obtained statements from other relatives and friends. Flanagan said the new evidence included Mrs. Stuart's engagement ring. ``After careful review of this new evidence, I instructed Boston police homicide detectives to arrest Charles Stuart for the murder,'' he said. Attorney John Perenyi said Stuart's brother, Matthew, 23, came to him early in December with his suspicions. According to Perenyi, Matthew Stuart said that on the night of the shooting, his brother asked him to meet him near the hospital and that he would pass a bag to him through the car window. Matthew Stuart said he took the bag, which contained a snub-nosed revolver. Asked if Matthew Stuart saw Mrs. Stuart, Perenyi said: ``That's a very difficult question, because Matthew did not expect to see her and did not see her. But he thought he saw something in the front seat of his brother's car.'' Perenyi said, ``It would seem to have been inevitable that Chuck had to have been shot at that time.'' A search of the Pines River in Stuart's parents' hometown of Revere on Thursday turned up the bag which included a Gucci bag, wallet, makeup and other of Mrs. Stuart's personal belongings. The gun, which Matthew Stuart said was disposed of separately, is missing. Matthew Stuart ``was really at a loss to give me a motive,'' Perenyi said in a telephone interview. ``He didn't think his brother was into gambling, drinking or other women.'' In recent weeks, police had several times discounted rumors that Stuart could have been involved. ``I would say the whole town is shocked. They were portrayed as a model couple,'' said Wally Arsenault, a restaurant manager in Reading. John Vajdic, who lives across the street from the Stuarts' slate-blue home, said: ``At this point, I still don't know what to believe. I still wonder what is the truth.'' The shootings of the prosperous suburban couple _ he a fur store manager and salesman, she a 30-year-old lawyer _ in an inner-city neighborhood drew cries of outrage about city violence from around the country, as well as charges from blacks and others that the outrage was spurred in part by racism. Stuart's dramatic call to police on a car phone after the shootings was widely broadcast. It took police about 10 minutes to figure out where he was, from clues such as the sound of sirens over Stuart's car telephone. Stuart had been shot in the abdomen, his wife in the head. At one point, dispatcher Gary McLaughlin said, ``OK, Chuck, help's going to be on the way, bear with me! Is your wife breathing?'' ``She's still gurgling,'' Stuart cried. ``There's a busy street up ahead. Ahh, man, I can't see where I am!'' McLaughlin patiently tried to coax Stuart into identifying some building or street near his car, and at another point said: ``You can't blank out on me, I need you, man. Chuck? Chuck?'' ``Oh man, it hurts and my wife has stopped gurgling, she's stopped breathing!'' Stuart replied. Stuart wrote a statement for his wife's funeral in which he said, ``For us to truly believe, we must know that (God's) will was done and that there was some right in this meanest of acts. In our souls, we must forgive this sinner because he would too.'' The couple had been married four years. Among those at the funeral were Gov. Michael Dukakis and Mayor Raymond Flynn. Shortly before Christmas, Stuart viewed a lineup. While officials refused to say whether an identification was made, news reports said Stuart had indicated that William Bennett, a man with a long police record, could be the assailant. On Thursday, prosecutors publicly cleared Bennett. Perenyi said Matthew Stuart came to him after the lineup. ``What he told me, when the brother identified Mr. Bennett as the assailant, that sort of pushed Matthew over the brink,'' Perenyi said. A man answering the telephone at the suburban home of Michael Stuart, Stuart's other brother, said the family had no comment. Mrs. Stuart's father, Giusto DiMaiti, was taken to a hospital Thursday morning with an undisclosed ailment but was released after an examination. In the hours after the first news reports of Thursday's developments, some still refused to believe Stuart could have had anything to do with the shootings. One neighbor wailed that, if Stuart had indeed killed himself, he ``just wanted to be with'' his dead wife and child.

DOC.HEAD: Some Women Upset by NCAA's Plans to Give Reagan Top Award
DOC.TEXT: The selection of former President Ronald Reagan for the NCAA's highest honor has spurred several female delegates to organize a protest at next week's convention in Dallas. University of Texas women's athletic director Donna Lopiano says she and others who will be at the convention believe Reagan set back the women's athletic movement during his eight years in the White House. ``As far as opportunities for women, as far as minority opportunities during Reagan's administration, they weren't very good. In fact, they were awful,'' Lopiano told the Austin American-Statesman. ``There will be a very low-key protest, but a very well warranted one,'' she said. The National Collegiate Athletic Association plans to meet in Dallas Sunday through Tuesday to discuss new legislation and to honor Reagan with the Teddy Award, named for former President Theodore Roosevelt. The award, presented since 1967, is given to a ``distinguished citizen of national reputation and outstanding accomplishment,'' according to NCAA spokesman Jim Marchiony. Carol Mann, a member of the Ladies Professional Golfers Association Hall of Fame, resigned from the awards committee because Reagan was selected. Other members have said they won't attend Monday's banquet, where Reagan is to be honored.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Industry and Unions Win Round in Dumping Action
DOC.TEXT: Far Eastern manufacturers have been dumping certain machine tools, small business telephone systems and door locks in U.S. markets, the Commerce Department said Thursday. ``Dumping'' is the sale of products at less than what the department determines is ``fair value.'' It can lead to imposition of duties to offset the ``dumping margin,'' the amount by which the price of the product fails to meet the ``fair value'' test, if the International Trade Commission finds that the affected U.S. industry is being hurt by the practice. The commission now has 45 days to decide that issue. The determinations Thursday were for: _Automatic metal-forming machine tools with multiple die stations, known as mechanical transfer presses, from Japan. Some $109 million were sold in the United States in 1988. The department said dumping margins ranged from 7.49 percent to 15.16 percent. The ruling was in response to a petition filed in behalf of the U.S. industry by the Verson Division of Allied Products Corp., the United Auto Workers and the United Steel Workers of America. _Small business telephone systems and subassemblies from South Korea, of which $227 million worth were imported in 1988. Dumping margins ranged from 13.4 percent to 15.85 percent. The ruling was sought by two competing U.S. manufacturers, American Telephone & Telegraph Co. and Comdial Corp. _House door locks and parts from Taiwan, of which the United States imported $49.5 million worth from Taiwan in 1988. The department said dumping margins were 1.27 percent to 17.75 percent. The ruling was sought by the U.S. Ad Hoc Committee of Door Lock Manufacturers.

DOC.HEAD: Last Iowa Sailors Honored for Bravery
DOC.TEXT: Twelve sailors and a Marine were honored Thursday for their bravery in fighting a fire that raged aboard the battleship USS Iowa following an explosion that killed 47 sailors last year. The men were the last of 43 servicemen to be honored for their actions in the April 1989 disaster. Capt. Fred P. Moosally, commander of the battleship, presented the awards aboard the ship with the 16-inch guns of ill-fated turret No. 2 looming in the background. ``I have said before hundreds of heroes were born on the morning of April 19 ... the actions of this crew made it possible for us to recover from this tragedy. All did the jobs they were trained to do despite the darkness, the heavy smoke and heat, and saved our ship,'' he said. The explosion inside turret No. 2 killed 47 sailors manning the three 16-inch guns and those in the decks below handling projectiles and powder. The explosion occurred as the turret was preparing to fire its guns. On the starboard bridge wing was Marine Capt. John A. Brush, 27, of Columbus, Ohio. Brush, then a lieutenant, was relaying the firing orders for the turret when the blast shook the ship. Brush rushed down the gangways to the turret. Rescuers were unable to get to the main hatch because of the turret's position. Instead, a smaller, nearly inaccessible hatch was forced open. The Marine immediately began hoisting firefighters up into the turret. ``There was a lot of smoke and heat coming out. The turret was still blazing. We were just trying to get people into the turret,'' he said. For his actions, Brush was awarded the Navy and Marine Corps Medal. Nine sailors also received the Navy and Marine Corps Medal, including Gunner's Mate John M. Mullahy Jr. of Randolph, Mass. Mullahy was one of 11 sailors stationed in the turret's magazine who survived the explosion. According to his citation, Mullahy went into the lowest section of the turret to activate the turret's sprinkler system to prevent a secondary explosion. Mullahy then carried one of his shipmates to safety before returning to the turret to remove burning powder bags from the dark and water-filled space. Two others received the Navy Commendation Medal. The 13th man, Chief Warrant Officer Samuel McGovern, 40, of Beaumont, Texas, received the Meritorious Service Medal for directing the firefighters and leading the damage control operations for 32 continuous hours. It was the highest of the 43 awards given to Iowa servicemen. A Navy investigation of the explosion said it was ``most likely'' was caused by sabatoge by a disgruntled gunner's mate who died in the explosion. Families of some of the Iowa victims and members of Congress have challenged the validity of the Navy's report. Moosally also unveiled a bronze plaque dedicated to the men who died in the explosion. The plaque will be mounted on the side of turret No. 2.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Spokesman Likens U.S. Trial of Noriega to `Lynch Law'
With AM-Panama
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet spokesman on Thursday likened to ``lynch law'' the expected U.S. trial of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and said that even a conviction would not justify the U.S. invasion of Panama. Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov said the trial will involve ``a violation of the rights of the government of Panama, a violation of the principles of non-intervention of the charter of the United Nations.'' ``No state has the right to take the law into its own hands,'' he told reporters. ``That's basically lynch law.'' Panamanian dictator Noriega surrendered to U.S. authorities in Panama City on Wednesday and was flown to Miami, where he faces drug-trafficking charges. Gerasimov questioned whether an American court had the right to try Noriega and said the United States violated international law by invading Panama last month and now removing Noriega for trial. ``From the outside,'' Gerasimov said, Noriega's capture looked like government vengeance against a former CIA agent who got away. He said it appeared that the real issue at stake in the American intervention was trying to hold onto the Panama Canal, which is due to revert to Panamanian control in the year 2000. He added that even if Noriega is found guilty of drug trafficking, armed intervention is still ``not how things should be done. That's not how the struggle with drug business should be waged.''

DOC.HEAD: Ethiopia Rebels Says Weekend Push Knocked Out 1,536 Troopers
DOC.TEXT: Ethiopian rebels kept up an offensive that has seen their greatest gains in a 14-year insurgency and claimed on Thursday that they ``put out of action'' 1,536 soldiers in recent fighting. The rebels also said they shot down a MiG-23 fighter jet and damaged a helicopter during a government air raid that inflicted heavy casualties on Debre Tabor, a garrison town in Gonder province recently captured by the Tigre People's Liberation Army. The rebels, fighting in conjunction with the much smaller Ethiopian People's Democratic Movement, said the government suffered the losses Saturday in a three-pronged guerrilla attack to the southwest, west and northwest of Debre Tabor. In a clandestine radio broadcast monitored in Nairobi, the Tigre rebels reported 1,465 troopers killed or wounded and 71 captured. They also claimed to have captured weapons and destroyed two tanks and seven vehicles. The broadcast did not mention rebel or civilian casualties. Reporters are denied access to the region and it is impossible to verify the reports independently. The rebels said earlier that they killed, captured or wounded more than 8,000 soldiers in capturing Debre Tabor and three other towns, including one 70 miles from the capital, Addis Ababa. The rebels since August have made their greatest gains since taking up arms in 1975 in an uprising seeking the ouster of Marxist President Mengistu Haile Mariam and greater autonomy for their province. They now control Tigre and have made significant advances into Wollo, Gonder and Shoa provinces to the south and the west. The government faces an even older insurgency in the northernmost province of Eritrea where rebels have been fighting a secessionist war for 28 years.

Exultant Panamanians danced in the streets and embraced American soldiers when they heard Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, who intimidated them for years, had walked out of the Vatican embassy and surrendered to U.S. troops. ``The people feel a sense of peace knowing that the monster is leaving our land,'' said President Guillermo Endara, who had been a frequent target of harassment for Noriega's thugs. Sheer jubilation gripped the capital of 1 million residents just seconds after radio and television announced that the man who ruled Panama for six years with no popular mandate had abandoned his sanctuary. Spontaneous celebrations broke out across Panama City.

The women warriors who helped invade Panama have shattered myths about gender in combat and made mincemeat of a congressional ban. ``It blew everyone's theories,'' said 2nd Lt. Kimberly Thompson, 23. ``Now they are regrouping.'' Despite the ban on women in combat, female soldiers vindicated themselves so well that the White House is leaping to their defense and a leading senator said the exclusion should be re-examined. Thompson, a platoon leader in the 988th Military Police Company from Fort Benning, Ga., knows the myths well. She is third-generation military and the wife of an airborne Ranger, a private who stayed home while she went to war.

U.S. marshals are throwing mattresses on the floor for federal prisoners and driving hundreds of miles a day in a hunt for empty jail beds as authorities grapple with the Northeast's inmate glut. The overcrowding problems were to be discussed at a ``Northeast jail crisis meeting'' scheduled today through the weekend at the U.S. Marshals Service headquarters in Alexandria, Va. The federal prison population has ``not just expanded, it has exploded,'' said U.S. Marshal Pasquale A. Mangini of Connecticut. The Bureau of Prisons said Wednesday a projected doubling of population in federal prisons during the next five years won't provide relief.

A federal task force is recommending a wide array of options for oil development at three controversial offshore sites near Florida and California and none of the choices would ban drilling altogether, according to administration sources. The task force report was to go to the White House today, according to Interior Department officials who said it would not be made public. Sources familiar with the recommendations said Wednesday the options for the leases off the California coast would envision oil and gas development, but in some cases include specific conditions, restrictions and various timetables. The task force adopted more restrictive options for the lease off the Florida coast, according to one source, including one that could delay development for several years because of environmental concerns.

Most of the 1980s were boom years for the economy as a whole, but they were a bust for banks and savings institutions which failed in numbers not seen in half a century. Capping a decade of failure for financial institutions, savings and loans in 1989 collapsed at the highest rate ever and bank closings fell only slightly short of a post-Depression high, regulators said Wednesday. Government seizure of thrifts in Texas and New Mexico on Dec. 21 boosted the tally of failed S&Ls to 328, far above the previous high of 277 in 1938. The Resolution Trust Corp., the agency created Aug. 9 to carry out President Bush's S&L bailout, took control of 318 failed thrifts, disposing of 37 of them by year's end. The old Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp. dealt with 10 S&Ls.

A study showing that global warming could speed the destruction of forests by fire and windstorms suggests noticeable change could occur in the Earth's forests by early in the next century, a researcher said. ``The rate of change will be faster than we thought before,'' said Jonathan Overpeck, the study's principal author. The change will be marked by the appearance of fast-growing species of trees in areas where mature trees have been destroyed, said Overpeck, a staff scientist at the Lamont-Doherty Geological Observatory in Palisades. Previous computer projections have shown that changes in temperature and rainfall could affect the growth of forests. This is the first to show that physical destruction of trees will play a significant role in changing forests as the Earth warms, Overpeck said.

DOC.HEAD: Samaritans Caught Between Israelis and Palestinians
DOC.TEXT: The Samaritans, known mainly for Jesus' parable of the Good Samaritan, use a Hebrew saying to describe their lives in the midst of the Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule. They say it's like being caught ``between a hammer and an anvil.'' Americans would call it trapped between a rock and a hard place. In any language, it means uncomfortable. About 275 Samaritans, whose day-to-day language is Arabic, live on Mount Gerizim or in nearby Nablus, a Moslem Arab town of 120,000 which has been a focal point of anti-Israeli unrest in the uprising. An equal number of Samaritans speak Hebrew and live in Holon, a Jewish city of 144,000 just south of Tel Aviv. ``In Nablus, there are those who understand what the Samaritans are, and say we always have lived with them. And there are those who say we are Jewish,'' said Itamar Cohen, seated behind the counter of his small grocery, the only shop on the mountain. ``But with all this, we are not Jews, and we are not Moslems. We have our own religion,'' said Cohen, 52, who also works for the Israeli government as a guide to the historical sites here. The Samaritan religion is an offshoot of Judaism. The Samaritans claim to be descendants of three of the 12 tribes of ancient Israel and believe that Mount Gerizim, not Jerusalem, is the place chosen by God for the true temple. Although Smaritans base their faith on the Old Testament, they're best known for an account in the New Testament (Luke 10:30-37) of the tale told by Jesus to fellow Jews about the Good Samaritan. At that time, Jews resented Samaritans as distorting the faith. Jesus' story was about a Samaritan who helped an injured Jew ignored by passing Jewish priests _ the Samaritan thus proving himself a good neighbor. Samaritan Scripture, a mixture of ancient Hebrew and Aramaic, consists of their version of the first five books of Moses. The Samaritans consider Moses to be the sole prophet of God. While they celebrate most of the same holidays as the Jews, many of their rituals are profoundly different, including the slaughter of sacrificial lambs on Mount Gerizim during Passover. ``Our goal is to continue our lives until the end of the world. We believe in the resurrection of the dead,'' Cohen said. But the Samaritans say _ quietly, cautiously, nervously _ that they are increasingly having trouble assuring their survival as a result of the nearly two-year-old Palestinian uprising. Several Samaritan homes in Nablus were burned last fall during the Jewish and Samaritan holiday of Sukkot, which commemorates the desert wandering of the Israelites during the Exodus. Nablus leaders have condemned the attacks and promised compensation, the Samaritans say. Most Nablus Samaritans are employed by the West Bank military government. Zevolon Altif, 60, a retired high school English teacher, said about 10 in the transportation and tax offices received telephone threats from Palestinians ordering them to quit. Two army cars now take them to and from work. ``It is not good for them to go in an army car in front of the surrounding population. At the same time, we don't know how to get out of this problem. They want to leave their work, but they can't earn their living any other way,'' Altif said. Until the uprising began, Altif and most Samaritans from Nablus lived on Mount Gerizim for only two months in the summer and during the three major religious holidays. Now, as a result of the increasing violence and army-imposed curfews, they are staying on the mountain as much as possible. Because of the uprising, few Holon Samaritans join relatives on Mount Gerizim except for holidays or celebrations, although all have homes there, said Israel Sedaka, 57, of Holon, who works for Israel's state commemorative coin office in Jerusalem. ``Since the intefadeh (uprising), we only go when there's no choice,'' Sedaka said. ``There's a road that you can drive without going through the city and placing yourself in danger.'' Although the Samaritans do not consider themselves Jews and are not considered to be Jews by the Israeli rabbinate, the Samaritans of Holon go to Jewish schools and serve in the Israeli army. The Samaritans of Nablus study in Arab schools and do not serve in the military. Some learned Hebrew after the 1967 Six-Day War, and many now choose between a Hebrew or an Arabic first name, depending on the listener. ``We were two parts of the same nation. Because of that, some people are suspicious,'' Altif said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Fri PMs, Jan. 6

For Release Fri PMs, Jan. 5, and thereafter
DOC.TEXT: The United Church of Christ, based in New York City since the denomination was formed by merger in 1957, opened its new headquarters here Jan. 2. Three top officers and skeleton crews of several national agencies have shifted work here. Three floors of the headquarters building at 700 Prospect Ave. are being renovated to provide working space for about 90 employes. Further renovations start in March. Altogether, national offices of the 1.6 million-member denomination have about 350 employes, most of them based in New York City. The two largest agencies are remaining there through 1990, the board for homeland ministries and board for world ministries, but will began shifting some personnel to Cleveland in 1991. The move from New York City to Cleveland was voted in July by the church's legislative general synod. Among officers who have already shifted to the new site is the denomination's president, the Rev. Paul Sherry.

Cardinal Johannes Willebrands, 80, of the Netherlands, has stepped down as head of the Vatican Secretariat for Promoting Christian Unity. He had led Roman Catholic ecumenical efforts for a quarter century. He was succeeded by Cardinal Edward Cassidy, 65, an Australian-born archbishop.

Southeastern Baptist Theological Seminary, embroiled in a two-year dispute between faculty and a fundamentalist-dominated administration, has been placed ``on warning'' by an accrediting agency. The Southern Association of Colleges and Schools says the Wake Forest, N.C., seminary must correct various deficiencies within two years or face further measures. Faculty members charge the seminary trustees in 1987 changed the way the school picked professors to ensure that only ``biblical inerrantists'' were hired in the wake of fundamentalists gaining control of the denomination.

A survey for the Central American University in Manuaga finds that revolutionary changes in Nicaraguan society has not led young people to atheism. Only 9 percent of 1,000 students said they don't believe in God.

A Jewish leader says religious organizations are facing either a ``breakdown'' or ``breakthrough'' in the fight against AIDS. There ``is a great danger of somehow becoming used to AIDS and the dreadful toll it exacts,'' says Rabbi A. James Rubin, interreligious affairs director of the American Jewish Committee. He told about 100 national religious leaders gathered to formulate a unified interfaith response to the AIDS crisis that it can't be met ``only as Jews, or only as Christians'' but ``only together, only in covenant.''

The U.S. military intervention in Panama ``cannot be understood as a valid act of a civilized nation,'' says the head of the United Methodist Church's national social action agency. ``Unilateral intervention, no matter its validity, can never be supported,'' says the Rev. Thom White Wolfe Fassett, general secretary of the Board of Church and Society. ``In order to validate such action it would have been necessary for the United States to press its claims to the Organization of American States or to the United Nations and receive support.''

The ``new Christian right'' was ``the surging religious force' that marked the 1980s and influenced a U.S. domestic agenda which dominated the decade, says noted church historian Martin Marty. Some of their ideas led to a necessary economic redirection, but ``now we can see how much of the achievement was based on illusion,'' Marty writes in The Lutheran, monthly of th Evangelical Lutheran Church in America. ``We seemed to be sitting in a dark but enjoyable theater through a decade-long matinee, delighting in the illusion,'' he adds. ``Now we walk out into sunlight squinting at a real world again. And we see as context the underclass, the homeless, the drug merchants and AIDS victims, the nation turned gambling-mad and self-centered.'' He calls the decade the ``Age of Greed,'' a ``pitiless and persistent rival of faith.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Fri PMs, Jan. 5

DOC.HEAD: NBC Movie On U.S. Drug Agent's Killing Strong But Flawed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: `Federale,' for Mexican officer, in 5th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: Nearly five years ago, drug thugs in Mexico kidnapped Drug Enforcement Administration agent Enrique ``Kiki'' Camarena in daylight near the U.S. Consulate in Guadalajara. They tortured him, then beat him to death. On Sunday, Monday and Tuesday, NBC's ``Drug Wars: The Camarena Story'' is telling his story and that of his DEA colleagues who fought the good fight despite cover-ups by Mexican officials and Washington foot-dragging. With Cuban-born Steven Bauer as Camarena and Craig T. Nelson as his drawling, emotional local-level boss, ``Drug Wars'' is a superb piece of work, filled with excellent ensemble acting. It's richly textured and well-directed. It has flaws, the most serious of them the use of clips from ``NBC Nightly News'' _ specifically anchor Tom Brokaw's prefaces to news reports on the drug war in Mexico, Camarena's slaying and the return of the agent's body for burial in Calexico, Calif. That's in a show that also has actors playing TV reporters and cameramen covering various parts of the drug war story, including the moment in which Nelson screams at a corrupt federale officer at the rancho where Camarena'dvertisements featuring Trump's endorsement will begin appearing in business magazines this spring. Silver said Trump's lawyers usually pounce on any attempt to use the Trump name, and ``we haven't lost a case.'' Trump said in his letter to Zito that he decided to join forces with PCL instead of fighting it because he examined the photo business cards and liked them. Silver said Trump has some of the cards with his photo on them but wasn't sure if he was using them regularly. ``I can't tell you if he hands them out to everyone,'' Silver said. ``He's never had a business card before, so I imagine that's his business card.''

For Release Monday AMs, Jan. 8, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: And Now: Lebanon's Civil War Becomes Board Game
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Now Lebanese can become ``militia leaders,'' and with the roll of the dice, kidnap foreigners, misappropriate public funds, bribe army generals, shell city centers during rush hour and run lucrative rackets. Lebanon's civil war has become a board game, thanks to bookstore owner Naji Tueini. Tueini, a 32-year-old Christian, said he got the idea for the game he calls ``Civil War'' and costs $23 while he was stuck in his bomb shelter during the six-month artillery war between Christian and Syrian forces last year. ``I created it to make the Lebanese laugh at their tragedy,'' Tueini said. Most Lebanese, who've seen just about everything, have mixed feelings about the game. ``It's fun,'' said Rima Halaby, a college student in Moslem west Beirut. But some complain that a game based on a war in which more than 150,000 people are reported to have been killed since 1975 is offensive. ``I won't allow it in my home,'' snapped housewife Majwa Shami. ``I think it's sick and will corrupt my children.'' Tueini maintains there's nothing immoral about his game. ``It's just very realistic,'' he said. ``If I'd included drugs and stolen cars as sources of income in the game then it would have been immoral. ``But people don't need to be taught how to be immoral. Everybody knows what happens here. ``The game's not just about Lebanon,'' Tueini added. ``It can be applied to all Third World conflicts like the ones in Cambodia, El Salvador and Nicaragua.'' ``I used the ingredients from Lebanon because we've had 15 years' experience.'' The game is set in ``Mabil ... a country torn by civil war'' and has become ``a mixture of savage and unscrupulous mini-dictatorships.'' But unlike Lebanon's army, fractured like the country itself between feuding Christians and Moslems, Mabil's military is strong and united. The object of the game, with two to four players, is to collect 40 military units, five more than those run by the army to take ``the reins of government.'' The instructions read: ``The best man will be the most unscrupulous. ``Civil war ... has its own rules which have nothing to do with the international conventions, with military rules of conduct or with what is commonly called human rights.'' The instructions note: ``In fact, the rules of civil war are nothing but the absence of rules. ``Racketeering, taking hostages ... terrorism, blind shelling, blockades, seizure of ports, corrupt practices and so on. All these are an integral part of the civil war.'' Players throw dice to move their markers around the yellow board, which is divided into squares, orange for events, green for battles and blue for revenue. ``The elementary rule of any civil war is to make money to buy weapons,'' Tueini said. ``To make money you need revenue.'' The squares denoting revenue sources include liquor, tobacco, restaurants, casinos, electricity and water _ and hostages, ``the most lucrative.'' If a player lands on a battle square he can declare war on any ``militia leader'' provided the aggressor has 15 military units. Players landing on an events square pick up cards outlining a situation that will determine whether they win or lose money. Tueini said all the events described have actually taken place in Lebanon. ``I picked the funniest and most unscrupulous scandals without naming names,'' he said. One events card reads: ``The regional power protecting you and the country where your hostages come from come to an agreement. Your `protector' asks you to release the hostages. In return you receive the equivalent of your throw of dice multiplied by 30 Mabilian pounds.'' Tueini noted: ``I've even printed a multiplication table for younger players who may not know how to multiply.'' Another events card reads: ``You have just received an international donation of flour that you have sold without scruples on the local market. You win 100 Mabilian pounds.'' Tueini has made 2,000 copies of the game in French and English and hopes to market it abroad. He said it's selling ``quite well.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday AMs, Jan. 8

DOC.HEAD: Bush OK But No Quayle, Conservatives Say
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: A panel of conservatives, grading the administration's first year, says President Bush is OK _ but he's no Dan Quayle. A conservative think tank issued that report card, giving Bush a gentleman's C. The vice president got an A. That spells success in one of Quayle's tasks _ covering the conservative political flank for the administration. It has been handled with differences in tone and emphasis that leave both Quayle and Bush room to insist there is no disagreement on policy. There can't be _ it is a fact of vice presidential life that the No. 2 man doesn't have any policy options of his own. Quayle has said there is no good guy-bad guy strategy at work. But on such topics as East-West relations, he tends to emphasize the negative while Bush deals with the positive. That reassures the right, still suspicious of Soviet intent, internal reforms notwithstanding. The White House describes that as a difference in perspective, not in substance. Quayle underscores his loyalty to the president and his policies at every opportunity, and dismisses suggestions that they're not always in tune. ``It's the age-old game that is played in trying to find some distinction between the president and vice president,'' Quayle said in a New Year interview with The Associated Press. Still, there are distinctions, and they register clearly with conservatives. That shows in the report card. The Heritage Foundation published the freshman year appraisal this month, in its quarterly magazine, Policy Review. Grading was done by five conservatives who were willing to put their names behind their marking system. Given the magazine deadline, Bush's decision to intervene in Panama on Dec. 20 didn't come within their grading period. Conservatives generally applauded him for it. And they unanimously applauded Quayle for his year's work. ``Quayle has proved to be a very effective advocate of conservative positions within the administration and as a liaison with conservatives on Capitol Hill,'' said Paul Weyrich, president of the Free Congress Foundation. Weyrich rated Quayle at A-minus, suggesting he ought to be more independent of the administration to add to his own stature and build ``a viable national political base for himself.'' That may sound good to conservative Republicans, but independence, in policy or politics, is not part of the job description that goes with the vice presidency. Bush got a B from Weyrich. Ditto on the card of Pat Robertson, the television evangelist who challenged him for the 1988 presidential nomination. Robertson, chief executive of the Christian Broadcasting Network, called Bush ``steady, competent, unimaginative'' and cautious. ``He has not told the American people where he wants to go,'' Robertson said. ``He has not outlined a cogent policy agenda for them to support.'' Robertson said Quayle merits an A as ``a superb vice president.'' ``Whether he can rehabilitate himself politically after the vicious beating he took from the media last fall remains to be seen,'' Robertson said. ``I hope he can.'' Amy Moritz, executive director of the National Center for Public Policy Research, agreed on the A and on the complaint about Quayle coverage. ``Quayle has done a tremendous job under this pressure and it's time the American people told the bullies in the media to lay off,'' she said. She saw Bush as no better than a C-minus, saying he has delivered neither victories nor vision. ``George Bush is not sure why he wants to be president,'' she said, so he reacts to events and compromises between opposing viewpoints. Harsher still was Edward H. Crane, president of the Cato Institute, who gave Bush a D. ``Bush is a creature of government who does not object to a single federal program or department,'' Crane contended. ``... His continued popularity among conservatives is a sad commentary on what's left of the Reagan revolution.''

DOC.TEXT: Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: Rehnquist's 18th Anniversary on High Court Finds Him Riding High
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court's nine members are among the most private of public officials. They wield enormous political power, but rarely hold news conferences or give interviews. A recent poll indicated only one in three Americans can name any of the nine. This, the second in a continuing series, offers an up-to-date look at one member of the nation's highest court.

Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, who early in his Supreme Court tenure was kidded for being an ideological ``Lone Ranger,'' marks his 18th anniversary on the high court Sunday _ now the leader of a conservative majority. The survivor of a bruising 1986 Senate battle over his elevation to chief justice, Rehnquist has emerged as the collegial orchestrator of a major rightward shift in the court's direction. ``The Rehnquist Court came of age'' in 1989, said A.E. Dick Howard, a law professor at the University of Virginia. ``I think he's been an enormously effective chief justice,'' added Professor Dennis Hutchinson of the University of Chicago. ``The court appears to operate more efficiently and harmoniously than it has in decades, and he's able to utilize the court membership in ways he thinks are advantageous.'' Rehnquist, who declined to be interviewed for this article, turned 65 in October. He has said privately he might have retired had he not become chief justice and if he found himself consistently in the minority on key issues. But his promotion and then-President Reagan's appointment of three conservative justices shelved all talk of retirement. Today, even those on the opposite end of the political spectrum applaud Rehnquist for his affability and brilliance. Justice William J. Brennan, the court's liberal anchor, has called him a ``splendid'' chief justice. Seasoned court observers say they are not surprised that an easy informality has been injected into the justices' private conferences and personal relations. ``I think Rehnquist has removed any internecine bitterness in the court,'' said Bruce Fein, a Washington lawyer and longtime court watcher. Rehnquist's predecessor as chief justice, Warren E. Burger, sometimes ruffled the feathers of his colleagues. But flashes of self-deprecating humor and a low-key style are more the Rehnquist hallmarks. The chief justice has been known to lead judges and lawyers in song in after-hours sessions at judicial meetings, wear a softball T-shirt to the justices' private conferences and tell a joke at his own expense. He has a well-earned reputation as a practical joker. But the public face Rehnquist shows is not always so convivial. A lawyer arguing before the court last month in support of a constitutional ``right to die'' had his concluding remarks brusquely cut off in mid-sentence by the chief justice. The allotted 60 minutes for arguments had expired. Rehnquist's at-times caustic interrogation of lawyers is defended by some scholars, who say his own high intellectual standards make him impatient with sloppy work. ``The more cerebral members of the court get upset at ineptitude,'' said Fein. ``The chief justice has to take the lead there and make sure arguments are productive.'' Rehnquist sometimes can appear ill at ease in public, as he did at the rancorous public hearings the Senate Judiciary Committee held before the full Senate confirmed him as chief justice by a 65-33 vote. Opponents challenged Rehnquist's integrity, honesty and commitment to equal rights. Five witnesses swore under oath that Rehnquist had harassed and had intimidated black and Hispanic voters as a Republican Party official in Phoenix in the early 1960s. The charges were nothing new. They were raised in 1971, when then-President Nixon nominated Rehnquist, a 47-year-old Justice Department lawyer, to the high court. On both occasions, Rehnquist swore he could not remember taking part in any harassment. Rehnquist's early years on the court were most notable for frequent, and often solitary, dissents that many feel laid the intellectual groundwork for the court's rightward turn of later years. In the mid-1970s, Rehnquist's law clerks gave him a Lone Ranger doll to symbolize his status. Rehnquist may have moderated some views since, but the more likely explanation is that the change in the court's composition has placed him closer to its ideological center. In his first court term as chief justice, Rehnquist seemed outmaneuvered by Brennan as court liberals prevailed in key cases. When voting in the minority, the chief justice must turn over to the senior justice on the other side the job of writing or assigning the court's majority opinion. When Justice Anthony M. Kennedy joined the court in 1988, a more-seasoned Rehnquist began to place his imprint on the court's work. The chief justice seems to have absorbed a lesson from a 1976 article he wrote about some of his predecessors: ``It may well be that the office of chief justice of the United States calls for skills and abilities more readily honed in the give-and-take of political life than in the practice and teaching of the law,'' Rehnquist wrote. There is little question of Rehnquist's intellectual capacity to lead. He graduated first in his class from Stanford University's law school in 1952. As a thinker and a writer, many place him in the first rank of the 16 men to have served the nation as chief justice. Rehnquist's plans may be uncertain. He has hinted privately that after several more years he might retire to spend more time with his four grandchildren and his hobbies, which include playing tennis and poker, studying history and painting landscapes in acrylic.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Anticipate Deluge of Data From Satellite Platform
DOC.TEXT: After 10 years of focusing on shuttles, NASA plans 64 space exploration missions this decade, creating a data deluge that could swamp an agency already drowning in information that's never been studied. ``We will acquire in the next three years what it's taken 25 years to get,'' said James Green, director of the National Space Science Data Center at Goddard Space Flight Center. The volume will double every two years after that, with a virtual information explosion in 1996 from the Earth Observing System. EOS is expected to transmit more data in 30 hours than is already stored from 25 years of space travel. Before EOS, the next three years should see the launch of the Cosmic Background Explorer, the Galileo mission to Jupiter, the Hubble Space Telescope, Gamma Ray Observer, Ulysses mission to the sun, the Mars Observer and the TOPEX Poseidon ocean-sensing satellite. Scientists hope EOS will yield data to such solve threats to the Earth's survival as global warming and the thinning of the protective ozone layer. The critical question is whether it will be in a form they can use. Industry hasn't developed hardware or software to serve the demands of disciplines as diverse as anthropology, zoology and atmospheric physics, so it has been up to government scientists to pioneer solutions that have put NASA at the cutting edge, but still short of making computerized data easily usable. Observers say part of the problem lies with NASA itself. The agency traditionally has been most willing to cut funds for archiving data if it ran short of money when launching a space mission. It is undergoing a change in focus, too, moving from an era of general space exploration to one of information gathering _ and funding for that lags. In the fiscal 1990 budget, the data center received $4.7 million for managing, archiving and distributing data, up from the 1989 budget allocation of $3.2 million. By comparison, NASA's entire 1990 budget was $12.5 billion. Green likens the data analysis and management after a space launch to the ``the last puppy that comes to supper _ if there's too many puppies, there's not much left.'' But while he agreed his area frequently gets short shrift, he said funding increases show the agency is moving in the right direction. ``The thing is you don't put the space probes up there for no reason,'' said David Dickerson, an aide to Rep. Bill Nelson, D-Fla., chairman of the House space science subcommittee. ``The distance they travel is not what's important. It's the information they send back. They're going to have to put increasing amount of thought and resources to that.'' Alan Robock, a University of Maryland meteorologist who is testing NASA techniques for improving accessibility to data, said the fault isn't just with the space agency. ``Computers and data analysis are not nearly as sexy ... they're harder to sell to Congress.'' William Campbell, a NASA artificial intelligence expert, is developing techniques to build intelligence into the data gathering. Increasingly fast and sensitive instruments can gather data faster than anyone can analyze or catalog it, Campbell said. ``It's not just the volume, it's the complexity.'' He and other NASA scientists believe they are on the brink of developing systems that would put the data in usable form almost from the time instruments capture it in space by analyzing it with the users' needs in mind. ``The idea is to build intelligence into the whole system from the back end to the user,'' he said. ``This is a whole new way of thinking about the problem. I contend it is the only hope.'' In the five years since Green took over, the Space Science Data Center has gone from a ``tape landfill'' to concentrating on data accessibility. But as it struggles toward answers to the pending data deluge, it is burdened with catching up from years of neglect. Of approximately 80,000 magnetic tapes dating to the early 1960s that are in a climate-controlled federal warehouse in Suitland, about half need to be restored, said Robert McGuire, who heads the project. About 9,000 have been restored since the effort began in July 1988. Another 30,000 to 40,000 tapes are at the Space Science Data Center. Under Green, the center's goals shifted from storage to accessibility and he said it now handles 6,000 requests a year _ up from 2,000 five years ago _ using new computer networks to universities and research centers, electronic mail, and the postal service. Data in demand on climate, atmosphere and other subjects are online in the computer in 15 systems. That information is stored on magnetic diskettes or high-density optical disks that hold as much as 40 of the sequential magnetic tapes and let the user go right to the needed data. If the technology doesn't exist to manage data beamed back from EOS, the instruments should be monitored only some of the time _ or not launched, Green said. ``It doesn't do anybody any good if we can't manage the data.''

DOC.HEAD: Men Get Breast Cancer Too, A Survivor Stresses
DOC.TEXT: Some of Alvin Burkett's co-workers thought he was kidding when he told them the diagnosis. Even some nurses didn't believe him. Burkett, a 51-year-old computer specialist from Bellevue, Neb., had breast cancer. And in June he had a mastectomy. As a man, ``you've got to be careful when you tell people you've had a mastectomy,'' he said recently. ``They think `vasectomy.''' Only about 900 men a year are diagnosed with breast cancer and some 300 die of it annually, compared to about 142,000 diagnoses and 43,000 deaths in women. Experts say it is too rare in men to justify widespread screening, as is urged for women, and that few doctors check for it while doing physicals. Burkett, now 52, had never heard of breast cancer in men when he noticed a lump near his right nipple, beneath the surrounding areola. An internist sent him to a surgeon for a biopsy, in which a piece of tissue is removed for microscopic inspection. Even before the diagnosis, Burkett had started checking around for information about male breast cancer, and found little available. By the time the lab reported the lump was cancerous, he said, ``I sort of suspected it.'' He spent two days in the hospital after a modified mastectomy. Tests at the time and since have shown no evidence of any remaining disease. ``My doctor says I'm a very lucky fella,'' Burkett said. In fact, the prognosis for men as a group is worse than for women, experts say. One reason is that men tend to be diagnosed in later stages, because few men or medical personnel are watching for it in earlier stages. In addition, because men have so much less breast tissue than women, it is easier for cancer to spread to adjacent tissue, said Robert Crichlow, professor and chairman of surgery at Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center in Hanover, N.H. Why is breast cancer so rare in men? It doesn't appear to be simply that men have so much less breast tissue, as the risk is not related to breast size in women, said Arthur Holleb, a retired American Cancer Society official who has studied breast cancer in men. Instead, the key seems to be that a man's breast is not the target for hormones that a woman's breast is; the changes hormones induce in a woman's breast may make cancer more likely than in a man's, he said. Any lump in a man's breast is reason to consult a doctor, especially if it is under the nipple, said William Donegan, professor of surgery at the Medical College of Wisconsin in Milwaukee. Most breast cancer diagnoses in men are made around ages 60 to 65, but men in their 20s can develop the disease as well. Donegan noted that many teen-age boys get harmless breast lumps that tend to disappear in a year or two. Breast cancer is very rare in teen-age boys. Doctors treat breast cancer in men just as they do in women, with surgery and sometimes follow-up chemotherapy or radiation treatment. A mastectomy removes the nipple and leaves a scar, Donegan said. Burkett has written to columnist Ann Landers and offered himself for an interview with a local television station about his experience. His goal, he said, is to spread the word that men can get breast cancer too. If that makes men examine their breasts and consult a doctor early about suspicious lumps, he said, maybe it will save some lives.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Promoting Church Moral Doctrine in Scientific Sphere
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.HEAD: By STEPHEN R. WILSON
DOC.TEXT: From AIDS to organ transplants, Pope John Paul II is keeping closing track of scientific issues to ensure the Roman Catholic Church's moral agenda is promoted in the push for progress. The relationship between science and religion is long and stormy, but things have come a long way since the church tried the 17th century astronomer Galileo Galilei for teaching that the earth orbits the sun. The process of reconciliation has accelerated under John Paul, who often addresses scientific issues and solicits research by Vatican-appointed scientists on developments of interest to the church. ``While it is not the church's specific role to advance knowledge of a strictly scientific nature, she cannot ignore or neglect issues which are closely related to her mission,'' he said Dec. 14 to a group of scientists meeting at the Vatican. ``This is particularly true when it is a question of defining the rules which should regulate human conduct.'' These are often issues that raise moral or ethical problems, such as artificial procreation, genetic engineering and nuclear war. But the Vatican has also promoted research into less controversial matters, including tropical disease, leprosy, and alternative energy. The pope frequently reminds scientists not to lose sight of the moral and ethical implications of their work, warning of potential risks and abuses. ``In its undisputable task of research and service, science has an intrinsic morality it must respect,'' he said Sept. 24 at the University of Pisa. Without imposing ``repressive limits'' on research, scientists should ``respect the supreme laws of nature and life,'' he said. That also was the message of a 1987 Vatican document condemning test-tube births, surrogate motherhood and experiments on living embryos. Church doctrine on sexual and moral issues also took center stage at an international meeting on AIDS in mid-November. While the meeting attracted hundreds of scientists, church officials set the agenda at the Vatican-sponsored conference. Issues with moral implications are also being taken up by the Pontifical Academy of Sciences. The academy, which dates to 1603 but took its present form in 1936, has become recognized as one of the world's most prestigious research institutes. It has 80 members from around the world, including 26 Nobel Prize winners. Many are non-Catholics or non-believers. In the early 1980s the pope sent envoys to world capitals to present the academy's dark conclusions on the possible consequences of nuclear war, and he embraced the scientists' opposition to deployment of weapons in space. In interviews, several academy scientists acknowledged that dealing with delicate issues can pose difficulties. ``It's hard to draw the dividing line between scientific issues and moral and religious issues,'' said Stanley K. Runcorn, who now teaches physics at the University of Alaska. ``But the academy has to maintain its view that it has something to say strictly on the scientific aspects of a lot of these problems. It has to try and avoid getting itself into political and religious controversies.'' Hermann Bruck, 84, an astronomer and retired professor at the University of Edinburgh in Scotland, noted not all scientists agree on such issues as when life begins and ends. But at the academy, he said, ``the fundamental belief is that if you get down to things properly in an unbiased way, you find there is never a real opposition between faith and science, because both things are concerned with truth about the world.'' William W. Morgan, a retired astronomy professor at the University of Chicago who has been an academy member for more than 25 years, said the institute's work has never been dictated by religious priorities. But he said he has noticed the academy is increasingly examining issues with ethical implications and he would not participate in meetings he considered too closely linked with morality. ``I'm not damning them, but this is not in the realm of what I would call science,'' said Morgan, 83, who now works at the Yerkes Observatory in Williams Bay, Wis. ``I am not qualified in such matters.'' The pope stresses that science and morality are intertwined: ``Scientific research and moral reflection must proceed side by side in a spirit of mutual help. We must never lose sight of the supreme dignity of the human person whose well-being research and reflection are called to serve.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Jan. 8

DOC.HEAD: Blue Laser Could Mean Big Gains in Data Storage
DOC.TEXT: A zinc selenide laser that produces a blue beam and can be focused more tightly than other lasers could eventually triple the amount of information stored on optical computer disks, its developer says. Japanese researchers in March developed a zinc selenide laser, but it had to be cooled to 135 degrees below zero Fahrenheit, according to the University of Florida, which announced a more practical, room-temperature laser. Zinc selenide produces a blue beam that can focus on a spot one-third the size of that produced by current materials, packing information more densely on optical disks, increasing capacity. Optical storage has been slow to be adopted in computers because it is not as economical as magnetic storage. But optical disks have some marked advantages, primarily in volume. The NeXT computer developed by Apple founder Steven Jobs is the first desktop model to use an optical disk as a primary storage device. Peter Zory, a University of Florida electrical engineer who led the development of the zinc selenide laser, said that before it makes its way into use for information storage, it will be necessary to develop a blue laser diode of the same material. Diodes allow lasers to be powered by electricity. Without them, semiconductor lasers must be powered by other lasers or electron beams. Zory, who has worked on lasers for IBM and General Electric, said IBM is trying another technique called second harmonic generation. ``It's expensive but they're doing it anyway, because they want that blue light. If we come in soon with the blue diode, it will blow that technology out of the water.'' Glenn Sincerbox, a former colleague of Zory's who manages optical recording for IBM in San Jose, Calif., said, ``Blue lasers are very important. We consider them strategic.''
DOC.HEAD: Planning Begins for Model Solar Village in Arizona
DOC.TEXT: Construction could begin by the end of this year on the first solar houses in the proposed $500 million Tucson Solar Village, which is envisioned as a guide for energy-efficient housing in the coming century. ``We're getting interest from all over the globe because of the uniqueness of this project,'' said John Beimfohr of the state Solar Energy Office. ``The overall effort will be to provide an affordable, mixed-use community using less energy and resources than traditional developments and complying with more stringent environmental performance codes,'' said Wilson Orr, project manager for the 800-acre village to be built on state-owned land. Workshops, review meetings and surveys will allow the public to offer opinions on transportation, density, jobs, energy costs, water use, solid waste management, open spaces, wildlife, recreation and affordability, Orr said. ``Basically, our drawing board is blank right now,'' he said. ``In the coming months, we'll be relying on the public to help us define this community and the performance standards for the community.'' Beimfohr said the village will incorporate such ``passive'' solar techniques as narrower, tree-lined streets to reduce the ``urban heat island effect,'' landscaping and house designs and orientation, as well as ``active'' techniques such as solar collectors to heat water or provide energy. Initial funding for the project will come from an $850,000 oil overcharge restitution fund administered by the state. Another $69,000 in the first year will come from the Urban Consortium, which administers energy-related funds for the U.S. Department of Energy, Orr said. Under a ``best-case scenario,'' officials said, construction on the first model homes could begin late this year, with land auctions by 1992.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Jan. 8
