DOC.HEAD: Biologist Develops `Last Meal' for Insect Pests
DOC.TEXT: Insect pests could be quickly and safely killed by enticing them to eat a gelatinous meal containing parasites, a biologist says. Such ``biogel'' pesticides can't harm plants, animals or the environment, but kill beetles, termites, cockroaches, boll weevils, corn rootworms, tobacco worms and other insects within days, said Frank Chang, a Temple University biology professor who developed it with graduate student Michael Gehret. ``Biogel'' is a soft material that contains an insect attractant, a feeding stimulant, food and nematodes _ insects' natural enemies, Chang said. Nematodes live naturally in the soil and farmers, to control pests, spray them in large quantities in fields, a process Chang said is generally inefficient. ``The nematodes can be rendered harmless by lack of moisture, ultraviolet light, and heat. It is most likely that many nematodes die before killing any insects. At the same time, insects are able somehow to detect the meatodes, and the pests will often avoid these supersaturated areas.'' By contrast, ``biogel'' placed in small containers attracts insects while preventing detection of the nematodes. ``Biogel reduces the use of nematodes by 99 percent,'' Chang said. ``In other words, instead of spraying 10 million nematodes per 225 square feet of soil, you only need 100,000. ``As the nematodes produce offspring in the remains of each insect, the progeny return to the soil to repeat the infectious cycle.'' He estimated that corn farmers who spend an estimated $10 an acre for chemicals to control rootworms could halve their costs. Ray McAllister, director of regulatory affairs for the Washington-based National Agricultural Chemicals Association, said Chang's work ``makes dramatic promises. As with all new products, it must prove itself in the marketplace against some stiff competition. ... ``It has potential, but it is not the cure-all and it is certainly not the replacement for pesticides.'' Attempts at biological control predate chemical pest control strategies and often have had good results, he said, but they tend to be specific to one pest rather than the variety that attack crops.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Dec. 8

DOC.TEXT: Sales of new houses jumped 9.6 percent in November, their fastest gain in four months, the government said. The Commerce Department said Wednesaday that new, single-family homes were sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 710,000 units in November after a revised 0.9 percent gain the month before. October sales originally were reported down 0.5 percent. It was the sharpest surge since a 14.1 percent advance last July.

Savings and loans collapsed in 1989 at the highest rate ever and bank closings fell only slightly short of a post-Depression high, regulators said. The tally of failed S&Ls jumped to 328, far above the previous high of 277 in 1938, officials said Wednesday. The Resolution Trust Corp., the agency created last August to carry out President Bush's S&L bailout, seized 318 failed institutions last year, disposing of 37 of them. An additional 10 bankrupt S&Ls were handled by the old Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp.

The nation's thrift institutions lost $5.6 billion in deposits in October, the 16th outflow in 17 months but an improvement over the previous month, the government said. The Office of Thrift Supervision said Wednesday the October outflow at 2,895 thrifts followed $8.7 billion in net withdrawals in September and brought the total for the year to date to $59.2 billion, leaving the industry with a total deposit base of $949.3 billion.

Trans World Airlines said it is adding a special fuel surcharge ranging from $5 to $20 per ticket, representing about 4 percent of an average ticket price. TWA, United Airlines, Midway Airlines and USAir Group Inc. also said Wednesday they were matching steep fare cuts announced Tuesday by Eastern Airlines, but were keeping the usual cancellation penalties that Eastern had eliminated. It is the first time since the 1970s oil crisis that U.S. airlines have imposed a surcharge to cover a dramatic jump in jet fuel prices and comes as they are discounting fares to encourage more business.

A federal judge has approved a $6 million settlement of a lawsuit filed by a CBS shareholder who claimed the company that owns the CBS television network was mismanaged from 1983 to 1986. The lawsuit was brought in 1986 by Roger Minkoff, a real estate investor from St. Croix, Virgin Islands, who owns 12 CBS shares. The settlement, in which the management of CBS Inc. admits no wrongdoing, will be paid by a corporate insurance policy. It was approved by a judge Wednesday. Of the settlement money, $4.5 million will go to the CBS treasury for an indirect benefit to shareholders.

Campbell Soup Co. has named David W. Johnson, chief executive officer at Gerber Products Co., its new chief executive as the food products company moved to squash speculation it will be sold. Johnson is the first outsider selected to head the company in its 120-year history. He replaces R.Gordon McGovern, who announced his early retirement in November after serving as president and chief executive since 1980.

UAL Corp. is accelerating the schedule for talks with its non-union workers over a possible employee buyout, but the company still will miss a deadline set by a major shareholder for coming up with such a plan. The talks are to begin two days after a Monday deadline imposed by the investor group Coniston Partners, which is pressuring UAL to enhance its stock value with a buyout plan or other measures, UAL Chairman Stephen Wolf said in an internal memo Wednesday.

Merrill Lynch & Co. said it is selling its Canadian retail brokerage operations to Wood Gundy Inc., a Toronto-based securities firm. The deal announced Wednesday is part of a piecemeal restructuring announced by Merrill Lynch, the largest U.S. brokerage, in November to reduce costs and improve profits in a slumping Wall Street business environment. Terms were not diclosed.

Imperial Chemical Industries PLC, a major British chemicals company, said it has completed the sale of its U.S. over-the-counter drug business to Johnson and Johnson-Merck Consumer Pharmaceuticals Co. for $395 million. As part of the sale, ICI said Wednesday it also acquired the U.S. rights to Merck Sharp and Dohme Inc.'s anti-depressant drug Elavil.

The stock market made little progress Wednesday, bogging down after its sharp rise to record levels in the opening session of 1990. The Dow Jones industrial average, up 56.95 points Tuesday to its first close above 2,800, slipped back 0.42 to 2,809.73. The dollar ended mixed against major foreign currencies. Bond prices declined as the government reported robust home sales. Gold futures prices fell decisively below $400 an ounce; sugar, energy and orange juice futures all climbed sharply; livestock and meat futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans advanced.

DOC.HEAD: Economic Activity Up in Biggest Cities in 3rd Quarter, Study Shows
DOC.TEXT: Economic activity rebounded in most of the nation's largest commercial centers during the third quarter as construction and employment levels improved, according to a study. The accounting firm Grant Thornton said Wednesday its index of seven economic vital signs for two dozen U.S. metropolitan areas rose from July through September after falling in the second quarter. The index showed the average growth rate of the 24 cities rose by 0.82 in the third quarter to 108.4. In the second quarter, the index fell 0.77. Activity picked up in 22 of the 24 centers in the third quarter, Grant Thornton said. In making its assessment, Grant Thornton evaulated factory hours, non-farm employment, construction permits, retail sales, business starts, business failures and money supply. Cincinnati, which had gains in employment, retail sales and construction permits in the third quarter, saw the largest increase in economic growth, followed by San Francisco, Atlanta, Seattle and Houston. San Francisco benefited from strong retail sales and employment growth, while Atlanta had the biggest gains in construction permits of any city. Seattle had the largest improvement in retail sales, and also had a pickup in construction permits and employment, and Houston posted large gains in construction permits and factory hours. Boston was the only city studied by Grant Thornton to show a drop in activity. Declines in employment, retail sales and factory hours and an increase in business failures were blamed for the area's poor showing. Growth remained flat in the New York metropolitan area, where weakness in employment and retail sales was offset by a moderate improvement in factory hours. During the 12 months ended September 1989, activity rose in all but seven metropolitan areas: Boston, Chicago, Dallas, Kansas City, New York, Philadelphia and Phoenix. Grant Thornton, founded in 1924, provides accounting, audit, tax and management consulting services in more than 50 countries.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Confidence Slightly Lower In December, Report Says
DOC.TEXT: Consumer confidence in the economy slipped in December compared with the previous month but the outlook for the next six months improved modestly, the Conference Board said. The Conference Board's monthly consumer confidence index, which is based on a nationwide survey of 5,000 households, registered 113.1 in December. That was down from a revised 115.1 the previous month and the lowest level since November 1988, the board said Wednesday. The survey said 17 percent believed ongoing business conditions were ``bad,'' up about two percentage points from November, while those who classified jobs as ``plentiful'' dropped to 27.5 percent from 29.6 percent, the survey said. The number of people who said jobs were ``hard to get'' remained unchanged at 20 percent, it said. At the same time, slightly more people, 18.1 percent vs. 17.6 percent in November, expected business conditions to improve, the survey said. Fewer people, 7.8 percent vs. 8.3 percent, said they would worsen. Buying plans were virtually unchanged from November to December. About the same percentage of people said they planned to purchase a new car or a home in the next six months, the survey said. The Conference Board is a non-profit business organization that conducts economic research and provides forums for businesses to exchange information.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Consumer Electronics Industry Can Revive, Study Claims
DOC.TEXT: The nearly dead U.S. consumer electronics industry could rebound in the 1990s through a major effort involving both industry and the federal government, a private research group says. A report issued Wednesday by the Economic Policy Institute called for relaxation of antitrust laws to allow manufacturers to share production facilities and for increased support by the government for research and development. ``Without an ambitious new effort, we are bound to fall farther behind those nations which take the new international manufacturing competition seriously,'' said Susan Walsh Sanderson, a professor at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and the author of the report. The report noted that in the past two decades the United States has gone from being the world's leading producer of electronics goods to a major importer of these products. Beginning in the 1970s, American companies gave up making radios and black and white televisions, and in the 1980s lost out in the competition to manufacture more sophisticated products such as video cassette recorders and compact disk players. Though Americans invented videotape, no VCRs are manufactured in the United States. Only one U.S. television company remains, Zenith Electronics Corp., though several foreign firms make TVs domestically. ``In one branch of electronics after another, U.S. firms have failed to achieve commercial advantage from technical innovation, while the Japanese and the newly industrialized countries of Asia have caught up with and in many instances surpassed their U.S. rivals,'' the report said. ``This pattern is repeated in cases where the technology is stable _ toasters, radios and irons _ and where the technology is changing rapidly _ televisions, video cassette recorders, semiconductors and computers.'' Lost markets for high-technology products are particularly threatening since this is where most experts believe the United States must make gains if it ever hopes to close its yawning trade deficits. The report hailed a recent decision by seven leading computer and semiconductor firms to invest up to $500 million in U.S. Memories Inc., a joint venture which will produce key computer components. It said such joint efforts were an example of the innovations necessary for the United States to compete in world trade. The study, entitled, ``The Consumer Electronics Industry and the Future of American Manufacturing,'' made these other points: _U.S. firms have been able to find government support in weapons manufacturing. The defense share of total federal spending on research and development rose from 51.4 percent in 1964 to 68.4 percent in 1987. But these funds are likely to shrink dramatically with the expected cuts in defense spending from a relaxation of East-West tensions. _As defense support for research and development declines, Congress must channel part of the ``peace dividend'' into increased civilian research, including the public financing of demonstration projects aimed at improving manufacturing processes. _The government also needs to adopt policies that will reduce the cost of capital to U.S. businesses and encourage more corporate investment in research into new products and development of new manufacturing processes. ``For decades military and space spending has been our country's only program for assisting competitiveness of electronics manufacturing,'' Sanderson said. ``With a major shift of these resources we could help to assure a strong underpinning for our national commercial security.'' The Economic Policy Institute is a non-profit research organization founded in 1986, with several prominent liberal economists among its founders. It is backed by grants from foundations, labor unions, corporations and individuals. It often advocates government intervention in trade matters.

DOC.HEAD: October Deposit Loss Less Than in September
With PM-S&L Bailout, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The nation's thrift institutions lost $5.6 billion in deposits in October, the 16th outflow in 17 months but an improvement over the previous month, the government said. The Office of Thrift Supervision said Wednesday the October outflow at 2,895 thrifts followed $8.7 billion in net withdrawals in September and brought the total for the year to date to $59.2 billion, leaving the industry with a total deposit base of $949.3 billion. The industry has recorded net withdrawals in every month starting in June 1988, except for July 1989, when net deposits totaled $66 million. Withdrawals earlier in the year, which hit a monthly record of $10.8 billion in January, were attributed to depositor uncertainty about President Bush's bailout plan and to rising interest rates, which made other investments such as money market mutual funds more attractive. Since the enactment of the Bush plan Aug. 9, however, continuing outflows have been attributed to a deliberate strategy by institutions to shrink their operations to meet new capital standards that took effect Dec. 7. As part of that, thrifts have been selling their assets, which declined a record $15.2 billion in September and a slight $6 million more in October. The thrift office, in a statement, said the industry's adjustment to new financial standards appeared to be continuing in October, but at a slower pace. ``This is just a momentary slowing in the shrinkage of the industry, but it's not over by any means,'' said Bert Ely, a private industry analyst in Alexandria, Va. ``One month does not make a trend. Basically the only way most thrift institutions can meet the new capital requirements is by shrinking and there's more to be done,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Campeau's Troubles Put Apparel Makers in Delicate Spot
DOC.TEXT: Clothing makers worried that they might not get paid by cash-strapped Campeau Corp. still are reluctant to let relations unravel with stores that have been good customers. But the financial crisis facing the Canadian retail and property company remains unresolved. Most of the garment manufacturers that traditionally supply merchandise to stock Campeau's U.S. department stores are holding back shipments until the situation becomes clearer. Some of them said Wednesday they are meeting small orders to satisfy shoppers at Campeau-owned stores, such as the well-known Bloomingdale's chain, which has been put up for sale to help ease Campeau's cash shortage. Bud Konheim, president of apparel maker Nicole Miller Inc., said his company has assured Bloomingdale's buyers that it won't withhold goods that customers want. ``I'm taking care of Bloomingdale's on special orders,'' he said. ``I am not cutting off any of these stores, rudely, crudely or abruptly. We still have to treat them as very good customers.'' But it isn't exactly business as usual by a long shot, for Konheim's company or its competitors. Several big factors _ companies that provide credit support to manufacturers _ started telling clients weeks ago that they wouldn't accept the risk of doing business with Toronto-based Campeau any longer. Over the past few months some mainstream suppliers have disposed of merchandise through discounters and off-price outlets instead of shipping to stores operated by Campeau's Allied Stores Corp. and Federated Department Stores Inc. divisions, based in Cincinnati. They were willing to take less for their goods rather than risk not being paid at all by Campeau. Manufacturers are waiting to see whether they receive payment for goods shipped to the Allied and Federated retailers between Nov. 20 and the week before Christmas. The deadline for those payments is Jan. 10. If the bills aren't paid, manufacturers likely will continue to balk. That raises the spectre of sparsely stocked shelves at such Campeau-owned retailers as Burdines, The Bon Marche, Lazarus and Rich's. Currently, there is a between-season lull in shipments from manufacturers to retailers. Most stores are in the midst of post-Christmas sales with enough winter merchandise to tide them over until late January or early February, when spring goods usually start showing up, retail analysts say. There has been speculation within the retail trade that heavily indebted Campeau might delay paying bills as long as possible so that it can accumulate cash before seeking refuge for its retailers in bankruptcy court. Allied and Federated had warned last month that they might be forced to file for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code unless bondholders agree to reschdule certain debts. Campeau has debts in high-interest junk bonds that were sold to finance its $6.7 billion takeover of Federated, parent of Bloomingdale's, in 1988. Geoffrey Lurie, president of GDL Management Inc., which specializes in advising companies in turnaround situations, said he is ``convinced'' that a Chapter 11 petition will be filed by Campeau on behalf of its retailers. Such an action actually would reduce the turmoil in the apparel trade, he contended. Manufacturers could resume shipments to Allied and Federated after a filing knowing that they would be among the first in line to get paid. Claims that crop up after a filing have priority over unsecured creditors who had payments due them before a company files for Chapter 11 protection. Meanwhile, an announcement Tuesday that Allied and Federated won a temporary reprieve from a threat by bank lenders to declare the retailers in technical default on a $2.34 billion loan didn't provide much comfort for suppliers. The banking syndicate led by Citicorp's Citibank agreed not to press the point before Jan. 15, giving Campeau more time to show it is making progress in sorting out its financial problems. The bankers previously said they might ask for full repayment of the loan, a demand that presumably could have forced Campeau to file a Chapter 11 petition immediately. ``There's no measure of comfort now,'' said Konheim of the Nicole Miller apparel company. He said in order for the garment trade to alter its stance toward Campeau it would like to see Campeau get backing for its restructuring plans from Citibank or another financially sound supporter. Bernard Chaus, who heads a women's clothing manufacturing company that bears his name, was more optimistic. ``The news certainly is encouraging,'' he said. ``We are quite confident that these stores will be in business for many years to come.''

DOC.HEAD: Merrill Lynch To Sell Canadian Retail Brokerage Operations
DOC.TEXT: Merrill Lynch & Co. says it will sell its Canadian retail brokerage operations to Wood Gundy Inc., a Toronto-based securities firm. The deal, announced Wednesday, is part of a piecemeal restructuring the largest U.S. brokerage launched in November to reduce costs and improve profits in a slumping Wall Street business environment. The sale of Merrill Lynch Canada Inc.'s retail arm includes the transfer of 20 offices, professional and support staffs, and access to the firm's U.S. research capabilities. Terms of the deal with Wood Gundy were not disclosed. Merrill Lynch's retail sales operation in Canada employs 685 people, including 264 registered representatives. After the sale, Merrill still will employ about 300 people in Canada in institutional sales, trading and research, investment banking, mergers and acquisitions, and cross-border financing. Dumping the retail operation will reduce Merrill Lynch's total work force to about 39,800 from a peak of more than 46,000 before the October 1987 stock market crash. Merrill officials said the firm decided to sell the retail division because it appeared unlikely Merrill Lynch would receive a banking license in Canada. ``We believe that the strategic future of the retail business is directly linked with access to the Canadian banking system,'' Jerome P. Kenney, president and chief executive of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, said in a statement. Kenney also said Merrill is studying its other businesses around the world as part of its streamlining effort. Since November, Merrill has abandoned the European commercial paper business and one equity division at its New York headquarters. A subsidiary, Broadcort Capital Corp., recently sold some retail-oriented clearing counts to a division of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. Merrill Lynch entered Canadian finance in 1969 when it acquired Royal Securities. After the deal with Merrill, Wood Gundy will employ more than 2,500 people in Canada and elsewhere. Wood Gundy, which is 62 percent owned by Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, has 39 offices in Canada.

DOC.HEAD: Coniston Nonplussed By Switch in UAL Buyout Talks
With PM-Air Fares, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Coniston Partners is dismissing as irrelevant a decision by UAL Corp. to accelerate the schedule for its talks with non-union workers over a possible employee buyout of the airline company. The talks will begin two days after a Monday deadline for a buyout plan imposed by the investor group, a major UAL shareholder pressuring the parent of United Airlines to enhance its stock value with a buyout or other measures. The announcement of the speed-up implied that UAL would not meet Coniston's deadline. But Coniston principal Augustus Oliver shrugged off the development. ``I don't view the scheduled meetings with non-contract employees as necessarily relevant to our Jan. 8 deadline,'' Oliver said in a telephone interview from New York. Oliver said the success of any employee buyout plan hinged less on the participation of UAL's 23,000 salaried and management employees than on the involvement of the unionized pilots, flight attendants and Machinists who together represent about 46,000 UAL workers. Those three groups, along with management, ``are the key to getting something off the ground,'' Oliver said. ``It then becomes important to find the proper role and place with non-contract employees,'' he said. ``We obviously think the non-contract employees are an important element in the company as a whole but I think the key focus in the company is the unionized employees.'' UAL's management already has met with leaders of United's pilot and flight attendant unions over an employee buyout plan. UAL Chairman Stephen Wolf, in an internal memo Wednesday, said the talks with salaried and management employees were being moved up to Jan. 10 and 11 from Jan. 16 and 17 ``to provide meaningful input on employee ownership issues prior to any significant developments'' that could affect the structuring of any new employee ownership proposal. ``One way to look at it,'' Oliver said, ``is that maybe Steve (Wolf) is scheduling these meetings to explain a proposal that they're going to announce prior to that.'' UAL fell $7.75 a share to close at $162.75 Wednesday on the New York Stock Exchange. A $6.75 billion buyout proposal led by UAL management and the pilots union collapsed in October when the group was unable to raise financing for the $300-a-share deal. The Machinists' opposition to the plan helped kill it. UAL management reportedly is considering a deal that would not include the company's 25,000 Machinist union members. Coniston, which owns 11.8 percent of UAL's common stock, has said it would press for a recapitalization of the company if there was no acceptable employee buyout plan by Monday. A recapitalization could involve a cash dividend to shareholders, although some analysts believe such a plan would be worth less than $200 a share. That compares with the $240-a-share buyout proposal that UAL management reportedly has discussed in meetings with its pilots and flight attendants. Airline industry analysts were divided on the significance of the accelerated meetings. ``It certainly isn't what Coniston wanted,'' said an analyst who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``Coniston set a deadline but the company is saying it will move at its own pace. We're not bullish on the stock.'' But Samuel Buttrick, of the investment firm Kidder Peabody & Co., saw room for give and take between Coniston and UAL. ``My interpretation is that the date needn't be set in stone as long as some progress is being made,'' Buttrick said.

DOC.HEAD: GM Chief Doesn't Rule Out More Plant Closures
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. Chairman Roger Smith urged the United Auto Workers to acknowledge the car industry is mired in a slump and declined to rule out more plant closures in the first quarter. Smith, at a news conference Wednesday to discuss GM's prototype electric-powered Impact car, said future closures would depend on demand for GM cars and that it was too early to predict demand this quarter. Forty-two assembly plants will be down for at least one week in January. The Big Three operate 53 assembly plants in the United States. Among the plants targeted for temporary slowdown are several in Ohio, including GM plants in Columbus and Dayton which will idle more than 4,700 workers, the company announced Wednesday. As automakers grapple with high inventories and low demand, total shutdowns will affect more than 127,000 auto workers. Smith declined to directly answer a question on what effect the plant closures would have on contract talks with the United Auto Workers, which begin in September. He suggested, though, that workers should realize the auto industry has hit hard times. The UAW ``has got good economists too, so they should know,'' Smith said. About this time last year, Smith accurately predicted record earnings for GM. But he refused to make such a prediction on Wednesday, saying that Securities and Exchange Commission rules precluded him from doing so. Reminded that he had done so last year before fourth-quarter earnings were released, he said, ``It was easier to read last year because of the first nine months,'' which he said were so good that it was clear a record would be set. Smith was peppered with questions about the documentary ``Roger & Me,'' which contains interviews with people who said they lost their homes after GM plant closures in Flint, Mich. One woman said she had to start killing rabbits for food after Smith shut down the plants, eliminating 30,000 jobs in the city of 150,000. ``I haven't seen it,'' Smith said. ``I'm not much for sick humor and I don't like things that take advantage of poor people.'' Filmmaker Michael Moore said he arranged with Warner Bros. to reserve a seat for Smith at every showing of the movie across the United States.

DOC.HEAD: New Chip: Smaller Than A Credit Card, Powerful as Room-Size Computer
DOC.TEXT: A computer chip built smaller than a credit card and packed with the power of a room-sized supercomputer has been unveiled by TRW Inc. and Motorola Corp. The new chip first will be used in the military as the brain in spacecraft, missiles and jet fighters, and the makers hope it eventually will help free United States from relyiance on Japanese chip makers. The chip, called CPUAX for Central Processing Unit _ Arithmetic Extended, is expected to enter the commercial electronics market as other technologies catch up. TRW and Motorola issued a statement Wednesday saying their chip can perform 200 million operations per second by placing several times more transistors on a chip than ever before. ``Two hundred million operations per second mean the (chip) is the computational equivalent of some supercomputers that fill an entire room, require elaborate refrigeration systems and weigh several tons,'' said Thomas A. Zimmerman, a research director at TRW, the Cleveland-based aerospace and defense company. The chip is packaged at 2.1 inches by 2.1 inches and weighs 1.5 ounces. It has 4 million transistors, each smaller than a light wave, according to TRW and Motorola, the Schaumburg, Ill.-based electronics company. ``Commercial successors of the superchip could find use in a wide variety of applications where high speed, small size and great computing power and reliability are needed,'' Zimmerman said. ``Among these are computer-aided design, medical diagnosis, plant process control and complex imaging.'' William S. Richardson, executive vice of Ncube, a Beaverton, Ore.-based computer company that builds such parallel processing supercomputers, said the TRW-Motorola chip ``is a pretty impressive system.'' ``When you put 4 million transistors on a single computer chip ... that in effect means far higher performance,'' he said. ``It's probably three or four times the number of transistors of anything before.'' The chip is able to ``repair'' glitches in its operations when used in conjunction with a ``satellite'' chip, essentially by disconnecting the faulty parts of the superchip, the companies said. The chip was produced by a TRW-Motorola contractor team working on the Defense Department's very high-speed integrated circuits program. The team has worked for 10 years on three phases of the program, the companies said. The self-repair function is probably necessary because the transistors are so tiny and the chip so complex that inevitable glitches otherwise would render it useless, said Richardson. He said that previously the smallest transistor in a computer chip was about 0.8 to 1.0 microns _ twice the size of those in the TRW-Motorola superchip. Recent top of the line chips have handled up to 50 million instructions per second, with industry leader Intel claiming 100 million to 150 million instructions per second for its newest and hottest microprocessor, compared with the new superchip's 200 MIPS.

DOC.HEAD: Apple Board Approves Repurchase of 2.5 Million Shares Of Common Stock
DOC.TEXT: Apple Computer Inc. said today its board of directors has approved the repurchase of up to 2.5 million additional shares of common stock. The ongoing open-market purchases are part of an ongoing program announced last August, when Apple's board first authorized purchase of 2.5 million shares. John Sculley, Apple's chairman and chief executive, said the purchase ``represents good long-term value to our shareholers.'' Last month, Apple projected a decline in earnings in the first quarter of fiscal 1990 and said sales would grow more slowly than previously predicted. The announcement surprised industry watchers, coming just two weeks after a top executive of the personal computer maker told security analysts in New York that it expected worldwide sales growth of more than 20 percent. Before August, Apple had completed two share repurchase programs in 1986 and 1987, which together involved 15 million shares of stock.

The stock market declined slightly today, continuing the indecisive trend that set in on Wednesday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 4.91 to 2,804.82 in the first half hour of trading. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 7 to 6 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 442 up, 520 down and 520 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 24.98 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Analysts said traders were confining most of their buying, for the second straight day, to stocks of industrial companies considered highly sensitive to the ups and downs of the business cycle. Many of those stocks languished in the waning months of 1989 amid spreading talk of an approaching recession. In December, analysts said, the cyclicals were further depressed by yearend tax selling. With the arrival of the new year, buyers began to move into this sector of the market, acting on the theory that recession worries had gone to unwarranted extremes. DOC.HEAD: Oldsmobile Phases Out Ad
LaserPhoto DT4, DT5
DOC.TEXT: Oldsmobile's highly touted ``This is not your father's Oldsmobile'' ad campaign has run its course and will be phased out, a company executive says. ``We will not be using it too much,'' Mike Losh, general manager of the Oldsmobile Division of General Motors Corp., said Wednesday. ``We're going to be doing more talking about the `new generation of Olds,''' he said. ``It's time to move on and change and evolve.'' The ``father'' advertisement was an ill-conceived project from the start, said analyst Thomas O'Grady of Integrated Automotive Resources Inc. of Wayne, Pa. ``It made a lot of statements that lacked the ability to sell the cars,'' he said. ``It was an ad campaign that had to go.'' O'Grady said the campaign made the mistake of targeting car buyers around 40 years old, who usually don't consider buying Oldsmobiles, while alienating the traditional, older Oldsmobile buyers by saying the car is not for them. Oldsmobile sales suffered in 1989. Through Dec. 20, the division's sales were running 15.4 percent behind last year's pace. Oldsmobile officials declined to say how much was spent on the campaign, but observers speculated it probably was an expensive one. Celebrities and their offspring are used in the ads. In one, ex-Beatle Ringo Starr is chased by a group of middle-aged women, slides down a banquet table, out a window and into the passenger seat of an Oldsmobile driven by his daughter, Lee. Part of Oldsmobile's new image actually is a throwback to a previous focus _ trucks. Losh on Wednesday showed off the Oldsmobile Bravada, a four-door sport-utility vehicle scheduled for production in late summer for the 1991 model year. Oldsmobile, which had stopped producing trucks in 1934, returned to the truck market last year with the Silhouette minivan. ``It will get us back market that we've lost,'' Losh said. Car buyers have been changing to truck buyers with the relatively recent popularity of minivans and sport-utility vehicles like Jeeps. ``We don't see ourselves doing a pickup truck, for instance,'' he said. Losh's comments came during the first day of the three-day media preview for the North American International Auto Show in Detroit. Also at the preview, Chrysler Motors President Robert Lutz said Chrysler was conducting two studies to develop a successor for its Plymouth Horizon and Dodge Omni subcompact cars. Those vehicles go out of production early next month when Chrysler shuts down its Jefferson Avenue plant in Detroit. Lutz said one of the studies involves a possible link with an Asian automaker, probably Mitsubishi Motors Corp. ``This study is focused primarily on Mitsubishi for the obvious reason that they are our primary Asian partner,'' Lutz said. ``But the study is not exclusively focused on Mitsubishi.'' Chrysler and Mitsubishi currently are involved in a number of manufacturing and marketing associations. Lutz said the second study was focused on whether the car could be developed exclusively by Chrysler. Whichever plan is selected, he said, the Omni-Horizon successor wouldn't hit showroom floors until the mid-1990s, after Chrysler begins car production from its LH program. At one time, Chrysler commanded a large chunk of the small-car market with its Omni and Horizon, partly with its America series of subcompacts. But since then, sales have eroded amid criticism that the subcompacts' styling had become stale. Combined Omni-Horizon sales through Dec. 20 this year had fallen to 78,461, that's 33.4 percent behind last year's sales pace.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean, Corn Exports Boost Crop Futures
DOC.TEXT: Soybean and corn futures were mostly higher in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, boosted by the Agriculture Department's confirmation of new export sales of those commodities. Wheat futures were slightly lower. The soybean market rose amid buying linked to a USDA announcement late Wednesday that 150,000 metric tons of soybeans were sold to the Soviet Union, with another 150,000 tons shipped to unknown destinations. The agency said Pakistan bought 26,000 metric tons of soybean oil, which further supported the soybean futures market. A sale of 100,000 metric tons of U.S. corn to China underpinned slight gains in the corn market. Today's early advance was also partly due to followthrough buying from yesterday's strong close, analysts said. In early trading, wheat futures were { cent to 1 cent lower with the contract for delivery in March at $4.09{ a bushel; corn was unchanged to \ cent higher with March at $2.38} a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 2 cents higher with March at $1.55 a bushel; soybeans were \ cent to 1} cents higher with January at $5.69 a bushel. Hog and pork belly futures soared their respective daily limits of 1.5 cents and 2 cents a pound on the Chicago Mercantile Exhange in response to Wednesday's quarterly USDA hogs and pigs inventory, which showed a much smaller U.S. herd than traders had expected. Some analysts have predicted several days of limit gains as the market digests the report. Live hog futures were 1.5 cents higher across the board with February at 50.5 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 2 cents higher across the board with February at 51.47 cents a pound; live cattle were .17 cent to 1 cent higher with February at 77.32 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .30 cent to .58 cent higher with January at 84.90 cents a pound. Cattle futures settled lower on Wednesday while hog futures rose and pork bellies fell.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Says NY-NJ Spill Much Larger Than First Thought; Monongahela Reopens
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with Coast Guard saying waterway remains closed, new estimate of spill, picking up 10th graf pvs, `The cleanup...'.
DOC.TEXT: Exxon officials say a heating oil leak is 20 to 100 times larger than first estimated, and that up to 500,000 gallons of fuel spilled into a waterway separating New Jersey and New York's Staten Island. The officials are investigating whether a leak detector in an underwater pipeline may have malfunctioned. The Coast Guard closed much of the Arthur Kill channel to boat traffic Wednesday. Coast Guard Chief Gene Hoff said today the waterway was likely to be closed an additional 24 to 48 hours. In Pennsylvania, officials reopened a stretch of the Monongahela River today that had been closed since New Year's Day, after some five dozen barges broke loose from moorings during a thaw. One wayward vessel spilled 10,000 gallons of gasoline into the water. Exxon said from 100,000 to 500,000 gallons were spilled into the Arthur Kill after the Coast Guard questioned its initial estimate of 5,000 gallons and the company conducted an inventory, officials said. Hoff said today the actual spill of refined No. 2 oil probably was closer to 400,000 gallons and that 100,000 to 200,000 remained on the waterway. Coast Guard Capt. Robert North on Wednesday had estimated the spill at 200,000 gallons and said about half already had evaporated. Of the remainder, about half had been contained by booms within the kill, he said. The spill, first discovered early Tuesday, left an 11-mile slick from Shooter's Island at the mouth of Newark Bay in the north, to Tottenville, at the southern tip of Staten Island. It was traced to an underwater rupture in a 6.7-mile, 12-inch pipe connecting the Exxon plant in Bayonne to its Bayway refinery and chemical plant in Linden. The Arthur Kill, which is in a heavily industrialized area lined with oil companies and storage tanks, was closed Wednesday afternoon to general traffic for the cleanup, North said. Vessels were being allowed through by special request. Dozens of vessels use the Arthur Kill each day, North said, adding that there was some backup because of the closing. The cleanup, which Exxon is handling, could take several weeks, North said. Ben Marvin, spokesman for the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation in Albany, said workers had recovered 10 oil-soaked waterfowl. Nearly two dozen ducks have been found dead, most on Prall's Island, a protected state wildlife sanctuary in the Arthur Kill. There was no evidence of damage to fish life, North said. Exxon initially said the pipeline's leak detector system automatically shut the pipeline. But Exxon Plant Manager Katherine Cochrane said Wednesday officials were not sure. She said it would have taken about three hours for the pipe to discharge 500,000 gallons at its full capacity of 168,000 gallons an hour. It is also possible that workers may have ignored the device's leak advisory because it has given faulty leak reports in the past, Ms. Cochrane said. Exxon spokesman Louis Jung said divers had determined there was a 4-foot by half-inch gash in the pipe. The company is trying to determine what hit the line, he said. About 50 workers were setting up booms to trap the oil or removing it from the water's surface with skimmers and vacuums, said Exxon cleanup coordinator Joe Czarnecki. He said priority is being given to environmentally sensitive areas such as Prall's Island and Saw Mill Creek. Pennsylvania officials said environmental damage was slight from the gasoline spill on the Monongahela. The Coast Guard had warned barge operators Dec. 26 that a thaw was expected by weekend and advised them to secure barges tightly so that rushing chunks of ice and high water would not knock the vessels free. But at least 61 barges were torn from their moorings, 37 of them at the Maxwell Dam 60 miles upstream from Pittsburgh. The Coast Guard began searching for sunken barges Wednesday over 20 miles of river with sonar equipment. The procedure was completed early today and the Coast Guard reopened the entire river to traffic.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Says Romania Cannot Move Quickly To Free Market
DOC.TEXT: Romania's economy is so centralized it would be impossible to move quickly to a free-market system, Prime Minister Petre Roman was quoted as saying Thursday. ``We are going to try to establish an appropriate relationship between planning and the market,'' he was quoted as saying by the independent French daily Le Monde. ``To say we will, starting now, create a market economy would not correspond to the situation in which we find ourselves.'' Petre said the new government, put in place by the National Salvation Front until free elections planned in April, would try to decentralize control over state-owned enterprises, but said the idea of privatization had not been raised, the newspaper reported. ``We favor the abolition of the state's monopoly on foreign trade but for now, our economy is a planned economy,'' he was quoted as saying. ``We can't say to the enterprises, `From now on do what you want.' That would destablize the whole economy.'' Petre, a French-trained scientist, said he had been a Marxist, but never a Communist, Le Monde reported. ``In any case, we are no longer the slaves of any ideology; that cost us too much,'' he said. Petre said two of the revolution's key figures, Ion Iliescu who is now president and Gen. Nicolae Militaru, now defense minister, had met several months ago to discuss ``bringing people together for the salvation of the nation,'' the newspaper said. ``But there was nothing organized, just a few contacts in a park, which besides were recorded by the security police,'' Petre was quoted as saying.

For Release PMs Friday, Jan. 5
DOC.HEAD: Will Bush Be A Giant Of A Leader?
DOC.TEXT: History demonstrates that rarely do two powerful leaders follow each other, but that relatively ineffectual leaders often do. That concept is the heart of what Eugene Jennings calls the L-(for leadership) principle, and it suggests intriguing possibilities for the future of the United States, the Soviet Union and much of Europe. What type of person, for example, is likely to follow Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev? Will the leadership of Eastern European nations be strong or weak? Can George Bush be a powerful leader so soon after Ronald Reagan? Jennings, professor emeritus at Michigan State University, is author of the landmark volume ``Anatomy of Leaderhip,'' written in 1961, which traces leadership back to the Egyptian pharoahs, and ``Princes, Heroes & Supermen.'' In addition, he has advised corporate chairmen and sometimes political candidates on how to conduct their affairs, the better to demonstrate their leadership. As he interprets the L-principle, powerful leaders come forth to fill voids, rising in response to circumstances and needs of people. But when they are through they often leave another void behind them. Into this void step what Jennings calls representative officials, or people who represent the popular thinking of their constituency. Unlike the powerful giants, these folks and their ideas aren't above or ahead of the people. In Jennings' view, Dwight Eisenhower was a representative leader rather than a giant. He was followed in the presidency by John Kennedy, who Jennings feels was emerging as a giant, and then Lyndon Johnson became one. ``Johnson came forth and filled the void,'' says Jennings. ``For better or worse, he changed the direction and character of what the country had been under Eisenhower.'' Under Jimmy Carter, says Jennings, the country lost confidence to do anything right, making conditions ripe for Ronald Reagan to come galloping in on a white horse. Does that mean George Bush and the nation are in for a dull time? Not necessarily, says Jennings, appearing to bend the L-principle just a bit. In his first term Reagan was a giant, he says, an example of the wedding of the individual and the needs of the people. ``In his second, he wasn't.'' After Reagan, says Jennings, ``we should be in a void, defined as the absence of a need or condition for strong-willed chiefs.'' But as he interprets the principle, Reagan actually created his own void in his final four years, leaving room for Bush to achieve the status of giant, should events conspire. It would be, he concedes, a rare but not unprecedented situation. More common is the succession of two or more representative officials, such as Harding, Coolidge and Hoover sandwiched between Woodrow Wilson and Franklin Roosevelt. But wouldn't that have made Harry Truman representative? That's another example of bending. Roosevelt, says Jennings, was a giant of a leader in his early years, changing the direction and character of the country, but he was worn and torn by the time he died in office. With the world turning over, as he puts it, and democracy sweeping old regimes from power, Jennings believes conditions are now ripe for a strong president to exert his will. Bush, he believes, could become a giant. In Jenning's interpretation, Winston Churchill was a giant, but Anthony Eden was not. Stalin was a giant, but he was followed by a series of less powerful officials. Gorbachev filled the void they created and, ``depending on how irreversible his initiatives are,'' he will be a giant. That brings up the future. The L-principle suggests that Gorbachev will leave a void, to be filled by the so-called representative or transitional types. First, however, Gorbachev must nail down his reforms. Jennings also feels that like them or not, the former leaders of the East bloc were powerful enough to leave a void that will be filled by transitional or representative types. That leaves the question of who will follow them. If the future remains unstable, he says, it could mean a giant of a leader, perhaps anti-democratic, could follow. The possibility of future dictators still exists, he says.

DOC.HEAD: Murdoch Magazines Plans Launch of Japanese Edition of Premiere
DOC.TEXT: News Corp.'s Murdoch Magazines said Thursday it had arranged for a Japanese publishing company to launch a monthly Japanese-language edition of its Premiere, The Movie Magazine. John B. Evans, president of Murdoch Magazines, said the new publication will be the first Japanese edition of a Murdoch magazine. Premiere, which features stories on the movie industry, was launched in 1978 as a joint venture of News Corp., the Australia-based multinational media company headed by Rupert Murdoch, and France's Hachette Publications Inc. News Corp. bought out Hachette's interest in February 1989. The magazine has a U.S. circulation rate base of 425,000. Kadokawa Shoten Publishing Co. Ltd., a leading publisher of books and magazines in Japan, has been licensed to produce the Japanese edition of Premiere and plans an initial circulation of 150,000. The Japanese edition will include about 50 pages of editorial features and art from the U.S. version of Premiere supplemented by 20 pages of Japanese-generated material. It also will contain advertising pages from the U.S. version of the magazine. Murdoch said the first issue of the new publication was released in November 1989 and that monthly publication would begin in March. The launch of the Japanese edition comes as major Japanese companies have demonstrated a growing interest in the U.S. entertainment business. Last year, consumer electronics giant Sony Corp. of Japan paid $3.4 billion for Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. Sony bought CBS Records for $2 billion in 1988. ``Having known Japanese whose knowledge of American films and music rivals that of most Americans, I am confident our joint efforts will be nothing less than a smashing success,'' Evans said in a statement. Murdoch Magazines publishes 11 magazines in the United States, including TV Guide, Mirabella, New Woman, New York, Seventeen and Soap Opera Digest. It also publishes 12 magazines in the United Kingdom and Australia and has interests in four others.

Shares surged higher at the outset, swept upward on professional trading interest, dealers said. But prices were later driven back by profit-taking. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index, which rose as high as 2,479.4 during the session, finished with a decline of 12.1 points, or 0.5 percent, at 2,451.6. DOC.HEAD: Litton to Sell Three Supply Divisions
DOC.TEXT: Litton Industries Inc. said Thursday it will sell three divisions that supply electronic and electrical interconnection products, saying the divisions no longer fit well with its corporate plans. The divisions are Advanced Circuitry and its Inter-Pak Electronics operation, based in Springfield, Mo.; Veam, based in Milan, Italy; and Winchester Electronics, based in Watertown, Conn. They have combined annual sales of about $170 million and employ about 2,200 people at locations in the United States and Europe. ``We believe that the interconnection products divisions will benefit from association with a company where they will fit better,'' said Alton J. Brann, Litton senior vice president and head of the company's components and industrial products business. Robert S. Knapp, a spokesman for the Beverly Hills-based company, said the operations are growing and profitable, but are being sold as part of Litton's strategy of concentrating on its three core businesses. Those are advanced electronic and defense systems, resource exploration services and industrial automation systems. Brann said he hoped the divisions would be purchased as a unit since they have complementary products. Litton said it has hired First Boston Corp. to handle the sale.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Close Sharply Lower; Grains Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices closed moderately lower Thursday and sharply below the day's highs as early excitement about new export business gave way to bearish technical signals. Most grain futures finished narrowly mixed. The soybean market opened with a burst of buying linked partly to new export sales of the commodity and partly to lingering bullishness from the previous session. But traders grew discouraged and selling materialized after the March contract failed to reach $5.85 a bushel, a point at which new buyers were known to be waiting. ``When that failure occurred, I think the bears gained a little more confidence and they began to press the market,'' said Pat O'Connell, a grain-market analyst with Refco Inc. in Chicago. DOC.HEAD: Edgar Announces Securities-Fraud Settlement with New York Brokerage Firm
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for AM-Fraud Fine item listed on AM-Business News Digest.
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. on Thursday paid a $1.3 million fine to the state of Illinois for securities fraud, an administrative penalty stemming from a highly publicized Wall Street corruption case. The negotiated settlement is the biggest such penalty for securities law violations in the state's history, far exceeding the previous record fine of $156,000, said Secretary of State Jim Edgar. The settlement also exceeds by nearly $1 million the highest penalty collected by any of the 36 other states with which the New York-based brokerage firm has reached agreements as a result of its pleading guilty last September to federal mail and securities fraud in U.S. District Court in Manhattan, Edgar said. In addition to the fine, Drexel agreed to pay for a first-in-the-nation search for Illinois investors who may be entitled to civil damages as a result of its fraudulent activities from early 1984 to late 1986, Edgar told a news conference in Chicago. Drexel also agreed to contribute $100,000 to an independent foundation that will educate the public about securities markets and safeguards to prevent fraud, Edgar said. ``This record settlement makes clear Illinois' firm commitment to enforce the law and combat fraud,'' he said. ``Security fraud and stock price manipulation will not be tolerated,'' Edgar said. ``The law is the law, whether you are a nationwide, multimillion-dollar operator or a one-person storefront shop.'' Steven Anreder, a Drexel spokesman in New York, said the firm was ``very pleased that we've been able to work to put this behind us.'' ``We're hopeful that we will resolve it with all the jurisdictions ... and be able to move on,'' Anreder said. Drexel has yet to settle securities-fraud charges with 13 states, including New York and California, the only two states in which the brokerage did more business than in Illinois. Edgar said the Illinois settlement stipulates that if Drexel negotiates significantly higher settlements with California or New York, the brokerage must increase the fine paid to Illinois to 53 percent of the California settlement and 66 percent of the New York fine. ``We wanted to make sure our settlement was in the proper perspective to those other settlements,'' Edgar said. The settlement allows Drexel to keep its brokerage license in Illinois, although the company sold its retail brokerage business last summer. Edgar said he rejected an initial Drexel settlement offer of $400,000. Drexel pleaded guilty to six felony counts and paid $650 million in fines and restitution to settle charges of insider trading and other offenses brought during the government's three-year crackdown on Wall Street crime. Edgar, whose office handles securities violations, driver and vehicle licensing, and other functions, is seeking the GOP nomination for governor in the March primary.

DOC.HEAD: Quaker State Backs Up Oil With Engine Warranty
DOC.TEXT: Quaker State Corp. is offering a free warranty on the lubricated engine parts of new cars for 10 years or 250,000 miles, extending warranties offered by automakers, said President Jack W. Corn. New car owners must meet strict rules to qualify, including an oil and filter change every four months or 4,000 miles by a lube shop or auto dealer. The Quaker State warranty does not cover claims already covered by auto manufacturers' warranties, but it will pay for deductibles not covered by automaker extended service contracts. ``We are providing every car owner who uses Quaker State additional protection for a quarter of a million miles or 10 years,'' Corn said Wednesday in a news release. The Oil City-based refiner previously offered a similar but more limited warranty available at fewer than 1,000 auto dealers nationwide, the company said. But the new warranty ``goes beyond that,'' said spokesman Benton H. Faulkner. ``Potentially, thousands of lube shops and auto dealers will offer it,'' he said. In recent years, General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co., Chrysler Corp. and other automakers have extended warranties on engines and transmissions. Chrysler extended its coverage to five years or 50,000 miles and GM and Ford followed with six-year or 60,000-mile coverage. Faulkner declined to reveal the cost of the warranty program. He said only, ``Our estimate is that we can manage it.'' He said Quaker State expects the warranty to increase sales of motor oil. ``This reflects our conviction that more people are concerned about caring for their vehicle properly,'' he said. The four-month, 4,000-mile oil and filter change requirement is more strict than that recommended by auto manufacturers, Faulkner said. But Quaker State has claimed for some time that motor oil should be changed more often than those recommendations, he said. ``This puts us on the record as saying what people should do,'' he said. The warranty is being offered through auto dealers, service stations and quick lube shops, Quaker State said. To enroll in the warranty program, car owners must sign up at participating shops that sell Quaker State motor oil. New car owners have six months from the date of purchase, or before the car has 6,000 miles, to sign up. Quaker State said it will replace or repair lubricated engine parts that fail or wear abnormally due to failure of its motor oil. To qualify for reimbursement, the company said, a new car owner must keep records of oil changes, which must be submitted at the time of a claim. Quaker State will pay for reasonable costs associated with parts and labor.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Drilling Hit 10-Year Low in 1989
DOC.TEXT: The number of oil and gas wells drilled in the United States last year was probably the lowest for any year in the decade, according to an annual survey by Petroleum Information. ``It was the worst year because of fewer wells drilled, less oil produced and the decline in gas production after it had been going up,'' Jack Ekstrom, director of industry affairs for the energy services reporting company owned by Dun & Bradstreet Corp, said Wednesday. ``What this means for the 1990s is that production will decline even faster than it has been.'' Petroleum Information expects well completions to total about 28,100 for 1989, Ekstrom said. The 1989 projection is 16 percent below the 33,500 wells drilled in 1988, the previous low for the decade. The worst year recorded by Petroleum Information was 1971, when 27,682 wells were drilled. The number of successful natural gas wells drilled last year totaled 6,401 through year-end, up 8.8 percent from 5,882 a year earlier. Meanwhile, the number of producing oil well completions totaled 8,009, down a precipitous 26.6 percent from the 10,916 counted at the end of 1988. Texas led the nation with 7,116 completions of exploratory wells through year-end. This figure exceeds Oklahoma with 2,070, Kansas with 1,989 and California with 1,467. And Texas bucked the trend with a higher success rate for wildcats, 23.6 percent compared with 21 percent in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Acres of Gadgetry at Disneyland for Adults
DOC.TEXT: Acres of glitz and gadgetry go on display Saturday as the 1990 Winter Consumer Electronics Show _ a Disneyland for adults _ opens here. The four-day show is designed to showcase what's hot for the consumer as the electronics industry enters its eighth decade. ``We're going to see all kinds of better mousetraps,'' Cynthia Upson, director of communications for the show, said Thursday. Some 70,000 manufacturers, dealers and journalists from the U.S. and 80 foreign countries are expected to view thousands of products showcased over 800,000 square feet of display space. Some 1,400 exhibitors are displaying 95 product lines at the city's convention center and four major hotels. The show is closed to the public. One of the highlights of the show will be the merger of audio and video products to create a total `home theater' environment. CES will showcase state-of-the-art home theater _ customized audio and video products _ in the grand ballroom of the new Mirage Hotel. ``We're really excited about this new exhibit area because it's the first time we have consolidated products which bring high fidelity audio and premium video technology into the home,'' said CES vice president Dennis Corcoran. ``It appears that the `90s will bring consumers more enjoyment in home entertainment than ever before.'' Ms. Upson calls the home theater concept ``one of the most exciting areas of technology we're seeing emerge in the 1990s.'' Also spotlighted this year will be the growing trend of creating offices in the home. Recent statistics show that nearly 25 million Americans currently work at home, and approximately 25 percent of those households contain two home-based professionals, Corcoran said. ``You are going to see a lot of personal electronics at the show, items that can be used in the home office such as translators, computers, and hand held items you can take on the go,'' Ms. Upson said. ``Now you can take a fax machine and cellular phone with you, and can fax something back to your office.'' Another major feature will be home automation. ``This system enables all the different appliances and consumer electronics products to talk to each other,'' Ms. Upson said. ``You can use your telephone to lock doors while you're away, turn on alarm systems, turn on the dishwasher, program the VCR, set heating or air conditioning. ``Last year home automation was still on the drawing boards, the engineers were still trying to iron out standards for manufacturers,'' she said. ``Now the standard has been developed and we're ready to go with the product. ``This year we will reach the point where the consumer can buy the product and add it to their home,'' Ms. Upson said. Other exhibits will range from telephone products and accessories to adult video software. The shows are held twice annually _ in Las Vegas in January and in Chicago in the summertime. The shows have been held since 1967, and are sponsored by the Electronic Industries Association, a Washington, D.C.-based trade association representing most manufacturers of audio, video and home information products in the U.S. The industry produced a record $33 billion in products last year.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Plunges Worldwide
Precede LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: A group of European central banks launched a surprise attack on the dollar Thursday that sent the U.S. currency tumbling around the world. Gold prices were mixed. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $398.60 a troy ounce, up $4.60 from Wednesday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $398.75 an ounce, up $4.40. West Germany's Bundesbank, accompanied by the Bank of England and the Swiss national bank, caught dealers by surprise when they began selling dollars during European trading hours. The moves ``scared a lot of people,'' said Pat Magill, chief corporate dealer at Daiwa Bank Ltd. in London. The dollar's biggest drop came against the West German mark. The U.S. currency touched levels against the mark not seen in about 19 months. When trading concluded in New York, the currency had lost about 4 pfennigs, falling to 1.6800 marks, its lowest level since May 11, 1988, when it finished at 1.6773 marks. ``The dollar got hammered, really destroyed,'' said Scott Horwitz, a vice president at the Bank of Boston's New York office. ``People got really nervous, and it compounded itself in the afternoon with more sell orders.'' Traders were shocked by the speed with which the dollar declined. The dollar had been gaining strength since last week, but ``it was not that huge of a rally ... the dollar was not all that high. People weren't really looking'' for any intervention to push it lower, said Jim Chorek, an analyst with Money Market Services International in Chicago. Volume was heavy. Chorek said rumors that the Federal Reserve was monitoring dollar rates ``really nailed (the dollar) again.'' Traders could not determine whether the Fed actually had entered the market to sell dollars. The dollar declined sharply against all major currencies except the Canadian dollar. Chorek said breaking the 1.6750-mark level during the day was ``a real bad sign'' and predicted the dollar could fall as low as 1.5600 marks. Traders speculated the Bundesbank intervened because it was disappointed with the mark's recent, relative weakness. The tumultuous activity stole attention from any anticipation of Friday's release of unemployment data for December. ``People are just squaring whatever damage is done and calling it a day,'' Horwitz said. In New York, the dollar closed at 143.65 yen, down sharply from 145.25 yen on Wednesday. The dollar fell in London to 143.30 yen. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 145.20 Japanese yen, from 143.40 yen at Friday's finish. A prolonged New Year's holiday closed Japanese markets earlier in the week. In London, the British pound rose to $1.6290, from $1.6080 late Wednesday. In New York, it cost $1.6350 to buy one pound, more expensive than Wednesday's $1.6115. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Wednesday, included: 1.6800 West German marks, down from 1.7208; 1.5395 Swiss francs, down from 1.5785; 5.7450 French francs, down from 5.8765; 1,263.00 Italian lire, down from 1,289.00, and 1.1607 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1599. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday included: 1.6825 West German marks, down from 1.7203; 1.5410 Swiss francs, down from 1.5722; 5.7500 French francs, down from 5.8745; 1.9275 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9370; 1,265.25 Italian lire, down from 1,286.00, and 1.1610 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1602. Gold fell in London to a late bid of $395.00 a troy ounce from $395.60 late Wednesday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $395.70, from $395.25 bid late Wednesday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.40 to close at a bid $394.89. Silver prices rose. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current deliver finished at $5.268 an ounce, from $5.151 on Wednesday. In London the metal rose to a late bid price of $5.22 a troy ounce, from $5.16 bid late Wednesday.
