DOC.HEAD: Zenith Protest of Unisys Contract Settled
DOC.TEXT: Zenith Data Systems Corp. has agreed to drop its protest against a $706 million Air Force contract to rival Unisys Corp. for desktop computer equipment, both companies said Thursday. Lawyers for the companies, an intervenor and the Air Force reached a settlement Wednesday evening that asks the General Services Administration's Board of Contract Appeals to dismiss the protest. GSA spokesman Steve Guiheen said the dismissal would probably be issued in one or two days. The Desktop III contract calls for Unisys, a computer manufacturer based in Blue Bell, to make equipment that combines two of the most widely used desktop operating systems _ UNIX and MS-DOS. The equipment would give the government wide flexibility in the types of programs it can run and the types of machines with which it can communicate. Zenith Data Systems, based in Mount Prospect, Ill., held the Defense Department's two previous desktop computer contracts and had vigorously sought the Desktop III contract. ``We maintained from the beginning that the protest was without merit,'' James McGuirk, Unisys vice president and general manager of aerospace operations, said in a statement. Unisys hopes ``to gain significant market share in the desktop arena'' as a result of the project, McGuirk said. Zenith Data Systems and the intervenor, Government Technical Services Inc., will be allowed to buy or license up to two units of any Unisys product offered under the contract at a 30 percent discount, according to the three-page settlement. The Air Force agreed to start its functional test demonstration by Jan. 24 at Gunter Air Force Base near Montgomery, Ala. Zenith Data Systems, which was sold last week by Zenith Electronics Corp. to Groupe Bull of France, had alleged violation of the Trade Agreements Act, improper evaluation of proposals and failure by Unisys to meet minimum requirements of the contract specifications. ``We are disappointed by the award of the contract to a competitor, but through discovery and the settlement, all of our concerns about the fairness of the competition and the adequacy of the contract are alleviated,'' Tom Buchsbaum, Zenith Data Systems' vice president for federal systems, said from Vienna, Va.

DOC.HEAD: Westinghouse Acquires Stake In Castle Rock
DOC.TEXT: Westinghouse Broadcasting Co. said Thursday it had paid $18.7 million for a 15 percent stake in Castle Rock Entertainment, a television and motion picture production company. Group W Productions, a subsidiary of New York-based Westinghouse Broadcasting, and Los Angeles-based Castle Rock will establish a division to produce television programming for first-run syndication, Westinghouse Broadcasting said in a written statement. Management of the unit will be the responsibility of Castle Rock, under the supervision of an executive to be chosen by Castle Rock and Group W, Westinghouse said. ``This move is consistent with our strategy to expand our interests in the programming-production arena,'' said Derk Zimmerman, president of Group W. Castle Rock, founded in 1987, produces ``Ann Jillian'' for NBC and is working on two other network television comedies to be launched later this year. It also produced ``When Harry Met Sally ...,'' a movie starring Billy Crystal and Meg Ryan. Westinghouse Broadcasting is a subsidiary of Pittsburgh-based Westinghouse Electric Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Rises
DOC.TEXT: The three leading measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended Dec. 25, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $802.4 billion from $795.5 billion the previous week. The measure known as M2 rose to a seasonally adjusted $3,227.1 billion from $3,215.7 billion. An even broader measure, M3, rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,043.1 billion from $4,036.6 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 4.5 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 is 3.3 percent, which is below the Fed's target range of 3.5 percent to 7.5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,191.2 billion, a 7.6 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,022.2 billion, up 2.5 percent, while M1 rose 6.5 percent to an average of $790.6 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $503 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, up from $496 million the previous week. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $293.7 billion in the two-week period ended Dec. 27, down from $295.7 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Pork Futures Score Limit Gains On USDA Report
DOC.TEXT: Hog and pork belly futures prices shot up their permitted daily limits Thursday after the Agriculture Department issued a quarterly hogs and pigs tally that showed far fewer animals than traders had expected. On other commodity markets, energy and orange juice futures turned lower; precious metals advanced strongly; and grains and soybeans were mixed. Hog futures settled 1.5 cents higher across the board on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange with the contract for delivery in February at 50.5 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 2 cents higher across the board with February at 51.47 cents a pound. Live cattle futures settled .20 cent lower to .40 cent higher with February at 76.95 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .35 cent higher with January at 84.55 cents a pound. Market analysts had predicted limit gains in the pork complex following Wednesday's USDA hogs and pigs inventory report, which showed a 3 percent drop in the national herd size from the end of 1988 to the end of 1989. The report also indicated that springtime farrowing intentions _ a measure of expected herd expansion _ were down 6 percent from a year ago. The report surprised most analysts, whose observations of slaughter rates relative to the September report had led them to expect little change in the December tally. One reason for the decline in herd size was the USDA's sharp downward revision in the September inventory. Some analysts found the revision especially disturbing because the USDA in September had revised sharply upward the June inventory number. ``It's really casting a little bit of doubt on the credibility of the hog numbers being released by the USDA,'' said analyst Dale Durchholz of AgriVisor Services Inc. in Bloomington, Ill. ``It makes you wonder what the actual benchmark is.'' Charles Levitt, senior livestock analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., was more blunt. ``The numbers just don't make sense,'' he said. ``We are being kicked around back and forth from one report to the next simply to make the inventory figure fit the subsequent slaughter.'' Orange juice and energy futures turned lower, ending steep runups in those markets linked to the December cold spell, which damaged the Florida orange crop, sharply boosted heating-oil demand, froze some oil refineries and taxed others to the breaking point. ``I think it was just a lot of liquidation,'' said energy analyst Andrew Lebow of E.D.& F. Man International Futures Inc. ``The crude-oil market had gone up about $2 iin three days. That's a huge move and the market was a little tired.'' West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled .27 cent to .57 cent lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange with February at $23.41 a barrel; heating oil was 1.45 cents to 5.01 cents lower with February at 73.19 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.25 cents to 1.94 cents lower with February at 65.29 cents a gallon. Brazilian authorities announced a resumption of orange juice exports to the United States after a week's suspension, which contributed to the drop in orange juice futures prices. Orange juice futures finished 1.05 cents to 3 cents lower on the New York Cotton Exchange with January at $1.71 a pound. Precious metals futures rebounded after two days of deep losses. Platinum led the rally as Japanese buyers returned to the market after a five-day New Year's break. On the New York Merc, platinum futures soared $16.30 to $18.90 with January settling at $488.70 a troy ounce. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold futures settled $4.40 to $5.30 higher with February at $400.80 a troy ounce; silver was 11.5 cents to 12.5 cents higher with March at $5.335 a troy ounce. Soybean futures prices finished moderately lower and sharply below the day's highs on the Chicago Board of Trade as early excitement about new export business gave way to bearish technical signals. Soybean futures settled } cent to 5 cents lower with January at $5.63\ a bushel; wheat futures were } cent lower to { cent higher with March at $4.09\ a bushel; corn was \ cent lower to 1{ cents higher with March at $2.38\ a bushel; oats were 1\ cents to 3 cents lower with March at $1.50} a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: US West Subsidiary Awarded British Franchise
DOC.TEXT: Comment Cablevision has been awarded the franchise to provide cable television and telecommunications services in Tyneside, England, it was announced Thursday. Comment Cablevision is owned by US West Inc., headquartered in Englewood, and US Cable Corp., based in Montvale, N.J. With 340,000 homes and 13,000 businesses, the Tyneside franchise area is the third largest ever awarded by the United Kingdom Cable Authority. Estimated construction cost is $160 million. Since cable franchises in the United Kingdom carry a telecommunications license, Comment Cablevision will offer telephone, facsimile and data services along with cable television, US West said in a release. US West Cable Communications, a subsidiary of US West, is a partner in seven other United Kingdom cable franchises which include nearly 1.5 million households. US Cable, which serves 175,000 cable television subscribers in more than 100 communities in the United States, is one of the largest privately owned cable companies in this country. US West serves communications needs of 10 million customers in 14 western states.

DOC.HEAD: Bridgestone-Firestone Recalls Certain Truck Tires
DOC.TEXT: Bridgestone-Firestone Inc. announced a recall Thursday of 86,000 radial truck tires, warning of potential cracking in the inner lining of a certain tire model. Most of the recall tires were sold by independent Firestone dealers. The tires were sold across the nation, said Firestone spokesman Bob Troyer. He said replacement tires have an average selling price of $250 each. Firestone brand dealers and stores were being notified Thursday. The defect could result in sidewall failure, but there has been no report of any accident or injury resulting from the condition, the company said in a statement. The recall involved over-the-road, drive-axle truck tires with the model designation T546 PSD Radial, in sizes 10R22.5, 11R22.5, 11R24.5, 295-75R22.5 and 285-75R24.5. The tires were produced the past two years at a company plant in Bilbao, Spain. The potential defect was noticed when some of the tires in question were checked after road damage of during retreading. ``We want to be certain that our customers obtain the maximum potential from Firestone radial truck tires both during the original tread life and in the retread stage,'' said Thomas R. Mertz, director of sales and marketing for Firestone brand tires. ``Therefore, on a voluntary basis, we are initiating this recall today to replace these tires,'' he said. Only the tubeless tires are involved, he added. Troyer also on Thursday confirmed an Akron Beacon Journal report that the company has targeted some 80 of its MasterCare stores for sale or closing. MasterCare is a 1,600-store chain. Troyer said the closings or sale of stores are in the normal course of business and do not reflect a financial problem. ``We review our stores continuously on profits, marginability and that sort of thing,'' Troyer said. ``In the normal course of doing business, we review the operations of our network of stores. Over the years, we have closed stores which were not profitable or were marginal. ``We are currently reviewing about 80 to determine whether or not they will be closed or perhaps sold to an independent tire dealer. At the same time, we are reviewing sites to add stores in an aggressive program to add MasterCare outlets.'' The Chicago-based Bridgestone-Firestone is presently relocating its corproate headquaters to Akron, which had long been headquarters of the former Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.

DOC.HEAD: Profit-Taking Sends Energy Futures Lower
DOC.TEXT: Energy prices fell sharply Thursday as traders decided to sell after two days of strong gains. The contract for February delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, fell 27 cents to $23.41 per 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, following a 79-cent rise on Wednesday and a jump of $1.07 on Tuesday. Prices of wholesale unleaded gasoline and home heating oil also fell sharply. The February contract for gasoline, which surged 5.48 cents over Tuesday and Wednesday, gave back some of those gains Thursday, falling 1.94 cents to 65.29 cents a gallon. Heating oil skidded 5.01 cents to 73.19 cents a gallon, wiping out the 3.95 cent gain it ran up the previous two sessions. Analysts attributed the rally earlier this week to strong fundamental demand combined with speculative buying. Andrew Lebow, an energy market analyst at E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc., said many traders, having watched the market move steadily upward in recent weeks, decided to liquidate some of their large positions on Thursday. An American Petroleum Institute report on Wednesday indicated heating oil stocks were at their lowest levels in years, but the markets appeared to be looking beyond those figures, Lebow said. Milder weather following the recent prolonged cold wave and anticipation of new oil imports coming into the United States may have been factors in Thursday's trading, he said.

DOC.NOTE: $adv07
For release Sunday Jan. 7
DOC.HEAD: William McLucas: New Top Cop on Wall Street
LaserPhoto WX8 of Jan. 4
DOC.TEXT: William R. McLucas, new head of the Securities and Exchange Commission's enforcement division, has been described by some associates a low-key, down-to-earth guy. Others say he's an intense lawman, savvy in stuff they don't teach in law school. But most agree that when SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden tapped McLucas, a 12-year SEC veteran, for what is widely perceived as the second most important job in the agency, it was a vote of confidence in the SEC staff. ``The world sort of saw this as an in-house race between McLucas and several other senior staffers at the SEC,'' said John Coffee, a professor of securities law at Columbia University. Picking an outsider ``would have had a demoralizing effect on the staff,'' said Coffee. ``It's commendable that people are promoted within the ranks when they deserve it and from what I've heard about him _ he deserves it,'' said Paul Curran, a prominent New York defense attorney. Breeden, only on the job since October himself, announced his selection of McLucas, 39, on the day after Christmas _ ending months of speculation about who would succeed Gary Lynch as Wall Street's top cop. Lynch, who headed the enforcement division for four years before leaving public service last summer, led the SEC's campaign against insider trading and other abuses by Ivan Boesky and other prominent Wall Street professionals. The choice of McLucas seemed to please almost everyone, from federal prosecutors to securities industry lawyers _ who are themselves mostly former government lawyers. ``He's a really smart and extremely personable guy,'' said Alan Cohen, head of the securities fraud unit of the U.S. attorney's office in Manhattan. Cohen's boss, U.S. Attorney Otto G. Obermaier, said he hadn't been in contact with McLucas since taking over as top federal prosecutor in Manhattan, ``but in my former life (as a prominent white collar criminal defense attorney), I dealt with him almost all the time. We didn't always agree on issues but I always found him fair, accessible, ready to reconsider a point of law.'' ``We see appointing someone from the staff as a continuation of their policies,'' said Susan E. Bryant, administrator of the Oklahoma Department of Securities, a state-level version of the SEC. ``We were glad to see Chairman Breeden appoint someone from the staff who is familiar with the issues,'' said Ms. Bryant, who is also president of a national organization of state-level securities regulators, the North American Securities Administrators Association. ``I do not think you could have had a more impressive choice,'' said Harvey Pitt, a prominent Washington lawyer who represented Boesky when the takeover stock speculator was nabbed in the insider trading scandals. Pitt, a former SEC lawyer himself who has known McLucas for years, said the new SEC enforcement chief is personable but ``he can be very tough, very forceful and energetic.'' Even Arthur Mathews, a Washington securities lawyer who had been touting a member of his firm, Robert McCaw, for the enforcement post, said McLucas was a good choice. ``I don't think anybody inside the SEC would've compared to McCaw, but once the chairman chose to go inside rather than outside, I think McLucas was the best choice,'' said Mathews. ``McLucas is very well liked and well respected by the bar, by the internal staff and by the investment community,'' said Mathews. Asked if it was wise to have an enforcement chief that everybody liked, Mathews said ``by like, I mean respect.'' When people describe McLucas, they use words like ``quiet,'' ``confident'' and ``compassionate.'' But Lynch, McLucas's predecessor, said he knows that such descriptions of incoming office holders can get excessive. ``I was described in so many newspaper stories as `soft-spoken' I thought I should start screaming,'' said Lynch, now in private practice in New York. ``I wouldn't describe Bill as low-key at all. I think he's a very intense person as a matter of fact. He certainly has a lot of common sense.'' If McLucas is down-to-earth, said Lynch it's because he has ``the knowledge you don't get in law school.'' McLucas, who is said to smoke a pipe occasionally and follow the football fortunes of his alma mater, declined to be interviewed, stating it was too soon for him to be talking to reporters. ``My preference is to get my sleeves rolled up and get the cases going and then give interviews,'' he said during one of the few intervals when he wasn't in a meeting or on the telephone last week. A native of western Pennsylvania, McLucas graduated Pennsylvania State University in 1972 with honors in political science and a Phi Beta Kappa key. He attended Temple University's School of Law in Philadelphia where he got his degree in 1975. After a two years as an attorney with the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, McLucas joined the SEC's Enforcement Division in 1977 and rose from staff attorney in the enforcement division to branch chief, assistant director and finally one of three associate directors under Lynch. While one of his in-house competitors, associate director John Sturc, made a reputation handling the SEC's cases against invesment banking house Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and Boesky, McLucas led the agency's cases against former Singer Corp. chairman Paul Bilzerian, California brokerage founder Boyd Jefferies and Rooney Pace, a defunct brokerage. ``He's had his fingers in the bread and butter cases that don't get the headlines like insider trading and parking,'' said Mathews, who represented Bilzerian.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Sunday Jan. 7.

DOC.HEAD: You Don't Qualify For A Mortgage? Think Again
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 19th graf pvs, `Convincing lenders... to ADD Schraw's affiliation; PICKS UP 20th graf pvs, `Good experience...; Moved in advance for Friday AMs
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of individuals and families who thought they didn't qualify for a home mortgage might be pleasantly surprised by relatively recent developments in an old law. Those developments enable some would-be buyers to qualify for loans with minimum downpayments and less than the usual income requirements, and to benefit from lower than normal closing costs. The Community Reinvestment Act was passed in 1977, but implementation on a large scale remained rather dormant until the past few years. Now it has been given a big push by Congress and by private-sector institutions. The latter, however, needed prodding themselves before they were convinced of the viability of the act's central theme, which is to compel lenders to provide mortgage financing equitably in all areas of their communities. Implementation was delayed also by confusion among lenders, by a failure of regulatory agencies to enforce compliance and simply by the effort needed to convince lenders that poor people could be good credit risks. That educational effort was pushed largely by the National Training & Information Center, a nonprofit, Chicago-based agency that trains community action groups in dealing with various social challenges. A big breakthrough occurred in September, when General Electric Capital Corp. developed a packaged program enabling laggard lenders to minimize risk in making loans to those who otherwise wouldn't qualify. GE Capital has signed up lenders throughout the country to offer the package, which involves a buyer education program, more flexible qualification criteria and mortgage insurance. Such loans then would qualify for sale by the lender to the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp., or Freddie Mac. The package benefits borrowers in a various others ways, among them: _They can designate a higher portion of their income (33 percent) to monthly housing expenses than the ratio (28 percent) accepted for traditional financing. _The traditional cash reserve requirement of two monthly mortgage payments is waived. _If the borrower hasn't develped a credit history, his or her payment record for expenses such as rent and utilities is acceptable in establishing credit worthiness. _In some instances, subsidized second mortgages may be employed to reduce housing costs. Education is at the foundation of GE's Community Home Buyer's Program. It involves four sessions of two hours each, plus two follow-up sessions, taught locally by the lender's personnel. The course explains the roles of participants in the application and approval process, the savings and income needed, household budgeting, credit reports, home selection, pre-sale inspections and tax and equity advantages. Forty-six institutions, covering the entire country, have signed up for the package, said Jeannette Bernay of GE capital in Raleigh, N.C. She said about 10,000 borrowers will be accommodated in the initial phase of the program, but that already there are hopes of expanding. ``We think we can make money in this,'' she said. Convincing lenders and regulatory officials that loans to the poor could be good business was a slow process, however. In some instances, said Tom Schraw of the National Training & Information Center, community leaders got action only by raising the threat of charter revocation. Good experience in Chicago and St. Louis helped. Lenders there cooperated and helped establish a record. In a five-year period, said Schraw, Chicago institutions lent $150 million with a default rate of less than 1 percent. GE Capital's entrance into the picture, encouraged by such experiences, now has given the effort a huge thrust, since it provides lenders throughout the country with a turnkey program for compliance with the law. Mortgage Guaranty Insurance Co. is testing a somewhat similar program in Milwaukee, Des Moines and Knoxville, although that company's major effort is in customized work for individual lenders. Those interested in obtaining local lenders affiliated with the GE Capital program may call the company's Action Center at 1-800-444-5664.

DOC.HEAD: Braniff Names Murchison New Chief Executive
DOC.TEXT: Financially strapped Braniff Inc. on Thursday announced David Murchison has been named the airline's new chief executive officer. The appointment of Murchison, 41, was approved earlier in the day by the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Orlando, according to a statement released by Braniff. The appointment, requested by Braniff, was backed by the airline's creditors in a bid to restore confidence in the company's efforts to reorganize, according to the statement. Orlando-based Braniff said the appointment would bring new direction to management at the cash-poor airline. On Sept. 28, Braniff filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors, laid off all but a skeleton staff and halted all regularly scheduled flights. That move followed an earlier fall cutback in the number of scheduled flights and a round of layoffs. Murchison served as vice president, general counsel and secretary of Braniff from September 1988 through Nov. 17, 1989. Prior to joining the carrier, he worked at Piedmont Aviation, where he served as vice president and assistant general counsel from 1985 to September 1988. Previously, Murchison was assistant general counsel and secretary of the Air Transport Association for six years, after serving two years as legal assistant to the vice chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board.

DOC.HEAD: Keating Says He Doesn't Know Who Decided on Controversial Stock Deal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with testimony from Keating. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Phoenix millionaire Charles H. Keating Jr. testified Thursday he doesn't know who in his real estate and thrift empire made the decision on a stock deal that stripped his Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of up to $12 million in potential profits. Testifying on his suit challenging the government's takeover last April of his Irvine, Calif., thrift, Keating said he personally had approved the Oct. 21, 1987 repurchase of Memorex stock at twice the price Lincoln had sold it for four months earlier. Federal regulators have focused on the Memorex deal and several related transactions with Phoenix developer and stockbroker Ernest C. Garcia as a centerpiece of their contention that Keating was operating Lincoln in an ``unsafe and unsound manner.'' A central figure in the savings and loan crisis and a related congressional ethics scandal, Keating spent more than a hour Thursday testifying about his use of Lincoln to finance massive planned community projects in the Phoenix area. In its takeover and a related $1.1 billion fraud and racketeering suit against Keating, the government contends his use of federally insured deposits in Lincoln to finance his dreams may eventually cost taxpayers up to $2 billion, making it the biggest of nearly 600 S&L failures since 1986. ``By losing the S&L we lost the ability to complete this program,'' Keating testified Thursday. ``The saddest thing in my life is that we were brought to this pass.'' Just two months ago, Keating had claimed a Fifth Amendment protection against self-incrimination in refusing to answer questions by the House Banking Committee, saying through attorneys that he wanted a more objective forum for laying out his case. The Memorex deal was part of a series of interwoven transactions with Garcia involving what the government says were ``sham'' land deals to book phony profits. Those profits enabled American Continental to collect deferred taxes from Lincoln on the deals. The source of those tax dollars totaling $94 million between 1985 and 1988, regulators contend, was actually federally insured deposits in Lincoln. No money was actually ever paid to the government as taxes. Justifying their takeover of Lincoln, the regulators contend that American Continental ``usurped a corporate right and opportunity'' of the thrift to reap a $12 million profit in two purchases and two sales of the same Memorex stock. The Memorex deals date back to December 1986 when Lincoln acquired 79,275 shares for $1 each as a sweetener to a purchase of $40 million of junk bonds as part of British financier Sir James Goldsmith's attempt to take over the company. Lincoln, which eventually made a $1.5 million profit on the junk bonds, sold the stock in June 1987 to Garcia for $1 million, with an option to buy it back for a maximum price of $4.25 million during the next 18 months. However, when the stock market crashed in October 1987, Garcia was in desperate need for cash, Keating testified, and American Continental purchased the Memorex stock from him for $2 million. Six months later, American Continental sold the stock for $13.2 million, reaping a $12 million profit that the government says should have gone to Lincoln. Keating testified that he was in Europe when Garcia wanted to sell the stock and that he approved having either American Continental or Lincoln buy it back. ``I don't believe that I made the decision where to put it,'' he said. ``I don't know who made the decision on waiving the (Lincoln's buyback) option.'' Another reason that Lincoln did not repurchase the stock, Keating said, is that the thrift ``at the time was under tremendous pressure from the regulators not to be in the equity business.'' His son, Charles H. Keating III, then chairman of a Lincoln subsidiary that held the option, testified earlier that he signed the waiver but had no detailed knowledge of the repurchase option and was not otherwise involved in the deal. ``It was a large company and there were a lot of deals going on,'' the younger Keating said. ``We have to rely on experts ... I would sign my name on something they did. I had a lot of faith in these people ... I would stake my life on what they did.'' The elder Keating said he bought Lincoln in 1984 after both the federal government and California deregulated the S&L industry so that thrifts could make direct investments in real estate. Previously, the great bulk of an S&L's investments had to be in home mortgages. ``I saw the S&L as a place to do land development and housing,'' he said. ``Ninety percent of what we do is housing. You could do precisely what we did with Lincoln at the time we bought it.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Dives, Share Prices Rebound
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar plunged against the Japanese yen at the start of the trading session Friday, while the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rebounded slightly. The dollar opened in Tokyo at 143.40 yen, down 1.80 yen from Thursday's 145.20-yen finish here after attacks on the U.S. currency overnight by a group of European central banks, including those in West Germany, Britain and Switzerland. The dollar, which tumbled against almost all major currencies around the world, ended at 143.58 yen in New York overnight. ``The dollar declined sharply after the surprise interventions in Europe to support the (West German) mark, as well as dollar-selling by the Bank of Japan to save the yen,'' said Masafumi Koyama, a trader with the Bank of Tokyo. ``After such wild fluctuations in one day, most market players have to make position adjustments,'' he said. ``Currency rates will move narrowly as participants won't make major moves while awaiting the releases of the U.S. economic indicators later today.'' The dollar is likely to remain between 143 yen and 144 yen, Koyama added. The United States will announce the nation's jobless rate for December and factory orders later Friday in Washington. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues recouped 49.72 points, or 0.13 percent, to move to 38,762.60 within the first 15 minutes of trading. The index shed 202.99 points Thursday, largely due to discouragement over the yen's weakness. Kazuhiro Nomura, a dealer with New Japan Securities Co., said the index rose as the yen's quick recovery reassured stock investors. ``The index fell more than it should yesterday, and market players are making adjustments by buying back issues,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Fired Keating Hotel Workers File $42 Million Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-one former employees of Charles H. Keating Jr.'s Phoenix hotels filed a $42 million lawsuit Thursday against a federal official who fired them last fall in what their lawyer called ``an early-morning, Gestapo-like raid.'' The lawsuit, filed in Maricopa County Superior Court, claims the workers were fired improperly, treated ``like common criminals'' and refused severance pay or references in many instances. Named as defendants were Herbert Chin, a senior investigations specialist with the federal Resolution Trust Corp.'s regional office in Denver, and three former Keating companies that are now controlled by the RTC. Chin, in a telephone interview, said he had not seen the lawsuit but believed his actions were proper. The suit does not name the federal government itself, but could be amended later to include the government, according to Kraig Marton, the lawyer who filed it. The hotels, the Phoenician and the Crescent, are owned by companies that are 55 percent owned by Lincoln Savings and Loan Association and 45 percent by a group of Saudi Arabian investors. Keating controlled Lincoln until federal banking regulators seized control last year, saying the thrift was in danger of collapse. Keating remained in control of the two hotels as long as the Saudis sided with him, however, and it was not until Nov. 16 that the federal regulators won agreement from the Saudis and seized control of the hotels. They moved in at 2 a.m., posting termination notices at the homes of the employees and allowing them to collect their belongings from the hotels under guard and while being videotaped by guards and news organizations. Chin said that the regulators picked 2 a.m. as the time to fire the workers in order to minimize disruption and that extra security and videotapes were meant to ensure that no one later claimed to be missing property. But Marton alleges in his lawsuit that the way the firings were handled caused great emotional distress. The government made it look like the fired workers were ``so dishonest as to require a large body of guards, many armed and in uniform, to be present'' and treated them ``like common criminals'' as the media recorded the events, Marton said. Marton also said in his suit that Chin and the companies under RTC control fired the workers without sufficient cause, refused to give many of them severance pay and refused to provide job references. Chin said he did not believe most of the workers had contracts specifying what was needed in order to justify a firing. He also said he believed all the fired clerical workers had been given severance pay and that the workers should seek job references from the Keating group rather than the government.

DOC.HEAD: 11,000 Positions to be Eliminated at Pacific Telesis Division
DOC.TEXT: About 11,000 jobs at Pacific Bell will be eliminated during the next five years, largely through attrition and an early retirement plan, officials of the Pacific Telesis unit announced Thursday. ``Staffing requirements change over time in this dynamic industry,'' PacBell President Phil Quigley said in a statement. ``What was appropriate in 1989 clearly will not be in 1994.'' About 7,600 non-salaried jobs and 3,400 management positions will be cut. They represent about 16 percent of the phone company's work force. Since the 1984 breakup of American Telegraph & Telephone Co., PacBell has reduced its work force by 17,000 to about 64,000 employees. PacBell serves more than 11 million customers throughout California. Pacific Bell and Nevada Bell Telephone Co. are two subsidiaries of San Francisco-based Pacific Telesis, one of the seven ``Baby Bells'' created by the breakup of AT&T. Other regional phone companies have recently announced similar labor cutbacks. Most employees will be offered an early retirement plan, PacBell said. Some managers who are not eligible will be offered retraining. Other jobs are expected to be eliminated through attrition.

DOC.HEAD: Japan, U.S. Disagree Over Trade Policies at Florida Meeting
DOC.TEXT: HOWEY-IN-THE-HILLS, Fla. (AP) _ U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter bluntly told his counterpart from Japan on Thursday that Japan would have to cooperate with the rest of the world in removing protectionist barriers to trade, according to Yeutter and others at the conference. Yeutter's comments at the gathering of agricultural leaders from five of the world's top food-producing areas were in response to the Japanese position that rice and other farm products vital to that nation should be exempt from the more liberal trade policies sought by other nations. The Japanese have for years closed off or severely restricted certain imports, particularly agricultural products, because of their professed need to be self-sufficient. Michihiko Kano, Japan's minister of agriculture, forestry and fisheries, led a 1{ hour discussion on the subject at an informal, closed-door gathering of agricultural leaders from Japan, the U.S., the European Community, Canada and Australia. ``We have to have a lot of debate with Japan over that,'' Yeutter told reporters afterwards. The informal sessions at central Florida hotel are being held in the final year of the so-called Uruguay Round of negotiations for the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the international organization based in Geneva. Ninety-six member nations of GATT have presented position papers on a wide range of issues, and negotiations are at a crucial stage. After the agreements are hammered out at the end of this year, member countries will pass enabling legislation to enact the new GATT policies. Also a major issue in the first session of the two-day gathering _ described as the first of a series of casual get-togethers _ was food safety. The ministers agreed to draft a crisis-management plan on food-safety issues once Canada and other participants develop more information and details on it. ``There were no real fireworks, but there were lively discussions,'' said a member of the Canadian delegation. Kano's presentation provoked the most comment. ``The Japanese want 100 percent self-sufficiency on rice and perhaps on other products,'' Yeutter said, meaning that Japan wants to continue shutting the door on imports of those products. ``We could make the same argument on industrial products'' such as automobiles and television sets and limit exports of those to this country, he said. ``This is not a one-way street: Japan cannot make protectionist arguments on agriculture and expect liberalization arguments to prevail in the industrial sector _ or vice-versa.'' Yeutter said there has to be a common understanding in some areas, ``and what that means is that Japan will have to find a way to be accommodating on rice ... just as we'll have to find a way to be accommodating in product areas where Japan and other countries wish to expand exports to the United States.'' Ray MacSharry, representing the 12-member European Community, said he was philosophically in agreement with the Japanese over the self-sufficiency issue. ``We do see food security as an important issue along the lines the Japanese propose,'' MacSharry said. ``The U.S. seems to be very strong on access (to the Japanese market) for rice.'' Officials said there was general agreement to a presentation by Canadian Agriculture Minister Donald F. Mazankowski that there was a great need for a coordinated crisis management plan on food safety. The problems created by the cyanide scare on Chilean grapes and the emotional debate over the use of the chemical Alar on apples make it mandatory that the countries involved in farm production communicate better with each other and with consumers, Mazankowski was quoted as saying. Another example cited by Yeutter of a problem that such a crisis-management plan could prevent, or quickly solve, was the Korean claim last summer that Florida growers were using Alar on citrus. The Koreans halted imports of thousands of tons of Florida grapefruit, causing heavy losses to producers until the industry could persuade the Koreans that Alar was never used on citrus.
